Africa News


July, 1996


d Zimbabwe Mugabe To Marry Former Secretary


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 14, 1996


LENGTH: 701 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe has announced his intention to marry his former private secretary, Grace Marufu. 

The semi-official Sunday Mail newspaper said Mugabe had revealed that he would tie the knot in mid-August.

This ends the year-long speculation surrounding the president's marital status.

A local weekly newspaper was last year taken to court after carrying an article saying President Mugabe had married Marufu in a private ceremony during the 1995 Easter holidays.

Mugabe later said he would publicly announce any intention to marry "when the time is due."

Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Panafrican Women's Group Reaffirms Battle For Rights


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 14, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The chairwoman of the Pan-African Women's Organisation, Thenjiwe Lesabe, urged African women Sunday to re-dedicate themselves to their complete liberation and to guarding their dignity.

"PAWO was and still is dedicated to assisting African women fight for their emancipation and effective integration in the process of economic, social and cultural development," she said.

She was addressing the organisation's special Southern Africa Regional Secretariat meeting in Harare. She said the economic crises in most African countries tended to affect girls severely. 

"We have to work out strategies to save girl children because these are future mothers who will mould our future generations," she said.

But planning these strategies has been hampered by the organisation's inability to meet regularly.

Lesabe, who is also Zimbabwe's minister for national affairs, employment creation and co-operatives, said the main stumbling block was that no country was willing to host the regional meetings.

PAWO is affiliated to the Organisation of African Unity and to the United Nations. Its aim is to ensure that women's concerns are brought to the attention of the highest policy making bodies.

In a message read on her behalf, PAWO Secretary-General Ruth Neto, said since the creation of the PAWO some 34 years ago, seven congresses, several council meetings, symposia and other statutory meetings had taken place but a number of countries had failed to pay their contributions.

At the last congress held in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso in 1992, only 22 members out of 52 attended.

She said some four years later, when PAWO was preparing to undertake another council meeting in preparation to the eighth congress, most of resolutions had not materialised due to lack of participation and failure to pay their contributions.

Neto said now that all African countries were free, with the exception of some West African countries still struggling for democracy, PAWO should adjust to the reality of their respective countries.

"PAWO should adjust itself to the new reality of our respective countries, by prosecuting the struggle for recognition and application of the rights of African women to participate in the decision making, in political, economic, cultural and social affairs at national and international levels," she said.

PAWO has its headquarters in Angola and has five regional secretariats, for Northern, Central, Western, Eastern and Southern Africa.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Botswana and Senegal Diouf and Masire Sign Cooperation Agreement


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 13, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegal and Botswana Saturday in Dakar signed an economic, technical and cultural cooperation agreement.

An official statement issued here said the agreement envisages the creation of a joint cooperation commission to guide the two country's bilateral relations. 

The agreement was signed in Dakar at the end of a three-day official visit by President Ketumile Masire, who arrived here Thursday and left for Gaborone Saturday.

According to a joint statement issued at the end of the visit, Masire and his host, President Abdou Diouf, reaffirmed their support for the Organization of African Unity's central mechanism for prevention, settlement and management of conflicts in Africa.

The two leaders also urged developed countries to increase their supports to African countries in their efforts to rehabilitate their economies.

They appealed for a considerable reduction or cancellation of the bulk of public debts owed by African states.

President Masire left Dakar Saturday morning for Gaborone.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996

Africa News


July, 1996


Swaziland King Intervenes To End strike


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 13, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Schools will re-open again in Swaziland next Tuesday, the kingdom's National Association of Teachers Central Executive announced in Mbabane Saturday.

It took the Swazi King Mswati less than an hour Saturday afternoon to end a nationwide teachers strike that has been on for the past four weeks. 

Addressing some 6000 teachers assembled in the gardens of the State Palace here, the 28 year-old King gently chided the teachers for delaying referring their problems to him after all legal channels used in their negotiations with the government had failed.

The king requested the teachers to go back to their classess and begin teaching whilst their leaders return to the negotiations table with the government.

King Mswati left no doubt in the minds of the teachers that their demand for an 18 percent salary increase instead of 9.9 percent, recently raised to 10.94 percent offered by government must remain a pipe dream.

However, the King indicated he would not be asking them to go back to school whilst negotiations continued unless he believed some sort of compromise was possible. He said he would expect to be kept fully and regularly informed as to the progress of the new round of negotiations.

Confirming the teachers acceptance of the king's decision, the Swaziland National Association of Teachers Central Executive's acting president, Phineas Mag, issued a statement thanking the him for his intervention.

He informed the nation in a radio broadcast that the schools would reopen this coming Tuesday.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe Controversial Film Set for Release


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 13, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The controversial Zimbabwean feature film "Flame", fresh from the world renowned Cannes Film Festival, will be released in Zimbabwe next month, director Simon Bright said on Saturday.

Bright said the Junior Chambers (Jaycees) would hold a premiere of the film on July 23 before it goes on circuit in the country. 

Bright said the film had been a big success at the French festival and played to full houses.

"The film did very well at Cannes, the audiences really loved it. It was invited to other film festivals in North Korea, Montreal and the Amian festival in November," said Bright.

He said there was a scene when a Japanese burst into tears when she saw the main actor in Flame, Marian Kunonga, at the awards presentations.

Flame ignited controversy during the early stages of production when police seized parts of the film on allegations that it was subversive and parts of it pornographic.

The film was later cleared and released back to the producers but Zimbabwe's war veterans associations objected to the film saying it was a denigration of the country's struggle and showed women in bad light.

The board of censors approved the film with a no under 16 age restriction.

6 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Olympics Can Nigeria's Under-23 Live Up to Their Dream Team Tag?


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996 by Vincent Obi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 667 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian soccer fans quickly named their Olympic team "The Dream Team" shortly after it shoved aside Zimbabwe to qualify for its fourth Olympic appearance since its debut in Mexico in 1968.

Nigeria's best result in the event was a 3-3 draw against Brazil, having failed to go beyond the first round.

This month in Atlanta, Nigeria will be lining up against soccer heavyweights Brazil, Hungary and Japan. 

On paper, the dream team appears well balanced and prepared to do the nation proud, especially with the crop of players already in camp in the United States.

The list of 18 players released last week by the Nigerian Football Association showed preference for foreign-based stars to their locally-based ones.

The team reads like a who's who in Nigerian youth soccer. It was drawn mainly from the under-17 squad that won the World Cup in 1993 in Japan and the under-20 team which took bronze in the FIFA Africa '95 tournament.

The Babayaro brothers (Emmanuel and Celestine), Taribo West, skipper Kanu Nwankwo, Tijani Babangida, Wilson Oruma, Teslim Fatusi, Augustine Okocha, Victor Ikpeba, Abiodun Obafemi, Garba Lawal, Sunday Oliseh, Kingsley Obiekwu, Mobi Oparaku and Joseph Dosu, are all richly endowed with talent.

They join forces with three over-aged players allowed in by the International Olympic Committee -- Uche Okechukwu, Emmanuel Amunike and Daniel Amokachi -- to fly the nation's flag at the centennial games.

Nigeria's opponents at Atlanta '96 -- Japan, Hungary and Brazil - are no new comers to Olympic soccer

Hungary is the most successful of the four in the group, winning the Olympic soccer title a record three times.

The Hungarians, on paper the weakest in the group, won in 1952 in Helsinki, Finland, 1964 in Tokyo, Japan, and in 1968 in Mexico City, Mexico.

Their first outing in 1912 in Stockholm, Sweden, earned them a fifth place. They were third eight years later in Rome in 1960 and second in 1972 in Munich, Germany.

The Brazilians, considered the traditional world soccer power, have surprisingly not done very well in Olympic soccer.

They were fifth in 1952 and fourth in 1976 in Montreal, Canada.

On current form, Nigeria and Brazil look set to advance to the next round. But Nigeria must first put its house in order if it intends to improve on its previous performance.

Stories of unpaid allowances and refusal by some players to report early in camp are worrisome developments.

Nigeria must also watch out for the Brazilian soccer machine, which mercilessly destroyed Ghana's Olympic team by a whopping eight goals to one in a pre-Olympiad friendly.

The Nigerian squad temporarily lost its dream team tag when it was demolished 3-1 by lowly-rated Togo recently. It, however, appears to have rekindled confidence in its fans after it held the Unites States team to a goal-less draw recently in Pomona (United States).

That confidence will have to be sustained in the team's action on and off the field, to justify its qualification for the Atlanta Olympiad.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe Zimbabwe Produces More Gold


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's gold output rose four percent to reach 12.17 tones
worth 150 million U.S dollars during the first six months of this year, according to the Chamber of Mines of Zimbabwe.

Production during the first six months of 1995 stood at 11.66 tones, then worth 120 million U.S dollars. 

The chamber, which has already projected annual gold output might, for the first time, surpass 25 tones this year, was disappointed by June's production of 1,862,53 kg, which was 8 percent lower than what was obtained the previous month.

"We don't really know what caused production to fall...(but) if the trend continues, we might reach 25 tones," an official of the chamber said on Wednesday.

On a month by month basis, gold output in January 1996 reached 2,211.47 kg, dropping to 1,912.82 kg in February. It climbed 6 percent to 2,023.48 kg in March and 2,135.16 kg in April, and dropped slightly in May to 2,031.14 kg.

Zimbabwean gold mines were expected to sustain production on the back of rising world demand.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Records Trade Surplus With Brazil


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 240 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's exports to Brazil last year stood at 284 million U.S dollars, as against 243.3 million dollars in imports, official figures released by the Brazilian embassy in Lagos Thursday showed.

The trade figures were the highest recorded in many years. 

Oil accounted for 280 million dollars, or 98.6 percent, of Nigeria's exports to the South American country. Leather goods, cashew nuts and rubber accounted for the other four million dollars.

Sugar accounted for 56 percent, or 136.4 million dollars, of Nigeria's imports from Brazil. Trucks, printing and packaging paper, steel products, automobile spares, and luxury buses accounted for the rest.

Meanwhile, Brazil is expected to sell a large quantity of bauxite and aluminum to Nigeria in 1997, when the West African country opens its giant aluminum smelting plant in Ikoti-Abasi in the south-eastern part of the country.

With the current increase in trade between the two countries, the embassy predicts that Nigeria's imports from Brazil could hit the 500 million dollar mark by the year 2000.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Niger Post-Election Tension Rise in Niamey


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996 by Idi Kotoudi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 227 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The Police in Niamey used tear gas Wednesday, to disperse hundreds of supporters of political parties who were to attend a rally in the capital of Niger.

A few people were wounded and others arrested by police. 

The rally was called by leaders of political parties which fielded candidates in the presidential election held on Sunday and Monday. Official results gave a 52.20 percent victory to Gen. Ibrahim Bare Mainassara, head of the military junta which took power on January 27.

Tension hit Niger after Monday's dissolution of the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI) by Gen. Mainassara, who accused it of bias in favour of his challengers.

The same day, the military ruler appointed another electoral commission to replace the CENI. It was this commission that announced his victory.

On Tuesday evening, the Union of Niger Workers (USTN) called for an indefinite strike, starting Thursday, to demand the re-instatement of the independent commission.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Zambia's Elections To Cost 10 Million Dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia is to spend an estimated 10 million U.S dollars on this year's presidential, parliamentary and local government polls, election officials said Thursday in the capital, Lusaka.

Joel Sikazwe, Deputy Director of Elections, told journalists that eight million dollars was earmarked for the general elections (presidential and parliamentary) while the local government polls were to cost 2.5 million dollars.

The Zambian government in 1995 signed an 18-million-dollar contract with a private Israeli firm, Nikuv Computers, to update the national voters roll. 

Sikazwe said the voters cards printed by Nikuv would be distributed to registered voters soon.

He said last week that a total of 2.3 million voters had been registered by Nikuv, some 600,000 less than those on the previous roll.

Some anomalies have, however, been detected in the voters cards printed by Nikuv in the United States. They include duplication of names, meaning that they appear on more than one roll. This could cause problems in the voting.

Some opposition parties, including the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former president Kenneth Kaunda, have demanded that the registration of voters should be repeated.

They have alleged that Nikuv had done a haphazard job so as to rig the polls in favour of the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba.

It is the first time since Zambia's independence in 1964 that a foreign company has been involved in the registration of voters.

UNIP and two other opposition parties earlier this year, lost a court application to nullify Nikuv's contract. An appeal has been lodged with the supreme court.

The opposition has also charged that Nikuv is a cover for Mossad, the Israeli external intelligence agency, hired by the Chiluba government to help manipulate the polls.

According to Nikuv's arrangement, all registered voters need to claim their voters cards to be able to cast their ballots in the forthcoming elections.

Chiluba has yet to announce the dates for both the general and local government elections.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe Contributions For Harare Solar Summit Slow


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - With only about two months left before the World Solar Summit opens in
Harare, only 40,000 U.S dollars has been collected in cash and kind, for hosting the forum which is expected to cost 5.5 million U.S dollars.

Austria and the European Union (EU) have made pledges towards the summit, to be held in the Zimbabwean capital September 16 and 17.

The Austrian government pledged some 100,000 U.S dollars and the EU about 130,000 U.S dollars. The summit is expected to launch the "World Solar Decade." 

The Zimbabwe government has set up an organizing committee which has so far raised the equivalent of 39,049 U.S dollars.

Authorities in Harare are already showing concern at the slow pace contributions are coming in.

At a news conference on Wednesday, Vice President Simon Muzenda, who is also chairman of the cabinet committee on state occasions, appealed to local organizations and the international community to contribute in cash and kind towards the summit.

"It is a challenge and singular honor that has been bestowed on us to host a summit that will spearhead a world programme which will concretely address issues of sustainable development," he said.

Muzenda said the Zimbabwean government's contribution to the summit would depend on the 1996/97 budget to be announced this month and also on the contributions.

"The Zimbabwean government is trying its best to ensure that the summit is a success. We are certain that the government will do its best to raise the money required. It is an international effort, so other countries should also come in," Muzenda said.

He said more than 200 heads of state and government and heads of international organizations and institutions had been invited but could not say how many had responded positively.

Some 14 committees have been set up to ensure the successful hosting of the summit being convened to solicit political support for the use of renewable energy technologies that are environmentally friendly.

Zimbabwe stood to benefit from hosting the summit through technology transfer, which would result in an economic boom and improvement of standards of living, especially in rural and remote areas.

A 15-member world solar commission comprising heads of state, under the chairmanship of President Robert Mugabe, has already begun work on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO)-initiated World Solar Summit Process (WSSP).

The commission will advise the summit on the best possible strategies to popularize the worldwide development and utilisation of renewable energies. The future role of the commission will be decided by the summit.

The WSSP was launched in 1993 in partnership with the EU and the International Atomic Energy Agency to create an awareness of the need to switch from conventional methods of energy to use of renewable energy technology.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996

Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Olympics Namibia's Fredericks Poised For Olympic Sprint Title


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996


LENGTH: 694 words


 

DAKAR, SenegaL (PANA) - At the Atlanta Olympics, Namibia's Frankie Fredericks, African record
holder for the 100m and 200m, will certainly be a major threat to European and American sprinters.

Since early June, at four meets -- in Saint-Denis and Villeneuve D'Asq (France), Helsinki (Finland) and Lausanne (Switzerland) -- he has run the 100m in under 10 seconds.

On July 3, Fredericks set a new African record, clocking 9.86 seconds in the race, beating the former record of 9.94 seconds, set by the Nigerian Davidson Ezinwa. His time was a hundredth of a second behind the American Leroy Burrell's world record of 9.85 seconds. 

After finishing second best, for a few years, in the sprint, the Namibian ace's motto at Atlanta will be: "gold, nothing but gold". The question is whether he can do a double and win gold in both the 100m and 200m events.

It is now certain that he will run the 200m, in which he beat world record holder, Michael Johnson (19.66) on July 5, in Oslo, Norway, clocking 19.82 seconds. This was the American star's first defeat in 21 races. Fredericks also set a new African record, beating the three-year-old record of 19.85 in the race.

Fredericks is one of Namibia's top sports ambassadors and his career is closely linked to the history of his country. After Namibia's independence, Frankie Fredericks left football for athletics.

Thanks to a grant from the Uranium company for which his father works, he had the opportunity to attend Brigham Young University in Utah, United States. There, while preparing for a Master's degree in Business and Administration (MBA), he rubbed shoulders with future American stars in college athletics competitions.

In August 1991, the International Amateur Athletics Federation (IAAF) admitted the Namibian National Federation, a few days before the World Athletics Championships in Tokyo, Japan. This enabled Fredericks to participate in the competition.

He finished 5th in the 100m final, setting an African record (9.97 secs) and gave his country its first medal in a world competition by winning silver in the 200m. It was also the first African medal in the sprint at a world competition since 1964, when Senegal's Abdou Seye, running under French colors, won the bronze medal in the 200m at the Tokyo Olympics.

In 1968, Jean Louis Ravelomanantsoa of Madagascar made it to the final but failed to win a medal in the 100m at the Mexico Olympics.

At the Barcelona Olympics of 1992, Fredericks won two silver medals (100 and 200m), Namibia's first medals in Olympic history.

At the 1993 world championships in Stuttgart, Germany, the Namibian athlete won gold in the 200m and set a new African record (19.68). Two years later, at the world championships in Goteburg, Sweden, he failed to repeat his feat but managed a silver in the same race.

In five years, Fredericks has won one gold medal and four silver medals at world championships and Olympics, a clear testimony of his talent as a sprinter.

In Atlanta, the Namibian athlete is expected to live up to his reputation, especially with his recent winning streak in the 100 and 200m races. This should give him a psychological edge over his greatest rivals.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Ethiopia Ethiopia Arrests Two For Counterfeiting Dollar Bills


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 11, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Two Cameroonians and three Ethiopian accomplices have been arrested in the Eastern city of Dire Dawa after having been found with 30,000 U.S. fake dollars bills.

According to a report local newspapers in Addis Ababa Thursday, the forgers were also found with the machine they used to make the fake money. 

Quoting police in Dire Dawa, the reports said the two Cameroonians and the three Ethiopians were arrested Tuesday, while trying to change an undisclosed amount of 100 dollar bills into birr, the Ethiopian currency.

Police later found their printing machine, an assortment of chemicals, 30,000 dollars in forged notes and a large sum of birr, in the possession of the five persons.

The two Cameroonians, whose names were not given, reportedly entered the country legally in early May from Kinshasa, Zaire.

They were quoted as telling police they had been engaged in forgery in Kinshasa and had gone undetected.

July, 1996


Burundi Workers Protest Against Killings In Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 12, 1996


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Activities ground to a halt in Bujumbura Friday, as workers in strifeThe work-stoppage was organized workers' union to protest the death of about 100 workers killed last week in the central town of Teza, in an attack on a tea packaging factory.
torn Burundi mounted a one-day protest against ongoing violence in the country. 

The move was also in memory of "all the genocide victims in Burundi" and coincided with the end of one week of reflection on genocide, initiated by Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo.

The Unions have urged government officials to abandon their ambivalent attitude to the crisis in the country and put an end to the continuing massacres.

The workers' action was particularly felt in Bujumbura which, reports said, had the semblance of a ghost town, as offices remained closed and the streets deserted.

Burundi has been the scene of ethnic violence in the past three years, caused by sporadic bloody clashes between members of the majority Hutu and Tutsi minority ethnic groups.

The clashes, which have claimed some 150,00 lives, began in October 1993. They followed the assassination of the first democratically elected Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye, in a failed coup mounted by the army which is dominated by the Tutsi.

Africa News


July, 1996


Mozambique Mozambique's Population Now Over 18 Million Mozambicans


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 12, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique will have an estimated 18.027 million people by the end
of 1996, with an annual growth rate of 2.7 percent, Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi said Thursday.

Speaking at a ceremony to mark World Population Day, he said that this meant that there are 600,000 more people in the country than in 1995. 

The birth rate in Mozambique was 6.4 in 1995, while infant mortality rate stood at 128 per thousand. There was also a dependency rate of 93. This means that every 100 members of the economically active population have to guarantee the subsistence of 93 people who are not of working age.

"The youthful structure of the Mozambican population means that the government faces a major challenge of creating jobs and planning social services, which calls for large scale investments," he said.

This year's celebration of the World Population Day coincides with the preparations for a general population census of Mozambique, due to take place in 1997.

"Although in a context of financial constraint, we are making progress in the preparatory activities for the census," he said.

In the formulation of a national population policy, he said, the conclusions of the international conference on population and development, held in 1994 in Cairo, would be taken into account.

The conference considered that population, poverty and development were inter-related factors which had to be addressed jointly.

Mozambique's population policy, he said, would focus on the harmonization of demographic trends with the country's economic growth.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Mozambique Frozen Chickens Flood Mozambican Markets


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 12, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Massive imports of South African frozen chickens are ruining the Mozambican poultry industry by undercutting local prices.

According to a report in Friday's issue of the independent news sheet "Mediafax", the South African chickens sell at 26,000 meticais (about 2.3 U.S dollars), while the Mozambican ones cost between 28,000 and 30,000 meticais a kilo.

Worried by the competition, the Mozambican Association of Poultry Producers (AVIACA) has written a strong protest letter to the minister of industry, energy, and tourism, Oldemiro Baloi. 

The association pointed out that the poultry industry is one of the few sectors of the Mozambican economy that grew massively over the past decade -- and with very little support from the country's banks.

In the mid-1980s almost all chickens consumed in Mozambique were imported. Since then, local poultry producers have rehabilitated existing poultry farms and built new ones, helping the country's move towards self sufficiency in chickens and eggs.

They invested in incubators, slaughterhouses, freezers, laboratories, and transport. In 1995, AVIACA members produced 6,000 tons of chicken, 800,000 dozens of eggs, and 15,000 tons of chicken feed. Since many producers have not yet joined the recently formed AVIACA, the real figures would be much higher.

Poultry production generated 1,800 jobs in 1995, says AVIACA, and provides employment for 10,000 peasant and co-operative chicken breeders.

In 1995, poultry production generated three billion meticais (about 263,000 U.S dollars) in taxes for the state budget. It also saved the country 20 million dollars that would otherwise have been spent in importing chickens and eggs.

The poultry producers told the minister that all this is now under threat from the South African imports.

"Not only is a considerable proportion of the imported chickens totally illegal, but in general the licensed importers bring in more than they declare," noted the AVIACA in its letter to the minister.

The smuggling and consequent evasion of import duties mean that the state receives less from the imports than from the local produce.

"The importers, seeking to maximize their profits, acquire produce whose low prices derive from years of being frozen, or from contamination, or from being stuffed full of hormones and antibiotics, which would bar them from access to more demanding markets," AVIACA's letter said.

"We are not calling for a ban on imports of frozen chickens but we do argue that imports should complement national production, and should obey mechanisms of quality control that safeguard the consumers' health and accord with notions of fair competition,"

Importers of the South African chickens use various tricks to get round imports and customs regulations. In particular, they exploit a loophole whereby imports valued at less than 500 dollars do not need an import licence. So the pirate importers make several imports per day, all valued at less than 500 dollars, the association said.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Uganda Coca Cola To Invest 30 Million Dollars in Uganda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 12, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The multi-national Coca Cola, has announced here that it will invest 30
million U.S dollars in two new bottling lines in Uganda.

"The first bottling line in Mbarara (south western Uganda) will be operational in April 1997. The other, a modern giant factory in Namanve, 18 kilometers (about 12 miles) east of Kampala, will be ready by the end of the year," said Majid Bagalaaliwo, a local Coca Cola representative in Uganda, Thursday.

Bagalaaliwo, who is chairman of Century Bottling Plant, made the announcement in a news release at the end of a visit by Carl Ware, Senior Coca Cola vice-president and head of its operations in Africa.

Ware presented his company's investment plans to President Yoweri Museveni on Tuesday.

The major share holders in Century are the Bagalaaliwo family and Coca-Cola SABCO, a South African company whose headquarters is in Port Elizabeth.

Century Bottling Company produces four million crates of soft drinks annually and pays the government one million dollars monthly in taxes.

Bagalaaliwo said the company has already acquired 20 acres of land in Mbarara. Negotiations for the acquisition of another 30 acres in Namanve, have almost been concluded, he added.

Coca Cola will also modernize existing distribution and marketing infrastructure, which will be expanded country wide. "I am sure you can anticipate the economic spin-off which investment of this magnitude will have on the economy and on the people of Uganda," said Butch Moldenhauer, Century's Managing Director.

"We are excited about the future of the Coca-Cola business in Uganda and we are committed to the success of our projects within this country," Moldenhauer added.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996

July, 1996


Africa-at-Large PANA's Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 12, 1996 by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Boutros-Ghali's bid for re-election as United Nations secretary-general, the summit of the Organisation of African Unity, elections in Niger and the establishment of Sierra Leone's Truth Commission, were among the leading issues discussed in the African press this week.

Boutros-Ghali's announcement seeking a second five-year term awakened the hostility of the United States government. The Lagos newspaper, Daily Times, said that while the U.S. claimed that its hostility was motivated by a desire to see a more efficient U.N. system, "the real reason behind Washington's moves may be nothing but sheer domestic politics."

It said: "It is no longer a secret that over the years, right wing elements in the United States have turned the world body into a favorite sport to be punched and vilified at every opportunity." 

Consequently, it said, "In a re-election bid that is already badly tainted by Whitewater, Paula Jones and Filegate, Mr. Clinton has chosen to vote against Boutros-Ghali perhaps to deny his republican opponents an opportunity to attack his foreign policy. But he went too far."

Trimming the U.N. bureaucracy, democratizing its Security Council, reducing the size of the U.S. contribution to the world body, it said, were all badly needed changes.

"Reforms of this magnitude, some observers have pointed out, go well beyond the purview of the secretary-general; it is an issue which the member states themselves must pursue vigorously," it said.

"Be that as it may, Africans must stand solidly behind Dr. Boutros-Ghali in his re-election campaign because as the first African to occupy that position, the secretary-general has acquitted himself quite well," it said.

He was called upon to occupy that position "at a crucial but difficult moment" in international relations.

It noted that with the end of the cold war, there was a dramatic shift of world attention, to the countries of eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

"In spite of this, Boutros-Ghali ensured that Africa was not marginalized within the U.N. system," it said. "He supported peace-keeping operations in Angola, Mozambique, Liberia and Somalia."

Earlier this year, it noted, he launched a special 25 billion U.S.-dollar initiative for the development of Africa.

"These factors, and the fact that past occupants of the world's highest public office have always had a second term, compel us to urge Africa to rally solidly behind Dr. Boutros-Ghali, to ensure that he is not denied a second term which is rightly his.

"Furthermore, Boutros-Ghali's second term would afford him the opportunity to realize the democratization of the permanent membership of the Security Council, which the big boys have hitherto monopolized to the exclusion of large sections of the globe.

"The membership of the Security Council indeed poses the biggest paradox of our time, namely, that those who are weeping louder than the bereaved, calling for democracy in other countries, cannot see the need to democratize the U.N. to ensure that all the free nations of the world conduct their affairs in an atmosphere devoid of bullying and condescending inequality."

Cotonou's Le Citoyen (The Citizen) and The Monitor, of Addis Ababa, agreed with the Daily Times.

Le Citoyen, a Beninese publication, commented on the endorsement given the Egyptian diplomat by the Organisation of African Unity.

"In fact, Africa has no reproach against Boutros Boutros-Ghali and his (first term) has been positive," Le Citoyen said.

"Mr Boutros-Ghali's major handicap is American hostility or, rather, Israeli hostility expressed through Bill Clinton, the U.S. president, who will be seeking a second term in office at the end of this year," it said. "In effect, Boutros-Ghali has become persona non grata (in the United States) because of his policy in the Near-East."

The Monitor noted U.S. assurances that it would not oppose the election of another African as secretary general.

"Although this is a good diplomatic compromise, Africans should not entirely leave the choice to be guided by the tastes of the United States. They will have to make their own independent choice and coordinate their diplomatic activities to this end, with other developing countries," the newspaper said.

"There are, of course, a lot of educated and talented African diplomats that can fill Boutros-Ghali's shoes. Whether they are endorsing the re-election of Boutros Ghali' or any other African candidate, they will have to close ranks as they have recently done at the Yaounde Summit and (work) for the best interests of Africa," it said.

"By its style of debate, its decisions, the bold affirmation of pride in being African, Yaounde '96 "presented for the O.A.U. an era of concrete resolutions," The official Cameroon Tribune said.

But Le Quotidien, Cameroon's first privately-owned daily, said it wished the resolutions will not end up as unimplemented "pious wishes".

La Nouvelle Expression, another Yaounde newspaper, saw the conference as a mere formality especially, it said, as there were no resolutions nor concrete decisions on conflicts such as those in Burundi, Somalia and Liberia.

Dakar's Sud Quotidien thinks the meeting was so mundane that it suggests it be held every two years, rather than annually.

"Even the Islamic Conference Organisation, which is better funded than the O.A.U., meets every two years," it noted.

In Niger, Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara Bare's dissolution of the country's independent electoral commission, in the middle of voting, and his arrest of opposition politicians came under vicious attack.

These acts, Cotonou-based Le Citoyen said, were motivated by his worry that his rivals would band together in opposition.

"He has thus vitiated the electoral process, creating a situation that some describe as a second coup, even though he denies it," the paper said.

"What credibility can be given to a ballot at which votes are said to have been counted by soldiers or under tight military surveillance?" said the Benin government daily, La Nation.

"After the military coup of last January, an electoral coup has now been staged," the Cotonou newspaper said.

Dakar's Le Soleil said that after his January takeover, Gen. Bare had all the tools needed to put the democratic process back on track. But to complete this mission, it added, he had to hold credible elections.

"To do so, the Independent Electoral Commission, though not the ideal solution, gave a certain guarantee of fairness. Its dissolution in the middle of vote counting and its replacement by a body exclusively comprising senior officials chosen by the military junta, raises strong suspicion on the credibility of the results announced after the election," it said.

The Daily Champion, another private newspaper published in Lagos, described as "timely, welcome and commendable," the establishment by the Sierra Leonean government of a National Unity and Reconciliation Commission.

The new civilian administration in Freetown set up the body to investigate the atrocities of the country's past military administration. The idea is to right whatever wrongs may have been committed by individuals or groups.

"If the commission carries out its onerous and historical assignment with the requisite objectively, candor and fairness, there is no doubt that the exercise will go a long way in removing sources of conflict in Sierra Leone," it said.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe South African Parliamentarians Visit Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - South African Speaker of parliament, Frene
Ginwala, said on Wednesday the withdrawal of the National Party from the government of national unity will strengthen the country's opposition in the national assembly and enhance democracy.

Ginwala, who is heading a seven-member South African parliamentary delegation on a five-day visit here, was speaking to reporters after meeting her Zimbabwean counterpart, Cyril Ndebele.

She said the level of debate in the South African parliament was as good as in any country in the world. 

"We have dull and sometimes very fiery debates, just like anywhere else, including Zimbabwe," said Ginwala.

"There will, however, be a significant shift in August this year when our parliament re-opens. The opposition will be significantly larger with the addition of one more larger party, the National Party. We anticipate more vibrant and challenging debates," she said.

Ginwala said the National Party's withdrawal would not only enhance democracy, but had also resulted in an increase in the number of opposition parliamentarians from less than 10 to well over 18.

The National Party of former Second Deputy President, Frederick de Klerk, pulled out of the government of national unity in June, claiming that the African National Congress (ANC) had refused to extend the current power-sharing arrangement beyond 1999.

Ginwala said South Africa was still trying to further democratize the process and institution of parliament, adding that the transformation would be through specific experiences and examples from others around the world.

Ginwala said the visit to Zimbabwe was part of efforts to cement relations between the two countries.

"We are engaged in a crusade of parliamentary reforms and draw a lot of inspiration from Zimbabwe, not only because we are neighbors, but also because we inherited a similar and common situation at independence," she said.

The South African delegation includes members of the majority parliamentary party -- Nelson Mandela's ANC, the Pan-Africanist Congress, National Party, Inkhatha Freedom Party and the Freedom Front.

LANGUAGE: English

July, 1996


Sports - Olympics Zambian Olympic Team Leaves for Atlanta


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Seven home-based Zambian athletes left Lusaka late Tuesday, to participate in the Olympic Games in the United States.

The seven, six boxers and one athlete, are part of Zambia's 12-person contingent to the July 19 to August 4 Olympics. The other five athletes, based in the United States, will join the team in Atlanta.

President Frederick Chiluba on Saturday, bailed out the team with a donation of 20,000 U.S dollars covering part of its travel expenses. The gift was in addition to other private donations and monies obtained from fund raising events.

There had been fears the team would fail to travel due to lack of funds.

Zambia's Olympic team comprises former world and current Commonwealth 400 meters hurdles champion Samuel Matete who is based in the United States. He is the country's major hope for a medal at the games.

Others are Godfrey Siamusiye, a 3,000 meters steeplechase specialist and Charles Mulinga (5,000m), Clinton Bufuku (200m) and Fackson Nkandu (5,000m). The only female on the team is the runner Ngozi Mwanamwambwa. She does the 200m and 400m.

The six boxers who left Tuesday with runner Nkandu are: Boniface Mukuka (flyweight), Oscar Chongo (bantamweight), Dave Mwale (light flyweight), Dennis Zimba (lightweight), Victor Kasote (flyweight), and Chris Mpande a featherweight.

The boxers returned to Lusaka recently from a six-week training stint at a South African army barracks in Blomfontein.

They were briefly camped in the midlands town of Kabwe by a local boxing promoter before departure.

LANGUAGE: English

21 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Science Nigerian Researcher Finds Cure For Herpes Simplex


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Adamu Lawal Toro, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

PRETORIA, South Africa (PANA) - A 40-year-old Nigerian doctoral student at the University of Pretoria, Anthony Afolayan, has found a cure for a peculiar disease among the white population in South Africa.

Afolayan, once a botany lecturer at the University of Ilorin, in south-western Nigeria, was able to resolve the riddle behind Herpes Simplex by extracting an active ingredient from a local herb.

Herpes Simplex is a disease that causes blisters and cracks, usually on the lips. 

Afolayan's doctoral dissertation was based on research on the medicinal potential of a local flowering plant called Helichrysum. The plant was found to be active against bacteria, fungi and viruses.

An extract from the plant was successfully used in treating about 100 cases of herpes among students and lecturers at the university in conjunction with a local hospital.

Following the publication of the breakthrough in international medical and scientific journals, many pharmaceutical companies are trooping to Pretoria to strike a deal for marketing the product.

An enthusiastic Afolayan told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) that he had been bombarded with offers of job across the globe. But he was likely to remain in South Africa to continue research on the other cures available from the plant, the researcher said.

The plant, which is found only in South Africa's Kwazulu- Natal province and parts of Lesotho, has for ages been used by the Zulus for treating headaches, bronchitis and other ailments.

Afolayan's supervisor, John Meyer, told NAN that the university was very proud of his findings.

"It has brought the university to the limelight and the potential for a lot of international collaboration, " he said.

Meyer said medication currently on the market for herpes which have not been as effective, cost more than 40 rands (about 10 U.S. dollars) per dose.

"The new discovery would go a long way in curing a disease that has afflicted Europeans for ages without cure," he added.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


22 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Niger Niger Unions Call Strike Over Muddled Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Idi Mama Kotoudi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The Niger Workers Trade Union Federation has called for an indefinite strike, starting Thursday, to protest against the conduct of presidential elections Sunday and Monday.

The unions and the opposition parties claimed Gen. Bare Mainassara dissolved the independent electoral commission after preliminary results showed he was losing. 

The results, announced by a hastily-appointed electoral commission, showed the military ruler, Ibrahim Mainassara Barre had won 52.20 percent of the vote.

The results mean there will be no run-off election. The strike was called in Niamey, Tuesday, at the end of an extraordinary congress of all trade unions, including those which are not affiliated to the Federation.

The government has tried to stop the strike by issuing a statement appealing to "the workers' sense of responsibility and judgment", while acknowledging their "right to industrial action."

The strike will coincide with a call from the opposition parties protesting the results, to turn Niamey, the capital, and other towns into "dead cities".

Political analysts in Niamey said the situation in Niger would be tense in the coming days.

There were reports that some presidential candidates in the elections had been put under house arrest while others had sought refuge in foreign missions.

The other presidential candidates were Mamadou Tanja, former president Mahamane Ousmane, Moumouni Adamou Djermakoye and Mahamadou Issoufou.

Mainassara seized power in a military coup on January 27.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa South African Business Confidence Improves


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Confidence in the South African business sector turned around in June, showing its first improvement after six successive months of decline.

The June business confidence index of the South African Chamber of Business (SACOB), released Tuesday, shows a rise of two percentage points to a level of 118.9. 

The main factor behind the increase in business confidence was the announcement last month of the South African government's macro-economic strategy.

"The business mood has largely improved," said SACOB chief economist, Ben Van Rensburg, "because the government has come forward with a specific view on how to take the country forward."

"The strategy," he added, "provides a framework which should make it possible for South Africa to achieve the targets generally regarded as the minimum which the country must attain if it is to negotiate itself out of the poverty trap in which it currently finds itself."

The South African government plan aims to create 500,000 jobs a year and boost economic growth to 6.0 percent by the year 2000.

Other positive developments which have boosted business confidence in South Africa, include the reversal of an increase in interest rates by the country's banks and a return to relative stability in the foreign exchange markets.

Another positive factor was the holding of peaceful local government elections in Kwazulu-Natal province two weeks ago.

SACOB Director-General, Raymond Parsons, says economic activity is levelling off, and adds: "fast implementation and monitoring of the economic strategy could see the country reach growth of five to six percent by the year 2000."


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Summits To Be Held In Harare, Ouagadougou and Algiers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 574 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organisation of Africa Unity summit in Yaounde, Cameroon, decided Tuesday that the 1997 summit will be held in Harare, Zimbabwe.

African leaders also confirmed that the 1998 meeting will be in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso and the following year in Algiers, Algeria.

In a press conference Tuesday, OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said "this shows we have perfected the art of planning." 

It is customary for the president of the country hosting the summit to assume the leadership of the 53-nation body, a prestigious position than can reap political benefits for the incumbent, at home and abroad.

The summit went into protracted discussions late Tuesday, during which the leaders resolved, among other issues, gave a six-month moratorium on debtor countries to pay at least 30 percent of their arrears of contributions to the body by the end of July.

As at June 1, arrears owed to the organization amounted to 53 million U.S dollars.

The leaders also urged the government, leadership and armed forces of Burundi to demonstrate greater political will for a negotiated and peaceful settlement of the conflict currently raging in that country.

Burundi has seen over 150,000 people massacred in three years of ethnic clashes between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi groups.

At least, 30 African leaders attended the summit, which also urged the international community to provide increased material and financial assistance to countries hosting Liberian refugees.

Some 800,000 Liberian refugees have fled the country during the six-year old civil war.

In an unprecedented move, children from parts of the continent addressed the summit on the suffering of their colleagues in conflict-ridden states. Some 60 children from 12 African countries embroiled in different kinds of wars attended the summit.

The children called for the imposition of sanctions on all countries that violated children's rights and appealed for an immediate end to the production of anti-personnel land mines.

The African leaders also endorsed United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's bid for a second five-year term in office.

Boutros-Ghali has, however, fallen out of favour with the United States, which is now lobbying for an alternative African candidate.

A Saudi newspaper quoted the head of the Organisation of Islamic Conference, Hamid Algabid of Niger, as saying he would seek the U.N. post if it fell vacant.

A spokesman for the OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, said on Tuesday the Tanzanian was not interested in the job.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large No Show At Africa Summit For Nigerian Leader


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 10, 1996 by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - Nigerian Foreign Minister, Tom Ikimi, told the assembly of African leaders meeting Tuesday in Yaounde, Cameroon, that Gen. Sani Abacha had made plans to attend the summit but was unable to come at the 11th hour.

Local radio had reported that Abacha was expected in the Cameroonian capital on Sunday, for the summit. 

"It's true that all expected the Nigeria leader to come, but I don't have any further explanation beyond what the Nigerian foreign minister said," OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, said Tuesday at a press conference.

He said the fact that the territorial dispute between Nigeria and Cameroon, over ownership of the Bakassi Peninsula, was not on the summit's agenda, should not be viewed ominously.

The dispute has been referred to the International Court of Justice at the Hague and the Togolese President, Gnassingbe Eyadema, has been mediating between the two countries.

"I have also been involved as the secretary-general of the OAU in discussions with both Nigeria and Cameroon," Salim said.

"The fact that the item is not on the agenda should not give the wrong impression. What is important is that both parties should avoid any acts of violence," he said.

The dispute over the oil-rich Bakassi Peninsula has at times flared into skirmishes. This week, Nigeria accused Cameroon of massing troops in the disputed territory.

Abacha's absence in Yaounde almost certainly means there will be no discussion of the dispute at the summit, something President Biya had made clear he wanted.

Meanwhile, Salim said the summit is one of the best attended, with 31 heads of state in attendance. The forum will end on Wednesday.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Amnesty Chapter Condemns Rise in Femicide


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 10, 1996


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Mufulira - Amnesty International (AI) chapter in the copper mining town of Mufulira has condemned the rising spate of violence against women in Zambia and it appealed to Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) to help fight the scourge.

AI Zambia women co-ordinator, Margaret Mbuluku said her organisation was greatly concerned and alarmed by recent police revelations that the numbers of women dying violent deaths in domestic settings were on the increase. 

Ms Mbuluku said various NGOs especially those working with women should intensify efforts to educate women on their rights, even in marriage and how these could be upheld by the individuals concerned.

Battered women should be encouraged to report their assailants to the police even if these were their husbands.

Ms Mbuluku said traditionists like Mr. Pardon Katongo who encouraged wife battering all in the name of love should be condemned.

''We strongly feel that love is not beating, but embraces peace,'' Ms Mbuluku said.

Police force public relations officer, Francis Musonda, revealed earlier in the week that 84 women died from acts of violence countrywide between 1994-95.

Mr. Musonda said violence against women was still prevalent in Zambia and appealed to the public not to hide cases of violence so that culprits could be brought to book.

Africa News


July, 1996


Southern Africa South African Defense Minister Visits Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 10, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Vice President Godfrey Miyanda has assured South Africa that there is no political crisis in Zambia. Speaking when he welcomed the South African Defence Minister, Joe Modise, and his delegation, Gen. Miyanda said the political situation in the country is very stable contrary to some reports.

"I want to assure you that contrary to some reports you have heard, there is no crisis in the nation as you will see for yourselves while you are here," he said. 

Gen. Miyanda also commended the African National Congress for the way they have managed to run the country since independence. He said after the struggle, the ANC should now direct their energy and efforts towards development and the creation of peace and stability in the nation.

Mr. Modise who is also chairman for Inter-state Security Defence Committee in the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) commended the Zambian government for their support during his country's struggle for independence.

He said Zambia's committment to bring about freedom in South Africa would never be forgotten.

Later when he met Defence Minister Ben Mwila Mr Modise commended Zambia for it's committment towards the creation of peace in the region. Mr. Modise said since the formation of the defence committee Zambia is among the countries that have made progress in creating peace.

He named the other countries who have made progress in resolving conflicts through peace as Botswana and Angola.

Speaking at the same meeting Mr. Mwila called on the South African delegation to prove for themselves that there is no political crisis in the country. He said Zambia is committed to resolve all the internal conflicts through peaceful means.

Mr. Mwila also assured the South African delegation that the future of their country is bright now that they have passed through the first year successfully.

He said South Africa still has a long way to go adding that they should learn to iron out differences with neighbouring countries peacefully whenever they arise.

Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia Firm Denies Links With Global Copper Scandals


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 9, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines yesterday vehemently denied any connection to a global copper sales scandal involving Japanese company Sumitomo. ZCCM's denial comes a day after government announced it was conducting extensive studies into the activities of Sumitomo's copper sales worldwide to establish linkages with the Zambian mining conglomerate.

Speculative trading on the copper market has lost the Sumitomo Corporation of Japan about US$1.8 billion. ZCCM was linked through its relationship with Global Minerals and Metals which is being investigated by the New York authorities. 

A metal trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, working for Sumitomo Corporation, is believed to have influenced copper prices on the London Metal Exchange to the extent that he held sway over the prices on the entire market.

British, American and Japanese investigators are now investigating how this became possible and want to bring out all who were connected with his operations.

But ZCCM director of corporate planning and corporate affairs, Pius Mambo, said in a telephone interview from Kalulushi yesterday that none of the investigating agencies had so far approached ZCCM over the trader's dealings.

"We are very surprised at the British press reports and sent a protest letter to The Guardian newspaper in London which was published. We'll also be getting in touch with The Post over a story published concerning the same issue. It is not correct that we are involved in shady dealings," said Mambo. "No official has approached us and we are not aware of any investigation."

But Minister of Mines Keli Walubita in an interview yesterday maintained government was studying the situation and would issue a report at the appropriate time, but he declined to reveal what form the 'investigations' would take.

Hamanaka, known as "Mr Copper", was alleged to have held back substantial stocks of physical copper in collaboration with some copper producers for the purpose of manipulating price levels on the market.

Some financial lawyers involved in a law suit against Sumitomo said these stocks far exceeded the company's needs. But this put Hamanaka in a position to make massive profits on the futures market.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Israeli Firm Discounts Fears of Double Registrations


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 9, 1996 by Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Nikuv Computers (Israel) Limited, the company updating the voters register, has discounted fears of double registers in the forthcoming general elections. Speaking in an interview on Saturday Nikuv Computers projects manager, Gershon Korda, said such a possibility did not exist.

"I cannot see that happening especially when one has already been given his voter's card," Korda said. "At least our company cannot do that." 

But chairman of the opposition UNIP retired General Malimba Masheke said both government and Nikuv Computers cannot be trusted over the matter.

"Everything was arranged in a secret manner," General Masheke said in an interview yesterday. "It is this secrecy which shows that the two were up to no good."

General Masheke also said that the register prepared by Nikuv Computers "would not be used because it was a dead issue".

"We are not going to use Nikuv register.We have nothing to do with the company because the issue is dead," Masheke said. "We have to use NRCs or re-register afresh."

The National Party also said Korda's assurance cannot be trusted because his contract is with a small clique in Zambia. National Party secretary general Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika said in an interview yesterday that the only assurance must come through discussion by all stakeholders.

"The people of Zambia have no relationship with Korda and Nikuv. Worse still Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda is on record as saying he did not have any knowledge of some aspects of the Nikuv agreement," Lewanika said, adding: "This was one of the items at the meeting where the MMD walked out and we are still waiting for them to return when they get responsible enough."

And Korda also said that his company only used information it was given by the elections office and nothing else.

"We do not invent data," Korda said. "Whatever is done comes from the elections office."

Korda revealed that the provisional registers which were printed in Zambia at the Mulungushi conference centre, were now ready and would be handed to the elections office this week. He also revealed that some voters cards, which provide for three presidential elections and parliamentary elections and by-elections, three local government elections and by-elections, had already arrived in South Africa from the printers in America.

"They will be collected at the airport by the elections office and brought to us before we hand them back," Korda said.

According to Korda, Nikuv will soon establish a National Information Centre at the elections office with twenty computers, twenty in-coming lines, twenty operators and some printers. It will also provide all the register data to the office which will make it possible for people outside Lusaka to phone in to check whether their names are on the register or not.

"The data belongs to the Zambian government that is why as far as possible everything was done here," Korda said.

He denied the accusation reported in the press that his sister company in Zimbabwe had messed up the voters register there.

"Mistakes in Zimbabwe were minor and we corrected them. No-one has paid any extra money for the correction," Korda said, adding that the company in Zimbabwe where it has operated for more than a year now, was legally registered.

"We are not registered in Zambia," Korda admitted alluding to the fact that the company was not intending to do so.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia Entrepreneurs Urged to Seek Financing Abroad


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 10, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The lack of long and medium-term financing in the country has hindered small scale business expansion forcing some entrepreneurs to start crossing borders in a bid to source financing.

And it was the lack of such facilities that had led to the slow growth of the small scale business sector, explained Investment Centre director general, Bwalya Ng'andu, at an investment financing seminar in Lusaka yesterday.

"What you will only find being offered by the banks in the country are short-term loans and over-draft facilities while what the businesses are looking for are accessible long term financing facilities," Ng'andu said in an interview yesterday. 

The one day seminar was intended to provide information on the sources of finances and also enlighten participants, drawn from the country's business community, on good project creation.

Ng'andu said this was why his organisation had taken up a role of linking up prospective borrowers with financiers to enhance growth in medium and small scale businesses.

"Our role is to show the people where they can source funding for their business expansion and investment," Ngandu said.

Among the lending institutions which gave presentations on their operations and access to finances were the World Banks, International Finance Corporation (IFC) and Africa Project Development Facility.

And speaking in an interview IFC's Zimbabwe based senior investment officer, Philip Condon, disclosed that economic and political stability was his organisations key consideration before providing finances.

"We are not a political institution but we consider the political climate in any country. We are not ready to invest in war torn places but for small incidents encountered in elections we just go ahead in financing," Condon said.

A total of five companies have benefited from IFC's facilities over the last 10 years with the latest beneficiary being Big Five Car hire with almost US $600,000.

IFC, has through its recently launched Africa Enterprise Fund, been financially supportive to viable small and medium scale businesses with investment of US$250,000 up to US$5 million.

The IFC funding covers 40 per cent of the whole cost of the investment project.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia President to Dissolve Parliament Next Month


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 10, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba will next month dissolve Parliament and announce the date for presidential and general elections, State House sources disclosed yesterday.

According the sources, the President will dissolve Parliament either at the end of August or in the first week of September and call for a snap election to be held within two to three weeks.

But Minister of Labour and Social Services and MMD chief whip Newstead Zimba pleaded ignorance of the forthcoming dissolution of Parliament or the announcement of the elections date. 

"I have been on leave since July 1. I don't know about when Parliament resumes or will be dissolved. I also don't know about the elections because I am on leave," Zimba said in an interview yesterday, advising: "You must ignore some of these things."

However, the State House sources' information is confirmed by the programme drawn by the Elections Office which starts this Friday.

The programme which starts with the briefing of registration and elections officers in various provinces ends with the distribution of registers and election equipment by the director of elections, Rabson Mwansa, on September 1.

And Elections Office assistant director, Joel Sikazwe, declined to be drawn into the matter claiming that announcing the date of elections is the prerogative of the President.

But Sikazwe could not say why the programme of activities of the elections office appears to confirm the State House information.

"We wanted to get set but you can conclude what you want," Sikazwe said. "I haven't said yes. The programme is to enable us and our field staff to get ready."

But three opposition parties said they are ready for the elections if the playing field is levelled and the register is right.

"We are ready for an election," said UNIP chairman retired General Malimba Masheke, "but we are not ready for an election which is going to be rigged."

General Masheke complained of lack of access to the media and the non existence of an independent electoral commission.

"We have no access to the media - both print and electronic," General Masheke carped. " No independent electoral commission which can lay the ground for free and fair elections."

Zambia Democratic Congress vice-president, Kasuka Mutukwa, said while his party was ready for elections the present situation was suspect From Front Page

"We are ready for an election but before any election is held it is absolutely necessary for the election machinery to be known to all stakeholders and the voters," Mutukwa said. "We are ready but we can only take part when we know that the playing field is level. It is like playing football."

And National Party vice-secretary for elections Benson Mpundu also said his party was ready for the elections but wondered why government wanted to spend money on the Mongu by-election.

"We are ready for elections and elections can be called anytime. But why should we go to the Mongu by-election?," Mpundu asked. "There must be a motive to that."

But President Chiluba last month warned opposition parties to brace themselves for the elections and advised those who were not ready to try their luck after five years.

"This country must move forward and must never remain stagnant as it was in the UNIP era," he said.

He added that time for the election was the time of reckoning when political parties had to go back to the people to seek a fresh mandate and those parties which had not done much for the people should count themselves out of the race.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia Still Tops Africa in FIFA Ranks


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 12, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has dropped one point on the world soccer rankings from the number fifteen slot to position sixteen but she remains Africa's top side.

According to the latest FIFA rankings released on July 3, 1996, and made available to The Post yesterday by Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) acting general secretary Julio Chiluba, South Africa has moved two places behind Zambia at position eighteen, while Argentina has moved to the number fifteen position.

But Chiluba has attributed Zambia's new position to the latest edition of the European Cup. 

"I think the dropping is because a lot of European teams recently featured in the European Cup," said Chiluba yesterday.

Brazil, the 1994 World Cup winners still maintain the top slot while the newly crowned European champions, Germany are second placed. France , the Czech Republic, Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden follow in that order.

Zambia's opponents in the World Cup Group C, Zaire are ranked 58 with Congo, taking up the number 103 position.

Nigeria, the 1994 Africa Cup champions, are surprisingly ranked 47th with Zimbabwe on number 66.

The next rankings will be made on August 28.

And the BP top eight competition starts this month with the first matches set for Woodlands Stadium and Kitwe's Arthur Davies Stadium but the draws will be made on July 18.

Julio Chiluba, yesterday announced the quarter-finals that will involve Mufulira Wanderers, Power Dynamos, Kabwe Warriors, Zamsure, City of Lusaka, Lusaka Dynamos, Roan United and Konkola Blades, will start on July 28.

The semi-finals will be played on August 11 at Woodlands Stadium and Nkana Stadium while the finals will be staged at Lusaka's Independence Stadium on August 31.

And embattled FAZ officials are tomorrow holding an executive meeting in Ndola at which a date for the annual general meetings expected to be set.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
