Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Olympics Zambia's Medal Hopes Hinge On Matete


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 15, 1996 by Maidstone Mulenga


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Atlanta - If Zambia has any hopes of winning a medal at this year's Olympic Summer Games in Atlanta, they must be in Samuel Matete's shoes.

And if Samuel Matete has any hope of having Olympic jewelry around his neck, this is his year to do it.

As the Games begin this Friday with an elaborate ceremony, the spotlight on Africa and indeed Zambia will be in the track and field events which many people see as the very essence of the Games-pure athleticism. 

Forget boxing medals, it will be tough to beat American boxers at their home turf, that's if Zambian boxers don't slammed by Cuban boxers who are hot favorite to win most of the boxing medals.

So, it will be in the Olympic Stadium with its 85,000 capacity that the cream of Africa and Zambian will be showcased.

Matete has shown he is serious he is about winning the Olympic medal that eluded four years ago in Barcelona, thanks for questionable call. In the last four weeks, Matete has - literally - being running from one race to another and chalking up impressive wins.

Just in the last two weeks, he ran in the Nikaia Grand Prix track meet in Nice France on Wednesday, just after participating in the Salamanca trace meet in Spain, the Athletissima Grand Prix in Lausanne Switzerland and the Gaz de France Grand Prix meet in France in a space of ten days.

In Switzerland, Matete won the 400 hurdles in 47.85 beating American Olympic trials winner, Bryan Bronson, second in 48.06.

In Spain, he ran 49.01 beating Yoshihiko Saito of Japan, 49.33., and Ashraf Saber of Italy, 49.66.

In the Gaz de France meet, Matete barely lost to Derrick Adkins of US who ran 47.70 compared to Matete's 48.06. While the NiKaia Grand Prix, Matete was nicked at the tape by Torrance Zellner of United States in 48.24 while Matete clocked at 48.27.

Like one sports reporter noted: If Matete fails to win a medal this year, he is history as far as the Olympics are concerned.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia President's Press Aide Face Contempt Charges


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 15, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - An application that President Frederick Chiluba's press aide, Richard Sakala, been charged for contempt of court in the subordinate court was on Saturday objected to by defence lawyer, deputy minister in the Office of the President, Eric Silwamba.

Silwamba arguing in the case where Sakala is facing contempt charges before magistrate Brian Simango, said the subordinate court has no jurisdiction to hear contempt cases that were committed outside their perception.

"The procedure for contempt is very clear, where contempts are committed outside the (subordinate) court, the only court competent to hear such proceedings is the High Court which has unlimited original jurisdiction," Silwamba said. 

Silwamba was replying to an application by lawyer Sakwiba Sikota that Sakala be committed for contempt and that common law be used in these proceedings.

Sakala is alleged to have on March 26, this year approached Patrick Mutale from Zambia Daily Mail, an accused person in the main case of theft of newsprint, to include Post Newspaper managing director, Fred M'membe to become the principle accused person. He was then sued for contempt.

Sikota countered Silwamba's argument saying the whole concept of power to punish for contempt is based on the notion that the courts must be given their dignity.

Sikota said it was also to insure that individuals no matter how powerful or well placed do not pervert the course of justice or that the individual no matter how weak is not intimidated or trampled upon by those who have an influence on state machinery.

"Our motivation for commencing these proceedings is to ensure that they are protected by the Judicial system against those whose desire is to subvert the judicial process which is the cornerstone of modern, civilised society," Sikota said. "We therefore are comfortable with this court proceeding by way of this application to protect the parties to this action by hearing this matter or in the alternative if the other side is more comfortable with this court referring the matter for trial before the High Court, to do so."

Sikota said the defence was comfortable to swim in any stream of justice.

But Silwamba said Sikota's submission was immoral saying there was no choice in courts of law as to which procedure to follow.

Silwamba said in morality, one can choose a stream but at law, you can't.

Magistrate Simango adjourned the matter to August 6 for ruling and August 7 for the main case of theft of newsprint in which Mutale is charged with Post Finance manager, Patrick Musengwa, and Daily Mail's James Nkhoma, Grevasius Mayenga and Frederick Mumba.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Zambian Copper Smelter Gutted by Fire


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia July 15, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - A mysterious fire yesterday gutted the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) Mufulira Division smelter furnace causing extensive damage which will cost millions of United States dollars to repair.

Industrial relations officer, Kelvin Imasiku, confirmed the incident. He said the fire caused extensive damage to the automatic furnace between 16:00 and 17:30 hours yesterday.

"I can only confirm that there was a blazing inferno which gutted the furnace around 16:00 hours," Imasiku said in an interview in Mufulira yesterday.

Imasiku said that the damage would definitely affect the production of copper cathodes.

Police in Mufulira confirmed the incident but declined to give details.

Some ZCCM fire fighters talked to at the scene said it took them more than one and half hours to put out the fire. They had to call in for a reinforcement of more fire engines from Kitwe's Nkana Division.

Some smelter staff talked to expressed concern and worry.

"If the damage is very extensive it is a big blow to the mining conglomerate and it would cost them dearly to resume the normal copper cathodes production," a smelter staff member who declined to be named said in an interview in Mufulira yesterday. "This automatic furnace is very expensive to maintain. The company spends millions of kwacha to have it overhauled and they have to hire experts from South Africa."

Another ZCCM senior staff member at the gutted smelter said this would greatly hamper copper production in Zambia because the other smelter at Nkana division was small and ineffective.

Imasiku declined to comment on whether or not any lives had been lost and referred all enquiries to ZCCM spokesman Francis Musonda.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

36 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Olympics Nigeria Goes for the Elusive Gold In Atlanta


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Jaiyeola Ajasa


LENGTH: 2680 words


 

Lagos - The fireworks will climb to the sky and spit beautiful colours to brighten up the night. The southern metropolis of Atlanta will play host to 197 nations. Ten thousand athletes from all over the world will gather for the Centennial Olympic Games. Mankinds' greatest sporting event will once again command the attention of the whole world.

There will be tears for victory, tears for defeat and tears for participating - the ultimate Olympic prize. The Nigerian athletes and officials that were expected to fly out to Atlanta last weekend will join their counterparts from all over the world. For the 87 athletes that will be adorning the nation's green-white-green colours, the daunting task will be to re-launch the country's 44-year campaign for the Olympic gold. Since the country's first outing at the Helsinki Games in Finland, the lovely yellow medal that has made heroes out of many has proved elusive.

Going by preparations for this year's Olympics, which have been haphazard to say the least, the country's contingent to Atlanta needs luck if it is to equal the Barcelona Games record. In Spain in 1992, the country recorded its best ever Olympics outing. Although the gold gates were again shut, the contingent returned from the games with three silver and a bronze medal. Events leading up to the country's participation in the Atlanta do not give hope for the kind of impressive outing needed to strike gold. 

In athletics, which is the prime sport of the Olympic Games, the athletes that will be representing the nation will carry a heavier burden as the country's main hope for the elusive gold. The 100 metres dash will see Nigeria's best Davidson Ezinwa lining up against athletes like Frankie "the flash" Fredricks, who has been in top form lately, running a world best time of 9.86 secs in Laussane, Switzerland.

Others that will compete against Ezinwa are Olympic defending champion Linford Christie, whose time of 10.04 secs during the British trials puts him in contention for the gold. World champion Donovan Bailey, who last week defeated Christie in Nice, France, winning with a time of 10.17 secs is another gold medal prospect. The Canadian, however, has a personal best time of 9.93 secs. Also to give Ezinwa stiff competition are world record holder Dennis Mitchell and his American counterpart Leroy Burell and another Canadian, Bruno Surin.

Against these top competitors, only an incurable optimist will tip Ezinwa for a medal. Ezinwa's best time was the Nigeria Mobil trial performance of 9.89 secs. via the archaic hand timing device. Other Nigerians that will compete in the 100 metres dash are Olapade Adeniken, Osmond Ezinwa, Deji Aliu and home based new discovery, Seun Ogunkoya. Going by current form and desperation for glamour, they may end up as also rans. Only Davidson Ezinwa has a good chance of making it to the finals where it could be anybody's race but his own.

In the women's event, Mary Onyali, who told the nation to expect her best, may find her best not good enough for gold when the gun goes off. The African track queen will find the hot Atlanta climate too hot for comfort when she takes on Gail Devers and Gwen Torrence, both of the United States, Marlene Ottey of Jamaica and Irina Privaloua of the Russian Republic.

The other Nigerian sprinters in the dash event will be lucky should they make it to the last eight in the world. Chioma Ajunwa, who will be competing in her first ever Olympic Games and who finished sixth behind Onyali's fifth position at the Laussane grand prix, will power fast but not fast enough to mount the medal rostrum after the tape must have been breasted. Same goes for Charity Opara-Thompson and Beatrice Utondu.

Tony Urhobo, athletes coach, told Theweek that should either Onyali or Ajunwa get to the finals, the 100 metres could be anybody's race. Urhobo, based on his assessment, will go down as an optimist because there will be no stopping the stiff competition between Ottey, Privalova, Torrence and Devers for the race to pick the gold, silver and bronze medals at stake. All Onyali, Ajunwa, Utondu and Opara-Thompson may do is pick up the numbers.

Same will be the case in the men's 200 metres. This race will attract world attention but the zoom lens will not be focussed on Olapade Adeniken, Deji Aliu and Francis Chikwelu. Never a good runner to place a bet on, Adeniken is the one likely to make it to the last eight. The others will likely watch from the stands as Fredricks takes on America's Michael Johnson. Onyali will, like Adeniken, lead Calista Uba and Utondu to a 200 metres female event where they will savour the joy of participating.

Even without being told, Sunday Bada knows that he will need more than legs to beat Johnson, who many expect to pick up the gold in the 400 metres event baring unforeseen circumstances. Bada, who has had a fairly good year, should be able to do well and get to the finals where he can then be sure of picking a medal should his legs combine effectively with his heart.

Nigeria's best chance in the athletics individual event lies in the 400 metres women event. Here, Falilat Ogunkoya, making a return after a lay-off that saw her giving birth to a son, stands a good medal chance. In the prestigious Laussane meet she came second behind lanky French runner Marie Joyce-Perec, the world record holder in the event. Twice they have met before the games in recent times and twice the French woman had dusted Ogunkoya. The Nigerian has expressed delight that she is putting the pressure on Joyce-Perec. "My confidence is building because I know she knows I am coming. The nation should expect the very best from me," Says Ogunkoya. Fatima Yusuff, who came third at the Mobil Olympic trials, will be ruled out at the peril of other competitors. The African record holder has a habit of coming from the dead to record impressive performance. She also has the habit of disappointing when the stakes are high. Olabisi Afolabi, who as at last week was still stuck in Italy, will also put in her best in this event when she eventually makes the trip to Atlanta.

In the estimation of many respected analysts, the nation with the good baton exchange should garner medals in the relay events. Ayo Ositelu, a veteran of many Olympics and a revered newspaper sports columnist, believes that the Nigerian female 4 x 400 metres relay stands a good chance to win the country her first gold medal. His view is shared by Urhobo, who give the sub - 50 secs recently run by three of the athletes as a good reason for the team to strike gold. The same goes for the female 4 x 100 metres although Onyali and Ajunwa are the only Nigerian women to have run legal sub - 11 secs. At the Bacelona Olympics, Onyali led Faith Idehen, Utondu and Opara-Thompson to capitalise on a faulty baton exchange by the Jamaican girls to win an unprecedented bronze medal.

When the shout "seconds out" rings out at the Georgia Institute of Technology, Nigeria will present four pugilist to trade punches for glory in the square ropes. It was boxing that produced Nigeria's first olympic medal - a bronze medal won at the Tokyo Games in 1964 by Nojeem Maiyegun. Again in 1972, it was boxing that put Nigeria on the medals table when Isaac Ikhuoria won another bronze at the Munich Games. The sport proved its special place in the country's Olympic Games history when Peter Konyegwachie punched his way to a silver medal performance after a controversial loss to Meldrick Taylor of the United States in the Los Angeles game. Two silver medals it was that went to the boxing team via a stupendous performance by Richard Igbinegbu and David Izonretei after good preparations by the late Brai Ayonote and his team for the last games.

But in Atlanta, shoddy performance and the politics that have plagued the sport's local government body will rob the country of medals in a sport that has given her the most memorable moments at the Olympics. Not lacking in quality boxers, the country qualified for six out of the 77 slots allotted Africa at the games, although she could have clinched 12. Super heavyweight, Duncan Dokiwari, sole gold medalist at the All-Africa Games in Harare last September, and Albert Eromosele, the light middleweight who emerged African champions at the continental championship in Tunis in March, lead other pugilists.

On the chances of the boxing team, Jerry Okorodudu, who got to the quarter final stage during the Los Angeles Olympics, does not see much to expect. He highlighted the lackadaisical approach of the sports ministry to settle the rift in the Nigerian Amateur Boxing Association, the quality of coaches as well as a strong opposition, as stumbling blocks to any medal hope in boxing.

"You learn boxing by boxing, not by training," he said, citing the case in the Nigerian boxing camp before the boxers left for the United States. "When you spar with the same partner everyday, it gets monotonous and you don't learn anything new." Before the Barcelona Olympics, boxers that took part in the games participated in the European qualifier in Halle, Germany in March 1992.

The next month Ayonote took them to Bangkok, where they traded punches at the 18th edition of King's Cup in Thailand. Later in May they took part in the international Berlin Boxing championship. They did not fail to plan and they succeeded. For the Los Angeles Games where the Nigerian pugilists were robbed but still won a silver medal, Odorodudu said they had international competition almost every month enroute the games.

For Dokiwari, Eromosele, Barnabas Imudia and Kehinde Aweda, only a miracle will see them beating the computer scoring device to get to the medal range. Already, Dokiwari and Eromosele have their concentration divided as they have signed on with the Ken Norton boxing camp in the United States to pursue a professional career at the end of the olympics. Twenty three year-old Dokiwari, who has won the Eagle twice consecutively, remains the country's best medal potential.

By African standards, the table squad that will be storming Atlanta will be an all stars parade. Bosed Kaffo, Funke Oshonaike and Kehinde Okenla have all won African titles many times. Sule Olaleye, Segun Toriola, Hakeem Hassan and Kazeem Nosir are the men's team Africa's torch-bearers. Table Tennis coach Olanrewaju Babatunde told Theweek on the teams' return to Lagos after the training camp in Ilorin that his players "are determined to surprise many people." He said that his team, which only began serious training last May for the Atlanta games, would do away with the impression of not rising up to the challenge during the meets outside Africa.

But the chairman of the Nigerian Table Tennis Association was more realistic in his expectation from the Olympics. According to him: "Those who succeed in the sports do not organise sports the way we do in Nigeria. You need long term vision and planning to succeed." He added that the sport has gone scientific where players need very good knock-up hall, bats, balls and other facilities. "Our players do not get good ranking at international level because they lack exposure and don't compete internationally." he pointed out.

When the table tennis event begins at the 71,000-seat Georgia Dome, there will be no time for excuses as the Chinese and the Swedish teams, together with other competing countries, will not welcome any. In the weightlifting event in which the country is yet to win a medal, Nigeria will be presented by Moji Oluwa and Innocent Ukpong who have reputations for pulling surprises. Both weight lifters have been out in the United States undergoing training for close to two months but it remains to be seen whether they will surpass the fourth placing of Ojadi Aduche during the Barcelona Games.

Fond Olympic memories will be made from these and many actions that will engage the attention of the world from July 19 to August 4. Many would try to see if Johnson will set the record of being the first man to win the 200 metres and 400 metres events at the same Olympics. To achieve the record and put his name in the record books, the race schedule has been changed to aid his run for immortality.

But 28-year old Fredricks, whose name is bigger than his country Namibia, could spoil Johnson's fun. In the pre-Olympic meet, the Namibian became the first athlete to beat the world champion when he made 19.82 secs in cold, wet and windy condition. The new Commonwealth record was enough to send jitters down the spine of Johnson, who knows that going into the ultimate challenge, Fredricks has a mental edge.

In Atlanta it could even be worse for Johnson, as the harsh weather condition could make him a victim of the heat of Georgia. He will feel the effects of the four grueling 400 metres race and will be running his fourth 200 metres in a space of 30 hours by the time he gets to the finals. Against Fredricks and Mike Marsh, even the slightest hint of dehydration could spell disaster.

For Fredricks this could turn out to be his year, all things being equal. He seems to have found his own supply of kryptonite and could make Africa proud. In Lausanne he ran a stunning 9.86 secs into a headwind, only 100th of a second off Burrel's world record. The week before, the Namibian had run 9.86 secs during a chilly night in Helsinki. This brilliant performance came after a brilliant inndoor season in which he broke the 100 and 200 metres world records. His form this year has been exceptional.

Fredricks has moved out of the shadows of the supporting cast to that of a major player. In the Los Angeles Games, Carl Lewis was the King. At Bacelona, Britain's Christie stole the show. At Atlanta, the name that might be on everybody's lip at the end of the whole show could be Africa's own Fredricks and not home boy Johnson. Olympics moments are made of feats like this.

Cover date: July 22


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria Fraud Uncovered in Enugu State


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Louis Onyia


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Lagos - If Mike Torey, military administrator of Enugu State, lays claim to clairvoyance in this particular matter, he would be justified. When he inaugurated a 10-member task force February 29, his conviction was that a good percentatge of the state's internally generated revenue does not enter government treasury but is diverted by some fraudulent government officials.

Torey's fear was confirmed May 8, when the task force headed by Steve Odutayo, an army major, completed its assignment and discovered that true to Torey's fear, 26 sub-tresurers and revenue collectors in the state defrauded the Enugu State government of the sum of N32,699,722.74 between January 1, 1994 and the end of May last year. The task force also found that a total of N69,104,086 is being owed the state by 10 government organisations and institutions as money deducted from their staff as Pay-As-You-Earn. 

Alleged to be deeply involved in the fraud is C.I.J. Afeli, sub-treasurer in the main sub-treasury, Enugu, who the task force recommended should pay N14,078,656.63. According to the report of the task force, Afeli appeared before it for about five times to reconcile his accounts. In the end, he submitted three different details of accounts and each of the three submissions contradicted the other.

In the event, the task force had to rely on the paper money register submitted by the sub-treasurer in the headquarters of the Ministry of Finance. The task force said that it could not obtain from A feli a complete bank statement covering the period, hence his statement could not be used to get his total credits and debits. However, the task force said that it was able to pick his opening and closing balances. Based on what it called the unreliability of the data submitted by Afeli, the task force carried out a "thorough scrutingy of his account" and arrived at its conclusions. The task force noted that out of a total revenue of N63,583,503.94 found to have been collected by Afeli, what he could account for was N49,504,847,31, leaving N14,078,656.63 unaccounted for.

In the course of its assignment, the task force went through cheque stubs of the sub-treasurer and discovered that three cheque numbers; 673619B, 673621B and 673630B amounting to N3,470,000, were irregularly drawn from the sub-treasurer's account between November 1994 and April 13 last year. The task force also discovered that payments were made to organisations and individuals directly from the revenue account by Afeli against financial instructions.

The task force noted that N28,103,881,02 was involved in the irregular payments, out of which N28,041,742,20 was alleged to have been used for payment of salaries. The difference of N62,138,82 was found to have been paid to individuals and organisations. The report also showed that the sub-treasurer drew five cheques amounting to N3,979,000 in favour of himself. The purpose of drawing the cheques could not be investigated, for, according to the report, "when the sub-treasurer was to be queried on this, he collasped on the floor of the House of Assembly, Enugu, venue of the task force's sitting and could not show up again till the report was finally compiled."

Other irregularities discovered by the task force includes the activities of C.O. Onwe, sub-treasurer for ikwo in Ikwo Local Government Area.

Onwe appeared before the task force last April 11, t0 reconcile his own accounts for the period between January 1, 1994 and May 31, 1995. During his submission, it was discovered that he operated three accounts: Development levy account number 9372, revenue account number 9373 and payment account number 5035, all in the Africa Continental Bank, Ikwo branch. Amount brought forward in 1994 from account number 9372 and 9373 and collections made stood at N1,744,808,01.

From this amount, the sub-treasurer claimed that he remitted to the accountant-general's office N724,262,27, bounced cheques amounted to N25,463,75, and ban charges of N10,552,16. The task force rejected this account by Onwe because, according to it, the N724,268,27 claimed to have been remitted by the sub-treasurer to the accountant-general's office was higher than what the AG's office and the paper money register confirmed. While the AG's office acknowledged total remittance of N677,614,91, the paper money register confirmed N700,402,27. Further, the task force said it rejected Onwe's claim because "he has not got enough facts to support his claims." It however, accepted the paper money figure of N700,402,27 because "it is the authentic document in which all remittances to the AG's office and government should pass through."

The task force also rejected the claim by Onwe that he received bounced cheques amounting to N25,463,75 for lack of evidence in support of the claim. After examining Onwe's account as submitted to the task force, it was discovered that he had to account for N1,033,570,55. When asked to do so, he allegedly was unable to do so. He admitted that he instructed the bank to transfer the sum of N591,500 from his revenue account into his payment account. He further said that he spent the balance of the sum on private matters. Like what? Onwe revealed that he used the said amount to build a private house, which he was ready to sell off to refund the money. On May 2, he submitted the particulars of the house, including the Deed of Assignment, Power of Attorney, land rent, receipt, notice of assessment, and approval of building plan to the task force.

Other sub-treasurers in some other local government areas are said to be withholding between N3,700,00 and N1,033,570,55 each which should have been lodged in the state government's account.

Cover date: July 22

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria More Signs of Discontent in Oil-Rich Rivers State


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Wisdom Dike.


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lagos - The scanty audience that attended the public sitting of the National Reconciliation Committee in Port Harcourt, Rivers State, July 2, was enough signal to Alex Akinyele, a former Information and Culture Minister and Chairman of the committee, that all would not be well that day. The first hint of trouble came when eight weight lifters of the Rivers State Sports Council distracted the session with noise while working out in the adjoining room at the Diette Spiff Sports Complex, venue of the committee's sitting. Not even the personal intervention of the traditional rulers, secretary of the Rivers State government and the police stopped the weight lifters.

Instead of reducing their noise, the sports men flared up "Do you think we are fighting here?" asked one of them. "Go and do your business over there. Don't disturb us. Everyday meeting, meeting, meeting and yet nothing works." It took the leader of the weight lifters more than ten minutes to calm down his men. A flustered Akinyele recoiled into his seat, waiting for a cue from Sampson Agbaru, secretary to the state government. 

After Akinyele's introductory address which outlined the committee's mission in the state, Robinson O. Robinson, a frontline ruler threw a bombshell. "Who are you reconciling now? he asked the committee. Robinson told the committee that as far as he was concerned, nobody was quarreling that that required national reconciliation. The NARECON delegation was taken aback but the audience got the traditional ruler's message.

Chukumela Nnam Obi, Oba of Ogoniland and immediate past chairman of the Rivers State Council of Chiefs, elaborated the issues at stake. He told the committee that the issues necessitating national reconciliation are numerous and should be addressed in the interest of the citizenry. "The June 12 issue is still unresolved; the crisis in education needs urgent attention and the problem of the neglected oil communities need to be addressed," he said. The Oba asserted that the issue of state creation which has affected the growth of Rivers State is a national issue, adding that only the splitting of Rivers could end the communal hostilities in the state. The elated audience responded with applause.

Next to take the floor was Harold Dappa-Biriye, the octogenarian statesman and community rights activist. Backed up with a memorandum and photographs, Dappa-Biriye presented an 11-point address aptly tagged "Issues for National Discussion and Reconciliation."

Worried by government's disregard for community rights, Dappa-Biriye stressed that the restiveness in the oil producing communities is a direct result of neglect and underdevelopmemt. According to him, laws guiding the prospecting of natural resources and minerals should be uniform and should accord respect for community rights. He recalled that in 1980 the Oyo State government signed a law on the Igbeti Marble which accorded the host community its right thus: Igbeti community 15 per cent, local government 10 per cent, prospecting company 25 per cent, federal government 20 per cent and the state government 30 per cent.

Dappa-Biriye warned that the government and the prospecting companies must be ready to accord the host communities 30 per cent of the proceeds as stated if the Liquified Natural Gas Project is to take off. Regretting the disrespect shown to traditional rulers and the civil society by the military, the elder statesman lambasted the military for disregarding the ethics of democracy.

Cyrus Nunieh, a former senator and lawyer from Ogoni, told the NARECON team that the "Ogoni have made enough sacrifices for the survival of the nation. The Ogoni issue must be looked into if genuine peace and progress must go on in the state. There is uneasy calm in Ogoni." Other speakers at the forum drew the attention of the committee to the Ogoni Bill of Rights (the working document of the Ogoni people), the human and environmental degradation in the Niger Delta and the human rights situation in the country.

The committee visted Ogoniland and promised to send another team to tour some areas in the state to verify claims of neglect and underdevelopment by the people.

Cover date: July 22


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

39 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria End of the Sultan's Honeymoon With Abacha?


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Emmanuel Ado


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lagos - The honeymoon between Muhammadu Maccido, the Sultan of Sokoto and the government of Sani Abacha may have come to an abrupt end. The reason, according to sources, is that the government is not impressed by Maccido's speech at his installation and presentation of staff of office last month. The sultan had in his speech urged the government to address the unprecedented suffering of Nigerians, just as he described the democratization programme of the government as "not a real thing to Nigeria." 

Before now, the government had frowned at the Sultan's comments on the annulled June 12, 1993 presidential election, which he once described as just another injustice, like the overthrow of Shehu Shagari government by the military in 1983. According to government's sources, Maccido's comment on the voided presidential election calls into questions government's reason for deposing Ibrahim Dasuki, who "hijacked" the sultanate from Maccido in 1988, since the June 12 annulment and other injustices have not been redressed.

Already, rumours believed to have been started by government agents are now making the rounds, alleging that the installation and presentation of staff of office to Maccido was marred because the sultan allegedly failed to make available to the organising committee, the full amount of money the federal government donated towards the installation ceremony. Sidi Mamman Asarakawa, vice-chairman of the finance committee, has reportedly been asked to explain how the money was disbursed.

At Maccido's installation, Ibrahim Sulu Gambari, the emir of Ilorin, had complained bitterly about the accommodation that was provided for him. Umaru Shinkafi, ex-presidential aspirant, had to use his powerful connections to secure a more dignifying accommodation for Gambari. But the emir of Gombe was not so lucky. He passed the night at an uncompleted guest house belonging to a serving military administrator.

The Sokoto State government is yet to release the report of the panel that probed the installation ceremony. As the report is being awaited, Maccido is said to be feeling uncomfortable that the government which used him to settle its problem with Dasuki, is abandoning him too soon.

Theweek learnt that government's attitude has re-enforced Maccido's determination to see Dasuki and to get the government to allow Dasuki to move to any place of his choice. Since Dasuki's removal, no member of his family has been allowed access to him. Sources told Theweek that when Maccido recently visited Abacha, one of the issues they discussed was the possibility of allowing Dasuki's family to see him, a postition that Shehu Malami, Dasuki's arch rival and Nigeria's High Commissioner to South Africa, and Mustapha Jokolo, emir of Gwandu, do not share. Jokolo, for one, has been most caustic in his public remarks on the former sultan. Sources said that he has not forgiven Dasuki for influencing his removal as the chairman of Gamji Bank.

Unsure of government's continued goodwill, Maccido is said to be redesigning the palace to suit his meagre resources. He is reportedly removing conveniences which would require enormous financial resources to maintain. According to sources, the sultan needs more than N6 million monthly to run the palace. Government's alleged unwillingness to provide the needed resources is said to have informed Maccido's pragmatic decision to reduce his expenses to the barest minimum. How long his apparently strained relationship with the Abacha regime would last remains to be seen.

Cover date: July 22


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


United States and Africa Officials Describe U.S. Policy For Women in Africa


BYLINE: Africa News Service July 15, 1996


LENGTH: 4987 words


 

Washington DC - Following are the prepared statements by Prudence Bushnell, deputy assistant secretary of State for African Affairs, and by Carol Peasley, senior deputy assistant administrator for Africa of the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID). They appeared before the Senate African Affairs Subcommittee on July 11 chaired by Kansas Republican Senator Nancy Kassebaum.

Bushnell testimony --
Madam Chairman, I am delighted to be here with you today to discuss women in Africa. I thank you for bringing attention to the issue of African women by holding this hearing and for your invitation to testify. Tomorrow I relinquish my responsibilities within the Bureau of African Affairs and I can think of no better way to spend my last full day as Deputy Assistant Secretary. In the three years I have served in African Affairs, it has become clear to me that the success of U.S. policy objectives in Africa rests, in part, on helping African women enhance their status in society and their participation in public life:

* We cannot promote democracy and respect for human rights without taking into account the role and treatment of women, who make up over 50 percent of the population of Africa. 

* In our efforts to prevent or resolve conflict, we must recognize that women and children are the primary victims of conflict in Africa; they are also the primary beneficiaries of humanitarian assistance and comprise the largest percentage of the refugee population. However, women also have a critical role to play in conflict resolution.

* The role and contributions of women to Africa's sustainable economic development are profound. In the agricultural sectors and the informal economy they are preeminent actors. Efforts to protect the environment, manage population growth and develop the continent's economic future must take women into account.

If we are beginning to view African women as critical partners we also recognize that they are not yet full partners in many aspects of their own societies. Women in Africa have made progress in some areas, but much still needs to be addressed.

As the Deputy Assistant Secretary responsible for global issues, I have made a concerted effort to put women on our policy agenda. I have made it a point to spend time with African women on my many visits to the sub-Saharan continent; I attended the Africa Preparatory Conference for the Beijing Women's Conference and have listened to African reactions to the Conference. To encourage follow up attention to the Beijing Action Plan, I asked our ambassadors to speak to the delegations and consider what we may have to offer to help countries implement their action plan. In Washington, the Africa Bureau is putting greater emphasis on women's human rights and participation in democratization when we review small program proposals under the 116E funding mechanism; we are looking for opportunities to speak out about African women in public fora and we are coordinating our strategies with other parts of government.

Although I did not attend the Beijing Conference myself, I think it helped to advance African women's interests and show the world what African women have to offer. African delegations left a strong and positive impression because of their unity of purpose and their ability to articulate and negotiate. Senegal, which led the Africa group, demonstrated strong leadership in uniting diverse delegations into a cohesive whole; the Ugandans were acknowledged as leaders in the developing world in efforts to empower women, youth and the handicapped; and the Ghanaians were singled out for making meaningful improvements towards bettering the status and welfare of women.

The African women to whom I have spoken since the Conference were invigorated by the sense of solidarity and the enormous array of ideas they encountered in Beijing. Learning that others around the world are struggling with many of the same issues they confront provided them a sense of partnership to a larger effort. Many were determined to maintain the networks they had formed -- particularly in southern Africa. Others felt that the contact between their government and NGO delegations contributed to a better understanding and appreciation of one another.

When one looks across the political landscape of sub-Saharan Africa, one sees an increase in the number of women leaders, but the total is still modest. The most senior ranking woman in sub-Saharan Africa is the Vice President of Uganda, who is herself committed to advancing the issues of women and girls. In Sao Tome and Principe, the country's first woman candidate for President garnered 14 percent of the vote on the first round to become king-maker for the July 21 second-round vote. In Kenya, women announced plans to form a political party led by women that would be "home" to all disadvantaged groups. In Uganda, 39 seats in a parliament of 276 members have been set aside for women. Overall, however, only 9.8 percent of the members of lower houses of Parliament in sub-Saharan African countries are women per data from the African-American Institute and only about 80 Cabinet-level positions of more than 900 are held by women.

Some of the constraints to greater political participation by women include:

* Too little money to help finance strong NGOs or to campaign.

* Lack of political knowledge, including knowledge of their basic civic rights and responsibilities.

* Lack of skills and information necessary to compete with men as equals in the political arena.

* Inhibiting societal attitudes about women's roles.

Africa's courageous women political leaders also face other problems which we do not confront here. Rwandan Prime Minister Agathe Uilingimana, who worked to implement that country's peace agreement, was among the first victims of the 1994 genocide. In Liberia, one of the women with whom you met during your January visit, Madam Chairman, was kidnapped and threatened, her house looted after criticizing publicly one of the warlords. In Nigeria, a courageous woman journalist is isolated and imprisoned for criticizing the regime. These women spoke out publicly. Meanwhile, countless thousands of others work quietly behind the scenes to form associations and groups to push for recognition of the basic human rights which we too often take for granted here.

More and more NGOs are working in individual countries on women's political participation, often with the help of USG funding provided through USAID. My colleague, Deputy Assistant Administrator for African Affairs Carol Peasley, can give you more specifics on USAID programs.

When I meet with African women I am often struck by the challenges and dreams they hold in common with American women. African women active in politics and the modern economy have talked to me about the subtle and overt forms of discrimination they face, much of it familiar to me. They talk about the delicate behavior necessary to confront hostility without becoming "strident." They discuss the pros and cons of affirmative action and they voice concern about a backlash from those who feel threatened by women's advances -- this includes other women.

Women in rural areas also hold things in common with us. One encounter I had with Tuareg women in Niger brought this home to me. Our Ambassador arranged a trip to the north, where the wife of the local prefect (herself a former Minister of Development) organized a meeting with women from three local cooperatives. As we sat in the shade of one of the few concrete buildings in the area, I was very aware of the chasm between our two worlds. Culture, language, education, religion and race divided us. My questions and remarks had to be translated from French into both Hausa and Tuareg. Yet, when I asked them what dreams they had for their daughters, they replied that they wanted their daughters to be self-sufficient -- to have some education and to learn a trade. I responded that many of us in the United States hold the same dream for our daughters.

There is much Africans must do if they are to realize their dreams for their daughters. While the increase and visibility of educated and professional women is notable, their numbers are still woefully small and the divide between them and the majority of uneducated, rural women stunningly large. In the same conversation I had with Tuareg women they talked about why many did not send their daughters to be educated -- fear of ridicule from their neighbors and concern that education would "spoil" their daughters as prospective wives. Traditional customs, practices and laws often form tremendous obstacles to women's advancement.

Following the Beijing Women's Conference, our embassies asked host country delegations which aspects of the Platform for Action were most critical to their country. The themes that emerged focused on women's and girls' education; eliminating domestic violence; increasing women's participation in politics; improving access to credit; and help in the health sector, issues which I believe will resonate with you, Madam Chairman, in your role as Chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee.

It is ironic that at the very time we find African women leaders articulating concrete needs we could help them address, we find ourselves constrained from doing so because of budget cuts! There is still much we can do. The USIA international visitor programs which bring African women political leaders to the U.S., such as a visit last year of members of the new South African parliament, remains an outstanding means of exposing African women to American democratic institutions. We can -- and do -- make reference to women in our policy speeches; our senior officials can highlight women's needs and accomplishments during visits to the continent. We can -- and do -- encourage other donors and officials of the international financial institutions to target women more directly. We can better coordinate initiatives on gender issues. But we also need resources. And I can think of no better investments than those targeted to the enhancement of the role and contributions of African women.

I want to end by noting your contributions to Africa, Senator Kassebaum, both as a role model and an advocate. Many African women have already been touched by your work and I thank you for your interest in this area.

ENDS

Peasley testimony --

Madam Chairwoman, I'm very pleased to be part of this important nearing and to have the opportunity to share ideas with you this afternoon. There are four key themes I would like to emphasize:

1) the important role that African women play and the disadvantages they labor under;

2) that African women are increasingly in a position to articulate their own needs and priorities;

3) that we in USAID are listening to them and following their leadership in the design and implementation of many different kinds of activities; and

4) I'd like to share some examples of successful USAID programs.

We know that African women have always played an extraordinarily important role on the continent. That role, however, is evolving rapidly.

We are all aware of the articulate and dynamic women from Africa who have captured media attention at recent international conferences on women and social issues. Working individually and together, these African women and their many sisters are also making progress at home through greater participation in politics and the economy and by enhancing their legal status.

Clearly, in recent years Africans and donors have increasingly recognized the importance of full participation of women to successful sustainable development strategies.

One key discernible trend that seems to be emerging from this is that more African girls are going to school, although on average they still represent only 43 percent of the primary school enrollment, and their share decreases as the level of schooling increases.

The gains in education and other positive developments are encouraging, but they are only a start. USAID intends to remain a major player in partnership with others to foster even greater improvements in the status of African women.

As I see it, we face four major constraints or challenges.

First, the inherent systemic biases against women throughout society need to be eliminated. These include discriminatory laws, customs and practices (in business, government services, the courts, classrooms, village councils and so on) that undercut efforts to improve the status of women. African advocates of gender equity give priority to this problem.

Second, more women need to participate at the policy and political levels, especially in parliaments. On average women constitute about 10 percent of members of parliament in Africa.

Third, we need to devise more effective strategies for encouraging fuller understanding and support of African men to gender equity, particularly men in leadership positions from the village to the presidency.

Fourth, poverty must be reduced. Lack of resources at the national, regional, local and household levels is a major impediment.

Meeting these challenges requires an intimate understanding of the various societies in Africa and the recognition that the path may be different from our own. The solutions must come from the Africans themselves. Given this, our approach emphasizes strengthening the capacity of African institutions (including NGOs, governments and parliaments) and investing as much as we can in economic growth, which is key to the sustainability of all our efforts in all sectors.

The Africa Bureau's strategy regarding women's empowerment

In view of these challenges and the strong African leadership that is emerging in this area, USAID and the Africa Bureau are more committed than ever to helping women realize their potential as leaders and as economic, social, and political forces for development.

This commitment starts from the top of Africa Bureau management. AFR/AA (Africa Bureau Assistant Administrator) John Hicks is a vocal advocate of gender-conscious development assistance and has provided strong leadership in this area. He challenges us at every level -- macro, sectoral and project and in dialogue with our partners -- to ensure that gender is a cross-cutting theme.

The Africa Bureau's Women in Development theme dates back to the mid-1970s, shortly after passage of the Percy Amendment. Our efforts were strengthened and sharpened with the inception of the Development Fund for Africa in 1987. The DFA provided clear guidance for the participation of and consultation with women on the design, monitoring and implementation of projects. I am proud to say that as a result, the Africa Bureau has become a trailblazer in USAID on gender-sensitive programming.

We have made important inroads, but there is potential to do so much more. And this potential is uniquely promising given the extensive nature of informal organizations and cooperation among women in Africa.

The Africa Bureau has long recognized that "women's projects" are not the answer. The overarching goal has been to integrate and mainstream gender issues throughout our development assistance programs and policy reform initiatives in Africa.

The reengineering process in the Agency is an excellent opportunity to expand our efforts because of the sharpened focus on participation and the customer.

For the most part, the systems that help ensure a gender focus in our programs in Africa are in place. We have established guidance incorporating gender into country program strategies and for monitoring the performance of our programs for gender inclusion. Gender disaggregation of data and reporting on gender-specific impact are consistently emphasized in our annual reporting documents on program performance.

I am pleased to report that our missions and Washington have responded well. For example, over the past year, missions in South Africa, Mali, Namibia, Ghana, Kenya and Tanzania have submitted country strategic plans that reflect the significant gender dimensions of the country programs. The missions early on seek out help in developing their strategies from the regional gender advisers located in Abidjan and Nairobi. Local women's groups are consulted extensively in the process. Washington reviews are characterized by broad participation throughout the Agency, including the Office of Women in Development. The bottom line is: the systems work, and they are internalized in our Bureau operations and culture.

Social, political and economic empowerment of African women

There is a direct connection between the series of U.N.-sponsored international conferences in Nairobi, Dakar, Copenhagen and Beijing and the emergence of African women and women's associations as powerful forces with clear roles in Africa's future.

The conference preparations and the conferences themselves have offered African women the opportunity to network, to develop skills and to legitimize themselves and their organizations in ways previously unknown.

There are other factors that have contributed significantly to the successes African women have achieved at these international fora. The political liberalization sweeping African countries since the beginning of the 1990s has meant that large numbers of women (and men) are, for the first time, able to organize and address issues of concern at the regional, national and pan-African levels.

Although recent achievements of African women and certainly their higher profile have arisen from new opportunities, strong connections with one another and the existence of powerful women leaders are nothing new in Africa. The crisscrossing web of women's associational life has long been a defining feature of many African societies. From mutual aid groups to civic associations dealing with schools and water access to traders' associations, these women's organizations set a standard for what can be done through initiative and broad participation, and they provide practical experience. The connections from the village to the newer, high-profile international organizations are not as distant as they might appear.

USAID sees its role now and into the future as one of fundamental support for the processes that are enabling African women to realize their existing potential. USAID will continue to engage a multi-level, multi-track approach in its efforts to empower African women and foster greater social, economic and political participation.

Activities at the national and international level are aimed at improving the skills of African women legislators, lawyers and advocates. The ultimate purpose of these programs is to build the capacity of influential leaders to create an enabling environment that fosters economic, social and political participation for all women.

Last year in Uganda, for example, all 52 women members of Uganda's Constituent Assembly attended a USAID-sponsored workshop on the "nuts and bolts" of effective legislation. And in Malawi, 100 women participated in a political empowerment workshop. These women have been key in the adoption of a new constitution that reflects women's issues and in the publishing of a standard guide and resource entitled Women and the Law in Malawi.

Further examples of these activities are discussed in reprints from the USAID-funded African Voices newsletter. Madam Chairwoman, I request that these newsletter articles be made a part of the record for this hearing.

At another level, USAID encourages and promotes significant women's participation in all of our sectoral development programs.

Up to two-thirds of our micro-enterprise loan recipients are women.

Women are central to our activities in the health sector; with obviously strong roles to play in child survival, nutrition, family planning and HIV/AIDS prevention. Surveys clearly demonstrate the strong desire of many women to have the ability to space, or limit the number of children they have. There is growing demand by women for family planning services. Also, with the high level of HIV prevalence in many countries (e.g., some 30 percent of urban women visiting ante-natal clinics in the most heavily affected countries are testing HIV positive), African women are leading the charge to improve HIV/AIDS education and control programs.

I think that because of the central role women play in Africa's development, our activities that fully incorporate gender concerns show a unique tendency to generate positive multiplier effects and program synergies. An interesting example comes from Namibia, where an association of women traders or hawkers had been working with our program to help Namibian NGOs strengthen their institutional capacity. On their own the women decided that what they really needed to do was to use their institutional strength to help fight HIV/AIDS in the rural areas where they had come from and where many of their future customers would come from. Knowing well what types of practices and behaviors needed changing, the women developed their own educational and informational program and used a grant from the USAID activity to take their campaign throughout rural Namibia.

It is now well established that an educated women is likely to have a higher income as well as a healthier and smaller family. Efforts to improve and promote girls' schooling are fundamental to our successful approach to basic education. In our eight major basic education programs in Guinea, Mali, Ghana, Benin, Ethiopia, Uganda, Malawi and Namibia, USAID and its partners are working to enact reforms that remove barriers at the national level while simultaneously working directly with communities to give them more say in dealing with the constraints that have kept girls out of school in the past.

USAID's concentration on girls' education is beginning to pay dividends. In Malawi, for example, USAID pilot tested a Social Mobilization Campaign to elicit the support and participation of parents, teachers and communities to educate girls. The results of the pilot were outstanding. There was a marked increase in girls' enrollment in the 1995/96 school year, the drop-out rate for girls was lower than for boys (for the first time ever), and of the 239 pupils in that district selected for secondary school, 106 were girls. The participatory approach is now active in 72 villages and communities around Malawi and further expansion will take place.

The Malawi model is indicative of our approach to girls' education. Our programs focus on what is needed to improve access and quality for girls. Girls' needs are additive to the needs of boys given the traditional bias against girls.

Education is the key to the future for African women, but there is still much more we can do to encourage and help African women deal with the problems they face today. Because of our field presence, USAID officers have numerous opportunities to hear directly from African women. A recurring theme is the desire for greater economic participation and security, particularly in agriculture, the predominant occupation of most women in Africa and where many of them see the greatest hope for improvements.

We have many successes in promoting women's opportunities in agriculture. In Malawi, women now have access to the more lucrative smallholder burley market. And in Francophone West Africa, USAID support for the women delegates working on the formulation of the Charter of Internal Rules for the CILSS-sponsored Rural Communities' Platform on Grassroots Participation and Policy Dialogue led to the inclusion of significant gender-conscious language and the stipulation that one of the two national delegates to serve on the Regional Council will be a woman. And in Kenya, agricultural policy reforms have resulted in increased farmer income, while simultaneously lowering food prices for the urban poor, most of whom are women.

Many individual women benefit from USAID programs to promote non-traditional exports. In Uganda, rates of return for rural labor have increased substantially through participation in the non-traditional agricultural program. For example, mushroom growers, the majority of whom are women, now earn an annual net rate of return of $1,500 per growing unit, which means more resources for families to meet their school fees, medical care and food needs. Likewise, vanilla producers, 75% of whom are women, have seen incomes rise over 25%.

And in Ghana, female-owned and -managed producer export firms increased by 31 percent. The first Global Women Entrepreneurs Trade Fair and Investment Forum will be held in Ghana this summer.

These programs are very encouraging and we'd like to do more if the resources were available. Working with African women is a true joy and very rewarding. I'm sure you will hear that message repeated by others addressing you today. I'd like to thank you again for providing the opportunity to discuss this extremely important topic. I know that all of us in the Africa Bureau at USAID hold African women in the highest regard and given the positive changes of the past few years, we anticipate great things to come in the future.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa's Lay Centres Pledge Support For A Just Society


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Kampala - The Church in Africa should use its lay training centres to promote human rights and civil society on the African continent.

It should also use these centres to promote a just community of men and women as people created in God's image with equal responsibilities in His service.

These were some of the recommendations passed during a training seminar on leadership in lay training, held here from June 6 to 25. 

The course was organized by the Nairobi-based Association of Christian Lay Centres in Africa (ACLCA), a continental fellowship of Christian lay centres, academies and movements of social concern.

The ACLCA training workshop brought together 30 participants from Egypt, Kenya, Madagascar, Tanzania and Uganda. They came from various centres in the Eastern and Northern Africa sub-region. Also present were representative of the ACLCA Youth Network from Ghana, Uganda, Malawi and South Africa.

Deliberations were based on the theme, Leadership Training for Building a Just Community.

In an interview with APS, ACLCA Executive Secretary Rev. Jonah Katoneene also disclosed that the organization will celebrate its silver jubilee from October 6 to 13 in Harare, Zimbabwe, under the theme Celebrating in Hope: Restoring Just Relationships.

The course participants condemned corruption and tribalism, saying the practices affected several countries in Africa.

"We commit ourselves to be agents of creating a just and ecumenical community, where people accept and respect each other as members of the human community regardless of their differences in tribe, race, culture and traditions," a communique released at the end of the course stated.

In the ACLCA statement, course participants committed themselves to work for justice, peace and reconciliation and "in particular we commit our centres to be places of healing and reconciliation."

The communique also urged churches in Africa to educate their members and called on African governments to pressurize for the cancellation of Africa's external debt, estimated at more than $300 billion.

This pressure should not be left to the churches alone, urged the ACLCA workshop which also called on the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the United Nations to add their voices and pressurize for the cancellation of Africa's debt.

Further on economic justice, course participants promised that they will particularly address themselves to the evils caused by the debt crisis in Africa, saying they do not believe that Africa is indebted to the West.

"Five hundred years of exploitation of the human resources (slave trade) and the mineral resources of our continent, has made the West rich. The exploitation has continued through other forms of domination such as the imposition of World Bank/International Monetary Fund (IMF) Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs) and debt servicing," noted the Kampala training workshop.

"We affirm that the debt has been over-paid. We demand for reparation in the name of justice and Christian love," participants stressed in their communique.

Established in 1970, the ACLCA, currently groups together more than 60 centres in 16 African countries and contact groups in another five countries on the continent.

The organization's objectives are to promote contacts and the development of a common purpose between lay training centres in Africa; to encourage common planning and deepen the church's responsibility in the world, and to stimulate the production of materials and information related to lay training among others responsibilities.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Niger Niger's Junta Leaders Claim Poll Victory Amid Confusion


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Niamey - Niger's military ruler General Ibrahim Bare Mainassara claimed an outright victory in the first round of the country's presidential election held on July 7 and 8.

An announcement by the National Election Commission (CNE) on July 10 said that Mainassara, who seized power in January, had won 1,262,308 (52.22 per cent) of the total vote, beating the man he overthrew, former president Mahamane Ousmane, said to have polled 477,431 votes (19.75 per cent).

They were followed by Mamadou Tandja of the National Movement for the Development Society (MNSD) - the country's main party - who polled 372,322 votes (15.65 per cent) and two other candidates, Mahamadou Issoufou and Moumouni Djermakoye Adamou, who garnered 183,826 (7.6 per cent) and 115,302 (4.77 per cent) votes, respectively. 

The results will be handed to the supreme court which has 15 days in which to endorse or invalidate the outcome under the country's new electoral code.

The election was marred by logistics problems and on July 8, the junta leader dissolved the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI) which had unsuccessfully pressed for more time to organise the poll and appointed another body, the CNE, to replace it.

The junta said CENI members had illegally given early results to political parties, thereby influencing the second day of voting.

Mainassara said the CENI had "manipulated" and "knowingly created a certain disorder."

On the night of July 8, telephone lines to the opposition candidates as well as those connecting the country to the outside world were cut off, shortly after police had used tear gas to disperse political party supporters who were preparing to stage demonstrations outside party headquarters.

The following day, the junta imposed a nationwide ban on demonstrations and public gatherings after threats from the country's Trade Union Federation (USTN) to launch an "unlimited general strike" unless the CENI was reinstated.

The abolition of the CENI, the suspension of international telephone lines and rumours of arrests, immediately heightened fears that Mainasassara was staging a second coup to stay in power, which the military strong man immediately denied.

"It is not a coup d'etat. I want to tell you the (electoral) process will not be interrupted," he said, pledging that "I will abide by the verdict of the ballot boxes."

Mainassara, who seized power on January 27 called the elections under international pressure to restore democracy and in the hope that it would legitimize his position as head of state and offer a viable alternative to traditional politicians.

In the month leading up to the poll, the commission repeatedly said it would not be ready in time but the junta twice rebuffed moves by CENI for a postponement.

All four challengers sought in vain an audience with Mainassara early last week to complain about the poll's poor organisation. They were also prevented from meeting international observers.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Rwanda Lashes Out At African Support For Boutros Ghali


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Yaounde - Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu strongly criticised a decision by African leaders to support Boutros Boutros-Ghali in his bid for a second mandate as United Nations Secretary-General.

Addressing a news conference here on July 10 at the end of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) summit, Bizimungu said that Rwanda, the only one of the 60 countries represented here at the OAU summit to openly express its non-support for Boutros-Ghali, believed that the outgoing UN Secretary-General did not deserve the post again because he had failed to perform to the expectations of Africa during his first five-year term.

Two other African states present at the summit, Ethiopia and Eritrea, are said to have voiced the opposition to Boutros-Ghali's second tenure of office .

But Bizimungu declared that "Rwanda has not supported Ghali because he has not delivered the goods to the expectations," and castigated the UN chief for his proposal to withdraw more than 2,000 UN troops from Rwanda at the onset of the killings in April 1994. 

The reduction of the UN presence in the central African state was a betrayal of the Rwandans who were massacred during the pull-out, he charged, declaring: "He has betrayed not only the people who were massacred, but he betrayed the African people."

Bizimungu said that while other African leaders had supported Boutros-Ghali in the spirit of African solidarity, solidarity had to go with accountability and an evaluation of Boutros-Ghali was negative.

Bizimungu was also of the opinion that it made sense to support another African who stood better chances of winning.

"I think Africa can find somebody else. I don't think we are short of people who can take up that position," he said, refusing to mention any possible candidates. Koffi Anan of Ghana is widely tipped to be a potential candidate for the top post.

Meanwhile, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose, who attended the summit to lobby for support from African countries present against Boutros Boutros-Ghali's candidature, told newsmen on July 10 that the US government "understand the support Boutros-Ghali has in Africa and it is entirely appropriate."

"But I don't think that the declaration is a firm ... and final endorsement" of the candidacy, Moose added.

On July 8, Boutros-Ghali defended his record, and pointed to a UN initiative launched in March to improve food security for Africans, diversify Africa's food production and facilitate access to world markets for African agricultural products.

The tongue-lashing came only five days after Rwandan ministers received sharp reactions from ministers from neighbouring Tanzania and Zaire when they refused to allow the OAU Council of Ministers meeting here to discuss their country's plight, arguing that it was a normal country that did not need any special attention.

Observers said the move triggered anger from ministers from the two countries, which are still hosting hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees who fled the 1994 genocide, where between 500,000 and one million people were said to have been slaughtered in the 1994 ethnic violence.

Rwanda's two neighbours argued that the situation could not be normal in Rwanda if so many of its people were still refugees, coupled with persistent reports of continuing ethnic massacres in the war-torn country.

It was only July 9, that the Rwandan state radio reported that at least 14 people, including a municipal leader, a prosecutor and a school principal, had been killed in two attacks in a north-western Kigali region.

Many other attacks, either by majority Hutu militants or in reprisal by the minority Tutsi-army, have continued in different parts of Rwanda, leading to hundreds of deaths this year alone.

Africa News


July, 1996


Somalia Bloody Battles Continue In War-Torn Mogadishu


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Mogadishu - Continued fighting between rival militias in the Somali capital, Mogadishu left at least 12 dead and 18 wounded overnight, witnesses said on July 10.

Hundreds of families could be seen fleeing the capital, and sporadic shooting was continuing throughout July 10 between forces of General Mohamed Farah Aideed and militiamen supporting north Mogadishu strongman Ali Mahdi Mohamed and those of Osman Hassan Ali "Atto".

The fighting was mostly around the south Mogadishu district of Medina, inhabited by Abgal clansmen loyal to Ali Mahdi, the self- styled Somali interim-president. 

The battle for Mogadishu has continued since April 4, with no peace negotiations in sight, and some of the shooting last week was across the "Green Line" which divides the capital -- the north controlled by Ali Mahdi and the south by General Aideed and Ali Atto.

Aideed and Ali Mahdi officials both claimed the capture of one battle-wagon during the overnight fighting.

On July 8, warring militias had been seen gearing up for a battle for overall control of the capital, with fighters from four separate factions taking up defensive positions.

Sporadic shooting had then continued at the "Green Line" dividing the city and in the south Mogadishu enclave of Medina, after three days of fighting which left at least 45 killed and around 100 wounded.

Four of Somalia's many faction leaders appeared to be shaping up for a fight over who is to control this shattered city -- General Aideed, who already commands much of south Mogadishu, Ali Mahdi, who controls the capital north of the "Green Line", Medina commander Musa Sudi Yalahow, who is allied with Ali Mahdi, and Ali "Atto", Aideed's former financier but now his bitter foe.

Aideed's forces pushed several kilometres into Medina in the earlier fighting, but witnesses said they had retreated by July 8.

Yalahow told reporters his men had captured one double-barrel anti- aircraft gun and two "technicals" -- pick up-trucks with heavy weapons mounted.

In north Mogadishu, meanwhile, Sheikh Ali Sheikh Mohamud, the powerful chairman of the Islamic court there, said sharia courts would be set up in any territory captured from Aideed.

Medina officials meanwhile said 43 per cent of their wounded were dying as a result of lack of medical supplies, adding that equipment promised by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and Somali Red Crescent Society had so far failed to materialize.

Somalia has been ruled by warlords since the overthrow of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre in 1991. UN troops pulled out in March last year after failing to bring peace to the Horn of Africa nation.

LANGUAGE: English
