Africa News


July, 1996


Sudan Sudanese Women Return From European Peace Mission


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Nairobi - A delegation of three women from the Sudanese Women Voice for Peace (SWVP) recently returned to Nairobi after a one-month tour of seven European countries namely France, Britain, Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Norway, and Italy.

During their tour to these countries which are interested in developments in the Sudan, the SWVP advocated for peace in what the women termed a "forgotten war" because of the atrocities suffered by fellow women, children, the aged and disabled particularly in southern Sudan.

The team's visit was sponsored by a Catholic church movement for peace, Pax Christi International, CAFOD, a Catholic relief agency and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA). 

Mrs Teddy A.D. Lotto, the head of the SWVP delegation told APS the group is intensifying efforts to appeal to the international community to continue advocating for an end to Sudan's 13 year-old war.

On their month-long mission, the SWVP team appealed to the host countries to consider the participation of women in all peace initiatives for the Sudan.

They also appealed for financial support for the girl child education and the youth in southern Sudan, saying the on-going civil war has denied this group the chance to go to school. Most of the youth mainly boys are recruited into the armies of the warring factions.

For fellow women, the SWVP team called for support to help their colleagues set up income generating activities that would go a long way in making them economically independent.

The Sudanese women further asked those countries manufacturing arms, personnel mines and landmines to stop supplying weapons to the warring parties, both the Sudan government and the Sudan Peoples's Liberation Army/Movement (SPLA/M), saying these arms are finishing the population of the people of the Sudan, especially southern Sudan where 1.5 million have been killed since the current civil war began 13 years ago.

SWVP also called on the international community to intervene in stopping the ongoing slavery being practised by the Khartoum government in the Nuba Mountains and Northern Bahr El-Ghazal region. "We need to have a just and ever lasting peace in Sudan," Mrs. Lotto emphasized.

"The international community is rushing to Bosnia, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Rwanda, Burundi and Somalia but the Sudanese case has not been given its due attention," observed the head of the SWVP delegation.

During their European tour, the women met women groups, church representatives and Members of Parliament in the countries visited, and drew their attention to the suffering in Sudan as a result of the war.

"We want them to appreciate that we are also human beings who need to be assisted. We want our values to be recognised. And this can only be done by ending the war so that we go back to our country and join in nation building," Mrs. Lotto told APS.

Meanwhile, 20 women from Ethiopia, Somali, Somaliland and Sudan met here from June 25 to 30 to discuss the subject, Community Conflict Resolution Management.

The six-day training of trainers (TOT) workshop was a forum for women from these countries to share experiences about their role in conflict resolution at the family level and in armed conflict as is the case in Sudan's current civil war.

The workshop also discussed community-based mediation and negotiation in which local chiefs have the authority to resolve any conflict arising either in the family or at neighbourhood level.

The workshop was sponsored by the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM) and facilitated by the South African Institute of Conflict Management.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Sudan Khartoum Accused Of Bombing Civilians


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Nairobi - A human rights body operating in southern Sudan has accused the Khartoum Government of dropping cluster bombs in the region with the aim of causing death among the civilians.

At a press conference here on July 10, a team of Christian Solidarity International (CSI) said; "On June 17, 1996, a total of 12 bombs, at least half of them of the cluster bomb type, were dropped on Chukudum and its population of 5,500 people (20,000 in the surrounding areas), scattering bomblets, which can and do detonate at any given time."

Bomblets fell next to the local primary school and the Roman Catholic church, whereas a bomb of a different type exploded 300 metres away from a hospital run by the Norwegian People's Aid, said Mr. Gunnar Wiebalck, who addressed the international press conference on behalf of the team.

Quoting the headmaster of the local school Mr. Joseph Ahileng, Mr. Wiebalck said; "One of the cluster bombs came down only 500 metres away from his school, in which about 475 children were present." 

Bombs are also scattered in front of the Roman Catholic church, putting church-goers at great risk, Mr. Wiebalck further said. This has been confirmed by the local priest, Fr. Maurice, who said "we are running like chickens or a rat chased by a cat, we are so vulnerable.

"The Khartoum government knows that we have a church here, they want to kill all of us. This has been the 17th time they have bombed our village since August 1993," Wiebalck further told the press conference.

Quoting the local Catholic priest, Wiebalck said many people feared leaving the village but a good number of them had already fled to the mountains.

And referring to information from a local commander of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA), Kuol Deim Kuol, Mr. Wiebalck said..."The government soldiers had intended to disrupt a peace conference between all the tribal chiefs of the area."

According to the SPLA, escalated cattle rustling in the area prompted elders and chiefs to come together to resolve the issue but the government soldiers deliberately targeted the June 17 peace talks. "The Government wants the people of southern Sudan to remain divided. They also know that there is a clinic here. They are after our clinic. Please come to our rescue here in southern Sudan. We are being annihilated," Wiebalck quoted the local SPLA commander appealing.

As a result of fear brought about by the bombs' dropping, local people have stopped cultivating the affected fields and many are frightened that children will be killed by hundreds of still un- exploded mini-grenades (or bomblets), which the cluster bomb released over wide areas of Chukudum.

Displaying some bomblets they had flown to Nairobi from Chukudum, the CSI team said they had already forwarded some of these to military experts to analyze their contents.

But addressing the same press conference to which several foreign missions, including those from the member states of the Inter- Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), and non-governmental organizations working in the Sudan were invited, Ali Sadiq, Counsellor at the Sudanese Embassy in Nairobi, vehemently denied the accusations.

"The Khartoum government is in no way involved in this kind of business." He also denied that the said site of attacks, Chukudum, is inhabited by civilians and that it has a school and a church. The embassy

official said contrary to the information availed by the CIS team, Chukudum is a training ground for the SPLA.

"Everybody is entitled to his/her own opinion, but I wish you could visit the said place and see for yourself the reality we are talking about here," observed Wiebalck in response to Sadiq. In a statement issued to the press, the CIS team condemned the use of such weapons against civilians, saying such were outlawed by the Geneva convention.

A member of the CIS at the press conference described cluster bombs as small in size, like toys and wrapped in plastic.

On February 8 this year, two American church pastors working in southern Sudan, in their report to the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC), accused the Khartoum government of dropping from the air approximately 40 plastic TNT landmines near a community water supply in Ikotos, Eastern Equatoria, southern Sudan.

This marks an escalation of what appears to be a concerted effort to target the civilian population in southern Sudan, said pastors Philip Rieman and Louise Rieman in their report.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Science Norway's Stance On Unprotected Sex Provokes African Protest


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Oslo - Norway will not apologise to Africans in the Nordic country after officials warned Norwegians not to have unprotected sex, i,e sex without using a condom.

About 100 people of African origin living in Norway demonstrated in the streets of Oslo on July 8, terming the Ministry of Health advisory "a racial slur" on people of African descent.

But a spokesperson for the Ministry of Health of Norway, Ms. Anne Alvik said here that the government was unrepentant. "We do not intend to apologise. Our warning to people to desist from unprotected sex goes for everybody including Norwegians. We simply do not understand why many people from Africa are so resistant to the use of condoms," she observed. 

Ms. Alvik said the whole world was concerned, because the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) pandemic was not just an African problem but a global tragedy. She doubted that the condom warning would stigmatize Africans living in Norway.

She said most people of African descent living in Norway were HIV- negative. "The problem is that they visit their countries of origin and this may pose a health problem."

Early this year, the former Israeli Prime Minister Mr. Shimon Perez was forced to apologise to the Ethiopian-Jewish community in Israel (the Farashmura) after an Israel newspaper, the Maariv, reported that blood donated by Jews who came from Ethiopia was routinely destroyed by the Israeli Blood Bank.

Thousands of Ethiopian Jews stormed the then Prime Minister's office in Tel Aviv and turned the whole demonstration into an explosion of anger for a litany of grievances against the Jewish state.

The Prime Minister conceded that the Blood Bank episode was racial and promised that there would be no such generalization in future. Each donation of blood would be treated on its own merit.

Meanwhile the head of the United Nations AIDS Agency (UNAIDS), Dr. Peter Piot has painted a gloomy picture about the spread of the disease that has so far claimed 6 million lives since it was first described in 1981.

Speaking at the 11th International AIDS conference in Vancouver, Canada Dr. Piot said 14 million people now carry the virus worldwide, 25 per cent of whom acquired the infection in the last two years.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Uganda Uganda's "Iron Lady" Defies Obote in Party Battle


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Kampala - Cecilia Ogwal, Member of Parliament for Lira Municipality, has appointed her own "Task Force" effectively masterminding a coup within her own Uganda People's Congress Party (UPC) of former president Milton Obote.

Ogwal's announcement of a task force follows a letter from the exiled former leader who lives in Zambia announcing the appointment of Dr. James Rwanyarare as the new Chairman of the Presidential Policy Commission (PPC) and the de facto leader of the UPC.

Over the last 10 years since Obote was overthrown, it is Cecilia Ogwal's tenacity that has sustained the spirit of the UPC which earned her the name "Iron Lady", likening her no-nonsense qualities to those of former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. 

In a letter dated July 5, Obote instructed that Dr Rwanyarare would be the de facto leader of the UPC in Uganda and "therefore be responsible to the PPC for the management, control and direction of UPC headquarters as well as structures in the countryside.

Rwanyarare was also appointed chief party spokesman.

In another letter to Mrs Ogwal also dated July 5, Obote told her "your actions and statements show that it is your utmost desire to put the UPC in disarray and therefore make it easy prey for the National Resistance Movement (NRM) dictatorship to kill."

The NRM is led by incumbent President Yoweri Museveni who was recently re-elected by a landslide to another five-year term in office under "a no-party system" of democracy.

Mrs. Ogwal has been bitterly criticised by Obote and Dr Paul Ssemogerere for contesting a parliamentary seat in the parliamentary elections of June 27.

After he was trounced in the presidential round held on May 9, Ssemogerere said the Inter Party Coalition (IPC) that brought together his Democratic Party (DP) and the UPC would boycott any further elections including parliamentary elections, charging that the Interim Electoral Commission in Uganda was partial. He claimed that the presidential elections were rigged.

Both Ssemogerere and Obote advised their supporter not to participate in the elections to choose parliamentary representatives.

However, Cecilia Ogwal defied both men and went ahead. She was elected MP in her Lira constituency. A number of other IPC supporters also participated in the elections which gave the "multipartists" (as the opposition is called in Uganda) about 20 seats out of 260 seats in Uganda's new Parliament.

Meanwhile, inaugurating Uganda's new parliament on July 8, President Museveni warned ministers against flouting government financial regulations. He warned that henceforth he will deal firmly with any cases of malpractises by civil servants and ministers.

"I am not a puppet of ministers. You should remember I came from the bush, and this time I have come directly from the people..."said the President.

(APS)


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe Zimbabwe To Ease Some Prison Rules


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Harare - The Zimbabwean government plans to introduce an open prison system which will allow all convicts to interact with their families.

A general amnesty to cover some classes of prisoners will also be announced by President Robert Mugabe as soon as sufficient ground work has been completed. A parole board has been set up to make recommendations on those who could benefit from the open prison system. 

The programme will help prisoners to keep in touch with their families and reintegrate into society.

Although the Minister of Justice, Legal and Parliamentary Affairs, Mr. Emmerson Mnangagwa declined to elaborate on the type of prisoners who are earmarked for the parole, it appeared that murder, rape, armed robbery and treason might be excluded from the amnesty which is designed to reduce overcrowding in prisons.

At present, nearly all Zimbabwe's 40 prisons are overcrowded, with some of the institutions holding up to one-and-a-half and upwards of their normal capacities in each cell.

Chikurubi Maximum Security prison in the north, near Harare has a capacity of 1,900 but is currently holding 2,400 prisoners. A cell designed for 23 prisoners is now holding as many as 40.

This overcrowding is also taking its toll on inmates, some of whom are suffering from respiratory diseases, diarrhoea, HIV/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) etc, brought about by poor diet, lack of ventilation and the general unhygienic conditions the prisoners are exposed to among other things. In 1995, about 500 prisoners were reported to have died in the country's prisons from "unknown" ailments.

Around the middle of June 1996, minister Mnangagwa toured some of the prisons gauging the general disposition of prisoners before the new system is introduced.

"We intend to introduce the open prison system soon. As I make my tour, I am observing attitudes of prisoners, their co-operation with prison officers and the general disposition to see the type of system we can introduce," he said.

During his tour, he interacted with prisoners, some of whom appealed to the minister to look into their cases for possible review.

The minister considered the effects of reduced budgetary allocations to prison services. Most of the

inmates' clothes were in tatters and Mr Mnangagwa promised that resources would be made available to ensure that prisoners were adequately clothed.

It was established that about 370 women and teenagers, who had been convicted of serious crimes such as car-jacking and drug-peddling, were locked up at the female section.

Chikurubi is the country's largest prison comprising three sectors - farm, medium and maximum. Most of the food like mealie-meal(maize meal), vegetables, milk and meat supplied to the country's prisons comes from there.

One should acknowledge that the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace (CCJP), Zimbabwe's oldest and most influential human rights group, has been vigorously campaigning for all forms of human abuses in the country.

Although founded by Catholics, the CCJP is in fact, now an umbrella body for all Christian churches in Zimbabwe. Started at the height of Zimbabwe's liberation war in the 1970s, the CCJP is a strong advocate of political, social and economic rights of the people of this Southern African country.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Malawi Malawian Government Clashes with Ex-President Over Trust


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Blantyre - A major tussle has broken out between the Malawian government and former Malawian dictator Kamuzu Banda's opposition Malawi Congress Party (MCP).

At issue is the Press Trust, Banda's former business conglomerate. The Malawian High Court ruled on July 1 that parliament had failed to follow laid down procedures when it passed a bill last year to restructure the trust, which accounts for up to 40 per cent of Malawi's economy. 

High court judge Dunstan Mwaungulu ruled that the trust, which had been expropriated by the government after parliament passed a bill for its restructuring, should revert to its original trustees, meaning Banda.

Mwaungulu said procedures followed by parliament to restructure the trust were flouted and that the bill did not pass under normal circumstances.

Temwa Nyirenda, a lawyer for Banda, had argued that the bill to restructure the conglomerate violated the constitution.

"The bill was proposed and passed in parliament in bad faith. The motive of the government was solely political and not to benefit the legitimate beneficiaries of the trust," Nyirenda argued.

He said banda's rights were violated because the bill effectively expropriates the Press Trust, incorporated by Banda in 1982 when he transferred his shareholding of 500,000 shares in Press Holding to the trust.

Banda owned practically all the shares in Press Holdings.

On July 3, the Malawian government announced that it would immediately lodge an appeal to the Supreme Court over a court ruling against its takeover of the Press Trust, and said that it was "shocked and surprised" at the ruling by the High Court.

Banda on the other hand maintained in a statement issued on July 2 that it was his personal enterprise, he was pleased with the court ruling and called on the new trustees appointed under the invalid legislation to immediately cease performing their duties and operating the bank accounts of the trust.

Banda's main MCP party last year walked out of parliament in protest, saying the legislation was passed to restructure the business conglomerate by former coalition partners, the United Democratic Front (DF) of President Bakili Muluzi and the Alliance for Democracy (AFORD).

The MCP charged that parliament had introduced the bill without observing a rule calling for 21 days notice.

The party also said MPs of UDF and AFORD did not form a quorum and depended on their former parliamentary majority to flout the rules.

But the government had claimed that the business empire was established to benefit the people of Malawi and therefore belonged to them.

Banda, 97, demanded US dollars 16.6 million for it, if it was going to be taken over by the Malawians, but the government turned down the offer as unreasonable.

Muluzi's government, which ousted Banda in democratic elections in 1994, last year ordered a police probe into the activities of the conglomerate, charging that some 41 million kwacha ($2.7 million) had been diverted from Press Trust to fund Banda's cash-strapped MCP.

The government wants the company to be free of political influence and no longer accountable to individuals but operate in a transparent manner.

Observers say the government was likely to table the bill again, following proper procedures.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Science African Experts Develop Locally Prepared Infant Foods


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Nairobi - All over Africa, food scientists and technologists are striving and succeeding in developing low cost weaning foods for the growing child based on crops traditionally grown in Africa such as sorghum, millet, yams, sweet potatoes, soybean and pumpkin leaves among many others.

At the recently concluded Africa-wide Food Technology workshop held in Nairobi, Kenya from June 24 to 29, participants emphasised that growth in food production within the African region has been lower than population growth over the past two to three decades.

Actual per capita food and energy intake levels declined over the same period. A second significant problem contributing to declining food availability in the African region is the post-harvest loss of food to rats, insects, fungus, etc. 

A third important cause of decreased availability of food has been the shift from traditional crops in Africa. A 1994 World Bank document observed that the per capita consumption of products like cassava had declined by as much as 50 per cent during the period 1961 to 1991. In the same period however, the per capita consumption of "foreign" crops like wheat had increased by as much as 35 to 50 per cent. In Botswana, traditionally a sorghum country, the consumption of maize has outstripped that of sorghum.

At the food technology workshop, it was emphasised that if Africa was to get out of the current food deficit gap, Africans will have to go back to their indigenous crops that are well adapted to the region such as sorghum, millet, cassava and yams. The food scientists lamented that research programmes had not given adequate priority to these crops.

According to Dr. Omozoje Ohiokpehai, National Project Coordinator of the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO) training programme for women entrepreneurs in food processing based in Botswana, many African nations could learn from the experience of the South African nation which took decisive steps to produce a traditional cereal based food substitute for its children. The cereal, tsabana, caught on so well that adults began to eat it as well.

With a population of 1.4 million people, Botswana suffers incessant drought problems. Crop production was seriously affected, particularly from 1982 to 1987, necessitating the importation of large quantities of food into Botswana by donor agencies and commercial importers.

The donations were being gradually phased out when the government of Botswana started to prepare for the development of a weaning food to replace previously donated soya milk.

A task force was set up to oversee the activities of the project coordinated by the Ministry of Health with the participation of other ministries including Finance and Planning, Agriculture and the Botswana Technology Research Service. A United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and World Food programme (WFP) consultant was attached to the project.

The American consultant recommended the use of maize and soya in the mixture but quite wisely, the government of Botswana insisted on using sorghum. Consequently several mixtures were made and the most successful turned out to be red sorghum plus soya at the ration of three parts of red sorghum to one of soya flour.

The mixture went through rigorous research before a local company, Foods Botswana, was engaged to produce tsabana commercially.

"Tsabana provides 42 per cent energy, 98 per cent protein and 100 per cent vitamin needs of infants in the (age) range between four and 36 months," says Dr. Ohiokpehai.

Tsabana is distributed free of charge from clinics once a month. During drought years, up to 80 per cent of the children are fed on tsabana.

Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation with a population of more than 100 million people, is also paying attention to the development of infant foods based on traditional crops.

Dr. Olatunji of the Federal Institute of Industrial Research (FIIRO) at Oshodi near the capital, Lagos says a number of commercial food items on the market in Nigeria are the result of local research efforts.

Staple foods like gari and fufu are predominantly energy (carbohydrate) foods with less than two per cent protein.

"Gari is a convenient ready-to-eat food that can be soaked in water and eaten as a meal especially now that the majority cannot afford protein rich foods," says Dr. Olatunji.

In order to make it suitable for the growing child, the FIIRO and the Ibadan-based International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) have succeeded in blending it with locally produced soy flour to make soy-gari with a protein content of 10 to 14 per cent.

For weaning infants, Olatunji and his colleagues at FIIRO have developed the Ogi-soy based on traditional cereals that have undergone partial fermentation to further boost nutritional and storage properties. Mass production of the product relies on the use of locally made machinery for milling and drying.

Dr. A.C. Mosha of the Gaberone Technology Centre says the process of fermentation - for example of porridge in gourds - is one of the oldest food preservation technologies in Africa. "In addition, fermentation is known to contribute to the flavour and nutritional richness of the food," he explains.

Studies have shown that the fermentation process has significant positive effects on the nutritional quality of root/cereal porridge preparation. The protein there-in is rendered more digestible while some minerals like iron become more assimilable.

In Kenya, scientists at the Kenya Industrial Research and Development Institute (KIRDI) have produced a nutritious fermented porridge suitable for children called uji. It is available in supermarkets.

The KIRDI has also developed techniques for censuring absolute hygienic production, particularly in order to ensure that aflatoxin, a harmful fungus does not thrive in a product.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Are Churches In Africa Ready For Self-Reliance?


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by Osman Njuguna


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Nairobi - In May this year, the General Secretary of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), Rev. Jose Chipenda, challenged churches in Africa to consider seriously ways and means that can boost self- reliance in their operations.

The Angolan clergy raised this concern against the background that funds that used to flow smoothly to churches in Africa for pastoral programmes from the "mother" Church mainly in Europe are dwindling.

"The wells are somehow drying up and we need to think seriously about possible alternatives for the church in Africa," Rev. Chipenda, told some 100 delegates who from May 21 to 22 met at Limuru on the outskirts of the capital, Nairobi to deliberate on Self-Reliance in the African Church.

But like other theologians, who have spoken on the issue before, Rev. Chipenda was quick to acknowledge that "the kind of self- reliance we are talking about, would not be achieved easily."

According to Mr. MacMillan Kiiru, who coordinated the church consultation, churches in Africa, would have to think seriously about being good stewards and managers of what God has already endowed them with. 

"Many times, we have gone astray in managing what we have been generously given by others for God's work on our continent. We therefore have to think seriously how we can take care of what God has given other people to give to us for His work on our continent, before we move to the next step of becoming self-supporting," he argues.

Mr. Kiiru, who has in the past conducted various consultations, workshops and meetings on stewardship and management for church leaders and workers in various parts of Africa, notes; "Sometimes churches, like other institutions, such as governments, have become victims of corruption and mismanagement, giving a bad name to the Church."

Commenting on the same subject, Dr. Mercy Oduyoye from Ghana, formerly deputy Secretary-General of the World Council of Churches (WCC), says; "Let us not fuss about it. We have to make it work for time is overdue. While the missionaries have comfortably supported us in the past, we need to stand on our own feet today. We have gone many miles away from being heavily dependent on our "mother" church in Europe for financial needs."

"While we were children, we behaved like them (children) but when we grew up, we behaved like adults, so says the Bible. And likewise, we should now accept to stand on our own feet, since the early missionaries did everything for us when we were toddlers spiritually," pointed out Mrs (Dr) Hannah Kinoti, a lecturer at the department of Religious Studies, University of Nairobi.

Prof. Patrick Matsikenyiri, a Zimbabwean teaching music and culture at the Methodist Church University in Mutare, emphasized on the need to talk more about self sufficiency; "We still have a number of 'doubting Thomases' who need preaching on the need to be self- supporting; a reality that the entire church in Africa should hear about."

Dr. Teresia Hinga, a Kenyan, who lectures at the DePaul University in the USA cautions that "the same Europe that has generously helped churches in Africa to pursue their pastoral programmes in the past, is today paying greater financial attention to the new foundland in the Eastern Europe after the collapse of Communism."

Former Presiding Methodist Bishop in Kenya, Lawi Imathiu says; "We simply need to urge the Church in Africa to move one or two steps up. We are not at a zero point in this aspect. We have already taken off the ground. One only needs to look around in Kenya for example, where Christians raise alot of money through harambees (kiswahili - pooling resources to meet a common need.

In our churches for example, there are times when, we have raised more money in a given period than what is received from our church donors in Europe," he adds.

Dr. Douglas Waruta, a lecturer in religious studies at the University of Nairobi proposes a structural overhaul for the Church in Africa if self-reliance is to be realised on the continent.

"We have built our Christian faith on structures that are too expensive to run. We might have to overhaul some of them to enable local churches to stand on their own feet," he says.

Addressing the May consultation, former Moderator of the Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA), Rt. Rev. John Gatu said self-reliance, must take the form of the Exodus Experience. The Hebrews in Egypt, could not appreciate the leadership of Moses or Aaron and many others of their own kith and kin until they left Egypt, he explained.

Unless the African leadership accept the challenge of self-reliance in order to undo the yoke of dependence and be able to set examples in training personnel, trusting one another regardless of the evils of ethnicity that seem to have raided not only Africa but the entire world today, the Church in Africa will remain poor, weak and will be unable to engage in her missionary calling to evangelize to all mankind, Rev. Gatu pointed out.

The former PCEA Moderator pointed out that self-reliance should not only be seen in terms of financial stability. "It also embraces the total life of the Church to be able to become the real Church of Jesus Christ, commissioned to carry the message to the utmost parts of the earth," he explained.

Rev. Gatu also had some advice for church leaders. For churches in Africa to achieve the intended goal of self-reliance, the church leaders will have to "strip themselves naked" before the Lord in terms of allowing Jesus to deal with their spirituality.

He further suggested that the same church leaders will also have to "strip themselves" of the comfort of salaries and benefits received from their relationships with overseas donors, and allow Jesus to direct the operation instead.

In his paper, Economic Challenges Facing the Church in Africa, a senior lecturer at the Institute of Diplomacy and International Studies, University of Nairobi, Dr Gerrishon Ikiara, told the consultation participants that while demands on the Church in Africa have been rising rapidly, the ability of the Church to provide or supply the required services has been hampered by various factors, among them, inflationary pressures, economic stagnation, poor tithing and other church collections, lack of business acumen by church leaders, bureaucratic or government obstacles and the dependency syndrome.

While it is said that the high rate of Christianity growth being experienced in Africa is a blessing in terms of the spread of the Word of God, Dr. Ikiara warned that "there are inescapable financial costs that are associated with this growth."

He cited the need for upgrading and infrastructure that the church operates in, church buildings, schools, hospitals etc; the impact of socio-economic crises, rapidly worsening poverty situation, the refugees, new epidemics such as the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), involvement of churches in the democratisation process and the creation of new social-economic institutions.

In his book, Hope for Africa and What the Christian Can Do, Kenyan scholar, George Kinoti, argues that "our extensive dependence on the Western Church for ideas, theology, personnel and money is unhealthy for the Church in Africa and unhelpful to the African people."

And this is true whether the imports come from liberal, evangelical, Pentecostal or some other Western source, says Kinoti, adding, that the dangers of mistaking Western culture, philosophy and psychology for Christianity are not sufficiently recognised.

Bishop Njeru Wambugu, the head of the National Independent Church of Africa (NIPA) in Kenya, sees the move by the mission-oriented churches in Africa to aim for self-reliance in their pastoral programmes as a clear sign that "they (churches) have realised the right gospel -- that they need to stand on their own feet, not only financially, but in other areas."

He reminds them of the famous Kiswahili saying, "Mwacha Mila ni Mtumwa" (One who fails to live up to his/her culture remains a slave).


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Burundi Tops OAU Summit As Mayhem Continues


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

Nairobi - As African leaders met for their annual summit in Yaounde, Cameroon, fears were fast rising that another ethnic bloodbath would erupt in Burundi amid calls for African peacekeeping troops to be sent into the impoverished, tiny former Belgian colony.

The spectra of a repeat of the savage violence which tore Rwanda apart two years ago was top of the agenda for the 53-nation Organisation of African Unity (OAU) at their three-day summit in Yaounde.

Burundi's low-level civil war between extremists from the Hutu majority and the minority Tutsi-dominated army threatens to degenerate into carnage as moves to find a peaceful solution founder amid escalating ethnic hatred.

Providing security to the country of 5.5 million people, however, ran into difficulty early this month when its Tutsi prime minister and Hutu president fell out publicly over what role an international peacekeeping force would play.

Burundi's neighbours, fearing unrest could spill over into their territory, had suggested a force composed initially of troops from Ethiopia, Tanzania and Uganda, but the OAU has yet to decide how it will be financed. 

Countries bordering Burundi and Rwanda are afraid an explosion of violence, similar to the ethnic violence in Rwanda in 1994 when between 500,000 and one million people were reported to have been killed, could engulf the entire Great Lakes region.

Plans to send African troops to strife-torn Burundi foundered on July 3 when President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu and Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo, a Tutsi disagreed.

The split came as Hutu rebels accused the Tutsi-dominated army of having killed more than 1,000 Hutu civilians the previous week with the aid of Tutsi soldiers from neighbouring Rwanda.

The National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), the biggest rebel group, said in a communique issued in Brussels, Belgium, that the soldiers, with "massive back-up" from Rwandan troops, had massacred more than 1,000 Hutu civilians in the north- western province of Cibitoke on June 27 and demanded an international inquiry into the alleged bloodbath.

No independent confirmation of any massacre has been obtained, as no international organisation has been working in Cibitoke since the assassination of three Red Cross delegates there on June 4.

But an army spokesman in Bujumbura said on radio that "not one Rwandan soldier has set foot in Burundi to help us," and in Kigali, a senior Rwandan Defence Ministry official dismissed the allegation as "nonsense....propaganda."

The president and prime minister had joined other regional leaders at a summit in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha on June 25 to seek military assistance, but Nduwayo on July 3 accused the president of wanting to "neutralise" the army, which is battling Hutu rebels in the conflict, whose casualties were mostly civilians.

Both men returned from the summit to accusations of treachery and back-pedalled fast, saying the force would be under Burundian command, with its missions defined by the Burundian military.

But the OAU Council of Ministers' draft resolution to the summit expressed strong support for a regional conference on peace, security, stability and development in the Great Lakes region, although ironically Rwanda, which has been a main topic for the last two OAU summits, was skipped from a list of countries to be discussed this year.

It is in apparent response to Rwandan officials who, at a meeting of foreign ministers laying the summit groundwork, objected to being bunched together with states such as Burundi, saying everything was normal in their own country.

According to a rapporteur's report from the ministers meeting on July 5, Rwandan Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana, stressed that the problems of Rwanda and Burundi which have the same ethnic make-up of 85 per cent Hutus and 14 per cent Tutsis, should not be confused as they were "different".

Expressing grave concern at the deteriorating situation in Burundi where Hutu rebels opposed to sharing power with the influential Tutsi minority are fighting an escalating guerrilla war, the African ministers expressed support for a peace initiative undertaken by Tanzania's elder statesman, former President Julius Nyerere.

The resolution "strongly supported the important (peace initiative) of Nyerere" and urged the country's political leadership, the military and the civilians to show a greater will for a negotiated and peaceful settlement to their conflict.

At the same time, the ministers deplored the continuing bloodshed in this tiny Central African state, saying: "The OAU Council of Ministers deplores and strongly condemns the brutal and bastardly murder of innocent people as well as humanitarian and aid workers."

United States envoys had also warned recently in Bujumbura against any coup d'etat after Tutsi extremists said that the arrival of foreign troops would unleash a full-scale civil war, with Tutsis forming guerrilla bands after accusing Ntibatunganya of being in cahoots with the Hutu rebels.

The two US negotiators, special peace envoy to Burundi Howard Wolpe and US special coordinator for Burundi and neighbouring Rwanda Richard Bogosian, said they fully supported the appeal for military assistance.

Belgian envoy Yves Haesendonck also expressed support for an African force after talks in Bujumbura with Ntibantunganya. Belgium administered Burundi under League of Nations and UN mandates from 1919 to 1962.

On Liberia, the ministers warned the warring faction leaders that the OAU would recommend imposition of severe UN sanctions on them, including the possibility of setting up a war crime tribunal to try faction leaders on gross human rights violations, if the next meeting of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) on Liberia was a failure.

Other conflicts up for discussion included Angola, Sierra Leone and Somalia, which have left Africa with millions dead and refugees.

A total of 19 draft resolutions were presented for debate by OAU heads of state and government at the summit, hosted by Cameroon from July 8 to 10.

High among the draft resolutions is the deadly Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) and its spread, which casts a long shadow over the proceedings of the pan-African body.

The resolutions called for more international assistance to fight AIDS, which affects Africa more than any other continent, with statistics showing that some 11 million out of the 18 million people in the world infected with the HIV virus, the precursor to AIDS, are found in Africa.

The number of draft resolutions was, however, slashed by half from the original 38 to 19, with Rwanda being one of those to be dropped, according to a copy of the draft resolutions.

Among them was their decision to give their support to UN Secretary- General Boutros-Ghali to seek a second final term as head of the world body, despite vehement opposition by the United States that has pledged to support any other African candidate, but not Boutros- Ghali, an Egyptian national.

The ministers, whose countries, have a total external debt expected to reach 320 billion dollars this year, also renewed the mandate of a sub-committee tasked with finding ways of resolving the burden of external debt. The continent's increasing indebtedness and debt- servicing have led to a deterioration of socio-economic conditions.

The ministers also deplored the attitude of France, United States and Britain towards Libya which is under UN sanctions because of its alleged involvement in terrorism.

Meanwhile, Algeria and Mauritania called for the OAU to implement UN resolutions on a referendum on self-determination for the Sahara. The question has been a bone of contention between Algeria and Morocco.

Conspicuously absent from the list of resolutions was the Bakassi peninsula conflict between the conference hosts, Cameroon and neighbouring Nigeria.

Speaking at the end of the Council of Ministers' session, OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim summed up Africa's troubled situation with a warning that the continent's hope on Burundi lay in the ongoing peace efforts by former Tanzanian leader, Julius Nyerere, although these efforts were apparently being rejected by the country's opposition.

The renewed clashes between Liberian clans and Somalia's factions respectively, have been equally frustrating, Salim said, pointing out: "The untold and extreme suffering and hardship imposed on the people of Liberia defies all description and reason."

"The tragedy in Somalia continues to haunt the international community," said Salim, adding that the sporadic fighting and humanitarian crisis continued to pose a serious challenge to the continent.

But the London-based human rights watchdog, Amnesty International (AI), commended OAU for giving priority to the Burundi conflict, warning that the worst could still come unless the OAU provided bold leadership to the international community on the issue.

Amnesty's warning comes as ordinary Burundians were becoming more and more cynical on the possibility of success of current regional efforts to resolve the Burundian ethnic debacle.

AI notes that it was at Arusha that a peace treaty for Rwanda was signed in 1993, eight months before the outbreak of the civil war there which saw Hutu extremists slaughter more than 500,000 men, women and children, most of them minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Olympics African Runners Make A Mark in Pre-Olympic Meet


BYLINE: Africa News Service July 15, 1996 by Reed Kramer


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Durham, NC - Previewing what could be intense Olympic competition between athletes from Africa and the United States, South African sprinter Hezekiel Sepeng bested American Johnny Gray in a down-to-the-wire 800 meters race during the "Gold Rush" track-and-field meet here on Saturday.
Vida Nsiash of Ghana came in first in the women's 100-meter hurdles, and South African Joha Morapedi won the men's 3,000 meters in the only other top finishes for African athletes in the meet.

In the women's 1,500 meters, South African Gwen Griffiths lost a close race to American Stephanie Best, a non-Olympian who bested U.S. teams members Lynn Jennings (3rd) and Kate Fonshell (4th). 

The competition was held at Duke University, which has a track very similar to the one that will be used for the Atlanta Games, and was the final pre-Olympic test for the participants.
For his victorious run, Sepeng set a stadium record of 1:43:47 and posted the third fastest time in the world this year. Gray finished third at 1:43:96, the fastest for an American this year, behind Einars Tupuritis of Latvia. Nsiash's winning time in the 100 meter hurdles was 13:57.
A large crowd of more than 28,000, most of whom remained in the stadium in spite a brief but heavy downpour, was deprived of seeing one highly touted U.S.-African match-up. South African pole vaulter Okkert Brits, a leading world contender, was a 'no-show,' leaving that event to the top American, Lawrence Johnson.

A large South African contingent did take part, with South African men chalked up third place finishes in the 4x400 meter relay and in the 300 meter steeplechase (Shadrak Mogosti), the 1500 meters (Johan Botha) and the 400-meter hurdles (Llewellyn Herbert).

Lofti Khaida from Algeria placed fourth in the triple jump and fifth in the long jump, which was won by American Carl Lewis, a three-time Olympic gold medalist. Two African runners placed in the men's 100 meters, Abdul Zakari of Ghana (12th) and Jean-Oliver Zirignon of Cote d'Ivoire (14th).

The meet was organized by Duke track coach Al Buehler and Dr. LeRoy T. Walker, a Durham resident and president of the United States Olympic Committee. The two men have teamed up to bring a series of major meets to this city over the past two decades, including two with strong Pan-African representation in 1971 and 1994.

Walker, a long-time track coach at North Carolina Central University in Durham who coached the U.S. Olympic team in 1976, trained 12 U.S. medal winners and numerous African champions, including Kenya's 4x400 gold medal team at the 1972 Munich Games.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

55 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Science 'Aids' virus hits South Africa's Kruger Park


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) July 12, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - Foreign zoos are reluctant to buy lions captured in the Kruger National Park because new research shows eight out of every 10 Kruger lions may be infected with the feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), a viral agent similar in structure to HIV but not transferable between human and cat species.

Research conducted by biologists and veterinarians on a sample of lions drawn from all regions of the park shows 80% responded positively to tests for FIV. But there is no evidence the virus has caused an outbreak of FAIDS (Feline Acquired Immunodeficiency) -- the cat world's equivalent of full-blown Aids -- or any other symptoms of fatal infectious diseases.

A research report published in the Onderstepoort Journal of Veterinary Research shows antibodies indicating the presence of FIV -- or a virus closely related to that which afflicts domestic cats -- were found in the vast majority of male and female lions that were captured, sedated and tested during the two-year study.

A comparative survey on a sample of lions from the Etosha National Park in Namibia found no evidence of FIV. However, epidemiological studies have established that 57% of lions sampled in European zoos and 73% of Asian lions at the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago also have the disease.

Although there is little evidence FIV in lions causes any serious pathological consequences, some zoos in North America say they will not buy lions from Kruger because it is unlikely they will pass obligatory Faids tests with a clean bill of health. The disease does not, however, affect the park's ability to sell wild lions to other game reserves in South Africa as FIV is not listed as a "notifiable disease".


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Science 'Extinct' Lions May Be In Ethiopian Zoo


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) July 12, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Johannesburg - Ever wondered why the beast roaring out of the screen at the start of every MGM movie doesn't really look like the cats you see in the Kruger National Park? It is because the ferocious lion with a long black mane which features so often in popular iconography is now extinct in Africa.

Or is it? Eleven animals which look remarkably like the magnificent Cape or Barbary lions -- subspecies resembling the near-mythical "biblical lion" that is thought to have died out in Africa decades ago -- have been "discovered" by a South African researcher at a forgotten zoo in Ethiopia.

Hym Ebedes, specialist wildlife researcher at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute, spotted a group of lions with distinctive long, wide black manes that reach under their bellies at a zoo in Addis Ababa during a research expedition into Ethiopia's wilderness areas late last year.

The scientist says the male cats in the pride, descendants of a group of lions kept by Emperor Haile Selassie at the royal palace in Addis before he was toppled in a 1974 coup, have the physical features of the North African Barbary lion or South Africa's Cape lion. Both were shot out of existence by white hunters and settlers during the colonial period. 

"Over the past 35 years I have seen hundreds of wild lions in game reserves, lots of captive lions in zoos all over the world, as well as photographs of lions in wildlife books from all over southern, western and eastern Africa, but I had never before seen anything so impressive, majestic and magnificient," Ebedes told the Mail & Guardian.

"The sight of a black-maned lion pacing around his cage just before feeding time in a zoo in Addis Ababa last October had an indescribable spine-chilling effect on me. This animal was exactly as I had always visualised and pictured the Cape lion, which became extinct about 150 years ago."

Barbary lions from the Atlas Mountain region in present-day Morocco were imported from North Africa into the Roman Empire. They were used in gladiator contests and featured in legendary accounts of Christians being persecuted by the Romans.

The last of the North African animals was shot dead in the Atlas region during the 1920s. Their ferocious features and beautiful black manes appear frequently in Greek mythology, biblical literature (the lions of Judea and the animal that Samson killed with the jaw of an ass), popular Western iconography (MGM movies and Simba cartoons), as well as the folklore of many African cultures.

The Cape lions, which had a strong resemblance to their North African cousins, were hunted by colonial farmers in the 19th century and were thought to have become extinct in the 1850s. Cape (Leo melanochaitus) and Barbary (Leo leo leo) lions -- each a subspecies of the same cat family (Panthera leo) -- probably developed similar features because cool winter climates and the absence of dense bush on each tip of the continent allowed their manes to grow longer than other types of African lions.

A 19th century account describes males of the extinct Cape lion as having "large manes that reach far behind the shoulders; belly mane developed; the yellowish colour of the mane around the face contrasts sharply with the blackish, or pure black colouring of their mane on the neck, shoulders, throat and chest."

There are three male lions, four lionesses and four cubs in the Ethiopian zoo. Mystery surrounds their history and presence in the East African country. It is known that they came from the private collection of Hailie Selassie, whose dynasty called itself the Lions of Ethiopia and always kept the wild cats to help cultivate its image of power.
The last of the Selassie families was overthrown in a military coup and was replaced by the Marxist government of Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1974. The lions were transferred to the zoo in Addis Ababa. Ebedes is the first Western veterinary scientist to have visited the zoo since the dictatorship was replaced in the early 1990s by an elected government.

"Given their enthusiasm for collecting lions, it is possible that Selassie obtained the animals from a private collector or a zoo in Europe that had, in turn, acquired them from the Cape or North Africa before these types of lion became extinct," says Ebedes.

Selassie is dead, while Mariam is living in exile in Zimbabwe. Ebedes has consulted Ethiopian historians to see if they know how the lions came to Addis, but these inquiries have drawn a blank. He says the best way to begin unravelling the riddle is to conduct comparative genetic tests on the live Addis animals and the skins of Barbary and Cape lions that exist in European museums.

Petri Viljoen, a biologist who specialises in research into the genetic features of South African lions, says the Ethiopian discovery offers intriguing prospects for breeding and possibly reintroducing into the wild a species that has disappeared from record.

But he warns that the excitement in zoological circles is based, so far, only on the physical characteristics of the animals found in Addis. Viljoen says captive lions are known to develop large torsos and long manes because they do not have to hunt in hot and dense bush. This, rather than genetic membership of a subspecies, could explain the physical characteristics of the Ethiopian lions.

Professor Fritz Eloff, renowned for his research into the lions of the Kalahari desert, says he has studied video footage taken by Ebedes of the Ethiopian pride. "I have seen lions from all over Africa, but never such lions. They look exactly like the pictures and sketches of the Cape lion that I have seen."

Eloff says DNA analysis is the only way to determine whether the Ethiopian lions come from the two extinct types of African cats. "The other important question that needs to be answered is, where the lions come from? Are they Ethiopian lions, or do they come from further north -- for example, from Morocco?"

Eloff says there are records of lions that resembled the extinct Barbary lions living at a zoo in Rabat, Morocco, during the 1970s. He agrees that private collectors in Europe may have kept Cape or Barbary lions and then supplied the offspring to the Selassie family.

Vratislav Mazak, a European zoologist and lion specialist, reports that the Cape lion was the first of the African subspecies to become extinct. It died out too soon for scientists to study it properly -- making it difficult to compare it to the pride in the Addis zoo. Mazak's scientific reports say there are only eight mounted skins in natural history museums in England, the Netherlands, France and Germany.

Meanwhile, the owners of the Kapama private game reserve in South Africa are negotiating with the Ethiopian government to buy some of the Ethiopian lions and bring them back to this country.

Ebedes has suggested the Cape Public Works authorities rehabilitate the historical lion enclosure at the old zoo at the Rhodes Memorial in Cape Town so that it can house these animals which strongly resemble the legendary cats who once roamed freely on the slopes of Table Mountain.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria Shell Faces Continuing Criticism as Nigerian Pressure Mounts


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) July 12, 1996 by Patrick Donovan


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Lagos - Give him a wig and black silk gown, and Napolean Agbedetse could have walked back into the south London courtrooms where he used to practise as a barrister. He is on the bank of the Abadino river, deep inside the mosquito-infested mangrove swamps of the Niger delta. Despite the shirt-soaking humidity, Agbedetse is immaculately dressed in a heavy black pinstripe suit.

Standing on the jetty amid a welter of gawking young boys, he cuts an incongruous figure as he courteously greets representatives of the Shell oil company and prepares, yet again, to do verbal battle on behalf of the Omadino people. This is only one of the hundreds of remote rural communities in Nigeria who feel they are being cheated out of their birthright by foreign oil companies.

This issue has rarely been out of the headlines since the country's military government late last year outraged international opinion by proceeding with the hanging of environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa -- a campaigner for the the Ogoni people, who live in the east of the delta. 

Shell, which operates a consortium responsible for drilling more than half the country's oil reserves, has been widely criticised for not doing more to oppose the execution. Shell is perceived by many in the West to have huge influence with the authorities as oil now accounts for as much as 90% of the government's revenue. But within the subsistence-level fishing communities like the Omadinos near the oil town of Warri, anger is steadily growing.

Last month, 60 protesters forced Shell to shut down its drilling rig in nearby Jones Creek -- the latest of a string of incidents throughout the Niger basin, where local communities' dissatisfaction has boiled over into direct action against Shell activities.

Six million people live in this 70 000km2 province. These are rural communities, eking out their living from the brown waters of the Niger and its fast-running tributaries snaking out across a massive expanse of rain forest and mangrove swamp.

But their living standards have plummeted: wildlife is scarce, and fish yields are down. How much this is due to the pressures of population growth, lack of land management or oil industry-related pollution depends on which lobbyists you listen to.

All of which raises the question of to what extent any international company operating in a deprived country should be held responsible for functions which are, or should be, the preserve of the national government. In the case of Nigeria, the debate is clouded still further by the failure of the national government to redistribute hefty oil revenues to the producing areas, and by the myriad local tribal tensions which make it almost impossible to get an accurate assessment of the views of local people.

Yet the debate that took place last week between Agbedetse and Shell's local general manager, Steve Ollerearnshaw, in front of an audience of villagers down the Abadino river does, in simplified form, highlight the underlying conflict.

Although he had cut out a career for himself as a British-based barrister, Agbedetse says that he was driven by his conscience to return to help his native Itsekiri tribe.

Waiting until the contingent from Shell has sat down in the corrugated tin-roofed meeting hall, Agbedetse drops to his knee before Chief Sunday and the other tribal elders, some wearing bowler hats and all seated at differing heights to reflect their varying degrees of seniority.

Waiting until his guests have been served Star beer or cola, he lulls them into a false sense of security, praising Shell for its "sheer hard work" which has "opened up the unknown hidden wealth of our country". And then he turns the knife. Listened to attentively by dozens of stony-faced villagers, Agbedetse accuses Shell of "dictatorship".

"On paper, they dialogue with the community on what developments are needed, but in reality Shell operatives dictate what they want, irrespective of the needs of the people," he says.

Not only do communities like the Omadino get little back from local oil exploration, but also Shell, he asserts, is decimating the region's staple occupation of fishing, through oil spills. He adds: "The plight of those of us in the rural operation areas is one of depression, neglect and poverty."

As they sit in their green overalls, several Shell officials have clearly heard this all before. Ollerearnshaw gets to his feet, pointing out that the company has given the community a block of classrooms and public toilets and will shortly be donating a health centre -- the latest items from Shell's $30-million-a-year community assistance programme for the Niger delta region. A further $100-million is allocated for the environment annually.

He tries to raise the point that Shell is a company, and cannot take on all the functions of central government. But one angry young man, wearing blue and white robes, attempts to hijack the meeting, angrily shouting that the company must do more.

Back in Nigeria's capital city, Lagos, the company's managing director Brian Anderson admits that adverse publicity surrounding its involvement in Nigeria has been "very bad" for the company's image, particularly the controversy surrounding the Saro-Wiwa hanging. But Shell insists that the situation in the Niger delta is far more complex, and Anderson claims that its influence on the hardline national government is far less than the West supposes it to be.

Shell's stance is that it is, after all, a commercial company with a 30% stake in a consortium in which the state-owned Nigeria National Petroleum Corporation has a majority holding. The group, which includes Elf of France and Italy's Agip, pumps more than half of Nigeria's output of two million barrels a day, giving the country oil revenues worth $7-billion, of which the government keeps 75%.

At least 3% of this revenue should flow back to the people of the oil-producing areas, according to the terms of a government decree. This is to increase to 13%, although the higher figure has yet to be ratified.

In practice, it appears that government aid has all but broken down, and Shell says that the administration is in arrears with its payments. That puts even more pressure on the funds Shell and its other partners have for community projects.

The problem is that for many of the rural inhabitants of the Niger Delta, Shell has effectively become the government. It may protest that it does not aspire to become a 21st century version of the East India Company; yet the more it seeks to pacify local people by taking over the role of building hospitals and providing schools, the more it replaces Nigeria's military dictatorship as a target for civil dissent.

And yet Shell has been extracting oil here for 50 years. It may play the role of the community-minded Western oil company, but why is it only now making such a fanfare about its perfectly laudable programmes to replant the mangrove swamps and bury its pipelines if not to improve its public image?

Of course attitudes change, but Shell cannot ignore the fact that it has drained billions of dollars of profits out of Nigeria during the past five decades. Its payback to the community has hardly been consistent over that period.

And as with all oil explorers, it has inevitably contributed to the pollution of the environment, although there is no obvious sign of any significant spillage within its operating areas in the delta.

But Shell is now having to pay in full. It has played such a pivotal role in Nigeria's economy that it must bear some responsibility when the going gets rough. But the company's predicament may be useful, too, for Nigeria's leader, General Sani Abacha: the controversy diverts attention from the country's fundamental problem -- the corruption and inefficiency in its own military government.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Burundi Warnings Fail to Stop Killing As Burundi Teeters on the Brink


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) July 12, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Bujumbura - There is a difference of opinion in Burundi about the cement factory manager who burnt 22 of his workers to death, and sold tickets to their fellow employees to watch. The manager is a Tutsi, his victims were Hutus. Today there are many in Burundi's capital, Bujumbura, who refuse to condemn him. Some even argue that the killings were a blow against genocide.

On a typical day, 100 people are killed in Burundi. In the three years since it began, the death toll has risen to over 100 000. Most are not killed in conventional combat. The Hutu rebels and Tutsi army, backed by their militias in the cities, rarely confront one another. Mostly they attack those unable to resist. Each side accuses the other of genocide. Each has a point. 

Genocide haunts the nations dotted around Lake Tanganyika. Rwanda witnessed the swiftest and most comprehensive mass murder of modern times. Survivors and witnesses are still being killed to prevent them telling what they know. In the refugee camps in Zaire and Tanzania -- where the West feeds and protects the killers -- the genocide hangs over the guilty and innocent alike, imbuing a fear of retribution that keeps two million people from going home.

But today the fear of genocide lives most openly in Burundi where it is used to justify mass murder, and where it threatens to kindle a larger war that could engulf the whole region.

Two weeks ago, faced with an escalating death toll, a war it cannot win and an economy close to collapse, Burundi's government bowed to pressure from its neighbours to accept foreign troops on its soil in an effort to quell the killing. The shape and mandate of the intervention force is to be decided by regional leaders who believe more than Burundi's future is at stake. If the nation descends into full-scale civil war, it is likely to drag Rwanda into the fray, plunge eastern Zaire into conflict and possibly embroil Uganda and Tanzania.

The dawn chorus in Bujumbura is provided by the young Tutsis singing as they jog through the capital. Gripping sticks and Kalashnikovs, they are members of the "civil defence units" formed over the past few weeks at the Tutsi prime minister's behest after Hutu rebel attacks on the electricity supply shattered the illusion of security created by ethnic cleansing. They are reminiscent of the youths who pounded Rwanda's streets before the killing.

The dilapidated heart of Bujumbura bustles for a few hours a day with citizens in a hurried search for necessities.

Some fear to walk the streets, especially close to the market, a target for random grenade attacks. The 9pm curfew killed Bujumbura's nightlife. Power cuts occur daily.

Most people prefer to get home by dusk and huddle in homes tucked into the hillsides sloping down to the edge of Lake Tanganyika. Even there, the war encroaches. Fishing boats are no longer permitted to scour the lake -- an attempt to prevent weapons being shipped across the water.

When the government first tried to enforce the curfew, the joke was that it applied to Hutus and foreigners. But that could not allay the growing sense of fear among Tutsis. So the army decided the Hutus had to go all together. Kamenge, a large township in the capital, was the first to be cleared with the enthusiastic assistance of the Tutsi militias. Its houses were wrecked in the army raids and its people massacred.

Certainly there was some support for the rebel cause. The Kamenge malcontents were run by a young man known as "Savimbi" who was as much into organised crime as liberation. But when it came to driving township residents out, the army did not discriminate between guilty and innocent, men and women, young and old. They left behind hundreds of dead.

Most of the Hutus forced out tramped into the nearby hills. Some still venture into the city in the mornings to sell food. Bujumbura needs the supplies, so they are tolerated.

But it is outside the capital where the real terror lies, and where the scale of murder is overshadowed only by its routine brutality.

Typical of the military's contribution to the murderous cycle was the massacre of at least 70 Hutu civilians in hills around Gitega a fortnight ago. Witnesses said six truckloads of soldiers armed with guns and bayonets drew up. Over five hours they hunted down their victims across four hills. A survivor described seeing men, women and children shot or bayonetted and their bodies tossed in a river.

The Hutu rebels respond in kind. Last week, they murdered as many as 100 people at Burundi's largest tea plantation, about 50km from the capital. They claimed that the only victims were soldiers. But of the 22 bodies I saw outside the factory, 16 were women and children. Some were babies, their skulls crushed even as they clutched their mothers.

"If there is no intervention by the international community -- very tough and very rapid intervention -- the conflict is going to get worse and it will not only affect Burundi. It will have a direct impact on Rwanda, Zaire, Uganda and even Tanzania. The whole Great Lakes subregion will burn."

This prediction was made by Jean-Marie Ngendahayo, Burundi's former foreign minister, who fled to South Africa. The warnings have sounded ever since Rwanda erupted in 1994.

African elder statesman Julius Nyerere, UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Jimmy Carter, senior American officials and Tanzania's President Benjamin Mkapa have all warned that Burundi is perilously close to the edge. "There is an almost frantic amassing of weapons of all kinds by each group. We must not let a replay of the 1994 Rwanda tragedy take place," Mkapa said at the regional summit two weeks ago.

The former American ambassador to Burundi, Robert Krueger, fired a parting shot in an official cable before his reappointment to Botswana, probably for being too outspoken in his demands for Western action.

He drew a comparison with the Oklahoma bombing. In proportion to its size, Burundi is suffering a death toll equivalent to that at Oklahoma each day, but few take notice.

'This cable is a reminder that in an obscure country in the heart of Africa, the killing is proportionately vastly heavier than what the cameras are covering; or, indeed, than in almost any place else in the world," he wrote.

Boutros-Ghali's appeals to the UN Security Council for an international force for Burundi have fallen on deaf ears. The memories are fresh of the US's debacle in Somalia under UN auspices.

Rwanda provided an unmitigated UN failure which counted among its victims the deaths of Belgian peacekeepers beside the hundreds of thousands of Tutsis. So far as the UN is concerned, Africa will have to look after itself.


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
