69 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria Does Abacha Plan to Exit in 1998?


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Yusuph Olaniyonu


LENGTH: 4854 words


 

Lagos - For political correspondents who besieged the hotel suite of Samuel Ikoku, on June 28, they had gone to hear him speak on the recent meeting of the Nigerian delegation with the Commonwealth Minister's Action Group. As a member of that delegation sent to argue Nigeria's case for re-admission into the commonwealth, the reporters hoped to get an insider information on what transpired at the meeting.

But the reporters came away with an even bigger story. As vice-chairman of the Transition Implementation Committee, TIC, to monitor the administration's transition programme, Ikoku was asked of the possible implications of the failure of the government to keep to the schedule of creating more states and local government councils in the second quarter of this year. Without pausing to think the matter through, Ikoku shot back that in the event, the TIC would ask for an alteration to the programme. He said the late submission of the report of the Mbanefo committee on states creation and boundary adjustment by one month has put the government in an awkward position, and that with the carry-over of plans for second quarter into the third, the schedule has to change. The only alternative, Ikoku said, was for the government to abandon states creation, an option he said the administration would not consider. "In fact, it is one of the things that has delayed the final draft of the constitution," Ikoku revealed. 

In addition to all this, Ikoku said the TIC was considering the short tenure given to councilors elected on non-party basis in March this year. According to the transition time-table, another council polls, to be contested on party platforms has been slated for the fourth quarter of the year beginning in October. This gives only a seven-month tenure to the councilors. Still, Ikoku sought to allay the fears of Nigerians that an alteration of the programme will result in an extension of the handover date: "I am not saying we are not going to make changes here and there in the body of the transition programme because when you come to implementation, you may be forced by circumstances to make one or two changes. But October 1, 1998 is inevitable."

From all appearances, Ikoku was only a forerunner. The following day, Mamman Nasir, the TIC chairman himself, told reporters that the head of state was angry at the delay in the submission of the report of the States Creation Committee as it might unhinge the transition time-table. With that kite from the two principal policemen of the implementation of the transition programme, Nigerians were once more rudely reminded of the Babandiga era when the handover date kept moving further away with every gust of that administration's whims. By Sunday when Ikoku's statement made the front page headlines of all the major newspapers, it blacked out the monstrous guidelines for the registration of political parties as the focus of general discussion, if not apprehension. Those who read a sinister omen into Ikoku's kite have a point; his antecedents are far from comforting.

An old political war horse, Ikoku started his political career well before the first republic as a Marxist, spawned by the Kwame Nkrumah ideological School, Winneba, Ghana. A member of the left of centre Action Group in the First Republic, he became the leader of parliamentary opposition in The Eastern Region and the party's secretary-general. Ikoku's atonishing metamorphosis occurred in the Second Republic when he swung from the leftist Peoples Redemption Party to the extreme right with the conservative National Party of Nigeria. After the collapse of the Second Republic, he wrote a book titled Fourth Coup D'etat: Options for Modern Statehood. In it, he advocated for a permanent place for the military in the governance of Nigerian.

He attempted to put his theory into practice, when he and other old politicians formed the Committee of Elder Statement and Concerned Citizens, a group whose only visible agenda was a campaign for former president Ibrahim Babangida not to handover power to civilians after an eight-year transition programme. Against the run of domestic and international opinion, the group, consisting of Tola Adeniyi, then chairman of Daily Times, Kalu Anya, a retired Chief Judge of Borno State, Margaret Ekpo and Jane Mokalu, both legislators in the old Eastern region, Austin Ezenwa, a former deputy governor in the Second Republic, Cyrus Nunnieh, a Second Republic senator, as well as others stated that "the on-going political process of that time would not promote a climate conducive to national unity, political stability and the welfare of the Nigerian people."

With the exit of Babangida from office, Ikoku found new outlet for his obstructionist antics to a quick return to democracy. As a government nominee to the constitutional conference under the government of Sani Abacha, he emerged as the touchstone for the defence of the military establishment. When the delegates voted overwhelmingly for the government to handover in 1996, Ikoku issued a statement to flail the delegates. Titled "Our March to Political Reconstruction," the statement condemned the 1996 handover date as unrealistic. In an argument more remarkable for its sophistry rather than its logic, Ikoku said that "The national constitutional conference has tended to bury its head in sand over the issues of putting an end to military intervention in the political arena while there is the tendency to confuse a terminal date with the termination of military intervention in politics."

Given his background, it was clear that Ikoku was being used as a catspaw for a pre-determined position by the administration. It was not surprising that contrary to its stated procedure, the conference revisited the issue of an exit date and ended up giving a blank cheque to the administration to relinquish power in its own time. This time around, Ikoku's blinding smoke on states creation may burst into an incandescent flame.

Like the many hurdles to Babangida's transition train, the report on states creation seemed to have been primed for a delay. That tardiness was planted way back in the last quarter of last year when the implementation of the transition time-table commenced. At the time, it was the government itself that failed to act on all the items listed for the very first quarter which included the inauguration of the states creation committee and other agencies of the transition programme. In fact, it was public outcry that the programme was already getting derailed that prompted the government to action. By then, the first quarter had lapsed leading to a spill over of first quarter agenda into the second.

As Joshua Ogbonnanya, a member of the constitutional conference pointed out, the State Creation Committee was not given enough time to carry out its assignments. It had five months to receive memoranda, study them, make verification of the claims by agitators and write a comprehensive report on its findings and recommendations.

Thus by May 31 when the committee was expected to submit its report, the panel had not agreed on what the recommendations should be. Thus, with only two weeks left in the quarter slated for the entire state creation exercise to be completed, the presidency had to issue an order for the committee to round up its work and submit a report to the head of state. The committee eventually did so on June 20, one month after the deadline. In the meantime, senior government officials and agencies had resorted to statements capable of undermining the work of the committee even before turning its recommendation in. Nasir was one such official. On several occasions, the TIC chairman openly condemned the agitation for states, thereby casting doubt on the sincerity of the government to go ahead with the exercise.

That doubt was heightened by a position paper believed to have been sent to the presidency by the Economic Intelligence Monitoring Committee of Samuel Aluko, arguing that the nation's economy was incapable os sustaining additional states. To compound the situation, the FRCN and NTA, two governmental broadcast stations joined in the campaign of denigration against state creation. With such discordant tunes from the government camp itself, it became apparent that the exercise could in fact hamstring the transition programme. Such fears were hardly helped by yet more reports that the administration is again considering setting up a panel of inquiry to investigate allegations that members of the committee were bribed by state agitators during their nationwide verification tours. The obvious conclusion is that the government may take time to see its way through the miasma of states creation. At any rate, the delay in laying the exercise to rest has been held responsible for the postponement of the promulgation of the 1995 constitution.

States creation aside, the issue of tenure for councilors now being bandied by Ikoku and company as a possible barrier to the exit date is even more inexplicable. When the administration announced the time-table of October 1 last year, Nigerians expressed dismay at the logic of conducting two local government elections in one year, the first one on non-party basis. Part of the criticisms then was that it would amount to a waste of resources: encourage graft in the elected officer; and help to distract attempts at party formation and registration. Several alternatives were suggested to the government. In fact, at the all-politician summit in December, the positions unequivocally rejected the plan to conduct council elections in March and December.

But the government rebuffed all suggestions. In reply, its officials argued that any alteration to the time-table will portray the government as unserious. Now the chickens are coming home to roost. The only apparent benefit seems to be that the non-party elections have provided a crop of loyalists to the administration at the grassroots level. As foreseen, the councilors are now importuning the state administrators and the presidency pleading for more time to enable them implement their programmes. Even now, many of the elected council officials are yet to settle down to business since they were inaugurated last March. They are still embroiled in election petitions against them at various tribunals, with many of the results being overtuned. Yet, the chaos in the third tier of government is now being cited as one of the compelling factors for a possible change in the handover date.

With the flows and ebbs in the transition programme, nothing seems to evoke the Babangida era more than the guidelines for party registration. Any hiccup arising from this part of the programme would appear to have been a wll orchestrated rehash from that past. Ironically, that is the major assignment for this quarter even as it seems doomed totatality. According to the requirements released three weeks ago, the associations have only four weeks to register a membership of 1,215 million each spread across all the states of the federation. The upshot is that the 23 associations which have procured their application forms at a cost of N500,000 each must recruit some 28 million Nigerians as card carrying members within this short period. Coming in the midst of the apathy created by the annulment of the presidential election and the clamp down on party formation until only recently, no honest association can be expected to fulfill this portion of the guidelines. Even in the last presidential election that was open to all adult Nigerians, only 14 million votes were recorded.

As if to make matters worse, the total population in some areas is less than the number of card-carrying party members required by the electoral authorities, Baba Galadima, an official of the All Nigeria Congress, has identified the federal capital territory, Abuja, as one such area. Says he: "The 1991 census figure for Abuja was about 300,000, so if you ask all the associations to produce 15,000 members each, all that population put together is more than 40,000 above the population." Taraba State is another. Yet, the ultimate Everest that the parties must surmount lies elsewhere: it is the crippling requirement that they must submit passport photographs of all their members. This is one venture that will consume huge finances from the parties, and impose impossible logistic problems. Galadima again: "I am not sure we have photographic materials worth N3 billion in this country even if the associations have the means and money to do it, the materials to perform that aspect cannot be obtained within the deadline." It is estimated that the political party would require N100 million to fulfill this requirement alone. Along with other requirements, it is conservatively estimated that the financial burden on each party for meeting the deadline in a state is N16 million. That translates to about N480 million for an association. In the event, it is surperfluous to note that apart from merger talks, the associations are deeply confused as to how to begin to go about satisfying the monumental demands of the electoral authorities.

Like it was under the Babangida regime, the only recourse open to the fledgling associations is to falsify figures and documents for registration, a task that is equally arduous and financially demanding. Yet, such recourse provides the fertile ground for disqualification and labeling of the political class as fraudulent. Authoritative sources last week revealed that a task force of security agents has been set up to monitor the activities of politicians and members of the various associations. The reports of this task force will play a major role in government's decisions on the registration exercise. Theweek learnt that like in the Babangida days, a mass disqualification of political associations might recur. The government, it is believed, might not go the whole Babangida hog of disqualifying all the associations and creating its own parties as it was done in 1989. What Abacha may do, according to sources is to demand for a second registration exercise with a modified set of guidelines. By then, the transition programme would have been off the course, with the ostensibly fraudulent politicians to blame for it. As a source sees it, the object is not only to stall the transition process, but to impoverish the political class to attenuate their influence on the programme. If that scenario plays out, only paperweight political aspirants who are more amenable to the administration's wiles would be left in the political terrain.

That route had been well trodden by Babangida. Just as the Abacha regime set up the constitutional conference to formulate a transition agenda, the Babangida regime impaneled a political bureau in 1986 to do preparatory work for a purportedly enduring transfer of power to civilians. That bureau, under Babangida's manipulation, was split, with some members recommending 1990 and others, 1994, for the handover of power, A committee appointed by Babangida himself settled for the half way date of 1992. Following impossible conditions for party registration, the administration disqualified 13 political associations that applied for registration for not meeting the requirements. It then proceeded to foist two government-created and sponsored political parties on the politicians. In 1992 when the presidential election became due, the administration encouraged a stalemate within the parties and thereafter disqualified the 23 aspirants. This necessitated an extension of the transition programme to 1993. Before the new exit date, the government inspired campaigns by certain individuals for Babangida to continue to rule. Such campaigns like those of Arthur Nzeribe's Association for Better Nigeria stated that "it is abundantly clear from the evaluation and assessment of the Transition Programme and the "newbreed" political and economic actors that Nigerians have so far not succeeded in laying a solid foundation for the Third Republic." From there, the obvious way was that "the presidential elections should be held in October 1996 and the civilian president be sworn in on January 2, 1997."

Unable to have its way at the bar of public opinion, the ABN took to the law courts where it created a gridlock of litigations under which the administration hid to nullify the presidential election held on June 12. 1993. When it came to Abacha's turn in 1993, he avoided the pitfall of naming a handover date. Its refrain then was its tenure would be brief and to be determined by the constitutional conference. Yet, when the conference in 1995 set the following year as handover date, the administration maneuvered the gathering into reversing itself and giving a blank cheque on which the government could write whatever tenure that pleased it. It did so on October 1, 1995 given itself an additional three years to the two it has spent. That period was supposed to embody a transition programme.

Now the chorus singers urging more years of military rule are back in business. To this group belongs Umaru Bukar Mandara of the National Solidarity People's Alliance, NSPA. And the Zanna of Borno. On June 8, Shehu Shagari, told the press that he had successfully midwifed an association consisting of 115 clubs across the country. He said the association was committed to the continued stay in office of Abacha as head of government after 1998. The NSPA, he said, is motivated by the good policies of the administration. "Nigerians," he said, "have never had it so good."

After his well-reported speech, there were reports that he was arrested. However close family sources said he was never arrested. Is Mandara and his NSPA then Abacha's equivalent of Nzeribe's ABN? Like Nzeribe, Mandara received only a slap on the wrist from information minister Walter Ofonagoro, who warned him to desist from his campaign. According to the minister, the government was not prepared to have another type of ABN which disrupted the transition programme of ex-president Babangida.

Curiously, Mandara's association was among those that picked registration forms for intending political parties. Also sharing Mandara's goal is Nzeribe. The former ABN chief is sponsoring another political group with the name of National Democratic Alliance, NDA. The NDA has declared that it is offering a platform for various categories of Nigerians, including serving military officers to aspire to elective offices. While the NDA was the first association to pick up registration form, Mandara's NSPA was the last, thus symbolically sandwiching all the other associations between them. An omen? Like other politicians who are also routing for Abacha not to go on the appointed date. Hyde Onuaguluchi, a former gubernatorial aspirant of the defunct National Republican Convention, NRC, in Enugu State, is one. In an interview with Theweek, the reverend-businessman said: "I think what we should ask ourselves is whether the time is ripe for a civilian president (or not)." He further added that "I think that the masses are happy with the sweeping changes going on in the society."

These orchestrations raise the spectre of David Mark, a brigadier-general retired by Abacha in its first attempt at consolidating his hold on power. Mark in an interview with Newswatch in 1994 had claimed that while making plans to seize power from the interim government of Ernest Shonekan, Abacha and Oladipo Diya, the chief of general staff, had preferred a prolonged stay in power by the military. "They wanted the regime to remain in power for a minimum of five years and a maximum of eight years." He said to fulfill his ambition, the Abacha government was adopting dilatory tactics such as "the conference, probe panel et cetera."

Even if the regime were stealing ideas from the Babangida regime, then it is doing so with added value of ingenuity. For example, instead of banning politicians as the Babangida regime did with Decree 25 of 1987, the Abacha government has continued to use security screening to preclude its "enemies" and their cronies from political power. Besides, the government has created policies which give it the twin advantage of clipping off the wings of over-ambitious politicians as well as winning public support. One such plan is the Failed Bank Tribunal Decree. The decree is aimed at restoring sanity to the finance sector by forcing individuals and corporation concerns who took loans and defaulted on the terms of payment, thereby contributing to the failure of many banks, to pay up or go to jail. The measures have sealed the fate of so many otherwise wealthy Nigerians who would have shown interest in politics or sponsored political parties. The seemingly undiscriminating application of the rules have won the government a lot of supporters. This policy-plan is one of the ostensible reasons why Onuaguluchi is pleading for more years for Abacha. Hear him: "The masses are happy with the Failed Banks Tribunal and the idea that there is no sacred cow in the society. The looting process is being stopped. Why are we in a hurry for any change? But we shouldn't change for changing sake, the economy is stabilising. The government should be allowed to conclude its programme."

The government is believed to have initiated such populist programmes to achieve exactly this kind of effect. The success of the Failed Bank Tribunal and the acceptance it has won the administration is encouraging it to set up another tribunal, this time around, to probe failed contracts and parastatals. Could the administration have synchronized this bold initiatives with the burgeoning campaign slogans of the Mandaras and the Onuaguluchis for such an exigent period as now?

All said, such domestic clamour for Abacha's tenacity of office is unlikely to jell with the international community. And probably with local politicians and oppostion groups who are already up in arms. From Ibadan where Layi Balogun, a former SDP presidential aspirant and Lam Adesina, a member of the Peoples Progressive Party, PPP, spoke, to Kaduna where Umaru Dikko, former minister of transport, expressed his view, to Enugu, where Chekwas Okorie, a chieftain of the Peoples Democratic Congress, PDC, vented his spleen, they all saw the Ikoku signal as an ominous sign of things to come. To them, the 1998 date was sacrosanct. Bristles Balogun: "The delay in the submission of reports on state creation is not enough a reason to alter the handover date." Ibrahim Mantu, a member of the Nigeria Centre Party warns: "if it becomes absolutely necessary for the transition programme to be amended, such an amendment should be restricted to the (date of) creation of states, local government and approval of the draft constitution." He warned against tampering with the exit date and programme for the formation of political parties. For him, "there is nowhere the creation of states or local governments can affect the transition process because what it involves is simply moving people into geographical boundaries."

Apparently jolted by developments, politicians have been canvassing among themselves for representatives of all the associations which took registration forms to meet with the government on the issue of guidelines and handover date. This idea was mooted by Dikko when he said that "unless politicians advise government on grey areas of the guidelines and the reason to allow people to form parties in a simple way, money politics cannot be eliminated." The idea has now caught on with all the associations. That same concern is growing in international circles. Just last week, Shinsuke Hirai, Japan's ambassador to Nigerian said that his country is closely monitoring the transition programme and declared that its completion on schedule is "the only antidote to the current stigma on Nigeria in the international community." Like Japan which has suspended all aid to Nigeria since 1993, the American government which hailed the recent releases of political detainees also expressed hope that the government will "continue to take such steps to improve the credibility of its commitments to the transition to civilian democratic rule." The Americans have refused to give the government a breathing space even after the transition programme was unfolded.

Perhaps, it is from the Commonwealth where Nigeria has only recently stanched the spate of sanctions against it that the government should expect the greatest resistance. While narrating the experience of the Nigerian delegation to London, Ikoku said other member nations showed outright aversion for continued military rule. He said "we have been reminded again that the outside world is disgusted with military rule." As Ikoku said, though the Nigerian delegation returned home beating its chest for having scored a big diplomatic victory, the CMAG members were distrustful of all the promises of smooth and timely transition to civil rule made by the delegation. Ikoku again: "Everywhere we go, they will say how are we sure it will not happen as it happened before (annulment)."

Some members of the commonwealth even took their suspicion to the level of proposing to finance and monitor the transition programme, an offer that was rejected by the Tom Ikimi-led delegation.

In all this, the ultimate Abacha surprise might come from elsewhere. As he continues to make the political waters murky, he has taken corresponding pains at trying to score a bull's eye on the economic front. If he succeeds before the exit date in applying the brakes to the hemorrhaging economy and turns it back to health, he could rightly expect a grateful nation to allow him have a change of clothing. It is perhaps in that direction that Nigerians and indeed the international community, should read Abacha's lip, like that of the former American President George Bush.

What is more, he has examples aplenty on the West Coast - from Jerry Rawlings of Ghana through Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso to Mainassara of Niger. More are on the way.

Cover date: July 15


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Nigeria Two Ministers Battle To Control Oil Inspections


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Ademola Adedoyin


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Lagos - It was the continuation of the battle from another front. When last Monday, Dan Etete, minister of petroleum resources, hosted officials of the Petroleum and Natural Gas Senior Staff Association, of the Department of Petroleum Resources branch in Lagos, Etete, for the umpteenth time, used the opportunity to assure the agitated unionist that he was solidly behind them in their agitation against the move to invite foreign inspectors for the nation's crude oil exports.

Sources at the closed door meeting called at the instance of the minister informed Theweek that Etete told the union members of his resolve to fight against the duplication of the functions of the department as such a move amounts to monumental waste of funds.

The controversy over the appointment of foreign inspectors to monitor crude oil exports came to a head early in the year when Ani claimed that he nation was losing about 150, 000 barrels of oil per day to buyers as a result of lapses of officials of DPR and those of other agencies charged with monitoring exports at the nation's terminals. The 150,000 barrels per day amount to eight per cent of the nation's total export of about 1.8 mbpd. Ani claimed to have had as his authorities the General Emmanuel Abisoye Panel of Enquiry on NNPC's report and that of the Major General Tajudeen Olanrewaju's panel which reviewed the report. Both reports are yet to be made public. 

Ani's pronouncement was, however, greeted with cynicism as officials of DPR and many oil analysts disputed the figure, insisting that there was no way Nigeria would have lost that much to overloading without adverse effect on producing companies and even the nation's budget. They insisted that contrary to Ani's pronouncement, the complaint from buyers has always been under loading, and that if there was overloading at all, it was nothing near Ani's figure.

Ani did not share this view and he made this clear. He went ahead last month to appoint two foreign firms - Global Inspection Services and Robinson International Agencies - to inspect the exportation and invoicing of crude oil at the terminals. Ani said their appointment would last two years at the first instance. Should the deal get the nod of the presidency, insiders claim that Nigeria would be poorer by about $330 million as payment for the two companies. Ani said the decree was in the offing to back up the new development.

Etete, however, has not taken this move, which he sees as undue interference in his ministry's affairs, lightly. Last October, long before Ani went ahead to appoint the foreign inspectors, Etete, in a letter to Ani, made exclusively available to Theweek, had said: "The appointment of any pre-shipment products inspection agent would be completely unnecessary. Such a measure would in fact be wasteful and only result in duplication of functions." He advised that "the funds earmarked for such misadventure should be better used to adequately equip the technical arm of my ministry (the Department of Petroleum Resources) in order to improve the discharge of its statutory obligations."

Theweek's investigations revealed that as at last week, the presidency was yet to make up its mind on who to support between Ani And Etete. Impeccable sources told Theweek that because of Etete's strong protest Sani Abacha, the head of state, has written two letters to Etete asking for further clarification on the issue. Etete himself confirmed this last Monday when he told the unionists that Abacha himself is interested in the matter and that he has written to ask for more details.

Information pieced together by Theweek shows that two weeks back, Etete and top officials of his ministry finalised a comprehensive policy proposal, which has been presented to the presidency. The presidency, according to sources, may have approved the proposal. One of the policy measures enumerated in the proposal is to make DPR a stronger, more responsive and well-funded outfit.

Etete promised the unionists last Monday that DPR, in line with the proposal will also soon answer a new name. He, however, did not promise them the autonomous status which they have been demanding since 1988 when they were merged with the ministry of petroleum resources.

Etete, according to sources at the meeting, also assured the unionists that a number of governmental agencies and commissions are behind DPR and are convinced that the department, give all the necessary tools and right incentives, would perform efficiently. One of such commissions is the National Economic Intelligence Committee. Theweek's investigations revealed that the committee has remained a formidable opponent of Ani's invitation of the two foreign agents to the nation's oil terminals. The agency is said to hold strongly to the view that a foreign inspector working with multinational oil companies who are selling Nigeria's crude oil to foreign buyers may not necessarily protect the nation's interest.

This view tallies with that of officials of DPR, who in a letter to Abacha last month revealed that for the department to function effectively, it requires just about 10 percent of the $330 million which was likely to be paid to the two foreign firms. The department complained of non-availability of basic tools like helicopters and vehicles. The DPR had told the presidency in a memo last year that it required about N1 billion to function effectively. The department believes that this bill is not outrageous given the fact that it generates about N40 billion annually.

Indeed, it seems like the vital department is deprived of funds given the fact that for 1996, only N67 million is allocated to it as capital expenditure, an amount it says is hardly enough to meet its basic needs. More troubling is the fact that half-way into the year, only a paltry N6 million has been released to the department. So serious is the department's financial predicament that the staff have not been paid their salaries in the past three months.

Funds apart, the department insists that given the procedure for the exportation of crude oil, it is not possible to lose about 150,00 bpd through topping. Topping is used to describe any further loading of crude oil in any available space in the export ship after loading the nominated and approved quantity of crude oil at designated and approved terminals. Asked the unionists: "Which terminal owner (i.e. oil producing companies) would allow her crude oil production to be given free to charge to a buyer?"

Disputing the logic behind Ani's invitation of foreign inspectors to combat the alleged collaboration of government agencies with foreign buyers, the union raised a poser in their letter to Abacha: "What will now happen under the wise men arrangement of appointing foreign inspecting agents to verify foreign oil producing companies, foreign terminals, foreign buyers, and foreign ships under the control of foreigners at the terminals?"

The department's seemingly brilliant argument does not seem to have convinced Ani. Sources at the ministry of finance told Theweek last Thursday that Ani is pushing ahead for the promulgation of the decree heralding the arrival of the two foreign inspectors. He is also said to have continued the negotiations with the two foreign firms. Ani is said to be convinced that even if the overloading is not as high as 150,00 bpd, there are still cases of overloading and that only experts, in this case foreign ones, can set the records straight.

While Ani is working real hard to push his policy through, Etete too is said to have intensified lobby to make the presidency reject Ani's measures. It is yet to be seen who among the two men will carry the day.

Cover date: July 15


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Gambia Koikoi Sanyang: Coup Plotter and Quintessential Rebel


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 15, 1996 by Theo Nichol


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lagos - It was a peculiar setting, not one of those coup plot stories already common in places like Nigeria and Ghana before 1984. For the first time since The Gambia became independent in 1965, the peace and tranquility of that tiny West African country was shattered that cool early morning of September 2, 1981 with the news that some junior military officers led by one rather obscure 28-year old called Koikoi Sambo Sanyang had sacked the 16-year old government of the revered President Dauda Jawara.

Koikoi, a brave revolutionary, had seized the opportunity of the absence from home of Jawara, who was attending the royal wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana in London, to stage his coup. And his was successful until the Senegalese military intervened and drove away the rebels. Compared to the French-trained Senegalese troops, the Gambians were more or less boys' scouts. 

At the end of the putsch, Jawara returned home to continue his reign while Koikoi fled into exile. Since that night when he left, he has been living in different countries in the West Africa sub-region: Ghana, Burkina Faso, Togo, Ivory Coast and Liberia, doing what he know best; supporting anti-government struggles.

Theweek recently tracked down Koikoi in Ivory Coast and then met his close aides in The Gambia and Ghana.

Koikoi, according to sources, assisted in the revolution which brought Jerry Rawlings, then a redundant flight-lieutenant in Ghana, to power in 1981. But after the success of that revolution, Rawlings dumped Koikoi, who had to move to Burkina Faso, which was then brewing its own revolution under the leadership of Thomas Sankara, a captain the Burkinabe army. There, Koikoi met with Foday Sankoh, now the Rebel United Front of Sierra Leone, and Charles Taylor, leader of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia. The three men joined hands in organising their rebel forces to seize power in their different countries.

According to Koikoi's close aides, things didn't work out too well between Sankara and these three rebels, who believed that the only way to get to power was through the barrel of the gun. Given the cold shoulder by Sankara, the three teamed up with Blaise Compaore, a captain and Sankara's deputy and, assisted by the late Houphet-Boigny of Ivory Coast, eliminated Sankara, whom they considered a stumbling block to their ambitions.

After Compaore seized power, he compensated Koikoi and co by providing a base for them at Po in Burkina Faso for the training of their commandos. According to the master plan of Taylor, Sankoh and Koikoi, three neighbouring countries were to be the target of the armed struggle. Sierra Leone was listed as the first to be attacked, but the rebels found a problem in late Samuel Doe who refused to give them a base to operate. They were to change their plans when in 1989, Houphouet-Boigny provided a base for them to attack Liberia under the banner of the NPFL. Koikoi became the artillery commander for the NPFL and lived in Buchanan, Liberia, as Taylor's second in command, with his Gambian troops heading various wings of the NPFL.

But in Liberia, like in Ghana, Koikoi's contributions were not adequately rewarded by Taylor, Koikoi soon left and returned to Burkina Faso, where he later had problems with Compaore over some ideological differences. Frustrated, Koikoi had to go back to Ghana, to live with friends in a bungalow in Lapaz, a surburb of Accra.

In frustration Koikoi later left for Togo, where things got worse for him. He fell sick and almost died. Miraculously, he survived. Some diplomatic moves were later made by the Nigerian government to get him to meet Yayah Jammeh, the new military leader of The Gambia and the second revolutionary to stage a coup there. Koikoi, however, suspected foul play in the initiative and refused to turn up in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, for the proposed meeting.

For now, he lives a good lie in Danane, supported materially by friends who live abroad and from spoils from his men in the battle-fields of Liberia. He is described as a devout family man though separated from his Burkinabe wife.

Cover date: July 15


LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Gambia The Gambia At Political Crossroads


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Swaebou Conateh, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 2017 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia (PANA) - Gambia's military-led government will be two years in power on July 22, amid some apprehension over when exactly civilian rule will be restored in the country.

Although developments towards that goal have been in line, the military government has not yet made a clear move to liberalize the political system.

Those who say progress is being made were emboldened in their belief by the statement of the Commonwealth Action Group that its meeting in June with the Gambian leader, Capt.Yahya Jammeh, in Banjul, was a good one.

The group, comprising Canada, Ghana and New Zealand, is to review the progress Gambia and Nigeria are making towards civilian rule. 

Observers of the Gambian political scene now say the remaining task for government is to lift the ban on political activity, imposed when it seized power July 22, 1994.

In spite of the Commonwealth's positive statement, some detractors hold a different view and have pointed to various factors to support their cautiousness. Among them is a statement Jammeh made, at a recent rally, that the holding of elections depended on the Gambian people.

On June 28, Jammeh, who heads the Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council (AFPRC), was quoted by the state-owned newspaper, The Gambia Daily, as telling a traditional chief that "there will soon be elections, as scheduled."

"The Head of State said it is in the hands of the people of The Gambia, not the AFPRC -- just as the people had asked the AFPRC to rule for two years, not for the period of four years the Government had previously announced," the newspaper said.

Skeptics saw contradictions in this position because the wishes of the people were expressed clearly when they objected to a four-year military administration proclaimed by Jammeh in October 1994. The feelings of Gambians on this issue were expressed in a January 1995 report by a National Consultative Committee, whose chairman was Lenrie Peters, a surgeon and poet.

The four-year program Jammeh announced in October 1994 had engendered adverse reaction within and outside the country. It plunged many people into despondency and, by November 1994, mutinous soldiers engaged the AFPRC government in a futile and bloody counter-coup.

Soon there were more political casualties: The government accused ousted Finance Minister Bakary Dabo, the only member of the former regime allowed to retain his cabinet post, of being the chief civilian co-conspirator in the foiled coup. He fled the country.

Next came a crippling economic measure taken by Britain. It issued a travel advisory warning British nationals to stay away from Gambia because of what it said was the unstable political and security situation there.

Overnight, Gambia's tourist industry, which receives the majority of its visitors from the Britain, grounded to a halt as travel agents pulled out en masse. Most hotels closed operations, throwing at least 10,000 Gambians out of jobs.

It was during this period of national disquiet that the government, in December 1994, set up the National Consultative Committee to ask Gambians whether or not they agreed with the four-year transition timetable.

The two-year transition period preferred by Gambians caused division within the ranks of the AFPRC. Subsequently, the council's much disliked vice-chairman, Capt. Sana Sabally, and the Interior Minister, Sadibou Haidara, were arrested and detained for allegedly attempting to assassinate Capt. Jammeh. Haidara died in detention while Sabally was tried and sentenced to nine years in prison by a military tribunal.

Although the government accepted the consultative committee's report, it rejected recommendations for the installation of an interim government and for a National Consultative Committee on a new constitution, to be adopted after the proposed review of the country's 1970 constitution.

Instead, it appointed a Constitutional Review Commission under the chairmanship of a Ghanaian judge. Subsequently government was to hold a referendum at which the population would decide on whether or not to adopt the new constitution.

Nonetheless, the adoption of a two-year timetable gave the AFPRC government some respite. Many Gambians relaxed all opposition to it, so as not to provide the military with an excuse to extend its stay.

Meanwhile, the government adopted a two-pronged strategy of compressing its four-year programme within the stipulated two-year limit. It embarked on programmes ranging from civic education to constitutional review, voter registration, the appointment of an electoral commission and promised to unban political parties by March, 1996 -- some three months before elections in July, 1996.

Nothing worked according to plan and problems piled up. Financial assistance from such traditional donors as the European Community, the United States and British governments were cut.

However, Jammeh's government cultivated new friends in Libya and Taiwan. Quickly, funds began to flow in for various development projects. These ranged from a new airport terminal to a national television service as well as to an up-country referral hospital and various middle and high schools.

A university extension programme was also developed with some Canadian institutions (Gambia has never had a university). Construction of a million dollar arch in commemoration of the July 22 takeover was also started.

Various anti-corruption commissions were set up to probe the record of the ousted government. Initially meant to complete their work within a six month period, some of these commissions are still grinding on, even though the public no longer appears shocked by the revelations which had won many of them over to the military government.

Belatedly, the constitution was finally reviewed by a Constitutional Review Commission. An official version has been published for public debate and input, prior to the presentation of a final version to a referendum scheduled for Aug. 7, 1996.

The Provisional Independent Electoral Commission was also set up, late, and has been engaged in implementing the transition process.

After consultation with the Government, it set the date for the referendum and for presidential elections at September 11, 1996, and parliamentary elections for December 11, 1996.

It also embarked on the registration of voters, an exercise which was concluded June 22, 1996. But its Chairman, retired educationist Gabriel Roberts, has said that the lifting of the ban on party politics would have to be done by the government.

Gambians however wonder what the government's next move will be. They note the failure to meet past datelines and the activities of the July 22 Movement, which has been campaigning in favor of government policies and the extension of military rule under Jammeh.

There feelings among Gambians that, like a good soldier, Jammeh could be seriously preparing for some other eventuality. Developments in the next few days will certainly show whatever eventuality, if any, that may be.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Supports Libya Against U.S., Britain and France


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity has come out strongly on the side of Libya in its crisis with the United States, Britain and France.

In a draft resolution passed Saturday night, the OAU Council of Ministers meeting here called on the United Nations Security Council to lift the sanctions imposed on Libya. 

The council warned that the continued imposition of sanctions against Libya "may compel African states to look into possible means of sparing Libya further suffering".

The council also said it supports Libya in its demand for "appropriate compensation" for the loss of human lives and material damage inflicted as a result of the "unjust sanctions".

Libya is under economic sanctions, including a ban on international air travel, imposed by the Security Council, following accusations that it harbored two men suspected of being involved in the bombing of an American airliner which crashed over Lockerbie, Scotland, several years ago. The sanctions were sponsored by the U.S., Britain and France.

The council said it was convinced that the proposal made by Libya that the suspects be tried in the Hague by Scottish judges in accordance with Scottish law was acceptable.

The proposal has enjoyed wide international support as "a practical solution of the problem."

The ministers called on the US, Britain and France to consider this proposal.

In brief statement to the council earlier, the head of the Libyan delegation said his country had never opted for confrontation with the three western countries and wanted to arrive at a quick solution acceptable to all the parties.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Niger Niger Elections Enter Second Day


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 160 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The first round of the presidential election in Niger, which started Sunday, continued in some regions on Monday. 

This followed a decision Sunday by the National Electoral Commission, to spread voting over the two days following logistical problems in some constituencies.

The commission had earlier asked government to postpone the elections to enable it sort out the problems. Government had refused.

There are five presidential candidates in the race, including the head of the ruling military regime Gen. Ibrahim Bare Mainassara.

He seized power in a military coup from a civilian government crippled by internal wrangling in January.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Ethiopia Senior Ethiopian Minister Escapes Assassination


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A senior Ethiopian minister, Abdulmegid Hussein, escaped assassination Monday, by two assailants in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

However the assassins, who managed to escape, killed a security officer and a policemen, Addis Ababa radio reported. 

Hussein, the transport and communications minister, was wounded in the arm, the radio said, quoting a government spokesman.

The gunmen opened fire as Hussein was stepping out of his car to go to his office in the ministry building in central Addis Ababa. The incident took place at about 8.30 a.m. (0530 GMT).

The two assailants were reported to have escaped in a car they seized at gun point. They were described as young men with Somali features. The hijacked car was later found some three kilometers from the scene of the shooting.

Hussein is chairman of the Ethiopian Somali Democratic League, the ruling party in the Ethiopian Somali region.

A number of Ethiopian Somali opposition groups accuse the league, and Hussein, of rigging Ethiopia's 1995 federal and state elections. Prominent among the accusers has been the Ogaden National Liberation Front, which has been at odds with the league and the federal government. The Ogaden front has launched occasional attacks on government forces in the vast Ogaden area of eastern Ethiopia. Hussein has been closely identified with the ruling Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front, since the fall of Ethiopia's Marxist regime in May 1991. He served as external relations and cooperation minister until a multiparty federal government was formed in Ethiopia in August 1995.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Mozambique Mozambique's Premier Supports Boutros-Ghali


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican Prime Minister, Pascoal
Mocumbi, said Monday that he favors a second term of office for the incumbent United Nations Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt.

Speaking at a Maputo news briefing, Mocumbi said he thought "it would be unjust not to allow Boutros-Ghali a second term." 

The United States administration is said it will not support a second term for Boutros-Ghali.

Mocumbi declined to comment on the United States position. However, he noted it was normal practice to allow a UN Secretary-General serve a second term of office.

He said there would have to be "very strong reasons" -- such as the death of or an incapacitating illness -- for a change to occur only at the end of the first term.

Mocumbi doubted that within the next two or three months a new candidate could appear "with a serious plan for restructuring the UN." He feared that any new plan produced would have been drawn up in haste, and would be worthless.

"We defend the interests of Africa, and we have to assess what Boutros-Ghali has done for Africa, how he has carried out his promises, and what proposals he has for a second term," said the prime minister.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


West Africa Nigeria Accuses Cameroon of Preparing Military Offensive


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military government has accused Cameroon of rejecting peace overtures and opting for a military solution to the dispute over the oil-rich Bakassi Peninsula.

An official statement issued late Sunday accused Cameroon of preparing to launch a major military offensive against Nigeria. 

Tom Ikimi, Nigeria's foreign minister, said in the statement that "Cameroon is actively engaged in a massive troop build-up and mobilization of heavy military equipment along our frontier."

He said Cameroon was doing this with the "full support and involvement of international collaborators and professional mercenaries."

The statement came ahead of the annual summit of African leaders that opened Monday in the Cameroonian capital, Yaounde. It was also in response to a letter dated June 19, 1996, from the Cameroonian foreign minister, Ferdinand Oyono, alleging that Nigeria had been amassing troops along the border since May 13.

Oyono also said the Nigerian government was constructing structures, including a police station, in parts of the of peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea.

Ikimi dismissed the allegations as "baseless" and accused Cameroon of constantly showing total disregard for international law.

Nigeria and Cameroon have been engaged in a longstanding dispute over ownership of the Bakassi Peninsula, rich in oil and maritime resources.

Both countries have stationed troops on their sides of the peninsula and have constantly blamed one another for breaking the uneasy cease-fire established in the area.

The two countries have referred the matter to the International Court of Justice for a solution.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Gambia The Gambia At Political Crossroads


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Swaebou Conateh, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia (PANA) - Gambia's military-led government will be two years in power on July 22, amid some apprehension over when exactly civilian rule will be restored in the country.

Although developments towards that goal have been in line, the military government has not yet made a clear move to liberalize the political system.

Those who say progress is being made were emboldened in their belief by the statement of the Commonwealth Action Group that its meeting in June with the Gambian leader, Capt.Yahya Jammeh, in Banjul, was a good one.

The group, comprising Canada, Ghana and New Zealand, is to review the progress Gambia and Nigeria are making towards civilian rule. 

Observers of the Gambian political scene now say the remaining task for government is to lift the ban on political activity, imposed when it seized power July 22, 1994.

In spite of the Commonwealth's positive statement, some detractors hold a different view and have pointed to various factors to support their cautiousness. Among them is a statement Jammeh made, at a recent rally, that the holding of elections depended on the Gambian people.

On June 28, Jammeh, who heads the Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council (AFPRC), was quoted by the state-owned newspaper, The Gambia Daily, as telling a traditional chief that "there will soon be elections, as scheduled."

"The Head of State said it is in the hands of the people of The Gambia, not the AFPRC -- just as the people had asked the AFPRC to rule for two years, not for the period of four years the Government had previously announced," the newspaper said.

Skeptics saw contradictions in this position because the wishes of the people were expressed clearly when they objected to a four-year military administration proclaimed by Jammeh in October 1994. The feelings of Gambians on this issue were expressed in a January 1995 report by a National Consultative Committee, whose chairman was Lenrie Peters, a surgeon and poet.

The four-year program Jammeh announced in October 1994 had engendered adverse reaction within and outside the country. It plunged many people into despondency and, by November 1994, mutinous soldiers engaged the AFPRC government in a futile and bloody counter-coup.

Soon there were more political casualties: The government accused ousted Finance Minister Bakary Dabo, the only member of the former regime allowed to retain his cabinet post, of being the chief civilian co-conspirator in the foiled coup. He fled the country.

Next came a crippling economic measure taken by Britain. It issued a travel advisory warning British nationals to stay away from Gambia because of what it said was the unstable political and security situation there.

Overnight, Gambia's tourist industry, which receives the majority of its visitors from the Britain, grounded to a halt as travel agents pulled out en masse. Most hotels closed operations, throwing at least 10,000 Gambians out of jobs.

It was during this period of national disquiet that the government, in December 1994, set up the National Consultative Committee to ask Gambians whether or not they agreed with the four-year transition timetable.

The two-year transition period preferred by Gambians caused division within the ranks of the AFPRC. Subsequently, the council's much disliked vice-chairman, Capt. Sana Sabally, and the Interior Minister, Sadibou Haidara, were arrested and detained for allegedly attempting to assassinate Capt. Jammeh. Haidara died in detention while Sabally was tried and sentenced to nine years in prison by a military tribunal.

Although the government accepted the consultative committee's report, it rejected recommendations for the installation of an interim government and for a National Consultative Committee on a new constitution, to be adopted after the proposed review of the country's 1970 constitution.

Instead, it appointed a Constitutional Review Commission under the chairmanship of a Ghanaian judge. Subsequently government was to hold a referendum at which the population would decide on whether or not to adopt the new constitution.

Nonetheless, the adoption of a two-year timetable gave the AFPRC government some respite. Many Gambians relaxed all opposition to it, so as not to provide the military with an excuse to extend its stay.

Meanwhile, the government adopted a two-pronged strategy of compressing its four-year programme within the stipulated two-year limit. It embarked on programmes ranging from civic education to constitutional review, voter registration, the appointment of an electoral commission and promised to unban political parties by March, 1996 -- some three months before elections in July, 1996.

Nothing worked according to plan and problems piled up. Financial assistance from such traditional donors as the European Community, the United States and British governments were cut.

However, Jammeh's government cultivated new friends in Libya and Taiwan. Quickly, funds began to flow in for various development projects. These ranged from a new airport terminal to a national television service as well as to an up-country referral hospital and various middle and high schools.

A university extension programme was also developed with some Canadian institutions (Gambia has never had a university). Construction of a million dollar arch in commemoration of the July 22 takeover was also started.

Various anti-corruption commissions were set up to probe the record of the ousted government. Initially meant to complete their work within a six month period, some of these commissions are still grinding on, even though the public no longer appears shocked by the revelations which had won many of them over to the military government.

Belatedly, the constitution was finally reviewed by a Constitutional Review Commission. An official version has been published for public debate and input, prior to the presentation of a final version to a referendum scheduled for Aug. 7, 1996.

The Provisional Independent Electoral Commission was also set up, late, and has been engaged in implementing the transition process.

After consultation with the Government, it set the date for the referendum and for presidential elections at September 11, 1996, and parliamentary elections for December 11, 1996.

It also embarked on the registration of voters, an exercise which was concluded June 22, 1996. But its Chairman, retired educationist Gabriel Roberts, has said that the lifting of the ban on party politics would have to be done by the government.

Gambians however wonder what the government's next move will be. They note the failure to meet past datelines and the activities of the July 22 Movement, which has been campaigning in favor of government policies and the extension of military rule under Jammeh.

There feelings among Gambians that, like a good soldier, Jammeh could be seriously preparing for some other eventuality. Developments in the next few days will certainly show whatever eventuality, if any, that may be.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Supports Libya Against U.S., Britain and France


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity has come out strongly on the side of Libya in its crisis with the United States, Britain and France.

In a draft resolution passed Saturday night, the OAU Council of Ministers meeting here called on the United Nations Security Council to lift the sanctions imposed on Libya. 

The council warned that the continued imposition of sanctions against Libya "may compel African states to look into possible means of sparing Libya further suffering".

The council also said it supports Libya in its demand for "appropriate compensation" for the loss of human lives and material damage inflicted as a result of the "unjust sanctions".

Libya is under economic sanctions, including a ban on international air travel, imposed by the Security Council, following accusations that it harbored two men suspected of being involved in the bombing of an American airliner which crashed over Lockerbie, Scotland, several years ago. The sanctions were sponsored by the U.S., Britain and France.

The council said it was convinced that the proposal made by Libya that the suspects be tried in the Hague by Scottish judges in accordance with Scottish law was acceptable.

The proposal has enjoyed wide international support as "a practical solution of the problem."

The ministers called on the US, Britain and France to consider this proposal.

In brief statement to the council earlier, the head of the Libyan delegation said his country had never opted for confrontation with the three western countries and wanted to arrive at a quick solution acceptable to all the parties.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Niger Niger Elections Enter Second Day


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 160 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The first round of the presidential election in Niger, which started Sunday, continued in some regions on Monday. 

This followed a decision Sunday by the National Electoral Commission, to spread voting over the two days following logistical problems in some constituencies.

The commission had earlier asked government to postpone the elections to enable it sort out the problems. Government had refused.

There are five presidential candidates in the race, including the head of the ruling military regime Gen. Ibrahim Bare Mainassara.

He seized power in a military coup from a civilian government crippled by internal wrangling in January.

Africa News


July, 1996


Ethiopia Senior Ethiopian Minister Escapes Assassination


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A senior Ethiopian minister, Abdulmegid Hussein, escaped assassination Monday, by two assailants in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

However the assassins, who managed to escape, killed a security officer and a policemen, Addis Ababa radio reported. 

Hussein, the transport and communications minister, was wounded in the arm, the radio said, quoting a government spokesman.

The gunmen opened fire as Hussein was stepping out of his car to go to his office in the ministry building in central Addis Ababa. The incident took place at about 8.30 a.m. (0530 GMT).

The two assailants were reported to have escaped in a car they seized at gun point. They were described as young men with Somali features. The hijacked car was later found some three kilometers from the scene of the shooting.

Hussein is chairman of the Ethiopian Somali Democratic League, the ruling party in the Ethiopian Somali region.

A number of Ethiopian Somali opposition groups accuse the league, and Hussein, of rigging Ethiopia's 1995 federal and state elections. Prominent among the accusers has been the Ogaden National Liberation Front, which has been at odds with the league and the federal government. The Ogaden front has launched occasional attacks on government forces in the vast Ogaden area of eastern Ethiopia. Hussein has been closely identified with the ruling Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front, since the fall of Ethiopia's Marxist regime in May 1991. He served as external relations and cooperation minister until a multiparty federal government was formed in Ethiopia in August 1995.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Mozambique Mozambique's Premier Supports Boutros-Ghali


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican Prime Minister, Pascoal
Mocumbi, said Monday that he favors a second term of office for the incumbent United Nations Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt.

Speaking at a Maputo news briefing, Mocumbi said he thought "it would be unjust not to allow Boutros-Ghali a second term." 

The United States administration is said it will not support a second term for Boutros-Ghali.

Mocumbi declined to comment on the United States position. However, he noted it was normal practice to allow a UN Secretary-General serve a second term of office.

He said there would have to be "very strong reasons" -- such as the death of or an incapacitating illness -- for a change to occur only at the end of the first term.

Mocumbi doubted that within the next two or three months a new candidate could appear "with a serious plan for restructuring the UN." He feared that any new plan produced would have been drawn up in haste, and would be worthless.

"We defend the interests of Africa, and we have to assess what Boutros-Ghali has done for Africa, how he has carried out his promises, and what proposals he has for a second term," said the prime minister.


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
