Africa News


July, 1996


Burundi Burundians At Loggerheads With Region Over Military Force


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 8, 1996 by A Correspondent


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Nairobi - Burundi appears to be heading towards political deadlock with East African regional leaders over coming deployment of an African military force to stabilise the war-torn central African nation.

Regional leaders see the military force as a peacekeeping force that would try to end the civil war which pits the minority Tutsi- dominated army against rebels from the Hutu majority, but Burundi's leaders maintain that they expect only "cooperation" and "assistance."

However, extremists on both sides are warning that the arrival of foreign troops would spark a full-scale civil war.

Burundi's Hutu President and Tutsi Prime Minister joined up the previous week to make a reluctant appeal to a regional summit in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha to help contain the fighting, in which most of the casualties are villagers, acknowledging that they could not stop the violence.

The request by President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya and Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo created a firestorm at home, with accusations flying that they were traitors, and thereby forcing them to backtrack, insisting that the force must be under a Burundian command, and saying that Burundi will define its mandate and its missions. 

The backtracking has run directly counter to what delegates from five African countries said at a meeting of a technical commission in Arusha on July 1, that the force should be a peacekeeping one with an independent command.

The host of the meeting in Arusha, Tanzanian Foreign Minister, Jakaya Kikwete, said the proposed peacekeeping force would not be looking for a fight but would nonetheless mean business.

"We don't want the troops to go to Burundi and fight anybody. We would like the troops to go there and keep peace, but with the capability to deal with those who are going to break the peace," he stated.

Kikwete refused to say which countries might send troops to Burundi and which might lead the force, but an official who took part in the meeting said on condition of anonymity that Tanzania, Uganda and Ethiopia might be willing to dispatch troops.

Kikwete said that when the Organization of African Unity (OAU), meeting at a summit in Cameroon starting on July 8, and the United Nations had given their blessing to the operation, implementation of the projects could begin.

The regional peacekeeping force would have to allow a national dialogue in Burundi to take place in a calm atmosphere, Kikwete stressed.

The delegations present at the July 1 Arusha meeting were from Burundi, Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Ethiopia, with Kenya participating as an observer.

The commission set up a panel of military experts to plan the details, with soldiers from Tanzania, Uganda and Ethiopia expected to provide the force's backbone.

That panel met on July 2 under the chairmanship of Tanzania's army commander, and is expected to arrive in the Burundian capital Bujumbura by the July 6 to 7 weekend.

The meeting took place despite a request from the Burundi delegation for a delay because preliminary studies had not been completed in Bujumbura. These studies are supposed to be delivered by July 3 to Burundi's national security council, its top security authority.

But observers saw the biggest problem in Burundi as being the defining of the mandate for the force. One that would be acceptable to the Tutsis, who make up only 14 per cent of the population but hold the levers of power, and the Hutus, who make up 85 per cent of the population, a definition some diplomats in the Burundian capital said would be an impossible task in view of the distrust and fear that pervades tiny Burundi, about the size of the Scottish highlands but with a population of 5.5 million people.

Ntibantunganya is widely believed to have long privately favoured the intervention of foreign troops as peacekeepers, but that is a position which must be nuanced in public.

The real surprise at last week's summit was that the Prime Minister joined the President in appealing for foreign troops, but only as a result of strong pressure from the region -- and particularly from the United States and the European Union.

Both have pledged not to provide any money for development until the situation is stabilised, though agreeing to contmnue emergency humanitarian aid for the tens of thousands of Burundians displaced by the fighting.

Money is the key, diplomats said, with Burundi's economy in tatters and the government fast running out of cash to pay soldiers and civil servants.

But one diplomat said the concept of the foreign intervention was agreed to too hastily, and was so vague "that there won't be any follow-up."

He noted that the army remained ferociously opposed to any foreign intervention, and said its leaders were only emitting "signs of goodwill."

The Tutsis in Burundi are opposed to Tanzanian participation in any force, and the Hutus are adamantly against the participation of Ungandans as a result of President Yoweri Museveni's support for the Tutsis in Rwanda during that neighbouring country's 1994 civil war, which left between 500,000 and one million people dead. The Hutus believe Ethiopian troops would also support the Burundian army.

The presidential camp in Burundi envisages the force as one which would place itself between the army and the rebels, providing a calm atmosphere for a national debate on how to resolve the three-year- old crisis.

But army spokesman Longin Minani declared that Burundi's soldiers would continue to fight the "genocidal" Hutu rebels, and would defeat them, even with the presence of foreign troops in the country, and suggested that the troops be deployed along the borders with Zaire and Tanzania to stop Hutu refugees in those countries making cross-border raids.

Minani also said that Burundi's powerful Defence Ministry had also demanded that the technical commission meeting in Arusha hold its future meetings in Bujumbura, pointing out: "They have to be in the field. That was foreseen, and it would be absurd for them to meet elsewhere."

Meanwhile, Hutu extremists in PALIPEHUTU -- the Party for the Liberation of the Hutu People -- said they saw the force as "coming to help the mono-ethnic Tutsi army, which is in trouble," while Mathias Hitimana, president of the Tutsi extremist Party for the Reconciliation of the People, declared on July 2 that the arrival of foreign troops would mark "the real start of the civil war," with Tutsis forming guerrilla bands.

The looming deadlock comes amid reports of continuing fighting in several parts of the country which has forced new movements of refugees and displaced persons.

According to an announcement on July 2 by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), some 4,000 Burundians, most of them Hutus who said they had fled ethnic violence, have arrived in Zaire and Rwanda since the last weekend.

The UNHCR quoted the refugees, who came from the north-western Burundian region of Cibitoke, where three members of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and three Roman Catholic clergy were killed last month, as saying that their homes had been burnt and members of their families killed.

Since the incident, no humanitarian organisation has been working in the region.

Clashes between ethnic Hutus and Tutsis are continuing, according to witness reports from the refugees.

UNHCR spokesman Ron Redmond, who said the agency was extremely concerned about the violence, added that 2,500 Burundians had arrived in Bugarama, south-western Rwanda, after failing to reach Zaire because the border is closed, while a further 1,900 arrived in Uvira, eastern Zaire, on July 1.

In total, there were an estimated 223,000 Burundians in neighbouring countries, most of whom are concentrated in Uvira and Tanzania.

Fighting began in Burundi two-and-a-half years ago following the assassination of its first Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye, in a coup attempt by Tutsi soldiers.

Tens of thousands of Burundians have since been killed in ethnic fighting which has now spread throughout the tiny country and become a civil war.

July, 1996


Sao Tome and Principe Voters Force A Run-Off Election


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Sao Tome - Sao Tome and Principe President Miguel Trovoada and a former Marxist ruler Manuel Pinto Da Costa finished neck-and-neck in the country's first elections held on June 30 and will face each other in a run-off on July 21, election officials announced on July 2.

Trovoada defied pre-election opinion polls in this tiny and impoverished twin-island state off the coast of West Africa and finished first in the election with 40.85 per cent of the votes, the electoral commission said.

He ended up slightly ahead of the 39.14 per cent for the favourite, former president Manuel Pinto Da Costa, who ruled from 1975, when the country won independence from Portugal, until 1991 at the head of a single-party Marxist-Leninist state. 

The electorate totaled 52,000 out of a population of 120,000 people, a 65 per cent turnout.

There were a total of five candidates, including former premier Carlos Da Graca, running in a campaign dominated by growing unemployment, rising inflation and shortages of basic necessities.

Graca had asked the commission to extend the poll to account for the delay, but many polling booths were unable to stay open beyond dusk anyway because of lack of lighting.

Ahead of the runoff, all eyes will be on the third-place finisher, former Foreign Minister Alda Bandeira, one of the first women in Africa to run for president, to see which candidate she endorses.

With 14.63 per cent of the votes, Bandeira was the candidate of the Democratic Convergence Party, the only group not represented in the coalition government in power since January.

Bandeira said after the first round results were announced that she was ready to negotiate with Trovoada and Da Costa, because "in a democracy, one must be open."

The third candidate was journalist and anti-corruption campaigner Armindo Tomba. Last week's presidential election was the country's first featuring more than one candidate. When Trovoada was elected in 1991, his two rivals pulled out before election day.

Over the two-week campaign, observers had noted a fall-off in enthusiasm for the outgoing president amid economic problems and political uncertainty.

Fifteen foreign observers from France, Portugal, the United States and the Organization of African Unity (OAU) are monitoring the polls.

Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Inkatha Tops In KwaZulu But ANC Grabs Foothold


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Pietermaritzburg - The Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) remained the top political force in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal province after local elections held there on June 26, but the ruling African National Congress (ANC) gained a major foothold in urban areas, final results showed on July 1.

Chief Mongosuthu Buthelezi's IFP obtained 44.4 per cent of the total vote compared to 33 per cent for President Nelson Mandela's ANC, a report by the IFP-dominated KwaZulu provincial government said.

In the April 1994 general elections -- the previous electoral exercise in the violence-torn province -- the IFP obtained 50.3 per cent against the ANC's 32.2 per cent. 

"The ANC has consolidated its support in KwaZulu-Natal cities, but the IFP overwhelmingly affirmed its strength in rural areas," election spokesman Warwick Dorning said.

Ex-president Frederick de Klerk's conservative National Party (NP) was third in the June 26 poll with 12.7 per cent of the vote, followed by the Liberal Democratic Party with 3.3 per cent, and the Indian-based Minority Front with 2.3 per cent.

Independent candidates took 2.9 per cent of the vote, with other smaller parties collecting less than 1 per cent each.

The IFP won a landslide in rural areas, with 393 regional councils compared to 113 for the ANC, the report showed.

The situation was the opposite in the cities. The ANC was in the lead, winning 135 councils in Durban compared to 21 for the IFP, and another 252 in other urban areas of the province against 144 for the IFP.

Both the ANC and IFP on July 2 claimed victory in the elections. IFP secretary-general Ziba Jiyane claimed his "was still the clear majority party," despite winning less than 50 per cent of the votes cast. "If some of the voting problems had been sorted out, we would have won 55 or even 60 per cent of the vote," he said, adding the IFP will legally contest the results in some areas of Durban.

ANC spokesman Carl Niehaus said, meanwhile, that his party leaders were "more than happy" with winning "important urban areas." "We have done much better than we expected ourselves, when you take into consideration that there is still not complete freedom of political expression in some rural areas," he said.

Niehaus noted that in addition to winning the cities, the ANC had improved its rural showing from five per cent in 1994 to 17 per cent on June 26.

Nearly 20,000 people have been killed in 11 years of fighting between the two parties, including more than 300 people and nine election candidates since February.

About 32,000 of the 1.5 million-odd voters who were registered in last week's poll will cast their votes later this year because of technical problems at several voting stations.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Kenya Two Kenyan Catholic Bishops Elevated


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service July 8, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nairobi - Maurice Cardinal Otunga, the head of the Metropolitan Catholic Archdiocese of Nairobi, on July 3 consecrated Rev. Alfred Kipkoech Rotich the Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Nairobi in charge of the Military Vicariate, one month after Pope John Paul II appointed him (Rotich) to the position.

In his new position, Bishop Rotich, 39, will be responsible for the Military Vicariate, which according to the Catholic Church pastoral set-up is equivalent to a diocese.

Covering all the armed forces, the Military Vicariate was established by the Vatican in January 1981. 

Addressing the congregation after the consecration, Cardinal Otunga told the new bishop: "You have been incorporated into the college of bishops, the direct representatives of the 12 Disciples, who followed Jesus Christ."

Cardinal Otunga also reminded the newly consecrated bishop that "the function of the bishop is not one of honour; but to serve and not rule."

The head of the Catholic Church in Kenya also reminded the congregation, which included the top brass of the military led by the Chief of General Staff Mohammud Mohamed, that as Christians, they "should guard the Christian faith against interference from people driven by selfishness and personal ambition."

And in his address, General Mohammud Mohamed said his office will give priority to religious issues. He also announced that plans were underway to put up a cathedral at the Eastleigh Air Base, where the July 3 consecration ceremony took place.

"History has shown that a religious soldier is more loyal, disciplined and diligent than a non-religious," General Mohamed said.

The new appointment of Rev. Rotich and his subsequent consecration as bishop comes in the wake of the appointment of Kenyan Catholic bishop for Nakuru Diocese, the Rt. Rev. Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki as coadjutor (Assistant) Archbishop of the Nairobi Archdiocese. Pope John Paul II made the appointment on June 27.

A statement released by the Vatican Embassy here on Bishop Ndingi's appointment said in part; "This gives Bishop Ndingi the right of succession if and when the incumbent Archbishop of Nairobi retires." Maurice Cardinal Otunga, the incumbent Archbishop of Nairobi assumed this position in 1973.

Bishop Ndingi, 65, who has been the head of the Nakuru Diocese for the last 25 years and whom the late Pope Paul VI consecrated bishop in 1969, has often rubbed shoulders with state authorities in the wrong way, due to his open criticism of matters touching on all forms of injustice.

Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Effects Felt from Non-Racial Constitution


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Washington, DC - On May 8th, 1996, the Republic of South Africa promulgated its first non-racial Constitution, thereby officially ending the transition from apartheid to universal democracy. The new document establishes the framework for a society which respects the rights of all individuals, regardless of age, race, or sex. However, the Constitution is not without its points of contention. 

Most importantly, the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP), which controls the KwaZulu/Natal provincial legislature, has boycotted the Constitutional Assembly to protest the document's federal character. Led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, Inkatha has consistently opposed a strong central government. Despite the IFP boycott and repeated calls for international mediation, the Constitutional Assembly outlined specific powers reserved solely for the provinces, such as road-building and sports administration. Ultimately, the battle for federalism/confederalism will have to be fought in the nation's new Constitutional Court.

Additionally, several Afrikaner-based groups decried the new Constitution for its emphasis on universal standards of education. They feel that the Afrikaans language is an integral part of their ethnic identity and have been actively promoting the idea of single-language schools. Although these groups were unable to muster significant support for their proposal, the new document does not necessarily outlaw single-language schools.

Lastly, the African National Congress (ANC), the party most responsible for the new Constitution, has been divided by a "lock-out" clause which would guarantee employers the right to lock out striking employees. While the ANC's traditional base of support in the labour unions has vehemently protested the clause, the party's more progressive wing has acknowledged that such a clause would improve South Africa's tarnished image as a country with labour problems. In an effort to block the inclusion of the clause, the labour unions staged a one-day, nation-wide strike on April 30th. However, the strike was poorly attended and an obscure reference to a labour relations code was unceremoniously inserted into the Constitution.

All in all, South Africa's first non-racial Constitution remains purposefully vague on a number of divisive issues like regional powers, single-language schools, and employer's rights. The document's authors recognized the futility of trying to prepare for every possible situation that might arise. Instead, the constitutional negotiators concentrated on the new society they were building and unambiguously depicted the rights and prerogatives of the individuals therein.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Sudan Sanctions Take Effect, War Spreads


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Washington, DC - On April 26, 1996, the UN Security Council voted - 13 to 0 with Russia and China abstaining - to impose diplomatic sanctions against the Sudan. Sudan had passed the deadline for handing over three suspects in the attempted assassination of Egyptian President Mubarak; Sudan is allegedly harboring the suspects. The sanctions included reducing the number of Sudanese diplomats in a country, departure of terrorist groups with headquarters in Sudan and banning of international conferences in the Sudan.

The sanctions were milder than the U.S., Britain and Ethiopia had hoped for. Egypt, who at first had pressed for harsher sanctions, backed down in the end, saying economic sanctions would make the Sudanese suffer and an arms embargo would endanger the unity of the Sudan. Egypt would not like to see an independent Southern Sudan controlling the waters of the Nile on which Egypt is so dependent. 

The Security Council gave the Sudan two weeks to turn over the suspects. After this the sanctions went into effect, to be reviewed in two months' time if the suspects are still not handed over. This will be early July.

Russia and China abstained because they feel sanctions on the Sudan is one embargo too many. They, plus others, including Iran, and Syria, have stated they will not adhere to that part of he sanctions which asks governments to reduce the number of Sudanese diplomats in their country.

Sudan has said the sanctions are inconvenient but not crippling. It has also said it will screen foreign organizations based in the Sudan.

The Civil War

1. The war can no longer be called "the war in the South."

It has spread to the Nuba Mountains for some time now. And there are recent reports that the Sudan Allied Forces (SAF), one of the military wings of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), has launched attacks in the North, near the town of Kassala. The SAF is a splinter group of former Sudanese army troops who escaped Sudan after the '89 coup. 2. Several of the SPLA factions (headed by Riek Machar, Kerubino Kwanyin Bol,) have signed a "political charter" with Khartoum; it is supposed to be the initiation of a peace process.

Most analysts are not taking the charter seriously. It has been denounced by Garang as a "sell-out". (Garang has been joined by another splinter faction, headed by John Luc.) surprisingly, the charter has gained support from Joseph Lagu, a former vice-president under Nimeiri, who had been living outside Sudan for the last three years. He still commands some support in the South, especially his home region of Equatoria. He has just returned to the Sudan. 3. The situation in the Nuba Mountains continues to worsen. It is not considered the "South" and is therefore not eligible for OLS (Operation Lifeline Sudan) relief. Reports of atrocities continue - villages burned and looted, people rounded up into "peace camps"which are more like concentration camps, land taken over by mechanized framing - but because very few people have access to the Nuba Mountains, hard evidence is difficult to come by.

One issue which perhaps needs more emphasis and which affects the Nuba, the SPLA and the northern opposition is the question of land.

For ordinary people in the South and the marginalised areas of the North, one of the main reasons why they are fighting is because of land. People became fed up with government officials and merchants seizing their ancestral lands; they took up arms to defend what was rightfully theirs.

Even before the recent atrocities, there has been a history of land confiscation. And to make matters worse, the land is being confiscated by rich merchants who use mechanized farming. It is well documented that mechanical cultivation rapidly degrades the topsoil, making the land vulnerable to wind erosion. Commercial farmers (mostly NIF supporters) are given 25-year leases on the land; the farmers exploit the land ruthlessly so that after a few years the land is so degraded that it is unusable. This has happened already in the North.

The government has been redistributing land to reward its followers.

The issue of land, along with the issues of sharia law and self-determination, will have to be dealt with in any peace negotiations.

IMF Relations

In early May an IMF team spent a week in the Sudan. A report will be issued later on Sudan's economy in the period between January and April.

Relations with the IMF have been difficult for a decade because of Sudan's failure to pay arrears which have now reached $1.7 billion.

Relations took a turn for the better last year when Khartoum began to make a token payment of $4 million per month as a sign of good will.

The talks ended without a debt arrears pact. The IMF is expected to discuss its relations with Sudan at a meeting in August.
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zaire Rwanda and Zaire: The Situation Grows More Complicated


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Washington, DC - The situation in Zaire has become more critical and more complicated in the last few months. Fierce fighting has broken out in Masisi, one of the most fertile areas in Zaire. Living in the area were Rwandan Hutus (Zairean Hutus now), some of whom have been there since the 1900's, Rwandan Tutsis who fled the violence in the 1950's, Zairean Tutsis who were in Zaire when the border was finalized, and other Zairean groups such as the Hunde.

Fighting in this area has broken out from time to time over the years. It has worsened since the large influx of Hutu refugees in '94. 

What appears to be happening is that the refugees have moved from the camps into Hutu villages in Masisi and are now joining with the Hutus in Zaire to drive out the minority Tutsis and establish a "Hutuland" in this rich agricultural land of northeastern Zaire.

Reports over the last two months say that at least 65,000 Tutsis have been displaced from their homes in Masisi; 11,000 have fled to Rwanda. Camps must now be opened in Rwanda because Zairean Tutsis are not entitled to repatriation. Many of the refugees are traumatized after days of terror. In one area 3000 Tutsis are trapped in two villages because of the fighting and a massacre is feared. At least 100 Tutsis have already been e movement of the displaced.

Meanwhile border raids from the camps into Rwanda continue. The Zairean troops have arrested more than 50 of the ringleaders in the camps. But refugees are still not going back in large numbers.

Events in Rwanda

Inside Rwanda, the security situation has worsened in some areas. It seems the rebels have become bolder and the army more on the defensive.

Both sides have been involved in attacks. Some of the incidents which have been reported in recent months:

- A woman was slaughtered; the evidence indicated that she was killed by genocide criminals who want to exterminate disturbing survivors and witnesses (25 such cases have been documented by African Rights).

- Infiltrators attacked a military prison in an attempt to free inmates; there was a clash with the army; the army killed at least 19 men (April).

- An armed gang burnt the entire Karengera township and freed the prisoners from the local prison (May).

- Rebels from Zaire raided local government offices and attacked three villages in Cyangugu region, killing at least 37 people. This was the worst attack since the end of the war in '94. Cyangugu fears civil war will start again.

- Shortly after the above attack, infiltrators attacked a jail near the border and killed more than 30 prisoners. It is unclear why the prisoners were killed.

Progress of Rwanda's Tribunal/Justice System

After two years, the Tribunal has indicted only eleven suspects. It is greatly hampered by lack of funds and by rivalry with the Rwandan Government who wants to try the suspects itself. One of the chief suspects, Theoneste Bagosora, who was arrested in Cameroon, is wanted also by the Belgian government for the slaying of ten Belgian peacekeepers. Since Cameroon has no extradition treaty with Rwanda, it has been a haven for genocide suspects. There is some indication, however, that Bagosora will be sent to the Tribunal.

Three suspects from Zambia are to be arraigned and transferred to Arusha, the seat of the Tribunal. They will be the first to go on trial. They include: Clement Kayishema, former governor of Kibuye who allegedly helped organize the slaughters in Kibuye where 90% of Tutsi residents were killed; George Anderson Rutaganda and Jean Paul Akaseyu, both charged with organizing and leading massacres in other areas.

Whereas the Tribunal has too few suspects in custody, the Rwandan justice system has too many. There are now more than 70,000 suspects in Rwanda's grossly overcrowded jails. Some attempts have been made to ameliorate prison conditions. And the Rwandan government is preparing to begin some trials.

In a surprise move, a U.S. court ordered a Rwandan suspected of war crimes to pay $105 million to relations of massacre victims. The Rwandan government was pleased that at least one suspect had been found guilty but troubled that the money was not allocated to build Rwanda.

Arms Flow

In addition to the culture of impunity, the flow of arms into the Great Lakes Region is another factor which exacerbates the situation.

A UN commission of inquiry uncovered strong evidence that Zaire had a part in shipping arms to soldiers of the former Rwandan army living in the camps. In April, the UN Security Council decided the commission should continue probing the arms flow to the camps. UN observers are to monitor airfield and other transport points.

The UN has also set up a trust fund to demilitarize central Africa and curb the flow of arms into the region. The trust fund will finance activities promoting "confidence-Building measures" and will support transparency in military acquisitions. An arms register will be set up.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Burundi Burundi Violence Grows Without Worldwide Attention


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

Washington, DC - Because the crisis in Burundi has not degenerated into a full scale massacre such as that in Rwanda in 1994, the gravity of the present crisis has perhaps not yet fully penetrated our minds. With an estimated 100 people dying per week, tens of thousands of refugees still fleeing to Zaire and Tanzania, thousands more displaced from their homes within Burundi, the situation is comparable to an all-out, if undeclared, war.

For a while the trouble was in Bujumbura and in the north; now it has spread to other parts of the country. Rebel soldiers have stepped up attacks in the south. Military observers said there have been seven attacks on Bururi in the last two weeks of May. The central province of Gitega, according to a senior military source, is caught in "total war" following the massacre in Buhoro of 235 civilians by the army after rebels had massacred some civilians there. Another massacre, for which the army is also blamed, of 200 people occurred in Bubanza (see map).The army continues to deny the massacres but eye witnesses have testified that they occurred. Human rights groups say that both rebels and the army almost routinely kill civilians. 

Bujumbura has been systematically ethnically cleansed (some call it "Tutsiville"). Hundreds of thousands of displaced people are sheltered and fed by aid groups. Rebels are now threatening Bujumbura; they say their purpose is not to attack but to get the army to talk.

The rebels, operating from Zaire, are believed to have gained ground this year. The President has criticized the army, saying guerrillas are operating with impunity both in the capital and in the interior.

The rebels appear to have access to sophisticated weapons, including land mines.

Recently three Swiss workers for the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) were killed in the North. Both sides are blaming the other; there was international protest at the killing of workers from a group such as ICRC.

Positions of the Different Groups

Political analysts say the Hutu are alarmed by the Tutsi-dominated army while the Tutsi are afraid of the Hutu masses. Only dialogue can bring a solution.

Militarily, there are several groups involved:

- the Tutsi-dominated army which, according to many, is the real power in Burundi and is not under the control of the government. Some also believe that the army is the main cause of the instability. (The army has been in control of Burundi for years.)

- Tutsi militia, composed of Tutsi extremists, and probably backed by the army

- CNDD (National Council for Defense and Democracy), the main rebel group operating from Zaire. It is pursuing an insurgency campaign to demand greater power. Its leader is Leonard Nyangoma, a former Minister in the government of the assassinated Pres. Melchior Ndadaye.

- other Hutu militia, composed of extremists. Politically there are:

- FRODEBU, the majority political party, mostly Hutu to which the President Sylvester Ntibantunganya, belongs and winner of the last elections.

- UPRONA, the opposition party, mainly Tutsi, to which the Prime Minister, Antoine Nduyawe belongs. The government is a fragile coalition of the two parties. Currently, the hard-liners on all sides refuse to negotiate. The rebels say they will refuse until Ndadaye's assassins are brought to trial. The Tutsi military and UPRONA refuse to negotiate with rebels they say are advocating genocide.

It is becoming more and more difficult for the President and the Prime Minister to come together. The Prime Minister has refused to negotiate with Nyangoma. The latter, although he had last month vowed to overthrow the government, is now willing to negotiate with the army which he feels is the real power. The army is not willing and the President maintains the negotiations must be with the government and not the army.

It is difficult to see how it can all be resolved and yet the only viable solution is through dialogue.

The President has recently demanded more accountability from the army; it is not certain whether they will heed the call.

Outside Intervention

The extent of outside intervention does show a great amount of concern on the part of the international community. It has yet to prove effective.

1. Julius Nyerere, former Tanzanian President and OAU envoy. Many people have put their hopes in the mediation of Nyerere; he is highly respected by the Bunrundians themselves. But the first round of talks last month ended inconclusively. Only FRODEBU and UPRONA representatives were present; CNND and other rebels were not invited.

The two parties agreed to condemn violence and criminality in Burundi and to seek the support of the international community in ending the crisis. But they could not agree on a formula of how to dismantle Hutu and Tutsi militias. Nyerere expressed regret at the decision not to invite the rebels. A second round of talks was convened on June 4. It has also ended without real agreement. It was Nyerere's opinion that UPRONA was most responsible for the impasse. UPRONA was insisting that CNDD be condemned. Nyerere warned that time is running out for Burundi. Another round of talks is planned.

2. OAU

The OAU renewed its observer mission to Burundi for three months; it now expires July 23. The OAU took this action to fulfill its responsibility and to support Nyerere's peace efforts. The mission. however, is strapped for funds.

3. UN

Boutros Ghali has stated publicly his fears that Burundi may erupt like Rwanda. He recommended that the UN establish a standby force to intervene quickly in case of a major upsurge in violence. He said that organizing such a force is beyond UN capabilities but urged key member states to take the initiative. The U.S. has stated it is prepared to help with logistics, transport and communications but not troops.

Meanwhile UPRONA, the army, the rebels all strongly denounce the idea of UN military intervention.

4. Visits of U.S. envoys

The number of envoys sent by the U.S. in April and May to visit Burundi shows there is a high level of concern:

- Brian Atwood, head of USAID, gave the message that aid to Burundi would discontinue until there was meaningful dialogue with opposing parties. Only emergency humanitarian aid would continue. Atwood traveled with Emma Bonino, the EU representative for humanitarian relief.

- Richard Bogosian, the U.S. Special Coordinator for the region, asked the government to probe the recent massacre reports from Buhoro and Bubanza.

- John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, condemned the recent massacres and told the warring factions that the U.S. would not recognize any government that came to power in a coup.

In a statement to Congress, Shattuck said the extremists are manipulating ethnic differences for their own narrow ends. Moderates are afraid to exercise leadership and isolate extremists because of personal danger.

- Anthony Lake, National Security Advisor, and George Moose, Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, paid a seven-hour visit to Burundi.

Lake warned the extremists; He said he was dismayed by the deterioration of the situation since he visited 18 months ago. In talks with the President and Prime Minister, Lake said the tension in Burundi is a major focus of U.S. foreign policy.

In a recent statement, the State Department has declared that genocide has been committed in Burundi by both sides. The U.S. is not under legal obligation to take action but because genocide is a violation of international law, cases of genocide may be taken to the UN and intervention sought. Tribunals may also be established.

Relations with Zaire

At the beginning of the year, an estimated 110,000 Burundian refugees were living in Zaire. This number has swelled in the last few months as thousands more fled to escape the recent violence. In an attempt, to stop the flow of refugees, Burundi in early May closed its side of the border.

In mid-May, the Prime Minister of Zaire, Kengo wa Dondo, visited Bujumbura. Although Zaire constantly denies that the refugee camps are havens for Hutu dissidents, it is well known that CNDD is operating from Zaire.

During the talks, Burundi and Zaire decided to reactivate a joint committee in defense and security established in '95. The committee will examine the accusations and come up with suggestions on how to resolve the matter.

While Kengo's visit is seen as an attempt to restore normal relations, observers believe it was motivated by the economic pinch Zaire is feeling from the border closure.

Schools in Burundi were affected by the border closure; Zairean teachers were stranded. Some schools had to close.

Many Hutu members of the 81-seat national assembly, fearing assassination by Tutsi extremists, live in Zaire and commute to Bujumbura for the semi-annual parliamentary sessions. (See advocacy section for action on Burundi.)
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Liberia Peace Delayed Is Peace Denied


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Washington, DC - Monrovia in the last few weeks has faced what is now known as a "semblance of peace." But war-wearied Liberians want more than a semblance of peace, they want the real thing: lasting and durable peace, an opportunity to put their lives back together.

Liberia, perhaps more than any other nation in West Africa, has suffered sufficiently. After more than six years of a brutal civil war that has left more than 200,000 dead, 800,000 others as refugees and more than a million displaced, Liberia deserves the good-will of people everywhere to end their nightmare. They deserve a special support from the United States of America government. 

That is why when the United States reportedly committed additional funding for the peace efforts in Liberia, that pronouncement was greeted with gratitude. But the U.S. still has not delivered. This delay in delivering the promised required resources to ECOMOG has historically compounded the suffering of the Liberian people.

Following the signing of the Abuja Accord in August 1995, a donor conference was held in New York in October at which time the United States promised $10 million in support for peace keeping activities. Less than half of that money was disbursed before the April 6th flare-up in fighting. All along, the urgency for the delivery of the funding was established but the U.S. would not act speedily.

It has been at least three weeks since a degree of calm has returned to Monrovia. A partial disarmament of some of the fighters who were holed up at the Barclay Training Center has taken place. The momentum towards more disarmament is greater given the following variables:

A. The largest warring faction, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) is in retreat. Mr. Taylor is reported to have set up a new military post in Totota. To coerce Mr. Taylor into disarming his men while he is in retreat is more likely than after he has regrouped and is re-supplied.

B. Some of the most hard-core fighters of the Liberia Peace Council (LPC), United Liberation Movement for Democracy- ULIMO/J faction is in Monrovia and more accessible. They can therefore be more easily disarmed and encamped but if they are allowed to return to the rural area, something which is now being allowed, it would be more difficult, if not futile, to disarm when they are in the bush.

C. Peace keeping soldiers have been patrolling Monrovia effectively and have set up check points around Camp Schiefflein and the Pynesville intersection. This has enabled them to partially monitor movement into and out of Monrovia.

D. A seeming crack is occurring between the two allies - Taylor of the NPFL and Kromah of the ULIMO-K faction who visited upon the Liberian people their most recent rendezvous with deaths, mayhem and destruction. Whereas Taylor has stated that he wants elections in August come hell or hot water, Mr. Kromah has stated that disarmamment should take place before elections.

This momentum must be built upon. The peacekeepers need to be provided the necessary logistics they have continuously requested and have been promised on countless occasions but never delivered. These logistics including all-terrain vehicles, communication gears, field hospitals, and adequate funding must be delivered as a matter of urgency, if the United States is really serious about assisting the Liberian people end the war.

Additionally, the augmentation of the peacekeeping force must be pursued expeditiously. Perhaps one reason why April 6 occurred was because Liberian warlords were convinced that given ECOMOG lack of an overwhelming force in Monrovia, they could get away with whatever they wanted. They must not be provided with that option again. ECOMOG must have the strength it needs to deter any behaviour on the part of the Liberian warlords which would jeopardize the safety of Liberians in the country.

Liberia's porous border with its neighbors, especially Guinea and La Cote d'Ivoire is cause for concern. The June 7 cross border raids by forces believed to be NPFL soldiers into Toulepleau, la Cote d'Ivoire, resulted in the death of 14 Liberian refugees. During the week of June 17, ULIMO-K forces, on an apparent foraging mission for food, over-ran the town of Yaragbara in Guinea wounding at least a dozen Liberian refugees. The death toll is yet to be announced. Earlier, on March 15 at least 35 persons were killed, several homes were burned down by the same group. The Guineans have now said that they will begin to pursue the rebel soldiers into Liberian territories.

In order to prevent these cross border raids and the continuous flow of arms into Liberia, these borders need a more effective monitoring. Guinea and La Cote d'Ivoire have to be persuaded and supported to achieve that.

ECOMOG's ability to return Monrovia, Buchanan and Kakata to their former safe haven status can only come about if a successful disarmament takes place. This will have the desired effect of convincing Liberians that they need not take to sea in unworthy sea vessels which are repeatedly denied docking rights by neighboring countries. No amount of condemnation from the rich nations of the world will make West African government take in these refugees, especially when these very rich nations are not perceived as urgently and concretely assisting the movement towards a peaceful settlement of the Liberian war. It is high time then, that promised assistance for the Liberian peace process be delivered immediately. For many Liberians, peace delayed is peace denied.
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Rwanda Rwanda and Zaire: The Situation Grows More Complicated


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, DC) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Washington, DC - The situation in Zaire has become more critical and more complicated in the last few months. Fierce fighting has broken out in Masisi, one of the most fertile areas in Zaire. Living in the area were Rwandan Hutus (Zairean Hutus now), some of whom have been there since the 1900's, Rwandan Tutsis who fled the violence in the 1950's, Zairean Tutsis who were in Zaire when the border was finalized, and other Zairean groups such as the Hunde.

Fighting in this area has broken out from time to time over the years. It has worsened since the large influx of Hutu refugees in '94. 

What appears to be happening is that the refugees have moved from the camps into Hutu villages in Masisi and are now joining with the Hutus in Zaire to drive out the minority Tutsis and establish a "Hutuland" in this rich agricultural land of northeastern Zaire.

Reports over the last two months say that at least 65,000 Tutsis have been displaced from their homes in Masisi; 11,000 have fled to Rwanda. Camps must now be opened in Rwanda because Zairean Tutsis are not entitled to repatriation. Many of the refugees are traumatized after days of terror. In one area 3000 Tutsis are trapped in two villages because of the fighting and a massacre is feared. At least 100 Tutsis have already been e movement of the displaced.

Meanwhile border raids from the camps into Rwanda continue. The Zairean troops have arrested more than 50 of the ringleaders in the camps. But refugees are still not going back in large numbers.

Events in Rwanda

Inside Rwanda, the security situation has worsened in some areas. It seems the rebels have become bolder and the army more on the defensive.

Both sides have been involved in attacks. Some of the incidents which have been reported in recent months:

- A woman was slaughtered; the evidence indicated that she was killed by genocide criminals who want to exterminate disturbing survivors and witnesses (25 such cases have been documented by African Rights).

- Infiltrators attacked a military prison in an attempt to free inmates; there was a clash with the army; the army killed at least 19 men (April).

- An armed gang burnt the entire Karengera township and freed the prisoners from the local prison (May).

- Rebels from Zaire raided local government offices and attacked three villages in Cyangugu region, killing at least 37 people. This was the worst attack since the end of the war in '94. Cyangugu fears civil war will start again.

- Shortly after the above attack, infiltrators attacked a jail near the border and killed more than 30 prisoners. It is unclear why the prisoners were killed.

Progress of Rwanda's Tribunal/Justice System

After two years, the Tribunal has indicted only eleven suspects. It is greatly hampered by lack of funds and by rivalry with the Rwandan Government who wants to try the suspects itself. One of the chief suspects, Theoneste Bagosora, who was arrested in Cameroon, is wanted also by the Belgian government for the slaying of ten Belgian peacekeepers. Since Cameroon has no extradition treaty with Rwanda, it has been a haven for genocide suspects. There is some indication, however, that Bagosora will be sent to the Tribunal.

Three suspects from Zambia are to be arraigned and transferred to Arusha, the seat of the Tribunal. They will be the first to go on trial. They include: Clement Kayishema, former governor of Kibuye who allegedly helped organize the slaughters in Kibuye where 90% of Tutsi residents were killed; George Anderson Rutaganda and Jean Paul Akaseyu, both charged with organizing and leading massacres in other areas.

Whereas the Tribunal has too few suspects in custody, the Rwandan justice system has too many. There are now more than 70,000 suspects in Rwanda's grossly overcrowded jails. Some attempts have been made to ameliorate prison conditions. And the Rwandan government is preparing to begin some trials.

In a surprise move, a U.S. court ordered a Rwandan suspected of war crimes to pay $105 million to relations of massacre victims. The Rwandan government was pleased that at least one suspect had been found guilty but troubled that the money was not allocated to build Rwanda.

Arms Flow

In addition to the culture of impunity, the flow of arms into the Great Lakes Region is another factor which exacerbates the situation.

A UN commission of inquiry uncovered strong evidence that Zaire had a part in shipping arms to soldiers of the former Rwandan army living in the camps. In April, the UN Security Council decided the commission should continue probing the arms flow to the camps. UN observers are to monitor airfield and other transport points.

The UN has also set up a trust fund to demilitarize central Africa and curb the flow of arms into the region. The trust fund will finance activities promoting "confidence-Building measures" and will support transparency in military acquisitions. An arms register will be set up.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - General Basketball: Zambian Group Raises Fund For Basketball Tournament


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 8, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Basketball Association (ZBA) has finally managed to raise eight million kwacha to send the junior national teams for a regional tournament in South Africa.

Association general secretary, Mwembe Kaona, said in an interview on Friday that the Zambia under-17 boys and girls teams will finally compete in South Africa. 

"We have at least managed to raise the required amount of money and the teams are leaving on Monday (today). As an association, we are happy with the help some companies gave us," said Kaona in an interview at Hotel-Intercontinental during a fund-raising dinner dance .

Last Friday, Kaona expressed fears that Zambia could miss the event after failure to raise K8m more to supplement the K4m raised earlier for the trip to South Africa.

The competition, which starts this week , will be contested by Swaziland, South Africa, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Angola, Mozambique and Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Mine Sale Partially Approved


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 5, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 
Livingstone - Government has approved the 80 percent sale of the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) through modalities worked out by the Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA).

ZPA chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, said in Livingstone yesterday during a ZPA forum organised for Southern Province businessmen that ZPA would soon announce modalities of the 80 percent sale of the part of ZCCM which will include Konkola and Mufulira mines. 

He said he was happy with the arragements so far reached and expected that the country would not be on the receiving end since all sales are aimed at improving the companies sold and making profit for the country.

Mr Chitalu said there was a lot of transparency in the way ZPA was handling the privatisation of companies and that anybody was welcome to visit their offices to find out.

Several opposition political parties have spoken against the sale of ZCCM which they have said was the life line of the country, but the continued heavy burden assumed by government in sustaining the mines has prompted government to approve the sale of the mines.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Cashew Farmers Doomed


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 7, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Livingstone - More than ten thousand cashewnut farmers in western province are facing an uncertain future following the confirmed decision of the Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) to liquidate the only market and firm assiting farmers there.

ZPA chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, accompanied by senior officials disclosed the sad development in Livingstone at Musi-wo-Tunya Hotel. 

Mr. Chitalu said the Zambia Cashew Company upon which the entire cashewnut project is dependent has to be liquidated soonest because of the losses suffered by this ventures.

He expressed worry at the fate of western province farmers who stopped the conventional farming methods and went through cashewnut growing saying the liquidation of the ZCC would affect their livehood.

Mr. Chitalu claimed that foreign investors who would have taken over the project and made it into one of the most vibrant farming projects had been hindered by matters of land which is controlled by the Barostse Royal Establishment.

He said investors were not secure after discovering the stronghold on land by the royal establishment and hence none had shown interest so far.

The cashewnut project in Western Province developed problems after key shareholders BP Africa, Zambia State Insurance Corporation, Landell Mills and Zambia National Provident Fund slowly withdrew leaving ZCC with no support financially.

Farmers growing cashewnuts have to wait for ten years before any meaningful profit has to be seen.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Zambia Explores Peace Studies


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 7, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Lusaka - Two Irish military officers arrived in the country today to explore the possibilities of establishing a United Nations peacekeeping wing at the Zambia Military Academy in Kamwala.

Commandant Ray Quinn and Lt-Col Oliver Macdonald will be in the country for 14 days. 

Lt-Col Macdonald said in an interview on arrival at the Lusaka International Airport that Zambia deserves a UN peacekeeping wing because of the good reputation she has established.

He said Ireland had a long history of peacekeeping dating as far back as 1958 when the first troops went to Lebanon as observers.

And Colonel Evaristo Chewe from the Zambia Army said the two officers will also conduct lectures concerning UN peacekeeping at the military school.

Zambia is among countries in Africa which frequently sent peacekeeping troops under UN to war troubled countries and the performance of the soldiers has been highly reputable.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Malawi and Zambia Zambia And Malawi Tighten Trade Links


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 7, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Ndola - Zambia and Malawi, through their respetive chambers of commerce and industry, are to improve on their trade ties by holding a joint trade exhibition in the border town of Chipata from September 20 - 22.

ZAM-NEWS, a monthly publication of the Zambia Chamber of Commerce and Industry, says the exhibition will help to promote official trade between Zambia and Malawi.

The exhibition also aims at showing Chipata-based businessmen Zambian products which they can sell to Malawi. 

The publication notes that thousands of dollars worth of Zambian goods cross into Malawi every day by courtesy of the hundreds of cross border travellers.

The chamber of commerce and industry would like to encourage this trade formally because it increases output of members' factories.

Meanwhile the Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) has warned that without a real and lasting development of export markets, the country will sink into terminal depression.

ZAM recalled that in the aftermath of the second world war, the British government coined the slogan 'export or die' to regenerate its industry and the phrase can be taken literally for the Zambian situation.

The associations says in its monthly publication, Zam News, that there is a direct link between what a country produces for export and the standard of living of its citizens.

The ongoing discussions regarding the various bi-lateral and multi-lateral trade agreements offer a vast potential for Zambia to enter new markets and boost the country's export earnings.

The association called for improved quality standard, competitiveness and market orienttion to boost exports.

The possibility of a real' level playing field' exists in various fora of negotiation and members must be ready to reap the benefits this will provide.

The publication reveals that there are many organisations offering assitance to firms wishing to enter the export market.

One of them is the European development fund which has financed an export development programme mounted by the government.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa-at-Large OAU Summit Opening On Course


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 7, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 
Yaounde - President Frederick Chiluba was expected to be among the heads of state and government witnessing the official opening of the 32nd summit meeting of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) in the capital of Cameroun - Yaounde.

The summit was scheduled to be opened by the organisation's outgoing chairman, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. 

Host president, who is the incoming chairman of OAU, Paul Biya will also address the summit.

Afterwards Heads of State and government will go into a closed meeting.

United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, OAU Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim and President of the Palestine National Authority and Chairman of the Executive Committee of the PLO, Mr. Yasser Arafat.

The conference hall was a hive of activity with traditional dancers performed outside to entertain delegates as they came for the summit.

Business and Finance Zambian Government To Improve Stadium


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency July 7, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Government has embarked on a fundraising campaign to raise about K15 billion to help it restructure the Independence Stadium before it can be put up for sale. Deputy Minister of Youth, Sport and Child Development Reverend Peter Chintala announced this in Lusaka. 

He said for a long time now government has wanted to commercialise the stadium but has failed due to the condition the stadium is in at the moment.

"We have planned to commercialise the stadium but it is in a very bad condition that no one would be interested to buy it," Rev Chintala said.

He said the deplorable condition of the stadium has prompted government to restructure it before it can be sold.

Rev Chintala also disclosed that commercialising the sports infrastructure is the only solution to improve their condition.

He also revealed that if enough money is raised, the sitting capacity at the stadium would be increased from the current 35,000 to 80,000.

Rev Chintala refuted claims that the bad state of the stadium led to the death of 8 soccer fans during World Cup qualifying match between Zambia and Sudan.

July, 1996


Science World Bank Pledges $19m to Zambia For Environment


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 8, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The World Bank has pledged 19.2 million US dollars to the Zambian government in support of the Environmental Support Programme (ESP).

Head of the visiting World Bank team Bashir Souhlar said the Bank would extend its support to all key stakeholders involved in environmental protection. 

Speaking at the signing of a memorandum of understanding with environmental minister, William Harrington, Souhlar said that the funding would be spread over a period of five years.

"The memorandum of understanding is a cornerstone in the environmental agenda to help Zambia meet its challenges towards building of institutional infrastructure," Souhlar said.

And the Zambian government assured the World Bank it had the commitment and political will to address the numerous and complex problems pertaining to environment not withstanding financial constraints.

"The establishment of the Environmental Council of Zambia and the enforcement of the Environmental Protection and Pollution Control Act of 1990 are all in themselves true testimony and confirmation of the government's commitment to environment," Harrison said.

Souhlar said the Bank would launch a pilot environmental fund to empower stakeholders like Non-Governmental Organisations, private enterprise and the community in the protection of the environment.

132 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia US Firm To Print Voters Cards


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 8, 1996 by Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Lusaka - An American firm has been sub-contracted to print the new voters cards by Nikuv Computers Limited because the Israeli company preparing the elections register has failed to produce them as per contract with government.

The development has also resulted in government failing to send observers to witness the printing as demanded by the contract.

Some cards have already been printed and are in the country.

Both director of elections Rabson Mwansa and his deputy Joel Sikazwe confirmed this in separate interviews on Thursday last week. 

"I authorised the change after consulting the permanent secretary in the Vice-President's office, Philip Daka, and the Elections Commission chairman Justice Weston Muzyamba," Mwansa said.

Nikuv Computers Limited project manager Gershon Korda said the printing of the cards in the United States was dictated by tight deadlines.

"Voters cards have been produced in the United States because that's where we found the best place to produce quality cards and meet the time table," Korda said in an interview on Saturday.

But Justice Muzyamba when approached at his office on Thursday declined to be interviewed without an appointment.

And while Mwansa claimed he was still waiting for authority for his men to travel to the United States to witness the printing of the cards, Korda said the trip had been cancelled.

The trip was intended for Zambians to witness and learn how work of this magnitude was being done.

"They cancelled their intention to visit the company. I had the names but it was their decision not to travel," Korda said. "They gave a reason but I cannot tell you. Ask them."

Mwansa also said his office had no choice but to approve the printing of cards in the United States because Nikuv cited the voter registration extensions as a reason for their failure to produce the cards in Israel.

"Nikuv said because of the extensions their contractors in Israel would not meet our deadline," he said.

Korda said Nikuv Computers had planned to print the cards in Israel but because of numerous extensions their contractors were busy with other things.

But he declined to name the United States company producing the cards.

"It is in New Jersey. It's a supplier of our company. There is no reason to reveal our supplier without authorisation from the company in Israel," Korda said.

According to Sikazwe the company approached the elections office in the first week of May this year saying they could not produce the voters cards.

"They asked if they could seek assistance from their fellow agencies in America. No company was mentioned and no specific town. Government gave a go ahead," Sikazwe said.

Sikazwe insisted, a matter which was later confirmed by Mwansa, that there was no breach of contract involved.

"I am not aware if the change is a breach of contract. The contract is to produce voters cards and where it is done is immaterial," Sikazwe said.

He could not, however, comment on the quality of the cards or the provisional register because the elections office had not seen them.

"Until then we cannot comment on the quality. We are expecting them on July 11," he said.

But Mwansa, who said he had not consulted the Ministry of Legal Affairs, added that if there was any breach of contract it was up to lawyers to look into the matter. He also said that the issue of witnessing the printing of cards was not in the contract and that his office was awaiting authority from government before anyone can travel.

According to Mwansa, his office has requested the new printers to start with Northern, Western and North Western Provinces and that some cards had started arriving.

And the Elections Office will from Friday this week mount briefing sessions for registration officers and provincial elections officers.

Sikazwe confirmed this at a press briefing he addressed in Lusaka on Saturday.

But the programme has received criticism from the opposition UNIP because two of the briefings for six provinces will be held in Kitwe and Kafue which they view as intended to exclude the attendance of political parties.

"Briefing of elections officers in Kitwe and Kafue is intended to exclude political parties. What are they trying to change? All political leaders are expected to be briefed together with registration and election officers," said UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda in an interview on Thursday. "All parties must have confidence in the system, if in doubt everything breaks down."

Sikazwe, however, said the change was due to time factor and not because his office intends to exclude anyone. He said parties were free to attend briefings on July 13 in Kasama and Mongu and on July 18 in Chipata.

National political leaders will be briefed at a later date in Lusaka.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

July, 1996


Sports - General Boxing: Zambian Featherweight Knocks Out Zimbabwean


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 8, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Luisaka - Zambian featherweight boxer Emmanuel Siame, made a successful trip to Zimbabwe where he clinched a second round knock out of Mkabela Sisagiso last week.

"It is a very successful trip and Siame did not waste time as he knocked out the Zimbabwean just in the second round. Though Mkabela had some bad cuts on his left eye. It was a very good fight for Siame and we were happy with the arrangements by the Zimbabwean promoters," said Iron Nkhoma and manager Felix Phiri who went to Zimbabwe with the boxer.

This is the second time the Zimbabwean is losing via a second round knock out after going down in just two rounds to Zambia's Pastor Pole in 1994.

And welterweight Stone Phiri will this Saturday at Star market make what he calls a "grand come-back" in the boxing ring after a long spell of inactivity.

"I am coming back this Saturday with a fight against Stanly Mabesi from Tanzania. Since this is my first come-back fight, I want to teach him a lesson and I will knock him out within ten rounds, I don't want to waste time," said the 34-year-old Phiri, in the company of his manager, William Mulenga.

But it is David Mpande, also set for a fight this Saturday that is overzealous of victory over fellow Zambian, Godwin Mutupuka. "I will be through with him just within three rounds, I will first play around in round two and three before knocking him down in round three. Though people say he is fast, he will be taught a lesson this Saturday," said Mpande in an interview yesterday.
