LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Malawi Life In Mbayani Town - Two Years After


BYLINE: Malawi News Online July 6, 1996


LENGTH: 1335 words


 

Blantyre - Some Malawians - those who are frequent visitors to Asia - say that after taking a walk from Blantyre's premier Mount Soche Hotel down to the densely populated squatter settlement known as Mbayani, they are easily reminded of India, land of contrasts.

The state-of-the-art-designed buildings of Malawi's biggest city, Blantyre, perch on the hill that overlooks Mbayani and the small hovels and shacks that are home to 80, 000 people. And Mbayani is a staggering contrast to the affluent living style of its neighbour.

Most of the people of Mbayani live in abject poverty (as do the residents of Ndirande - with its more than 100,000 people - and Bangwe, Chimwankhunda and Chilobwe). They do not want to be reminded that they are now part of the second republic. They do not see much difference from what they have always experienced; see nothing changed in the new political climate - at least not socially or economically. 

"As a matter of fact, life is even harder today than it was two years ago," laments Selina Chimbaya. Unfortunately for Selina and many others in her shoes, inflation, to which the prohibitive cost of living in Malawi is attributed, is an animal she does not and will never understand.

She says she hates to be reminded that today she is under a new administration which only 2 years ago promised to bring a semblance of class and prosperity to her life. "The schools and clinics which were promised to us by the government are nowhere to be seen," she said.

Martha Chisale adds fuel to this argument when she speaks of the irony of the fact that 75% of the pupils in schools in the city centre come from Mbayani, but Mbayani has no school of its own.

"Our small children are at risk of being knocked down by cars as they cross the many roads to go to school," she pointed out. "Where are our leaders who toured the slums on foot, going from house to house and apparently sympathising with us?"

President Bakili Muluzi has said that his government has a mission. That mission is to fulfil the promises spelt out in the UDF manifesto, but, as he said, for this they need time. However, without even the most basic amenities - water, health and recreational facilities - the waiting is hard, even for people who have no other option.

Sanitation does not exist in Mbayani and the huts are built too close to each other. This makes it difficult to dig a rubbish pit, pointed out one of the residents, Chifundo Phiri. As a result, people simply dump refuse in the streams, providing all the hazards of contaminated water.

Only a few of the residents of Mbayani have taps in or near their houses, and these few charge exorbitant prices to the others who use them. And, naturally, with so many people living below the poverty line, the only other choice is water from the contaminated streams.

Mbayani has no public health centre, despite being one of Blantyre's most densely populated areas. The nearest facility is the Queen Elizabeth Central hospital, seven kilometres away.

One resident, Masauko Chingwalu, feels it is the local representatives in parliament who should shoulder the blame for the lack of development in their areas. Another blames the party for having a deaf ear when it comes to the suffering of people in places like Mbayani.

Others, however, find their own solutions for what it takes to have a happy life - and live in places like Mbayani.

"I chose to stay in Mbayani because this is within walking distance to my place of work," said civil servant, James Binali. "But, living here is tough, so I drink. What else is life for. It is the only way to forget one's miseries and hope that tomorrow will be brighter.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Effects Felt from Non-Racial Constitution


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Washington, DC - On May 8th, 1996, the Republic of South Africa promulgated its first non-racial Constitution, thereby officially ending the transition from apartheid to universal democracy. The new document establishes the framework for a society which respects the rights of all individuals, regardless of age, race, or sex. However, the Constitution is not without its points of contention. 

Most importantly, the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP), which controls the KwaZulu/Natal provincial legislature, has boycotted the Constitutional Assembly to protest the document's federal character. Led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, Inkatha has consistently opposed a strong central government. Despite the IFP boycott and repeated calls for international mediation, the Constitutional Assembly outlined specific powers reserved solely for the provinces, such as road-building and sports administration. Ultimately, the battle for federalism/confederalism will have to be fought in the nation's new Constitutional Court.

Additionally, several Afrikaner-based groups decried the new Constitution for its emphasis on universal standards of education. They feel that the Afrikaans language is an integral part of their ethnic identity and have been actively promoting the idea of single-language schools. Although these groups were unable to muster significant support for their proposal, the new document does not necessarily outlaw single-language schools.

Lastly, the African National Congress (ANC), the party most responsible for the new Constitution, has been divided by a "lock-out" clause which would guarantee employers the right to lock out striking employees. While the ANC's traditional base of support in the labour unions has vehemently protested the clause, the party's more progressive wing has acknowledged that such a clause would improve South Africa's tarnished image as a country with labour problems. In an effort to block the inclusion of the clause, the labour unions staged a one-day, nation-wide strike on April 30th. However, the strike was poorly attended and an obscure reference to a labour relations code was unceremoniously inserted into the Constitution.

All in all, South Africa's first non-racial Constitution remains purposefully vague on a number of divisive issues like regional powers, single-language schools, and employer's rights. The document's authors recognized the futility of trying to prepare for every possible situation that might arise. Instead, the constitutional negotiators concentrated on the new society they were building and unambiguously depicted the rights and prerogatives of the individuals therein.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


136 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Sudan Sanctions Take Effect, War Spreads


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Washington, DC - On April 26, 1996, the UN Security Council voted - 13 to 0 with Russia and China abstaining - to impose diplomatic sanctions against the Sudan. Sudan had passed the deadline for handing over three suspects in the attempted assassination of Egyptian President Mubarak; Sudan is allegedly harboring the suspects. The sanctions included reducing the number of Sudanese diplomats in a country, departure of terrorist groups with headquarters in Sudan and banning of international conferences in the Sudan.

The sanctions were milder than the U.S., Britain and Ethiopia had hoped for. Egypt, who at first had pressed for harsher sanctions, backed down in the end, saying economic sanctions would make the Sudanese suffer and an arms embargo would endanger the unity of the Sudan. Egypt would not like to see an independent Southern Sudan controlling the waters of the Nile on which Egypt is so dependent. 

The Security Council gave the Sudan two weeks to turn over the suspects. After this the sanctions went into effect, to be reviewed in two months' time if the suspects are still not handed over. This will be early July.

Russia and China abstained because they feel sanctions on the Sudan is one embargo too many. They, plus others, including Iran, and Syria, have stated they will not adhere to that part of he sanctions which asks governments to reduce the number of Sudanese diplomats in their country.

Sudan has said the sanctions are inconvenient but not crippling. It has also said it will screen foreign organizations based in the Sudan.

The Civil War

1. The war can no longer be called "the war in the South."

It has spread to the Nuba Mountains for some time now. And there are recent reports that the Sudan Allied Forces (SAF), one of the military wings of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), has launched attacks in the North, near the town of Kassala. The SAF is a splinter group of former Sudanese army troops who escaped Sudan after the '89 coup. 2. Several of the SPLA factions (headed by Riek Machar, Kerubino Kwanyin Bol,) have signed a "political charter" with Khartoum; it is supposed to be the initiation of a peace process.

Most analysts are not taking the charter seriously. It has been denounced by Garang as a "sell-out". (Garang has been joined by another splinter faction, headed by John Luc.) surprisingly, the charter has gained support from Joseph Lagu, a former vice-president under Nimeiri, who had been living outside Sudan for the last three years. He still commands some support in the South, especially his home region of Equatoria. He has just returned to the Sudan. 3. The situation in the Nuba Mountains continues to worsen. It is not considered the "South" and is therefore not eligible for OLS (Operation Lifeline Sudan) relief. Reports of atrocities continue - villages burned and looted, people rounded up into "peace camps"which are more like concentration camps, land taken over by mechanized framing - but because very few people have access to the Nuba Mountains, hard evidence is difficult to come by.

One issue which perhaps needs more emphasis and which affects the Nuba, the SPLA and the northern opposition is the question of land.

For ordinary people in the South and the marginalised areas of the North, one of the main reasons why they are fighting is because of land. People became fed up with government officials and merchants seizing their ancestral lands; they took up arms to defend what was rightfully theirs.

Even before the recent atrocities, there has been a history of land confiscation. And to make matters worse, the land is being confiscated by rich merchants who use mechanized farming. It is well documented that mechanical cultivation rapidly degrades the topsoil, making the land vulnerable to wind erosion. Commercial farmers (mostly NIF supporters) are given 25-year leases on the land; the farmers exploit the land ruthlessly so that after a few years the land is so degraded that it is unusable. This has happened already in the North.

The government has been redistributing land to reward its followers.

The issue of land, along with the issues of sharia law and self-determination, will have to be dealt with in any peace negotiations.

IMF Relations

In early May an IMF team spent a week in the Sudan. A report will be issued later on Sudan's economy in the period between January and April.

Relations with the IMF have been difficult for a decade because of Sudan's failure to pay arrears which have now reached $1.7 billion.

Relations took a turn for the better last year when Khartoum began to make a token payment of $4 million per month as a sign of good will.

The talks ended without a debt arrears pact. The IMF is expected to discuss its relations with Sudan at a meeting in August.
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zaire Rwanda and Zaire: The Situation Grows More Complicated


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Washington, DC - The situation in Zaire has become more critical and more complicated in the last few months. Fierce fighting has broken out in Masisi, one of the most fertile areas in Zaire. Living in the area were Rwandan Hutus (Zairean Hutus now), some of whom have been there since the 1900's, Rwandan Tutsis who fled the violence in the 1950's, Zairean Tutsis who were in Zaire when the border was finalized, and other Zairean groups such as the Hunde.

Fighting in this area has broken out from time to time over the years. It has worsened since the large influx of Hutu refugees in '94. 

What appears to be happening is that the refugees have moved from the camps into Hutu villages in Masisi and are now joining with the Hutus in Zaire to drive out the minority Tutsis and establish a "Hutuland" in this rich agricultural land of northeastern Zaire.

Reports over the last two months say that at least 65,000 Tutsis have been displaced from their homes in Masisi; 11,000 have fled to Rwanda. Camps must now be opened in Rwanda because Zairean Tutsis are not entitled to repatriation. Many of the refugees are traumatized after days of terror. In one area 3000 Tutsis are trapped in two villages because of the fighting and a massacre is feared. At least 100 Tutsis have already been e movement of the displaced.

Meanwhile border raids from the camps into Rwanda continue. The Zairean troops have arrested more than 50 of the ringleaders in the camps. But refugees are still not going back in large numbers.

Events in Rwanda

Inside Rwanda, the security situation has worsened in some areas. It seems the rebels have become bolder and the army more on the defensive.

Both sides have been involved in attacks. Some of the incidents which have been reported in recent months:

- A woman was slaughtered; the evidence indicated that she was killed by genocide criminals who want to exterminate disturbing survivors and witnesses (25 such cases have been documented by African Rights).

- Infiltrators attacked a military prison in an attempt to free inmates; there was a clash with the army; the army killed at least 19 men (April).

- An armed gang burnt the entire Karengera township and freed the prisoners from the local prison (May).

- Rebels from Zaire raided local government offices and attacked three villages in Cyangugu region, killing at least 37 people. This was the worst attack since the end of the war in '94. Cyangugu fears civil war will start again.

- Shortly after the above attack, infiltrators attacked a jail near the border and killed more than 30 prisoners. It is unclear why the prisoners were killed.

Progress of Rwanda's Tribunal/Justice System

After two years, the Tribunal has indicted only eleven suspects. It is greatly hampered by lack of funds and by rivalry with the Rwandan Government who wants to try the suspects itself. One of the chief suspects, Theoneste Bagosora, who was arrested in Cameroon, is wanted also by the Belgian government for the slaying of ten Belgian peacekeepers. Since Cameroon has no extradition treaty with Rwanda, it has been a haven for genocide suspects. There is some indication, however, that Bagosora will be sent to the Tribunal.

Three suspects from Zambia are to be arraigned and transferred to Arusha, the seat of the Tribunal. They will be the first to go on trial. They include: Clement Kayishema, former governor of Kibuye who allegedly helped organize the slaughters in Kibuye where 90% of Tutsi residents were killed; George Anderson Rutaganda and Jean Paul Akaseyu, both charged with organizing and leading massacres in other areas.

Whereas the Tribunal has too few suspects in custody, the Rwandan justice system has too many. There are now more than 70,000 suspects in Rwanda's grossly overcrowded jails. Some attempts have been made to ameliorate prison conditions. And the Rwandan government is preparing to begin some trials.

In a surprise move, a U.S. court ordered a Rwandan suspected of war crimes to pay $105 million to relations of massacre victims. The Rwandan government was pleased that at least one suspect had been found guilty but troubled that the money was not allocated to build Rwanda.

Arms Flow

In addition to the culture of impunity, the flow of arms into the Great Lakes Region is another factor which exacerbates the situation.

A UN commission of inquiry uncovered strong evidence that Zaire had a part in shipping arms to soldiers of the former Rwandan army living in the camps. In April, the UN Security Council decided the commission should continue probing the arms flow to the camps. UN observers are to monitor airfield and other transport points.

The UN has also set up a trust fund to demilitarize central Africa and curb the flow of arms into the region. The trust fund will finance activities promoting "confidence-Building measures" and will support transparency in military acquisitions. An arms register will be set up.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Burundi Burundi Violence Grows Without Worldwide Attention


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

Washington, DC - Because the crisis in Burundi has not degenerated into a full scale massacre such as that in Rwanda in 1994, the gravity of the present crisis has perhaps not yet fully penetrated our minds. With an estimated 100 people dying per week, tens of thousands of refugees still fleeing to Zaire and Tanzania, thousands more displaced from their homes within Burundi, the situation is comparable to an all-out, if undeclared, war.

For a while the trouble was in Bujumbura and in the north; now it has spread to other parts of the country. Rebel soldiers have stepped up attacks in the south. Military observers said there have been seven attacks on Bururi in the last two weeks of May. The central province of Gitega, according to a senior military source, is caught in "total war" following the massacre in Buhoro of 235 civilians by the army after rebels had massacred some civilians there. Another massacre, for which the army is also blamed, of 200 people occurred in Bubanza (see map).The army continues to deny the massacres but eye witnesses have testified that they occurred. Human rights groups say that both rebels and the army almost routinely kill civilians. 

Bujumbura has been systematically ethnically cleansed (some call it "Tutsiville"). Hundreds of thousands of displaced people are sheltered and fed by aid groups. Rebels are now threatening Bujumbura; they say their purpose is not to attack but to get the army to talk.

The rebels, operating from Zaire, are believed to have gained ground this year. The President has criticized the army, saying guerrillas are operating with impunity both in the capital and in the interior.

The rebels appear to have access to sophisticated weapons, including land mines.

Recently three Swiss workers for the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) were killed in the North. Both sides are blaming the other; there was international protest at the killing of workers from a group such as ICRC.

Positions of the Different Groups

Political analysts say the Hutu are alarmed by the Tutsi-dominated army while the Tutsi are afraid of the Hutu masses. Only dialogue can bring a solution.

Militarily, there are several groups involved:

- the Tutsi-dominated army which, according to many, is the real power in Burundi and is not under the control of the government. Some also believe that the army is the main cause of the instability. (The army has been in control of Burundi for years.)

- Tutsi militia, composed of Tutsi extremists, and probably backed by the army

- CNDD (National Council for Defense and Democracy), the main rebel group operating from Zaire. It is pursuing an insurgency campaign to demand greater power. Its leader is Leonard Nyangoma, a former Minister in the government of the assassinated Pres. Melchior Ndadaye.

- other Hutu militia, composed of extremists. Politically there are:

- FRODEBU, the majority political party, mostly Hutu to which the President Sylvester Ntibantunganya, belongs and winner of the last elections.

- UPRONA, the opposition party, mainly Tutsi, to which the Prime Minister, Antoine Nduyawe belongs. The government is a fragile coalition of the two parties. Currently, the hard-liners on all sides refuse to negotiate. The rebels say they will refuse until Ndadaye's assassins are brought to trial. The Tutsi military and UPRONA refuse to negotiate with rebels they say are advocating genocide.

It is becoming more and more difficult for the President and the Prime Minister to come together. The Prime Minister has refused to negotiate with Nyangoma. The latter, although he had last month vowed to overthrow the government, is now willing to negotiate with the army which he feels is the real power. The army is not willing and the President maintains the negotiations must be with the government and not the army.

It is difficult to see how it can all be resolved and yet the only viable solution is through dialogue.

The President has recently demanded more accountability from the army; it is not certain whether they will heed the call.

Outside Intervention

The extent of outside intervention does show a great amount of concern on the part of the international community. It has yet to prove effective.

1. Julius Nyerere, former Tanzanian President and OAU envoy. Many people have put their hopes in the mediation of Nyerere; he is highly respected by the Bunrundians themselves. But the first round of talks last month ended inconclusively. Only FRODEBU and UPRONA representatives were present; CNND and other rebels were not invited.

The two parties agreed to condemn violence and criminality in Burundi and to seek the support of the international community in ending the crisis. But they could not agree on a formula of how to dismantle Hutu and Tutsi militias. Nyerere expressed regret at the decision not to invite the rebels. A second round of talks was convened on June 4. It has also ended without real agreement. It was Nyerere's opinion that UPRONA was most responsible for the impasse. UPRONA was insisting that CNDD be condemned. Nyerere warned that time is running out for Burundi. Another round of talks is planned.

2. OAU

The OAU renewed its observer mission to Burundi for three months; it now expires July 23. The OAU took this action to fulfill its responsibility and to support Nyerere's peace efforts. The mission. however, is strapped for funds.

3. UN

Boutros Ghali has stated publicly his fears that Burundi may erupt like Rwanda. He recommended that the UN establish a standby force to intervene quickly in case of a major upsurge in violence. He said that organizing such a force is beyond UN capabilities but urged key member states to take the initiative. The U.S. has stated it is prepared to help with logistics, transport and communications but not troops.

Meanwhile UPRONA, the army, the rebels all strongly denounce the idea of UN military intervention.

4. Visits of U.S. envoys

The number of envoys sent by the U.S. in April and May to visit Burundi shows there is a high level of concern:

- Brian Atwood, head of USAID, gave the message that aid to Burundi would discontinue until there was meaningful dialogue with opposing parties. Only emergency humanitarian aid would continue. Atwood traveled with Emma Bonino, the EU representative for humanitarian relief.

- Richard Bogosian, the U.S. Special Coordinator for the region, asked the government to probe the recent massacre reports from Buhoro and Bubanza.

- John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, condemned the recent massacres and told the warring factions that the U.S. would not recognize any government that came to power in a coup.

In a statement to Congress, Shattuck said the extremists are manipulating ethnic differences for their own narrow ends. Moderates are afraid to exercise leadership and isolate extremists because of personal danger.

- Anthony Lake, National Security Advisor, and George Moose, Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, paid a seven-hour visit to Burundi.

Lake warned the extremists; He said he was dismayed by the deterioration of the situation since he visited 18 months ago. In talks with the President and Prime Minister, Lake said the tension in Burundi is a major focus of U.S. foreign policy.

In a recent statement, the State Department has declared that genocide has been committed in Burundi by both sides. The U.S. is not under legal obligation to take action but because genocide is a violation of international law, cases of genocide may be taken to the UN and intervention sought. Tribunals may also be established.

Relations with Zaire

At the beginning of the year, an estimated 110,000 Burundian refugees were living in Zaire. This number has swelled in the last few months as thousands more fled to escape the recent violence. In an attempt, to stop the flow of refugees, Burundi in early May closed its side of the border.

In mid-May, the Prime Minister of Zaire, Kengo wa Dondo, visited Bujumbura. Although Zaire constantly denies that the refugee camps are havens for Hutu dissidents, it is well known that CNDD is operating from Zaire.

During the talks, Burundi and Zaire decided to reactivate a joint committee in defense and security established in '95. The committee will examine the accusations and come up with suggestions on how to resolve the matter.

While Kengo's visit is seen as an attempt to restore normal relations, observers believe it was motivated by the economic pinch Zaire is feeling from the border closure.

Schools in Burundi were affected by the border closure; Zairean teachers were stranded. Some schools had to close.

Many Hutu members of the 81-seat national assembly, fearing assassination by Tutsi extremists, live in Zaire and commute to Bujumbura for the semi-annual parliamentary sessions. (See advocacy section for action on Burundi.)
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.

LANGUAGE: English

139 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Liberia Peace Delayed is Peace Denied


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Washington, DC - Monrovia in the last few weeks has faced what is now known as a "semblance of peace." But war-wearied Liberians want more than a semblance of peace, they want the real thing: lasting and durable peace, an opportunity to put their lives back together.

Liberia, perhaps more than any other nation in West Africa, has suffered sufficiently. After more than six years of a brutal civil war that has left more than 200,000 dead, 800,000 others as refugees and more than a million displaced, Liberia deserves the good-will of people everywhere to end their nightmare. They deserve a special support from the United States of America government. 

That is why when the United States reportedly committed additional funding for the peace efforts in Liberia, that pronouncement was greeted with gratitude. But the U.S. still has not delivered. This delay in delivering the promised required resources to ECOMOG has historically compounded the suffering of the Liberian people.

Following the signing of the Abuja Accord in August 1995, a donor conference was held in New York in October at which time the United States promised $10 million in support for peace keeping activities. Less than half of that money was disbursed before the April 6th flare-up in fighting. All along, the urgency for the delivery of the funding was established but the U.S. would not act speedily.

It has been at least three weeks since a degree of calm has returned to Monrovia. A partial disarmament of some of the fighters who were holed up at the Barclay Training Center has taken place. The momentum towards more disarmament is greater given the following variables:

A. The largest warring faction, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) is in retreat. Mr. Taylor is reported to have set up a new military post in Totota. To coerce Mr. Taylor into disarming his men while he is in retreat is more likely than after he has regrouped and is re-supplied.

B. Some of the most hard-core fighters of the Liberia Peace Council (LPC), United Liberation Movement for Democracy- ULIMO/J faction is in Monrovia and more accessible. They can therefore be more easily disarmed and encamped but if they are allowed to return to the rural area, something which is now being allowed, it would be more difficult, if not futile, to disarm when they are in the bush.

C. Peace keeping soldiers have been patrolling Monrovia effectively and have set up check points around Camp Schiefflein and the Pynesville intersection. This has enabled them to partially monitor movement into and out of Monrovia.

D. A seeming crack is occurring between the two allies - Taylor of the NPFL and Kromah of the ULIMO-K faction who visited upon the Liberian people their most recent rendezvous with deaths, mayhem and destruction. Whereas Taylor has stated that he wants elections in August come hell or hot water, Mr. Kromah has stated that disarmamment should take place before elections.

This momentum must be built upon. The peacekeepers need to be provided the necessary logistics they have continuously requested and have been promised on countless occasions but never delivered. These logistics including all-terrain vehicles, communication gears, field hospitals, and adequate funding must be delivered as a matter of urgency, if the United States is really serious about assisting the Liberian people end the war.

Additionally, the augmentation of the peacekeeping force must be pursued expeditiously. Perhaps one reason why April 6 occurred was because Liberian warlords were convinced that given ECOMOG lack of an overwhelming force in Monrovia, they could get away with whatever they wanted. They must not be provided with that option again. ECOMOG must have the strength it needs to deter any behaviour on the part of the Liberian warlords which would jeopardize the safety of Liberians in the country.

Liberia's porous border with its neighbors, especially Guinea and La Cote d'Ivoire is cause for concern. The June 7 cross border raids by forces believed to be NPFL soldiers into Toulepleau, la Cote d'Ivoire, resulted in the death of 14 Liberian refugees. During the week of June 17, ULIMO-K forces, on an apparent foraging mission for food, over-ran the town of Yaragbara in Guinea wounding at least a dozen Liberian refugees. The death toll is yet to be announced. Earlier, on March 15 at least 35 persons were killed, several homes were burned down by the same group. The Guineans have now said that they will begin to pursue the rebel soldiers into Liberian territories.

In order to prevent these cross border raids and the continuous flow of arms into Liberia, these borders need a more effective monitoring. Guinea and La Cote d'Ivoire have to be persuaded and supported to achieve that.

ECOMOG's ability to return Monrovia, Buchanan and Kakata to their former safe haven status can only come about if a successful disarmament takes place. This will have the desired effect of convincing Liberians that they need not take to sea in unworthy sea vessels which are repeatedly denied docking rights by neighboring countries. No amount of condemnation from the rich nations of the world will make West African government take in these refugees, especially when these very rich nations are not perceived as urgently and concretely assisting the movement towards a peaceful settlement of the Liberian war. It is high time then, that promised assistance for the Liberian peace process be delivered immediately. For many Liberians, peace delayed is peace denied.
For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

140 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Rwanda Rwanda and Zaire: The Situation Grows More Complicated


BYLINE: Around Africa (Washington, D.C.) July 8, 1996 by the Africa Faith and Justice Network


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Washington, DC - The situation in Zaire has become more critical and more complicated in the last few months. Fierce fighting has broken out in Masisi, one of the most fertile areas in Zaire. Living in the area were Rwandan Hutus (Zairean Hutus now), some of whom have been there since the 1900's, Rwandan Tutsis who fled the violence in the 1950's, Zairean Tutsis who were in Zaire when the border was finalized, and other Zairean groups such as the Hunde.

Fighting in this area has broken out from time to time over the years. It has worsened since the large influx of Hutu refugees in '94. 

What appears to be happening is that the refugees have moved from the camps into Hutu villages in Masisi and are now joining with the Hutus in Zaire to drive out the minority Tutsis and establish a "Hutuland" in this rich agricultural land of northeastern Zaire.

Reports over the last two months say that at least 65,000 Tutsis have been displaced from their homes in Masisi; 11,000 have fled to Rwanda. Camps must now be opened in Rwanda because Zairean Tutsis are not entitled to repatriation. Many of the refugees are traumatized after days of terror. In one area 3000 Tutsis are trapped in two villages because of the fighting and a massacre is feared. At least 100 Tutsis have already been e movement of the displaced.

Meanwhile border raids from the camps into Rwanda continue. The Zairean troops have arrested more than 50 of the ringleaders in the camps. But refugees are still not going back in large numbers.

Events in Rwanda

Inside Rwanda, the security situation has worsened in some areas. It seems the rebels have become bolder and the army more on the defensive.

Both sides have been involved in attacks. Some of the incidents which have been reported in recent months:

- A woman was slaughtered; the evidence indicated that she was killed by genocide criminals who want to exterminate disturbing survivors and witnesses (25 such cases have been documented by African Rights).

- Infiltrators attacked a military prison in an attempt to free inmates; there was a clash with the army; the army killed at least 19 men (April).

- An armed gang burnt the entire Karengera township and freed the prisoners from the local prison (May).

- Rebels from Zaire raided local government offices and attacked three villages in Cyangugu region, killing at least 37 people. This was the worst attack since the end of the war in '94. Cyangugu fears civil war will start again.

- Shortly after the above attack, infiltrators attacked a jail near the border and killed more than 30 prisoners. It is unclear why the prisoners were killed.

Progress of Rwanda's Tribunal/Justice System

After two years, the Tribunal has indicted only eleven suspects. It is greatly hampered by lack of funds and by rivalry with the Rwandan Government who wants to try the suspects itself. One of the chief suspects, Theoneste Bagosora, who was arrested in Cameroon, is wanted also by the Belgian government for the slaying of ten Belgian peacekeepers. Since Cameroon has no extradition treaty with Rwanda, it has been a haven for genocide suspects. There is some indication, however, that Bagosora will be sent to the Tribunal.

Three suspects from Zambia are to be arraigned and transferred to Arusha, the seat of the Tribunal. They will be the first to go on trial. They include: Clement Kayishema, former governor of Kibuye who allegedly helped organize the slaughters in Kibuye where 90% of Tutsi residents were killed; George Anderson Rutaganda and Jean Paul Akaseyu, both charged with organizing and leading massacres in other areas.

Whereas the Tribunal has too few suspects in custody, the Rwandan justice system has too many. There are now more than 70,000 suspects in Rwanda's grossly overcrowded jails. Some attempts have been made to ameliorate prison conditions. And the Rwandan government is preparing to begin some trials.

In a surprise move, a U.S. court ordered a Rwandan suspected of war crimes to pay $105 million to relations of massacre victims. The Rwandan government was pleased that at least one suspect had been found guilty but troubled that the money was not allocated to build Rwanda.

Arms Flow

In addition to the culture of impunity, the flow of arms into the Great Lakes Region is another factor which exacerbates the situation.

A UN commission of inquiry uncovered strong evidence that Zaire had a part in shipping arms to soldiers of the former Rwandan army living in the camps. In April, the UN Security Council decided the commission should continue probing the arms flow to the camps. UN observers are to monitor airfield and other transport points.

The UN has also set up a trust fund to demilitarize central Africa and curb the flow of arms into the region. The trust fund will finance activities promoting "confidence-Building measures" and will support transparency in military acquisitions. An arms register will be set up.

For more information, contact the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a group of people of faith working towards positive change for the peoples of Africa, at PO Box 29378, Washington DC 20017; telephone 202 832 3412; fax 202 832 9051; e-mail afjn@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


July, 1996


Liberia O.A.U Considers Possible Sanctions Against Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996 by Tarcey Munaku , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) is seriously considering calling for the imposition of severe international sanctions against war-torn Liberia and the setting up of a war crimes tribunal against the leadership of the country's warring factions.

The O.A.U. Council of Ministers meeting in Yaounde, the Cameroonian capital, has proposed a resolution recommending the non-recognition of any Liberian government which comes into office through the use of force or violence.

Liberia, Africa's oldest republic, has been ravaged by a brutal civil war since 1989, which has spawned a frightening refugee crisis as several warring factions wreak mayhem and destruction on the west African nation of 2.5 million people. 

If approved by the heads of state and government at their 32nd ordinary conference from July 8 to 10, the resolution will also give teeth to the West African Peace-Monitoring Force (ECOMOG), changing its mandate from peace-keeping to peace-enforcement.

The resolution sends a strong message to Liberian faction leaders such as Charles Taylor, Roosevelt Johnson and Alhaji Kromah, warning them that should the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) assessment of the peace process turn out to be negative, the O.A.U. would help sponsor a draft resolution in the United Nations Security Council for the imposition of severe sanctions.

This will include the possibility of setting up a war crimes tribunal similar to the one on the Rwanda genocide, to try the leadership of the factions on the violation of the human rights of innocent civilians.

The resolution also calls on the warring factions to return all items looted from the capital, Monrovia, during the recent round of fighting in April to their rightful owners.

It urges the international community to scrupulously comply with the arms embargo imposed on the warring factions by the U.N. Security Council.

On Burundi, the ministers, also proposed a resolution expressing "very serious" concern on the "very unstable", tense and politically polarized situation that continued to prevail in a nation torn apart by ethnic fighting.

The resolution entrusts the central organ of the O.A.U. on conflict prevention and management to pursue its efforts to prevent a further deterioration of the situation in Burundi.

More than 150,000 people have been killed in the past three years in clashes between the majority, but underclass Hutus and the minority but economically powerful Tutsis.

The resolution also requests the Secretary-General of the O.A.U., Salim Ahmed Salim, to persevere in his efforts to find a lasting solution to the conflict in Burundi and to report to the next session of the council of ministers.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


142 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Leaders Discuss Continent's Bank


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon (PANA) - A summit of African member countries of the African Development
Bank is scheduled to begin Sunday in Libreville, capital of Gabon.

The one-day meeting, initiated by president Omar Bongo, will focus on the administration of the bank group.

Attention will be on solving the problem of the difficult working relationship between the board of governors and the president of bank. 

The issue of arrears of contributions, estimated 820 million U.S. dollars will also be discussed, to enable the finance institution to play its role of mobilizing investment funds for African countries.

The bank had been hit by a serious financial crisis. Its net profit dropped by half in two years, from 165.2 million dollars in 1992 to 77 million in 1995.

Its loan portfolio also fell by 60 percent in three years, from 3.4 billion dollars to 1.4 billion in 1994.

Meanwhile, the African Development Fund, which provides soft loans to the continent's poorest countries, was recently replenished after two and a half years of paralysis.

The replenishment of the fund allows the bank to resume disbursement of loans to 39 poor African countries which do not qualify for loans from the ADB proper.

Out of the 53 member countries of the bank, only a dozen are qualified for its loans at prevailing market interest rates.

Set up in 1963, the bank groups 53 African countries and 24 non-regional countries, among them the United States, Germany, France and Japan.

The Libreville summit will be preceded a meeting of Finance ministers who represent their countries at the bank's annual board of governors meetings.

At the last such meeting in Abidjan in May, some African members rejected demands by the non-regional share holders that the capital base of the bank be restructured to give them equal powers with its African owners, prompting Bongo's intervention.

Currently, the 53 African countries own two-thirds of ADB shares as against one-third for the non-African countries. The bank's total assets are currently estimated at some 33 billion U.S. dollars.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Children To Address Assembly Of Heads State


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996 by Peter Mwaura , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 
YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - A two-day children's mini summit will take place here beginning Saturday on the eve of the annual heads of state meeting of the Organization of African Unity (OAU).

This first-ever such initiative, organized by UNICEF with the support of the OAU, is intended to draw the attention of Africa to the suffering and agony of hundreds of thousands of innocent children caught in the midst of wars and hostilities. 

Children from 12 African countries, which had to face or are still facing conflict situations, will participate in the mini summit.

The children who will participate in the summit witnessed and experienced the horrors of war and survived.

"They will be in a unique position to make the most compelling case in favor of durable peace," OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim told the opening ceremony Thursday of the Council of Ministers.

The foreign ministers are preparing for the assembly of heads of state and government scheduled for Monday.

The assembly is expected to focus on the problem of conflicts in Africa and seek solutions.

The group of selected children will express their feelings and demands on behalf of more than half of the continent's population of the age of 18 and below.

Two of these children, a boy and a girl, will have the opportunity to address the assembly of heads of state and government, Salim said.

"They will no doubt convey the ideals, enthusiasm and expectations of the African children who are ready to serve as agents of change and understanding across all kinds of divide," he added.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Southern Africa Zimbabwe Dissidents Led By Former Mozambican Rebel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

MAPUTO, (PANA) - Zimbabwean dissidents known as Chimwenjes are now under the command of a
demobilized general of Mozambique's former anti-government movement Renamo, the Beira daily newspaper, Diario de Mocambique, reported Friday.

The newspaper named the general as Armando Mabache, and also claimed that the Chimwenjes have moved their main base inside Mozambique closer to the Zimbabwean border. They have abandoned the Zomba area, and have set up camp in the Chimanimani mountains, on the boundary between Sussundenga and Mossurize districts, in Mozambique's Manica province. 

The newspaper suggests that the Chimwenjes were preparing to set up their military logistics and launch an offensive into Zimbabwe.

Their ultimate goal is said to overthrow the Zimbabwean government of President Robert Mugabe. Captured Chimwenjes have said that the group is the armed wing of the small Zimbabwean opposition party, ZANU-Ndonga. This party is led by Ndabaningi Sithole, who is currently facing charges of plotting to assassinate Mugabe.

The Chimwenjes, who were captured January in a clash with the police, also told reporters that they were allied with Renamo during the war of destabilization funded by apartheid South Africa, against the Mozambican government. However, Renamo leaders have repeatedly denied any link to the Chimwenjes.

The Mossurize district administrator, Eduardo Gimo, told the newspaper that over the last two months the Chimwenjes, under Mabache's command, had looted two kiosks and a shop, and raped two nieces of a local Regulo (a quasi-traditional chief). Several other women have been kidnapped.

Meanwhile, the former chairman of the Mozambican parliament, veteran nationalist Marcelino Dos Santos, has accused Renamo of being "deeply involved" with the Chimwenjes, and has called for a national crusade against the Zimbabwean group.

Cited in Friday's issue of the Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, Dos Santos declared "from the village up to the city the whole people should be politically and militarily mobilized to face this kind of aggression."

Asked what proof he had of continued links between Renamo and the Chimwenjes, Dos Santos said, "That's for later. Right now I'm just stating it. And it is not you (reporters) to whom I will present the proof."

Dos Santos said the Chimwenjes might grow into a major force just as Renamo had done. However, unlike Renamo which enjoyed the support of apartheid South Africa, the Chimwenjes are not backed by any regional power. Furthermore, captured Chimwenjes put their total strength at less than 40.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Uganda Museveni Re-Appoints Woman Vice-President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996 by Moses Draku , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni Thursday re-appointed Dr. Specioza Wandira Kazibwe as Vice-President.

Her appointment was unanimously approved by the newly-elected parliament in Kampala on Thursday. 

Dr. Kazibwe, 41, was elected member of parliament for Kigulu south constituency in eastern Uganda, during the June 27 no-party legislative polls.

Married with five children, Dr. Kazibwe, a surgeon was first appointed a deputy minister in 1991.

She was later named minister of gender and community development. In 1994, she was elevated to the vice presidency in a cabinet reshuffle.

The Ugandan constitution states that the president shall, with the approval of parliament, appoint the vice president and cabinet, respectively.

Earlier on Thursday, the Ugandan parliament set-up an appointments committee to beat the July 8 deadline when a new cabinet is supposed to have been installed.

The committee is composed of the speaker, one member of parliament from each of the 39 districts, six women representatives, two for the army and the youth. Disabled persons and workers are to be represented by one each.

The committee was expected to start screening potential ministers Thursday evening. Parliament also endorses the appointment of judges, the army and police commanders, the ombudsman, and heads of national commissions.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa's Woes Rekindle Nostalgia for Pan-Africanism


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996 by Felix Njoku , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - "Africa is not geography. Africa is demography," said Rex Nettleford, a history and political science professor at the University of the West Indies in Kingston, Jamaica.

"There is Africa wherever you find people of African origin," said Nettleford who is also the founder and artistic director of the acclaimed National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica, which draws inspiration from African dance and music tradition.

Nettleford is unhappy that this tradition is fast disappearing under the weight of the continent's economic, social and political problems which, he argues, should be the concern of the negroid race. 

This summation may sound strange to some people in a continent where ethnic strife and sectionalism have replaced the peoples' time-honored tradition of being their brothers' keeper.

In Rwanda and Burundi in central Africa, an estimated 1.2 million people have been killed in ethnic wars in the past three years. Similarly, in Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria and South Africa, hundreds of people have been killed in ethnic clashes.

Border skirmishes are becoming increasingly common. Some governments expel hundreds of thousands of immigrants from neighboring countries on the slightest pretext. In some cases, eminent people who fought hard for independence have suddenly lost their citizenship in the life-and-death struggle for political power.

People of various ethnic groups now mutually refer to each other in derogatory terms: some unprintable here.

Today's Africans prefer to identify themselves in terms of geographical location (West Africans, East Africans), language (Anglophone, Francophone, Lusophone) and even by religion (Christian, Muslim, animist).

Given this scenario, one wonders if these are the same people to whom Nettleford attributes a common ancestry.

Is this the Africa for which Revered Leon Sullivan and others have deployed enormous efforts in the past three decades to redeem?

Alas, one ceases to wonder, when one recalls that the Pan-Africanist movements which began in the late 18th century, though spurred by the sad history of the black race, were rooted in the African Diaspora.

"The trans-Atlantic slave trade is no more. Many of us have become part and parcel of the decision-making process in our countries. But we are still fighting for the goals of emancipation," Nettleford told this writer in Amman (Jordan), where he, and other educationists, attended the recent forum on Education For All.

Others have said as much.

"Africa is suffering from bad leadership and disunity," under oppressive neo-colonial forces, said Louis Farrakhan, leader the Nation of Islam, during a trip to a number of African countries in November 1995.

Those who have cared to look at the situation of Africans over the years agree that the majority of them are, by far, worse off now than they were after independence some 30 years ago.

Worst hit is sub-Sahara Africa, an area which some people prefer to call Black Africa. This part of the continent has been made into an island onto itself, hypothetically cut off from the mainly affluent Berber and Arab north and from the white-driven industrialized South Africa, at the other extreme.

Search for sub-Sahara in a data base and the array of words such as AIDS, wars, famine, genocide, debt, dictatorship, among others, pop up with some kind of uncanny rhythm, more than enough to discourage the interaction.

African problems, many of them man-made, have seemed so overwhelming that the African scholar, Ali Mazrui, once urged a "benign colonization" of trouble torn states by the more stable ones on the continent, as a possible remedy. He was barked down by furious and frustrated colleagues for uttering what they considered to be an abomination.

But Nettleford said black peoples the world over faced more or less the same problems. Conflict, poverty and disease are intertwined. They emanate from the neocolonial situation, he said, citing ongoing political and social problems in Nigeria, as a case in point.

"Whatever crises there are in some African countries now, should not lead us to give up hope," he said.

The United States and European countries went through much more difficult times, before emerging as great powers today.

Therefore, it would amount to some kind of arrogance on the part of Africans to think they are so different from other people that they won't make mistakes.

Nettleford, who has been to several African countries, also took issue with outsiders who think they have been ordained by nature to "teach" Africans how to go about just everything.

"I have often had to remind people in the United States and other places who like to hold tutorials for other nations that they did not do too well for up to 90 years after their independence," he said. But this does not mean that Africans should not condemn evil and wrong doings in their countries. Meanwhile, Africans and those in the diaspora, especially intellectuals, should engage in constant networking on how to improve their lot.

"If Africa does not remain important to us ourselves, it won't be to anybody," he added.

This sounds like a dire message to African leaders now in Yaounde, Cameroon, for the annual Summit of the 33-year-old Organisation of African Unity, the body that supplanted Kwame Nkrumah's United States of Africa.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large O.A.U Considers Possible Sanctions Against Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 5, 1996 by Tarcey Munaku , PANA Correspondent


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) is seriously considering calling for the imposition of severe international sanctions against war-torn Liberia and the setting up of a war crimes tribunal against the leadership of the country's warring factions.

The O.A.U. Council of Ministers meeting in Yaounde, the Cameroonian capital, has proposed a resolution recommending the non-recognition of any Liberian government which comes into office through the use of force or violence.

Liberia, Africa's oldest republic, has been ravaged by a brutal civil war since 1989, which has spawned a frightening refugee crisis as several warring factions wreak mayhem and destruction on the west African nation of 2.5 million people. 

If approved by the heads of state and government at their 32nd ordinary conference from July 8 to 10, the resolution will also give teeth to the West African Peace-Monitoring Force (ECOMOG), changing its mandate from peace-keeping to peace-enforcement.

The resolution sends a strong message to Liberian faction leaders such as Charles Taylor, Roosevelt Johnson and Alhaji Kromah, warning them that should the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) assessment of the peace process turn out to be negative, the O.A.U. would help sponsor a draft resolution in the United Nations Security Council for the imposition of severe sanctions.

This will include the possibility of setting up a war crimes tribunal similar to the one on the Rwanda genocide, to try the leadership of the factions on the violation of the human rights of innocent civilians.

The resolution also calls on the warring factions to return all items looted from the capital, Monrovia, during the recent round of fighting in April to their rightful owners.

It urges the international community to scrupulously comply with the arms embargo imposed on the warring factions by the U.N. Security Council.

On Burundi, the ministers, also proposed a resolution expressing "very serious" concern on the "very unstable", tense and politically polarized situation that continued to prevail in a nation torn apart by ethnic fighting.

The resolution entrusts the central organ of the O.A.U. on conflict prevention and management to pursue its efforts to prevent a further deterioration of the situation in Burundi.

More than 150,000 people have been killed in the past three years in clashes between the majority, but underclass Hutus and the minority but economically powerful Tutsis.

The resolution also requests the Secretary-General of the O.A.U., Salim Ahmed Salim, to persevere in his efforts to find a lasting solution to the conflict in Burundi and to report to the next session of the council of ministers.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

July, 1996


Gambia Gambia's Jammeh in Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 812 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Gambia's visiting military ruler, Capt. Yahya Jammeh, held talks with his Nigerian host, Gen. Sani Abacha, Thursday.

Officials at the Nigerian presidency said the talks covered bilateral and regional issues. Capt. Jammeh is on a two-day state visit. 

Gambia and Nigeria belong to the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS).

Meanwhile, according to Nigerian military sources, Gambia has asked for a renewal of a military cooperation agreement with Nigeria.

Nigeria has helped the tiny West African state train its army. The Jammeh administration suspended the programme when it seized power on July 22, 1994.

Military sources said the Gambian authorities had asked for the return of Nigerian instructors to Banjul, to boost the professionalism and quality of their army.

Nigeria's director of defence information, Brig.-Gen. Fred Chijuka, said the Gambian request was being studied by the Nigerian government.

Sports - Olympics Nigeria Names Olympic Soccer Squad


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria has named its final 22 players for the Under-23 Olympic soccer event in Atlanta, United States.

The Nigerian Football Association (NFA) said in Lagos, Thursday, the final team list contains 18 regulars and four alternate players. 

The alternate players are, Patrick Pascal, Ndubisi Ndah, Jonathan Akpoborie and goal keeper, Abiodun Baruwa.

The 18 regular players include two goal keepers, Emmanuel Babayaro and Josehp Dosu, AJAX Amsterdam striker, Kano Nwankwo and defender, Taribo West.

Others are, Austin 'Jay-Jay' Okocha, Uche Okechukwu, Emmanuel Amunike, Tijani Babangida, Wilson Oruma, Victor Ikpeba, Abiodun Obafemi, Garba Lawal, Sunday Oliseh, Kingsley Obiekwu, Mobi Oparaku and Daniel Amokachi.

Nigeria, which is representing Africa, along with Ghana and Tunisia, will play in the same group with Hungary, Japan and Brazil for the summer olympics opening later this month.

The Nigerians are already in the United States, where they are expected to play pre-tournament friendly encounters with the Saudi and American teams.

Before leaving Lagos last week, a hurriedly assembled Nigerian side won 2-0 against a local team, Shooting Stars, after being humbled 1-3 by the Togolese national team.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Treason Trial Adjourned For Lack of Case File


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The trial of eight Zambian opposition leaders accused of treason, was adjourned by the magistrate's court here, on Thursday, after the prosecution failed to produce the case file.

The magistrate, Francis Nsokolo, adjourned the case for mention until July 18, for lack of a file specifying the charges against the politicians.

Nsokolo also said the court would carry out preliminary inquiry on the conduct of the Director of Public Prosecutions, if he fails to submit the case file in two weeks. 

Nsokolo was reacting to a submission by a senior defence counsel, Edward Shawana, that the court should have initiated a probe on why the prosecution did not commit the accused for trial in the high court.

Meanwhile, the High Court will Friday, rule on the habeas corpus application filed by the accused last week, challenging the legality of their continued detention without trial.

The eight, all leading members of former President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party (UNIP), were arrested early June and charged with four counts of treason, in connection with bomb explosions in parts of the country claimed by a group which calls itself the "Black Mamba."

Defence lawyers urged the high court presided by Justice Peter Chitengi, that the men be set free since the state appeared to have no evidence to try the suspects.

A state counsel, Teddy Nondo, said that he had personally seen the director of prosecution who confirmed receipt of the case file, saying he was studying the matter.

Meanwhile, police Thursday, turned away UNIP supporters in the court premises. This was to prevent a repetition of the pandemonium which broke out during the last two court sessions.

Shawana had earlier appealed to the magistrate to tell the police that they had no powers to stop, harass or intimidate citizens who wanted to hear the case.

Nsokolo agreed with the defence lawyer that people must be accorded an opportunity to hear the case since the matter was not being held in camera.

Among the accused is UNIP deputy leader, Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta, who did not appear in court Thursday, because he has been admitted to a private hospital here.

Yeta fell sick last week while in court, after reportedly drinking some water. Medical authorities at the hospital have denied speculations that he could have been poisoned by some people in the court.

Africa News


July, 1996


West Africa Nigeria Rotates Troops In Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria has sent about 1,500 troops to beef up the West African Peace Keeping Force (ECOMOG) in Liberia.

Nigeria has the largest continent in ECOMOG's estimated 10,500-strong force. 

A military spokesman said in Lagos Thursday, the troops, who left Lagos for Monrovia Wednesday, would take over from those who have concluded their tour.

They left in a Nigerian naval ship, NNS Ambe, which brought home some 1,400 displaced Nigerians from Monrovia two weeks ago.

The Commander of Nigeria's Western Naval Command, Commodore Ibrahim Magole, urged the soldiers before their departure to be "loyal, dedicated and good ambassadors" of the country in Liberia.

ECOMOG, now under the command of Nigeria's Maj.Gen. John Inienger, was originally sent to Monrovia in August 1990, by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), to try and stop factional fighting in Africa's first republic.

The war begun Dec. 24, 1989, in form of a rebellion by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) against the government of late President Samuel Doe.

Doe was killed in September 1990, by Taylor's former ally-turned-foe, Prince Yormie Johnson, now an exile in Nigeria.

In spite of ceaseless peace efforts by the ECOWAS and the international community, the six-year-old war, which has claimed some 150,000 lives, has continued in Liberia, founded in 1847 by freed slaves from the United States.

Observers blame the warlords for the continuation of the senseless war, which has also made refugees of about half of Liberia's 2.5 million population.

Renewed hostilities among the factions erupted April 6, resulting in the evacuation of foreigners and further attempts by more Liberians to flee their devastated country.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Western Sahara Morocco Accuses Rawlings of Bias Over Western Sahara


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - Morocco has accused President Rawlings of Ghana, in his capacity as chairman of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), of bias and negative intentions in asking the United Nations to revive its involvement in Western Sahara.

In a letter to the Security Council in June, Rawlings reportedly urged the UN to reconsider its temporary suspension of its settlement plan for the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara.

Reacting to the letter, the Moroccan prime minister, Abdellatif Filali, said in a letter to the council that "the concerns of Mr. Rawlings regarding peace in the region are a poor disguise of his relentless animosity towards Morocco." 

Filali, who is also his country's foreign affairs and cooperation minister, accused the ECOWAS chairman of perpetrating "political skid" by acting without the knowledge of the members of the sub-regional organisation.

"Judging from the reaction of the countries concerned, it is now an established fact that the latest developments of the Sahara question were not discussed at any ECOWAS meeting," he said, adding that ECOWAS the member countries had dissociated themselves from the action.

Filali said that instead of interfering in the issue, the ECOWAS chairman should "save his energies...for the settlement of the tragedy that has long affected his sub-region." He was referring to the six-year-old civil war in Liberia.

The Security Council, saying that Morocco and the Polisario Front lacked the will to implement the settlement plan, voted on May 29, to suspend the identification of potential voters in a proposed self-determination referendum for the former Spanish colony.

It also decided to reduce the strength of the UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO).

The identification process, which is far behind schedule, is aimed at determining who is eligible to vote in a long-overdue referendum on the self-determination of the people of Western Sahara.

In the 1980s, the Organization of African Unity (OAU) recognized the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR), which was proclaimed by the Polisario Front. This prompted Morocco to withdraw from the continental organisation.

Three ECOWAS members, including Ghana and Nigeria, have observers in MINURSO, whose strength is being reduced from 288 to 230.

But Senegal says it has nothing to do with the appeal by the ECOWAS urging the UN to maintain its involvement in Western Sahara.

"Although it is a full member of ECOWAS, the Republic of Senegal was never consulted on the initiative that culminated in the letter...from the current chairman of ECOWAS to the president of the Security Council" concerning Western Sahara, Senegal's ambassador to the UN, Ibra Deguene Ka, said.

Senegal's action is the latest in the controversy generated by Rawlings' letter.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Tourism Set To Become Top Money-Earner


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The South African tourism industry can grow to 10 percent of Gross Domestic Product by the year 2005, earning the country almost 10 billion U.S. dollars year in foreign exchange, thereby creating one million new jobs.

This is the opinion expressed in a white paper on Development and Promotion of Tourism in South Africa, released recently. 

But this can be achieved only if the main factors currently inhibiting tourism in South Africa are overcome, the paper says.

The factors as crime, poor service, inadequate protection of the environment, unsatisfactory ground transport systems; and inadequate tourism education and awareness.

Dawie de Villiers, until this week Minister of Environmental Affairs and Tourism in the Government of National Unity, said tourism currently contributes four percent to South Africa's GDP. "This is well under the world average," he said, "and nowhere close to the percentage of countries with well-organized tourism industries."

The white paper stipulates the key policies required to lift tourism to the desired levels, and says an implementation strategy to reach these objectives is now being prepared.

"This strategy will also contain details regarding projects and target dates, and is planned to be completed by September 1996," said de villiers.

He pointed out that some critical programmes, such as training and safety and security, were already being addressed, but said that full scale implementation of the new strategy would start only toward the end of this year.
