154 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Says Mission In Burundi Not Effective


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 4, 1996 by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 760 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity mission in strife-torn Burundi would not be able to avoid or contain a tragedy if one erupted there.

In a report to the Council of Ministers meeting, opening here Thursday, OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim says the political and security situation in Burundi has deteriorated dramatically in the last few months and is "extremely tense and volatile".

"Given the prevailing political and security situation, I am becoming increasingly convinced that the (OAU) mission, as presently constituted, is not in a position to avoid or contain a tragedy in that country if it were to erupt," Salim reports. 

The OAU has a 47-member military observer mission in Burundi. Its mandate is to help restore peace.

The mission has found it increasingly difficult to operate as the security situation in the country degenerates. In some cases "even the safety and security of the OAU military observers has become a matter of serious attention."

The OAU should be prepared to redefine the mandate, size and composition of its mission in Burundi, Salim suggests.

"In doing so we might consider a variety of options, including the option of withdrawing the military component of the mission and only maintain an OAU presence at the political level to monitor developments and assist as and when the need arises."

Salim, however, suggests to the council that "for the present our mission should continue with its activities despite the difficulties," as one way of backing the initiatives of Tanzania's former president Julius Nyerere for peace in that country.

The crisis in Burundi begun when fighting broke out between the Hutu majority and Tutsi minority after the democratically elected Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye, was killed by Tutsi soldiers in an abortive military coup in October 1993.

Fighting between Hutu militias and the Tutsi dominated army has forced thousands of civilians to flee the capital, Bujumbura, and led to much destruction of life and property.

Meanwhile, Several thousand university students in Bujumbura on Thursday, demonstrated against proposals to send a regional peacekeeping force into Burundi.

The proposal was made last week at a regional summit in Arusha, northern Tanzania, on the ethnic conflict in the central African state.

The students, from Burundi's only university, demanded the resignation of the president, Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, saying he had plans to dismantle the regular army.

The demonstrators carried banners that read: "Foreign Military Intervention in Burundi Equals Dismantling the Army", "We Demand Conscription of the Youth into the Army", or "The Regime in Power Must Fall", "We Want New Men to Lead the Country."

The army is dominated by the minority Tutsi who are pitted against the majority Hutu.

The current president, Ntibantunganya, is Hutu although his cabinet includes some Tutsi ministers, including the prime minister, Antoine Nduwayo.

The six neighboring states -- Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Tanzania and Zaire -- that attended the Arusha meeting on June 25, plan to send a peacekeeping force to Burundi.

The Tutsi opposition, led by the Unity for National Progress (UPRONA), formerly the sole party, is also strongly opposed to any foreign military intervention in the country's crisis.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Ethiopia Police Say Assassination Plot Foiled


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 30, 1996


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Addis Ababa - A statement issued by the Investigation Coordination Department of the Police Force Central Bureau said police has foiled the conspiracy of a clandestine organization to assassinate high government officials, renowned individuals and foreigners especially American citizens.

The alleged members of the illegal, underground organization including its chairman Dr. Taye Wolde-Semayat and deputy chairman and economic affairs head Seleshi Berhane as well as other members have been put under police custody following the abortive attempt, the statement said.

It said rather than organizing peacefully and carrying out legal and peaceful political work, the illegal organization has been undertaking until early 1995 extensive activity following the insurrectionist path to establish an underground organization initially under the name "Ethiopian Unity Patriots Front".

Following is the full text of the statement. 

According to the constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, every citizen has the right to subscribe to the political view of his choice, to organize freely and in accordance with the law and regulations to move throughout the country to mobilize supporters and to protest in a peaceful manner. This right has been exercised in full since the beginning of the transition period when it was inscribed in the Charter. This right is respected today with a greater constitutional guarantee following the adoption of the Constitution which was produced with the participation of all the peoples of our country.

Whereas the democratic rights of citizens and peoples are constitutionally guaranteed, their implementation can only succeed when all citizens exercise their rights in a lawful and orderly manner. The fact that during the transition period and since then, political parties were established and succeeded in functioning legally, and that citizens began to extensively exercise their democratic rights is a proof of this reality. As has been seen to date, all measures taken by the government, from ensuring peace and stability to the establishment of democratic structures to promote the exercise of democratic rights emanate from the Government's desire to provide proper legal protection for the democratic activities of citizens and political parties.

While the activities of political parties that are carried out in a peaceful and lawful manner need to be protected and encouraged, it is the duty and responsibility of the law enforcement bodies of the government to protect against illegal activities aimed at destroying by force the peaceful and democratic order achieved through sacrifice, and to take legal action if such activity has indeed taken place.

In this regard, the Investigation Coordinating Department of the Police Force Central Bureau has began a legal investigation into an illegal organization that is bent disrupting the peace of the land, destabilizing the democratic process and furthermore fomenting disorder and terror. As soon as the investigations initiated by the department are complete, the matter will be brought to the attention of the relevant bodies for their decision.

The matter that is being examined by the Investigation Coordination Department of the Police Force Central Bureau is the following. As referred to earlier, rather than organize peacefully and carry out legal and peaceful political work, until early 1995 extensive activity has been undertaken following the insurrectionist path to establish an underground organization initially under the name " "Ethiopian Unity Patriots Front" and a short time later under the name "Ethiopian National Patriots Front". Among those that initiated and organized this movement are included:

1. Dr. Taye Woldesemayat

2. Ato Sileshi Berhane and three other collaborators

These persons and their collaborators who chose to embark on this illegal and destructive path carried out secret meetings in Addis Ababa and after elaborating the organization's programme, elected among themselves Dr. Taye Woldesemayat as Chairman, Ato Sileshi Berhane as Deputy and responsible for Economic Affairs, and other for military responsibilities. Following a plan to implement the programme of their underground organization, they took various measures giving priority to identifying sources of income, securing weapons and recruiting former military officers to carry out military duties. Accordingly,

1. Regarding sources of Income:

The organization, for financing its illegal activities has decided to follow the method of forcing people especially wealthy individuals to pay contribution as well as robbing, by forceful means, governmental and private business institutions.

2. Regarding Arms:

In order to fulfill the plans of the organization the first option was to collect arms through purchase and in this regard a launcher and an Uzi rifle with their ordinances were captured. Moreover, to carryout their activities they have stockpiled different types of armaments in Eastern Gojjam where they were captured.

3. Recruitment:

As indicated above, in order to increase its source of income through robbery and to be able to use the arms that were acquired former army officers -- namely Captain Moges Assefa, Lieutenant Chane Tolla Teffera and Dagne (Targeta Leuel) -- were recruited and issued weapons. The Ethiopian National Patriotic Front, as it was initially established in a clandestine manner, conspired and planned to carry out terrorist activity especially in Addis Ababa to augment its income through robbery, to assassinate high government officials and renowned individuals as well as foreigners and especially American citizens. This conspiracy was foiled before it was executed and Sileshi Berhane escaped arrest while Lieutenant Chane Tolla Teffera was arrested after an encounter with security officers and after causing a slight injury on a policeman with the rifle issued to him by the organization.

Others are under detention pending investigation of their case in accordance with the criminal code.

In connection with this clandestine plot, Gebre Tsadik Haile Mariam, the person who was involved as a coordinator, liaison man and organizer was apprehended concealing an Uzi rifle and numerous bullets. He is currently under investigation along with his accomplices.

According to the results of the investigation obtained so far, Gebre Tsadik Haile Mariam has deployed in 1987 Ethiopian calendar a team of this illegal organization to throw grenades on the premises of the American Government Aid Agency USAID, located near the Bole Road. Moreover it has also been ascertained that in 1985 Ethiopian calendar an attempt was carried out to murder an American employee of the USAID.

The Department of Investigation Coordination of the Central Police will submit, through the Federal Attorney's Office the case to the appropriate court as soon as the investigation on the alleged criminals is completed.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Ethiopia Flood Devastation Assessments Underway


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency July 5, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission(DPPC) said no devastation has occurred in Afar due to the overflowing of Awash River while the regional state's administration asserted that the flooding has affected thousands and needs urgent solution.

The commission in its recent statement said that it has confirmed from a team deployed in the Gewane and Bure-Mudaitu localities in the discussions had with regional officials that there was no disaster and no need for assistance.

Dr. Kifle-Mariam Amde-Mariam, leader of the team, said his team has survived the reportedly affected localities by helicopter except Afeambo and was briefed during its meeting with officials that no emergency relief aid was needed and the already reached not yet distributed. 

Ato Esemael Alisero, head of the regional state, said the team had discussed the matter with regional officials but was not informed that the disaster has not occurred.

He said the flooding repeatedly devastated the localities this rainy season, adding governmental and private enterprises have cooperated to construct a dike to prevent the disaster.

Ato Esemael said the available aid would be distributed to the victims through food-for-work program.

The official urged the Ministry of Water Resources and other concerned bodies to support its efforts of seeking lasting solution to the problem.

The DPPC said it has sent 2,000 blankets, 200 quintals of biscuits, 100 tents and 60 rolls of plastics to the victims.

The Afar Regional State administration had reported that over 50,000 inhabitants fled their homes due to the flooding.

Meanwhile, the North Omo Zone administration said 2,170 people affected by the overflowing of Bilate River in Humbo Woreda were provided with 490 quintals of food grain, nutritious food and tents.

Social affairs head of the zonal administration, Ato Daniel Demissie said the relief aid was distributed to local farmers and workers of Bilate Agricultural Development Enterprise who were dislodged from their homes by the flood.

90 quintals of beans and 900 liters of edible oil as well as medicines were provided by the World Vision Bilate project.

Ato Daniel said the food aid lasts only for five days and that additional relief food is required to help the victims.

The flood has also caused water-borne diseases affecting children and the aged, Ato Daniel said, adding the people are in dire need of medicines and medical personnel.

The flood has affected over 2,170 people, killed 1,900 domestic animals and destroyed crops on 1,500 hectares, it was learnt.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


East Africa Ethiopia Asserts Rights to Nile


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency July 5, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia as a sovereign state has the right to harness rivers in her territory and has begun activities to develop the Nile basin with an outlay of 50 million birr, a senior government official announced.

Ato Shiferaw Jarso, Minister of Water Resources, in an interview with Ifoyita, a private magazine, said the agreement reaches between Egypt and Sudan to share the annual water flow of the Nile River in 1959 without consulting the Upper Valley countries will not be implemented in countries like Ethiopia. 

Without exploiting Nile, which accounts for half of the country's water resource, it is virtually impossible to overcome famine and be self -sufficient in food he noted.

The minister said Ethiopia's stand to use the Nile equality and in common has the backing of international law.

The accord reached in Helsinki, Finland, on the use of River Nile in 1966, has provisions for balanced and equitable utilization he said, adding this has given Ethiopia a legal ground.

Egypt and Sudan have been preoccupied for long in propagating the idea that Upper Valley countries should not use the river for they receive sufficient rain water, he said, adding the right to equitable utilization, the idea Ethiopia adheres to, as won acknowledgment. There will be no negotiation other than this, he added.

Small-scale irrigation projects are under way in Tigray, Amhara and Oromiya regional states to use the Nile River, he said.

Ethiopia gets 110.15 billion cubic meter of water from its rivers while the subterranean water resource is estimated at 2.5 billion cubic meter, the magazine said.

The Nile basin, which covers 17 per cent of the area of the country, accounts for 52.62 billion cubic meter of the total water resource of the nation.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Angola Boutros-Ghali Calls on Angolans To Speed Up Peace Process


BYLINE: United Nations July 3, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

United Nations - If the peace process in Angola is to succeed, the parties, especially the Uniao Nacional para a Independencia Total de Angola (UNITA), must show greater readiness to implement, in good time, the commitments they have entered into, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali notes in his report on the UN Angola Verification Mission (UNAVEM III).

In the report, submitted to the Security Council today, Dr. Boutros- Ghali says the pace of implementation of the Lusaka Protocol has somewhat improved during the last two months. "The promulgation of the Amnesty Law, the completion of the quartering of the rapid reaction police, the partial withdrawal of Angolan Armed Forces (FAA) to barracks, some progress in the quartering of UNITA troops, and a small beginning to the incorporation of UNITA military personnel into FAA, are all positive factors," the report notes. 

On a cautionary note, the report says that the coming two weeks will be critical, noting that the parties have not fulfilled the time-frame agreed upon between President dos Santos and Dr. Savimbi during their meeting at Libreville on 1 March. "Continuing delays in the quartering of UNITA troops, the high number of desertions from the quartering areas, the unsatisfactory quality and quantity of weapons and ammunition handed over, the failure to quarter UNITA police personnel and the incomplete withdrawal of FAA from forward positions all require urgent corrective action if the peace process is to retain credibility," the report says.

Recommending the extension of UNAVEM III mandate for three months until 11 October, the report states that UNAVEM III has become the UN's largest peace-keeping operation. "As the February 1997 target for the completion of the UN peace-keeping operation in Angola is fast approaching, I have initiated contingency planning for the phased downsizing of its military component as soon as the quartering process has been successfully concluded and the incorporation of UNITA troops into FAA and the formation of the unified armed forces have reached an advanced stage," the report concludes.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Assessment Sees Progress in Angola Peacemaking


BYLINE: Africa News Service July 3, 1996


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Washington DC - Following are the principal sections from Situation Report Number 3, issued by the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) in the Bureau For Humanitarian Response of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) on July 1.

Overview

The Government of the Republic of Angola (GRA)and representatives of the National Union for Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) signed the Lusaka Protocol, a comprehensive peace agreement, on November 20, 1994. The protocol called for a cease-fire, the quartering and disarming of UNITA troops, and the formation of a unified national army. In return for its demilitarization, UNITA would take part in a government of national reconciliation.

On February 9, 1995, the United Nations (U.N.)Security Council authorized the establishment of a 7,500-member peacekeeping operation, the U.N. Angola Verification Mission III (UNAVEM III), to help guard the current peace agreement. On September 25-26, 1995, President dos Santos and UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi attended the U.N.-sponsored Angolan Roundtable Conference, held in Brussels, Belgium. During the conference, more than $1 billion was pledged by international donors toward a multi-year reconstruction program that included demobilization, mine clearance and awareness, rehabilitation of basic infrastructure, reintegration of war-displaced persons, community development, and a reduced humanitarian assistance program to aid the transition from emergency to development. On December 8, 1995, during his first official visit to the U.S., dos Santos met President Clinton. 

For now, the success of Angolans' efforts to move from prostration to reconstruction depends on the reintegration of soldiers and their families into civilian life. Enduring tension between UNITA and GRA forces threaten to keep large parts of the country isolated, and therefore less capable of shaking off the ills produced by the long war.

In recent months, however, came signs of greater efforts by both sides to live up to the Lusaka Protocol. On March 1, President dos Santos and Savimbi met in Libreville, Gabon, where they reiterated their commitment to the Lusaka Protocol and agreed to a timetable by the end of July, and to the subsequent formation of the Government of Unity and National Reconciliation. On May 21, both sides reached agreement on the means for integrating UNITA troops into the Angolan Armed Forces (FAA). On June 3, a group of 15 UNITA officers were sworn into the FAA, with another 30 officers entering the FAA on June 15. As of June 25, 51,537 UNITA soldiers were registered in 14 U.N.-run quartering areas (QAs) On May 8, the Security Council extended the mandate until July 11, and called on both sides to complete the quartering of UNITA troops. Severe inflation and a moribund economy led President dos Santos to replace key government ministers on June 7.

Numbers Affected

The number of Angolans inside the country currently requiring external emergency assistance is estimated at 2.2 million, including internally displaced persons (IDPs) and demobilized soldiers and their families. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) also estimates that there are some 325,000 Angolan refugees in neighboring countries: 200,000 in Zaire; 96,000 in Zambia; 12,600 in the Congo; 1,600 in Namibia; and 15,000 in 32 other countries.

Total U.S. Government (USG) Humanitarian Assistance FY 1996 (to date): $48,776,095.

Current Situation

In 1995, UNITA officials throughout Angola harassed humanitarian relief workers and denied them clearance for flights and road convoys. Several organizations suspended relief activities in December 1995 for security reasons, but most resumed operations in January 1996. The opening of roads for peacekeeping and humanitarian purposes has been hindered by thousands of unexploded mines, numerous destroyed bridges, and a lack of security in many parts of the countryside. Nonetheless, access throughout the country has gradually increased, and new pockets of needy populations continue to be identified. IDPs in some provinces have slowly begun to return home, and targeted assistance programs have been shifted to help them rebuild their lives. Banditry, landmines, and general insecurity have nevertheless deterred many IDPs from returning home.

The U.N., non-governmental organizations (NGOs), the GRA and UNITA are all working to reopen the country by improving roads and implementing mine-clearing programs. The Central Mine Action Office of the U.N. (CMAO) estimates that there are 10 million landmines in Angola. The country suffers from one of the world's highest per-capita rates of mine accidents, which have left an estimated 70,000 civilian and soldier amputees. CMAO works closely with the GRA's Mine Action Institute (INAROE) as well as with international NGOs to conduct de-mining and mine-awareness activities. USAID supports the mine-awareness and de-mining activities of four NGOs and provides technical assistance to CMAO. Some budding commerce, free movement of people, and reconstruction have resumed.

Winter rains ceased temporarily in January, damaging some crops, such as corn. Pockets of malnutrition continue to appear. Early this year emergency food interventions followed a report in December 1995 by the World Food Program (WFP), World Vision Relief and Development (WVRD), and Action Contre la Faim (ACF) of high levels of malnutrition in Gonguembo, Kwanza Norte Province and in Cusse, Huila Province. A joint WFP-GRA-UNITA team also reported alarmingly poor nutrition levels in Likua, Cuando Cubango Province. A survey by CARE in April showed malnutrition in the area around Quilengues and Catala, Huila Province, resulting from physical isolation imposed by the political/military situation, poor rainfall, and theft. CARE and WFP undertook feeding programs to overcome malnutrition in the communities.

Political/Military Situation

Although fighting officially ceased with the signing of the Lusaka Protocol, decades of accumulated hostility and mistrust set the stage for subsequent cease-fire violations. More than 500 U.N. observers are currently stationed in 50 sites throughout the country to monitor such violations, and an additional 5,800 UNAVEM III troops are acting as a further buffer to deter skirmishes. Despite many cease-fire violations in late 1995, efforts by both sides in early 1996 have enabled the peace process to progress.

Together, UNITA and the GRA have released more than 500 prisoners of war since November 1994. In accordance with the Lusaka Protocol, the GRA has begun to barrack its para-military Rapid Intervention Police. The two sides have formally agreed to military integration provisions, including ways of merging UNITA forces into the FAA, and for demobilizing excess manpower from both sides to create a unified army of 26,000 former GRA soldiers and 26,000 former UNITA fighters.

As stated in the peace agreement, QAs have been erected throughout Angola for the registration and disarmament of UNITA soldiers under U.N. supervision. To date there are 14 QAs. Likua QA, Cuando Cubango Province, opened in early June. In mid-May, Savimbi promised to have 50,000 UNITA troops in QAs by June 15, and 60,000 by July. As of June 25, 51,537 UNITA personnel had registered, although desertions reduced the total by 4,849. With them came 56,085 dependents. Days before the June 15 deadline, UNITA delivered enough troops to the QAs to satisfy UNAVEM officials.

Security Situation

Although a recent increase in the numbers of UNITA soldiers registering at QAs points to progress in demobilization, the enduring presence of military checkpoints and unrecovered land mines have prevented thousands of IDPs from returning to their homes. Lawlessness prevails throughout most of the country. On April 3, two UNAVEM officers and the deputy representative of OXFAM were murdered by unknown gunmen on the road between Cubal and Lobito in Benguela Province. Aid convoys on the road were consequently suspended for a week.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996

Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance International Lawyer Explains Donors 'Interference'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 3, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - An international law expert last Saturday explained the supposed "interference" of donors in Zambia's affairs, urging the government to closely examine its international affiliations with a view to understanding them better.

Citing the problem posed by the attempt of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) to intercede in Zambia's affairs, Michelo Hansungule, an international law expert and University of Zambia Law School lecturer, said Zambia as an independent state which had voluntarily joined international organis- ations was bound by law to follow their regulations.

He said " the international personality of a country and therefore its sovereignty is affected by the membership of the state in an organisation or agency". 

"Article Four of the SADC treaty provides that its member states shall act in accordance with the following principles; sovereign equality of all member states; solidarity, peace, and security; human rights, democracy, and the rule of law; etc," he said.

But ruling MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata, who participated in the debate on The implication of donor aid on the democratic process, organised by the Legal Resources Foundation, said the government had not erred in any way and demanded that Hansungule cite specific areas where it had gone wrong.

"There is no crisis in the country," Sata maintained.

But UNIP secretary general Sebastian Zulu insisted that the government had breached all the aid conditions demanded by donors including democratic governance.

"Zambia and other governments receiving aid are currently accountable to the donor community for the money donated to show how it has been spent. This has been the only real accountability in societies in which there has been no democratic control. It is important that this accountability included political questions and in particular that it was tied to progress in democracy, human rights, and the rule of law until such time that democratic institutions and attitudes had developed to the extent that the local aid recipient society can bring their government to account," Hansungule explained.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Party Laments Zambia's Sinking Image In Region


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 3, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Democratic Congress National Secretary Derrick Chitala has called on President Chiluba not to undermine Zambia as a legitimate state in the SADC region.

"The tragedy for Zambia is that President Chiluba has undermined the legitimacy of our government. That is why not a single neighbour agreed to come and open this year's Zambia International Trade Fair (ZITF)," said Chitala. 

But opening the ZITF last Saturday, President Chiluba did not comment on the low participation of the international community but encouraged Zambians to look forward to a bright future.

"The whole structure of the economy has changed in the last five years...Goods are now available on the market, the infrastructure is improved, the roads, hospitals, and schools, have been improved," said the President who explained that this was due to the on-going privatisation programme.

Supporting the President, ruling MMD national secretary, Minister Without Portfolio Michael Sata, said yesterday it was not mandatory for the President to attend every meeting in person.

"It is enough that Zambia was represented at the SADC meeting. That is the purpose of representatives and missions abroad, to cover for the President," said Sata who dismissed Chitala's claims "as nonsense".

ZITF chairman Leonard Kafunda was, however, disappointed with the non-appearance of South Africa, Zimbabwe, and India who he said had confirmed but failed to show up at the last minute.

"I would like to appeal to exhibitors to avoid last-minute pull-outs and appeal to countries in the region and beyond to take advantage of the trade fair," Kafunda said.

He urged the government to work closely with business organisations.

Some government sources revealed that President Ketumile Masire of Botswana had been invited to open this year's fair but had declined due to last Friday's SADC meeting.

However, Chitala said the near boycott of the Zambian trade fair was just one sign, among many, that the international community was not pleased with what was happening in Zambia.

"What Chiluba should know is that the cold war is over and no despot can find peace in either East or West. We only have one world of democracy, and if Chiluba continues to subvert democracy in the manner he has done this one world will find him and he'll be crushed," Chitala warned. "His defence of sovereignty is false and he is transforming our country into a pariah."

Meanwhile, Mozambique President Joachim Chissano told the Zimbabwean Sunday Mail newspaper after the SADC meeting that he did not approve of the current amended constitution.

"...I cannot approve of what has been done...had matters been thought over differently, animosity would have been avoided and perhaps the prestige of the man who is thought of as the father of the Zambian nation would have been protected," he reportedly said.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia's Group Is Tough


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) July 3, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - National team deputy skipper, James Phiri has described Zambia's grouping in the final stages for the world cup qualifiers as the toughest in Africa.

"This is the toughest group among all the groups, we really have to work hard just from the beginning because we are in a tough group," Phiri said in an interview at Sunset Stadium yesterday during a league match between Zanaco and Power Dynamos. 

But the goalie, who is yet to recover from his arm injuries, insisted that Zambia, which has been placed alongside South Africa, Zaire and Congo, has a lot of chances of emerging winner of the Group 3.

"As the top seeded team, I think we stand a good chance of qualifying for the world cup.This is our only chance of ever playing in the world cup finals, but all our opponents are tough hence we don't have to underrate them," said the Zambian goalie of the games which will see Zambia visit Congo between 8 and 10 November this year.

Group one has 1994 African champions, Nigeria, Guinea, Kenya and Burkina Faso, while Group two has Egypt, Namibia, Tunisia and Liberia while Cameroon, Zimbabwe, Angola and Togo make up Group four.

Morocco, Gabon and Burundi are in Group five.

Africa News


July, 1996


United States and Africa Former Ambassador Criticizes U.S. Efforts in Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 26, 1996


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the prepared testimony by former U.S. Ambassador to Liberia James K. Bishop for the U.S. House of Representatives Subcommittee on Africa. Bishop also served as deputy assistant secretary of State for human rights.

Thank you for the opportunity to appear before the Committee today. The plight of the Liberian people has received too little attention in Washington. The Committee's initiative is most welcome by those who want to see the U.S. government act more vigorously to assist the Liberian people in their hour of extreme need. 

It is not necessary to remind members of this committee that Liberia was established as a nation by Americans, freed from slavery in this country. The special relationship between the two countries dates from the time of American settlement 175 years ago. Given the disparity in size and wealth is it not surprising that Liberians have set greater store in this relationship than have Americans. But it is disappointing that the United States government, which was able to take Liberia's support for granted when American security was threatened, has responded so hesitantly to the desperate pleas of Liberians caught up in a conflict brought on in part by their friendship for the United States.

During two world wars which presented little threat to their national interests Liberians formally allied themselves with the United States. In the latter conflict rubber from Liberia was among the critical inputs enabling America to become the arsenal of democracy. Airfields and port facilities the U.S. military were permitted to construct on Liberian soil became stepping stones for the supply of allied forces fighting the Nazis in North Africa and Europe.

With the onset of the Cold War Liberians again put their security at risk to assist the United States. Permission was given to build extensive communications, navigation and information installations which almost certainly put Liberia on our global adversary's target list. Unrestricted U.S. military access to the country's international airport facilitated resupply of forces sympathetic to the United States in the proxy wars waged in Africa between the United States and its adversaries. Diplomatically the Liberians joined the United States in contesting the efforts of the Soviets and their allies to extend their influence throughout newly independent Africa. Whether it was recognizing Israel or expelling the Libyans, the United States could count on Liberia for consistent support.

The conflict which has transformed more than half of Liberia's population into refugees or internally displaced persons while killing over 150,000 of their number began as a Libyan-backed incursion. Charles Taylor's forces received arms and training from both the Libyans and Libyan surrogates in Burkina Faso. This targeting by the Libyan government was intended, I believe, as revenge for Liberia's outspoken opposition to Libyan aggression and subversion in Africa. Still smarting from the U.S. Air Force raid on Tripoli, Qadhafi probably also saw an opportunity to avenge himself on Washington by threatening the security of the cluster of American strategic assets located in Liberia.

Despite a mutual defense pact the atrocities committed by President Doe's troops as they responded to the incursion quite properly ruled out any U.S. military role defending the Liberian government Doe headed. But Washington's decision to disengage from diplomatic efforts to bring the conflict to a negotiated conclusion was an ominous sign. It soon became clear that the United States was going to seriously disappoint those Liberians who thought the special relationship would prompt Washington to make an effort to resolve their conflict at least as serious as that which Washington had engaged in to solve civil wars in African countries in which the United States had no historic interests.

As it became increasingly clear that the officials of the neighboring Ivory Coast were stoking the fires of civil war by permitting arms and other supplies for Taylor to transit their territory, there were no vigorous American protests. The Ivory Coast was on the Security Council and the U.S. was not going to jeopardize Ivorian support for American objectives at the U.N., particularly after Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. So the arms continued to flow in. Soon Taylor was being allowed to export logs cut from the rain forest to earn the money to pay for the arms. The American government remained mute.

An American naval flotilla was dispatched to Liberian waters to assist in the evacuation of Americans and foreigners. When the American embassy was threatened a few hundred Marines were sent ashore. But the pleas of Liberians that the Marines remaining on board be sent into Monrovia to chase the belligerents out of the capital before they destroyed it went unheeded. Absent American leadership the United Nations Security Council took no step to dispatch peacekeepers. For the first time in the history of the United Nations that responsibility was left to a regional military coalition, a coalition formed by some of the world's poorest states, left to finance their peacekeepers without any United Nations support.

For the past six years the United States has substituted humanitarian assistance for the exercise of the political will necessary to resolve the Liberian conflict. It apparently has not been on the agenda for high-level meetings with the French government. Paris' long-standing antipathy to Nigerian leadership aspirations in West Africa has made it an important and not always helpful actor in the Liberian drama. Hesitation, wishful thinking and bureaucratic gridlock have inhibited American financial support for the peace accords negotiated by West African states. The most recent and promising of these was signed last August. Although American experience in Mozambique, Angola and in dealing with conflicts far removed from Africa should have made it obvious that substantial funds would have to be provided for retraining and resettlement programs for combatants, none had been set up when the war resumed in April. Half of the meager $10 million earmarked by the U.S. to support a peacekeeping force on which the West Africans have expended hundreds of millions of dollars still had not been committed by April.

The Liberian civil war has been grotesque. The faction leaders are war criminals as reprehensible and deserving of punishment as those indicted by the International War Crimes Tribunals. The Liberian people are their victims. They are powerless before the intoxicated boy soldiers conscripted by Taylor, Boley, Kromah and Johnson. It is the Liberian people we have let down. If we are not willing to use our professional military forces to protect them, at least we should not deny them the protection envisioned by the United Nations Charter their government signed as a founding member. If we cannot even muster the resolve necessary to do this for our Liberian allies, let us cobble together a policy which combines financial support for the West African peacekeepers with significant programs for retraining and reintegrating the combatants, international monitoring of Liberia's borders to inhibit arms inflows, a ban on imports of Liberian goods from territory controlled by the warlords, and assistance to Liberian civil society, so that it has a chance to become the foundation for the eventual construction of a democratic Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Says Zaire Making Democratic Progress


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a statement issued on June 28 by Glyn Davies, acting State Department spokesman, welcoming "some important and long-awaited strides" by Zaire in preparing for May 1997 elections.

Zaire has made some important and long-awaited strides in preparing for the elections envisaged under the transition to democracy launched over six yeas ago. The United States congratulates Zaire for seating a National Elections Commission (NEC) earlier this year, and for the NEC's announcement of a concrete electoral calendar calling for national, legislative, and local elections beginning in May 1997. These encouraging developments have given new impetus to a democratic transition which had too long been mired in partisan squabbling among Zaire's political factions and legislative inertia.

The United States believes that Zaire's political class and civil society must now work closely together to finish the enormous tasks which remain to prepare for elections. The High Council of the Republic-Transitional Parliament must adopt an electoral law and move a draft constitution to a popular referendum. We hope that these documents will be finalized in consultation with civil society, in a spirit of openness and concern for the will of Zaire's people. We look forward to an atmosphere of free discourse which Zaire's citizenry may learn more about the electoral process and its eventual candidates. The United States will continue to monitor closely the evolution of the election process in Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Wants To Cut Off Liberia's Factions


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 28, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2614 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the prepared testimony on Liberia by acting assistant secretary of State for African Affairs William H. Twaddell before the U.S. House of Representatives Subcommittee on Africa.

I am pleased to report that the situation in Liberia has improved since Assistant Secretary Moose met with you in early May. The city of Monrovia has been relatively calm for one month. Some fighters of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and of Alhaji Kromah's United Liberation Movement for Democracy (ULIMO-K) have left the city or observe the "no guns on the streets" dictum of the West African Peacekeeping Force, ECOMOG. The standoff at the Barclay Training Center has been resolved with the fighters of Roosevelt Johnson's ULIMO-J having left the center unarmed. ECOMOG is deployed throughout the city and is seizing arms caches and exerting its authority to keep the peace. A large majority of those made homeless by the fighting have returned to their homes, although many whose homes were destroyed remain in displaced persons centers, including about 4,500 persons in the Embassy's Greystone Compound. Some Liberians and others have sought ways to leave Liberia, including on boats. There is still augmented security at the Embassy, but evacuation flights have virtually ceased with the resumption of commercial air traffic into Monrovia on June 17. 

Current Situation

The United States government is energetically pursuing the opportunity provided by relative restoration of calm in Monrovia to push for resumption of the peace process. Our strategy remains consistent with what we described to you in May. Its core elements include: increased support for ECOMOG; enhanced diplomatic efforts aimed at encouraging maintenance of the cease-fire and restoration of the Abuja peace process; and stepped-up pressure on the faction leaders to cooperate. As Secretary Moose said in May, we believe the Abuja Accord, which provides for an interim government, disarmament, demobilization, and the holding of free and fair elections, continues to be the best framework for a permanent solution. ECOMOG remains key to achieving this goal. The early August Summit of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) will be critical when the West African leaders measure the progress toward reestablishing the peace process and take decisions regarding their continued involvement.

At this moment, Special Presidential Envoy for Liberia, Ambassador Dane Smith is in the region. Last week he consulted with European governments, to explore how we, in conjunction with our allies, can best work with the countries of the region to strengthen ECOMOG. Ambassador Smith is also exploring ways we can work with others to keep pressure on the faction leaders to participate in good faith in the peace process. We are convinced that the faction leaders must be made to see their interests are best served by the reestablishment of a functioning national government and the disarmament and demobilization of fighters.

The last point, keeping pressure on faction leaders, is closely related to the timely topic we are here to discuss today. The ability of the faction leaders to find collaborators in the international community to whom to sell illicit Liberian commodities to provide the wherewithal to arms merchants to procure and deliver weapons and munitions, is at the core of the tragedy of this seemingly endless conflict. Breaking this vicious cycle is critical to ending the war.

The Arms Trade

A steady flow of arms and munitions to Liberia's warring factions has kept the Liberian conflict going for over six years. Our information about this trade is sketchy and full of gaps but does lead to some conclusions. Almost all weapons currently reaching Liberia transit countries in the region rather than arrive directly in Liberia. Which country, depends on which faction is the intended recipient. Arms reaching Charles Taylor's NPFL most likely transit Burkina Faso and Cote d'Ivoire. Those destined for Alhaji Kromah's ULIMO-K are likely to pass through Guinea. Some of the Krahn factions have in the past received weapons from Nigeria via Nigerian troops in ECOMOG.

Illicit cross-border trade in Africa is not uncommon because of porous borders. The extent to which arms transfers to Liberia reflect conscious national government policy of the countries is difficult to gauge. Clearly, corrupt local or national government officials and ethnic sympathies make it possible for such transfers to continue even in the face of official policy expressly forbidding them.

Most of the arms and ammunition reaching Liberian factions are purchased on the gray market through private dealers in various countries, primarily in Europe. The NPFL, ULIMO-K, and the LPC have been the primary recipients of illicit arms shipments.

The international community has long discussed the critical importance of ending arms flows to the Liberian factions. A 1992 ECOWAS declaration called on all nations to stop arms transfers and restrict commercial activity with Liberia. Later that year, the United Nations Security Council imposed an international arms embargo on Liberia. When the United Nations agreed to send an observer mission to Liberia (UNOMIL), the mandate included responsibility for monitoring cross-border trade in an attempt to end illicit arms transfers. UNOMIL troops were deployed on the borders until fighting in September/October 1994 forced them to withdraw to Monrovia.

Revenue Sources

The steady supply of arms -- none of the factions keeps large inventories -- depends on a steady supply of money. The primary source of funds appears to be from the sale of commodities from Liberia's trove of natural resources, principally diamonds, timber, gold, and rubber. At present, Taylor and his current ally Alhaji Kromah control the most of the areas where these commodities are found, namely across the northern tier of the country and along the border with Cote d'Ivoire. Kromah's rival, ULIMO-J, had access to some diamond areas before being pushed out of Tubmanburg. A Florida political science professor, William Reno, wrote recently: "The war has been as much a battle over commerce inside and beyond Liberia's borders as it has been a war for territory or control of the government."

Publicly available trade statistics suggest the magnitude of revenue available to Liberia's faction leaders from commodity sales. From 1990 to 1994 Liberia's diamond exports averaged $300 million annually. During the same period, timber exports averaged $53 million annually, rubber exports, $27 million annually, and gold exports close to $1 million annually. Iron ore exported from 1990 to 1993 (none was taken out in 1994) averaged almost $41 million annually. Even taking into account the inevitable smuggling of some of these commodities, especially diamonds, discounts for trafficking in illegal products, and bribes for officials in countries these products transit, the sums of money available to faction leaders are still substantial. Charles Taylor, who has long controlled the most lucrative areas of the countryside, could have upwards of $75 million a year passing through his hands.

Just as most of the arms entering Liberia transit neighboring countries, so the commodities whose profits pay for the arms transit neighboring countries en route to their final destinations. To a large extent, those destinations are in Europe. Trade records indicate that most Liberian-origin diamonds probably find their way to Belgium. Buyers in France and Malaysia are the primary customers for Liberian timber.

Another source of funds, notably since the Abuja Accord of August 1995 brought the faction leaders into the ruling Council of State, has been revenues from Liberia's maritime registry, which constitute 90 percent of the Liberian government's legitimate revenue. Following disbursement to the government last fall of ship registry revenue, there was a notable rise in foreign travel by Liberian faction leaders, especially those on the Council of State and their supporters, who travel with large entourages. Ship registry revenues are about $16-20 million annually.

Business Deals and the United States

Although the United States is not believed to be a major source of arms for Liberia or a principal recipient of illicit Liberian commodities, it is fertile ground for activities that have contributed significantly to the coffers of Liberian faction leaders and have certainly helped prolong the war. Most of the Liberian faction leaders and their associates have spent many years in the U.S., often as students, temporary workers, even as permanent residents. They own property, own or operate businesses, and, more importantly, they know how the U.S. system works and how to make it work for them.

Their activities fall into five major categories: direct fund-raising, investments, U.S. bank accounts, scams, and the sale of raw materials. The following examples are indicative:

-- New Horizons, a group based in Providence, R.I., aggressively solicited funds for several years through a sophisticated newsletter and direct appeals via radio talk shows and personal appearances at Liberian-American events. In 1994, New Horizons raised over $2 million, some of which was used to finance the coup attempt of former Doe Lieutenant General Julue in September 1994. The group, which used to confine its activities to New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Maryland, conducted major fund-raising efforts in 1995 in California and Texas.

-- Charles Taylor either owns or controls a tree service company in Maryland, a legitimate business which reportedly won a contract to provide all landscaping services to the City of Baltimore, thereby generating $2 million monthly to the business.

-- When negotiations seemed headed toward peace about a year ago, numerous wealthy businessmen in the U.S. reported contacts from certain Liberians and unsuspecting U.S. church leaders asking them to contribute to a dubious fund to rebuild Liberia. Monies contributed later disappeared. Another scam offered commodity concessions or monopoly business opportunities in gold or diamonds in postwar Liberia at extremely favorable terms. We do not know how many hundreds of thousands of dollars may have been collected in these appeals.

Conclusion

All of this adds up to a grim picture: warlords wantonly exploiting their country's resources to keep themselves and their rag-tag forces in weapons with virtual international impunity and, in some cases, complicity.

The Administration is keenly interested in putting an end to the United States serving as a source of weapons or funds for faction leaders. However, curbing the generation and expatriation of funds, even when it is highly probable that they are fueling the Liberian war, is difficult as long as those involved comply with U.S. law. Fund-raising activities are not restricted and funds are easily spirited out of the country. Evidence of arms purchases in the United States, money-laundering, transportation of stolen merchandise, non-payment of taxes, or non-compliance with asset reporting requirements are easier to combat. But arms are not generally being purchased in the United States and most of the lucrative commodity trade is directed elsewhere. Even were commodities entering the United States, consider how difficult it would be to prove Liberian origin of timber, for example.

Nevertheless, we continue to seek ways to constrict these activities. As Ambassador Moose announced in May, the United States reimposed visa restrictions on the faction leaders and their close associates for impeding the peace process by renewing fighting in Monrovia in April. Discussions with European Union members have resulted in many of them agreeing to follow suit. We are also exploring with our European allies the extent to which other measures might be imposed collectively on Liberian faction leaders if they fail to cooperate with restoration of the peace process.

The U.S. government firmly believes it is in the interest of all the people of Liberia to end exploitation of Liberia's riches for illicit benefit of a few to the detriment of the majority. With its rich natural resource base, Liberia has the potential to be a wealthy country. Not only is the plunder of Liberia's resources contributing to a continuation of warfare, it is depriving the people of Liberia and future generations of their rightful inheritance. We believe it is incumbent on all countries to ensure that the U.N. Arms Embargo against Liberia is not violated within its territory. We have called on its neighboring countries to adhere strictly to the U.N. arms embargo and several U.N. Security Council resolutions on Liberia have urged the international community as a whole to do the same.

We have (urged) and will continue to urge countries aware of violations to bring them to the attention of the U.N. Sanctions Committee; only then is the U.N. obliged to investigate allegations. Both aspects should be tackled equally aggressively: the illicit commodity sales that provide the warlords wherewithal, and the mechanisms of arms purchase and delivery. States or individuals engaging in or turning a blind eye to either are perpetuating Liberia's tragic war and should have to answer for their acts before national and international laws.


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Civil War In Sudan Not On OAU Agenda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996 by Peter Mwaura , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1290 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - The long-running civil war in Southern Sudan does not feature on the Agenda of the council of ministers of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), now scheduled to begin here Thursday.

The Council will prepare for the Assembly of the OAU heads of state and government next week. The Summit is expected to focus on the problem of conflicts in the continent. 

The omission of the southern Sudan problem contrasts with the attention that is being given in the OAU Agenda to other rebellions against established governments in Africa.

These include conflict situations in Sierra Leone, Burundi, the armed infiltration by the army and militia of the former government in Rwanda and the defiance of Gen. Roosevelt Johnson of ULIMO-J of Liberia against the council of state.

The summit will also examine the government crisis in the Comoros and the tribulations of the peace process in Angola.

It will also focus on Somalia, where three is no central government and warlords are pitched against each other, Western Sahara, where a referendum for self determination has so far been hampered by difficulties in identifying voters, the territorial dispute between Eritrea and Yemen, and the dispute between Libya and the Britain, France and the United States, who have maintained sanctions against Tripoli over accusations of supporting terrorism.

But OAU spokesman, Ibrahim Dagash, told Journalists Tuesday, the civil war in Sudan, as well as the territorial dispute between Nigeria and Cameroon, which has also been omitted from the agenda, "could come up during the heads of state meeting".

The Sudan People's Liberation Army has been fighting a protracted guerrilla war against the Khartoum Government, to press demands for autonomy and the removal of "sharia" laws in Southern Sudan, which is predominantly christian and animist as opposed to the Arab Muslim north.

The civil war, which started in 1983, has resulted in thousands of refugees and displaced persons and economic destruction, as well a straining of relations between Sudan and some of the neighboring countries.

Although the civil war has been forgotten, Sudan, Africa's largest country, features prominently in the report of the OAU Secretary-General's report to the meeting -- in connection with the attempted assassination on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on June 26, 1995, soon after his arrival in Addis Ababa for an OAU Summit.

The incident, in which Sudan was accused of harboring three of the suspected would-be assassins, damaged relations between the country and Egypt as well as Ethiopia.

Last March, OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, visited Khartoum "to demonstrate my personal concern and that of the OAU over the gravity of the problem arising from the attempted assassination of the President of Egypt."

On May 10, the United Nations Security Council imposed a number of punitive measures against Sudan for not extraditing the three suspects and supporting terrorists and subversive groups.

Sudan also features in Salim's report in connection with the presidential and legislative elections it held march 6-17. At the invitation of the Sudanese Government an OAU team monitored the elections which, it reported, were "conducted peacefully".


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Angola Currency Clamp Down Dollar Counterfeiters


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - The National Bank of Angola, the country's central bank, is collecting all 100 U.S. dollar bills printed in 1990 and 1993 now in circulation in Angola, to return to the United States for a check of their authenticity, banking officials said in Luanda.

The director of the Supervision Department at the bank, Joao Abel, told reporters Tuesday that "given the sophisticated level of the forgery, we do not have the technical means to detect forged bank notes. 

And there is no other solution than to send them to the United States," he added.

Thousands of forged 100-dollar bills are circulating in Angola where forgers were arrested last week. This activity is mainly by diamond traffickers in the Lunda-Norte and Lunda-Sul provinces, in the north-east and east of Angola.

Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Mandela Keeps Taiwan Ties For The Moment


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996 by Lionel Williams , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa is to maintain its diplomatic ties with Taiwan for the moment, even though a break has been stipulated as a prerequisite for establishing diplomatic relations with Beijing.

Confirming this Tuesday, South African President Nelson Mandela said he would make no such decision until China resolved what he referred to as "an internal matter." 

Mandela, who is in direct contact with Taipei and Beijing over the sensitive issue of which China should be recognized by South Africa, pointed out that Taiwan and the People's Republic of China had supported the African National Congress in the war against apartheid.

He said he could not be assisted by a country and then reject it once he came to power.

"I haven't got that type of immorality and I will not do it," he added.

"This is an internal (Chinese) matter," he said. "We believe in one China. Resolve your problems. Don't expect us to."

Meanwhile, President Mandela is to make a three-day official visit to Israel beginning August 19. He will also meet with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat.

This follows the announcement, earlier this week, that the South African leader is to make state visits to Britain and France in July. He will be in the United Kingdom from July 9 to 12, before moving on France from July 13 to 16.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1996


West Africa Abacha, Rawlings And Eyadema Discuss West African Problems


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings has held talks with the Nigerian military leader, Sani Abacha, aimed at reviving the central role of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, ECOWAS.

Briefing the media on the talks, Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi said that for sometime now "it seemed that ECOMOG has taken center stage and there was the need to re-define the central theme for which ECOWAS was established". 

ECOMOG is the West African Peace Monitoring Force sent by the community to Liberia in 1990 at the height of the civil war.

Tuesday's talks, lasting four-and-a-half hours, were held behind closed doors. But officials said they were also aimed at furthering previous consultations, between the two countries, on the Liberian crisis and how best to harmonize their joint efforts at bringing lasting peace to that country.

Ikimi said that Abacha had come to meet Rawlings since the Nigerian leader did not attend the Accra emergency meeting of the ECOWAS Committee of Nine on Liberia, after the upsurge of fighting April in Monrovia.

The talks also touched on the impending summits of the Organization of African Unity and of ECOWAS. He thanked the Ghana government for responding to the visit despite the short notice.

"This express the cordial relationship that has transcended our various governments," he said.

Accompanying Abacha were the Minister of Information, Walter Ofonagoro and Wada Nas, Special Duties.

Abacha, also met briefly Tuesday, with Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyedema.

Information was not immediately available on details of the talks held in Eyedema's home region of Kara, some 400 kilometres north of the Togolese capital, Lome.

Togo, a co-founder with Nigeria, of the Economic Community of West African States, is mediating in Nigeria's dispute with Cameroon, a non-ECOWAS member, over ownership of the Bakassi Peninsula.

170 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large UN Space Agency To Link African Professionals


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The Geneva-based United Nations Office for Outer Space, is to establish a satellite-based information network to link African scientists, educators, professionals and decision makers, according to an official of the agency.

The chief of the space applications section of the office, Adigun Ade Abiodun, said in New York Tuesday the system, to be known as the Cooperative Information Network (COPIN), would encourage the use of space technology to improve health care and education.

It would also help efforts to protect Africa's natural resources and environment, he added. 

Adigun, speaking on a UN television programme, World Chronicle, said the network would be established with the support of some European countries and the European space agency.

It would allow African experts in various fields to exchange information and conduct library research locally and globally.

He said the decision to establish the network was taken in 1993 at Dakar, Senegal, at a conference organized to sensitize African countries to the uses of space technology.

"At the conclusion of that particular conference, the participants implored us to please bridge the communication gap between and among African professionals, scientists, educators and decision-makers," said Abiodun, a Nigerian.

"Through this COPIN programme, which is really to be managed by the professionals and the universities, we hope that the opportunity will be created to enable what I call mass participation in this effort," he added.

Apart from COPIN, the UN specialized office is also planning to set up centers for space science and technology education in Africa.

Abiodun said the centers would be established in Nigeria, for the Anglophone African countries, and in Morocco for the Francophone countries.

According to Abiodun, "the two countries are developing the necessary legal tools of agreement."

Meanwhile, the UN office plans another conference in South Africa in November, which Abiodun said was aimed at widening the use of the technology across Africa.

The conference is to be held with the support of the South African government and the European space agency providing financial assistance.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Business and Finance Nigerian Securities Boom


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 3, 1996 by Paul Okolo , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The value of securities traded on the Nigerian Stock Exchange rose by 20.6 billion naira in the January to March quarter, according to the latest figures from the exchange (81 naira =1 USD).

The report also shows that market capitalization hit 191.7 billion naira, up from to 171.1 billion in the previous three months. This represents a 12.1 percent rise. 

Brokers said new listings and strong (price) gains in the manufacturing sub-sector accounted for the growth.

The all-share index soared by 171.65 points in the period, or by 3.4 percent.

However, the report said the gains during the quarter were moderated by losses in the banking and petroleum sub-sectors.

Oil shares suffered due to a slowdown caused by the scarcity of petroleum products while the banks have been experiencing difficulties as a result of distress in the economy.

Meanwhile, turnover of shares traded last week was up on the previous week's figures.

Some 25.9 million shares valued at 133.9 million naira were traded last week in 1,101 deals.

The previous week saw 11.4 million shares worth 100.9 million naira change hands in 1,187 deals.

The health care sector was the most active with 8.1 million shares worth 26.5 million naira changing hands in 35 deals. This was followed by the insurance sector with 5.3 million shares worth 3.9 million naira in 47 deals.

The all-share index for the week rose by 27.7 points to close at 5798.72 as against 14.4 in the previous week.

WAPCO was the biggest gainer, rising by 0.60 naira to 23.90 naira, followed by Cadbury and Northern Nigerian Flour Mill which added 0.44 naira and 0.40 naira respectively, to end at 21.00 naira and 7.95 naira.

A glut of brewing and tobacco shares further depressed their prices.

Nigerian Breweries shed 0.20 naira to 15.00 naira, a 0.20 naira loss.

July, 1996


South Africa De Klerk's National Party Quits SA Government


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996 by Lionel Williams , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The white-dominated National Party of South African led by deputy president, Frederick de Klerk, pulled out of Nelson Mandela's government of national unity Monday, effectively losing its grip on power for the first time in half-a-century.

The NP now becomes the main official opposition to President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC), which won a majority in the first South African multi-racial polls in April 1994. 

The NP, which won 20 percent of the votes in the elections, announced a few months ago that it was leaving the government because the ANC had refused to extend a power-sharing arrangement beyond the next election in 1999.

Relinquishing his position as deputy president after 18 uninterrupted years in government, de Klerk claimed his party could be back in power sooner than his critics expected.

He predicted a change in the trend of voting along racial lines, saying "I am confident that this fluid situation presents better opportunities for us, and that our time outside government will be much shorter than the experts might now believe."

He added that he expected to win support from millions of black people who have become disenchanted with the ANC. He also predicted that the National Party would have a black leader one day.

"The time will come," said de Klerk, "when the overwhelming majority of those who vote for the National Party will be blacks, browns and Indians.

"In the final analysis -- I don't know when -- there will be a black or a brown leader of the National Party standing before you," he said.

July, 1996


Angola Counterfeit Dollar Ring Dismantled in Luanda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996


LENGTH: 174 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - Angolan police announced Monday that they had dismantled a ring of counterfeiters involved in forging United states dollar bills in Luanda. 

The gang specializes in making fake 100 dollar notes, the police said in a statement.

It said an Angolan and 15 other African nationals were arrested in a police raid in the capital on Sunday.

Equipment used by the fraudsters were also seized during the police operation code-named 'Lightning', it added.

The police said most of the culprits were from Cameroon, Congo, Gabon and Mali. The amount of counterfeit dollars seized in the operation was not revealed.

July, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Reassures UN On Transition Programme


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, has assured the United Nations of continuous progress in the country's transition to democracy programme and the release of detainees.

Abacha told a UN envoy, Lansana Kouyate, in Abuja on Thursday, that the current release of detainees (eight have been freed), would continue according to established procedures, a UN spokes person, Sylvana Foa, said in New York on Monday.

She told reporters that the Nigerian head of state gave the assurance while briefing Kouyate on the actions being taken by the government in response to the recommendations of the UN fact-finding mission which visited Nigeria from March 29 to April 13. 

Abacha also disclosed that commissions had been established to examine other recommendations made by the mission, the UN official said.

The UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, despatched Kouyate to Nigeria as a follow-up to the report of the fact-finding mission, released last month.

"Mr. Kouyate said that the secretary-general hoped that Nigerian authorities would proceed as quickly as possible to carry out the commitment in their interim response to the fact-finding mission's report," Foa added.

In its response to the report, Nigeria said it would amend the Civil Disturbances Act, under which author Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others were tried and hanged in November last year, to exclude members of the armed forces. This is to ensure that verdicts reached under the decree could be appealed.

Other measures contained in the response include the immediate review of the cases of persons being detained under certain decrees promulgated by the military government.

Meanwhile, the Nigerian leader was reported to have raised the problems of Liberia during his meeting with Kouyate, an assistance secretary-general in charge of political affairs in the world body.

He said though he was aware of the effort by the UN secretary-general to obtain additional resources for the sub-regional peace keeping force (ECOMOG), in Liberia, the operation still needed more support from the international community.

The Nigeria-led ECOMOG, along with a handful of UN observers, is saddled with overseeing the implementation of the Abuja peace accord, widely seen as the last-ditch attempt to end the six-year old Liberian civil war.

Kouyate, who has since left Nigeria, was also scheduled to visit other west African countries, to discuss the Liberian issue.

July, 1996


Uganda Uganda's Parliament To be Inaugurated On Tuesday


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda's new parliament will be inaugurated on Tuesday, following the declaration of the full results of parliamentary elections held on June 27.

The date for the first sitting of the new parliament was announced by President Yoweri Museveni on Sunday, in accordance with a constitutional requirement that the new parliament must be convened not later than seven days after the elections. 

Meanwhile, international observers have endorsed the polls, saying they were transparent, in spite of some deficiencies.

"The elections we observed from 24-28 June were transparent. Despite the deficiencies that we have outlined, the international observer group believes that the parliamentary elections mark a further positive step within the transition in Uganda," a statement issued by the observers on Sunday said.

The over 70 international observers came from Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Greece, Japan, the Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Tanzania, Germany, the United States and the Organisation of African Unity.

"The atmosphere at polling stations with a small number of exceptions, was tranquil," the observers said.

They said they had visited 800 polling stations in 36 of the 39 districts in the country.

Niger Niger Election Slated For July 7


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The military government in Niger has insisted it will organise presidential polls on July 7, rejecting calls for a postponement by the Independent National Electoral Committee (CENI), a government release has said. 

According to the release issued in Niamey on Sunday, the military government said it did not agree with the committee's view that it would be impossible to hold the poll on that date.

CENI told reporters last Thursday, that it would be impossible to hold the election on 7 July, because of difficulties in preparing a new voters' register and cards.

Five candidates, including incumbent military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Bare Mainassara, who took power in a January 27 military coup, are running for president.

177 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Conflict Resolution Expected To Dominate OAU Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996 by Peter Mwaura , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 614 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - Discussion of conflicts and disputes are expected to dominate the meeting of the Organization of African Unity Council of Miniters meeting, beginning in Yaounde, Wednesday.

The meeting will set the agenda for a three-day summit begininig next week.

The summit, an annual event in which heads of state and government meet to seek solutions to African problems, is also expected to deliberate on economic cooperation and integration. 

African ambassadors began their two-day meeting Monday, in the Cameroonian capital, to prepare for the council of minisers meeting which is expected to end Saturday, one day before the start of the summit.

In keeping with its tradition, the summit will choose the host, Cameroon's President Paul Biya, as the new chairman of the 53-member continental body. Biya will take over from the incumbent, Ethiopia's President, Melez Zenawi.

The O.A.U. Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, in an interview broadcast Sunday by Radio Cameroon said the hotbeds of Africa and economic development will feature prominently in the summit.

He said the heads of state will, in closed sessions, talk frankly about the conflicts and disputes afflicting the continent and seek solutions.

The organisation has changed in the last four years, Salim said, and the heads of state can be expected to go beyond passing declarations.

Delegates, he said, will deliberate on what Africa could do about the conflicts and how to prevent them.

Africa's flashpoints include Liberia and Somalia, where factional leaders and warlords have been fighting each other; Sierra Leone and Sudan, where rebel movements are at war with the governments, and Rwanda and Burundi, where ethnic fighting has created instability in the Great Lakes region.

Morocco's claim over Western Sahara, or the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, and the territorial dispute between Cameroon and Nigeria over the Bakassi Peninsula, would also feature at the summit.

The conflicts have resulted in seven millions refugees and 15 million displaced people, according to 1995 figures. They have also led to widescale destruction of property and disruption of economic activities in many countries.

Meanwhile, Yaounde has braced itself to receive some 2,000 delegates and observers expected in the Cameroonian capital for the O.A.U. meetings.

"We are ready to receive heads of state and delegates of all the 53 countries of the O.A.U., the general manager of the Yaounde Conference Centre, Ndifontah Nyamndi, told PANA.

The centre, built in 1982 with a four-billion-franc grant (about eight million U.S. dollars) from China, is the summit venue.

This is be the second time Cameroon is hosting the summit. The first was in 1974.

LANGUAGE: English
