July, 1996


Southern Africa Mugabe Snubs South African Deputy President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996 by Lionel Williams , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe is reported to have publicly snubbed South African Vice-President Thabo Mbeki, when both of them met last week at a conference on attracting private investment to Africa, the Star newspaper reported at the weekend.

The Johannesburg daily said "Mugabe could not bring himself to speak a word to South Africa's Deputy President Thabo Mbeki on Wednesday night, although the two were seated next to each other at a dinner in Accra, hosted by Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings."

It said that Mugabe sat between Rawlings and Mbeki on the dais. "When toasts were offered, Mugabe clinked glasses with Rawlings. Mbeki reached across and touched glasses with Rawlings, but Mugabe stared straight ahead and would not toast with Mbeki," it added. 

"Mugabe's coldness to Mbeki," it said, "stood in stark contrast to the otherwise cordial, light-hearted summit on how to attract private investment to Africa.

"Meanwhile, Mugabe stared conspicuously straight ahead as if Mbeki were not there. Mugabe frequently turned to his left to try and engage Rawlings but never looked to his right to Mbeki," it said.

"When Rawlings left the table for 20 minutes Mugabe stared straight ahead, never uttering a word to Mbeki who talked freely with other guests," the newspaper said.

"At the dinner's end, Mugabe shook hands with Rawlings, then walked past Mbeki without a word or handshake," it said.

The report suggested that Mugabe's slights stemmed from deep jealousy. He was once the centre of attention among the frontline states but has now lost the spotlight to Mbeki and President Nelson Mandela.

Strained trade relations may have also helped sour relations between the two countries and their leaders, the report added.

But when contacted by the newspaper, Mbeki denied having been snubbed by Mugabe.

A spokesman for the deputy president said the report contained factual inaccuracies and was based on groundless assumptions. "The report was based on assumptions and observations made with insufficient information and no concrete evidence," he added.

Africa News


July, 1996


Southern Africa South Africa Retaliates Against Mozambique's Visa Requirements


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 1, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

MAPUTO, (PANA) - Mozambique's policy of charging heavy fees for entry visas has drawn swift retaliation from South Africa. From Monday, Mozambicans will find that South African visas are no longer free of charge. 

A notice published Sunday by the South African High Commission in Maputo, warns that starting July 1, each visa request must be accompanied by a fee of 30 U.S. dollars.

This charge, the high commission says, is being imposed on citizens of all countries who charge South African nationals for entry visas.

South African has tried, repeatedly but without success, to persuade the Mozambican immigration authorities to reduce the chrage.

South Africa is the most important destination for Mozambicans travelling abroad. The High Commission makes no mention of any possibility of paying the new charge in Mozambican currency, the metical.

So, if Mozambicans continue to flock to South Africa, this will drain thousands of dollars in hard currency from Mozambique to South Africa every week.

On paper, members of the 12-nation Southern African Development Community are supposed to be advancing toward the free movement of persons and goods throughout the region. In practice, as the latest measure shows, barriers are going up, not coming down.

A similar visa-free provision within the 16-member Economic Community of West African States has been operating for years and successfully. This community also issues a common travel document valid within the region.

Africa News


July, 1996


Sudan Sudan Begins Oil Production In Upper Nile


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996 by Yahya El-Hassan , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Gulf Petroleum Sudan Company Ltd has said oil production at the Adar Yiel field in the country's Upper Nile area, would commence at the end of July.

The Secretary in charge of oil prospection, Gen. Salah Wahbi, told a local daily newspaper at the week-end that three oil wells in the area will begin lifting the crude.

Wahbi told the Al-Ingaz Al-Watan daily, Sunday, that the Adar Yiel field held some 170 million barrels of crude. Up to 60 million barrels of this amount can be drilled by using the conventional methods. 

He said at the experimental stage the field will be producing 5,000 barrels of crude per day.

Sudan, he said, was negotiating with five foreign companies for oil prospecting in the country.

He said another five companies have been prospecting since 1993 in the Higlig field in western Sudan, in association with the state-run petroleum company.

The field is expected to produce a minimum of 10,000 barrels of crude per day. He said production could be raised to a maximum of 25,000 barrels per day.

Wahbi said the Wehda oil field, in the south, has a reserve of 660 million barrels. Of this, 150 million barrels can be extracted at a rate of 25,000 barrels a day.

Production in this field would start by the end of the rainy season, when oil wells would be fully linked to a storage facility, being constructed by the Canadian state petroleum company.

The Wehda (Unity) oil field is the biggest in Sudan. So far, he said, some 19 wells have been sunk there.

Overall, some 45,000 barrels of crude would be pumped daily from these fields when Adar Yiel and Wehda start production.

Sudanese President Omar El Bashir said recently his country spends 80 percent of its export earnings on the importation of petroleum products. This adds up to some 360 million U.S. dollars annually.

Khartoum imported the bulk of its oil from Gulf states until 1990, when this was stopped in reaction to Sudan's support for Iraqi President Sadam Hussein when he invaded Kuwait and started the Gulf War.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zimbabwe Foreign Investors Boost Harare Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Foreign investors have poured in nearly 1.2
billion zimdollars into the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange since government allowed them to buy and sell shares three years ago, a stockbroking firm said on Tuesday.

In a statistical analysis released in Harare, Edwards (AMPER) Company said the total foreign purchases and sales since June 23, 1993, up to June 21 this year, were valued at 2.69 billion zimdollars (269 million USD), while the net inflow was 1.194 billion zimdollars (119 million USD). 

The market was still active despite the recent downward trend in the key industrial index, with speculative purchases and sales taking place in major quoted companies such as Delta Corporation, Hippo Valley, Mashonaland holdings and Nickel giant, Bindura.

The company said in a brief commentary, that during the period ending June 21, 1996, foreigners were net sellers while the local market was soft, largely due the Colcom holdings rights issue, as well as the proposed flotation of the Seed Company of Zimbabwe, and the discount company of Zimbabwe.

Foreigners sold parcels of shares in at least 13 companies and bought in six quoted companies, among them, TA Holdings, and Barclays Bank.

Meanwhile, the Zimbabwe Stock Market, considered to be Africa's second largest after South Africa, was now capitalised at over 40.23 billion zimdollars (4.02 billion USD). This figure is expected to soar when the Discount Company and the Seed Company are listed on the exchange before the end of the year.

Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Mugabe Resumes Call For Transformation Of U.N.


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996


LENGTH: 374 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe intensified
his campaign Tuesday for the restructuring of the United Nations, saying Africa needed two permanent seats on the world body's Security Council.

"We support Organization of African Unity calls for two permanent seats to be allocated to Africa," he said. 

Opening the second session of parliament in Harare, Mugabe said Zimbabwe wanted the U.N. restructured to ensure "greater accountability and transparency" in all its organs.

Mugabe made the same calls when he attended the U.N. General Assembly in 1994.

Meanwhile, he said Zimbabwe supported the Organization of African Unity Mechanism on Conflict Resolution because African problems needed African solutions.

However, he said, this was not to ignore the role of the U.N. Security Council as the custodian of world peace and security.

He said Zimbabwe would continue to abide by its international obligations to ensure peaceful resolution of conflicts, particularly in Africa, in the spirit of co-existence, cooperation and understanding.

He told parliamentarians the government intended to sign bilateral extradition treaties with such countries as South Africa, the United States and Botswana, and make sure Zimbabwe was not a "safe haven for criminals."

Already, he said, there were plans to open the sub-regional office of Interpol in Harare, to improve cooperation in stamping out international criminal activity.

Complementary to this, he said resources would be allocated to the Zimbabwe police so the force could deal with rising white collar crime in the public and private sectors.

183 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Zambia Kaunda Challenges Govt Over Alleged Stolen Money


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KASEMPA, Zambia (PANA) - The leader of the opposition, Kenneth Kaunda,
has challenged the government to take him to court if it can be proved he stole six billion kwacha (4.53 million U.S. dollars) during his 27-year rule.

Addressing a public rally at Freedom Square Monday in Kasempa, about 350 kilometres (about 219 miles) north-west of Lusaka, Kaunda said President Frederick Chiluba and his ministers were spreading information accusing Kaunda of stealing the money. 

"Since they took over the running of the government in November 1991, I have been a free man, up to today, and have not been arrested for allegedly stealing money. Why should they continue spreading malicous information about me? Kaunda asked.

He made these remarks while touring the north-western province accompanied by his United Independence Party National Chairman, Malimba Masheke.

Although the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy has passed a law barring Kaunda from contesting the presidency in the 1996 presidential and parliamentary elections, Kaunda has said he would stand on the UNIP ticket whether or not the ruling party approved.

Kaunda will address public ralies in Mwinilunga, in the far north-west of the country.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Mandela To Visit Britain And France


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - President Nelson Mandela of South
Africa is to pay official visits to the United Kingdom and France later in July.

He will visit Britain from July 9-12 and then move on to France from July 13-16. 

Announcing this Monday, the South African Department of Foreign Affairs said the two state visits would aim at strengthening bilateral relations between South Africa and the two countries concerned.

Mandela's trip to Britain -- the first official one by a South African head of state -- has a packed itinerary. He will deliver the keynote address at the conference of the British Confereration of Industry, have tea with the Queen Mother at Clarence House, and meet Prime Minister John Major, opposition leader Tony Blair, Liberal Democratic Party leader Pady Ashdown, and Commonwealth Secretary-General, Emeka Anyaoku.

In their discussions, Mandela, the four cabinet ministers and two deputy ministers accompanying him, will be concentrating on such issues as investment opportunities in South Africa and the restructuring of state enterprises.

In France, he will address businessmen at a special breakfast on July 16. He will also be holding a series of top-level meetings with senior cabinet members.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


South Africa Poll Underscores Dwindling Support For Inkatha


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, (PANA) - The final results of the first democratic local government election in South Africa's Kwazulu-Natal Province held last week, have revealed declining support for Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP).

Figures released by the Election Control Center gave the Zulu-dominated Inkatha a total of 44.4 percent of the vote, followed by President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress with 33 percent and Frederiek de Klerk's National Party, with 12 percent. 

The remaining 10.6 percent went to the other minor parties.

Election officials point out that the figures represent a significant drop of 5.6 percent in overall support for the IFP, compared with the votes it won in the general election in April 1994.

The ANC, on the other hand, increased its total voter support by one percent.

The most important trend which emerged from last week's local government elections is the ANC's domination of the main cities and towns in Kwazulu-Natal, in addition to its significantly improved performance in the rural areas.

The party's national executive committee member, Carl Niehaus, told reporters here, that the ANC won 47 percent of the vote in the urban areas, compared with only 17.2 percent by the IFP.

This underlined the crumbling of the IFP's support base in the towns and cities, he said.

In the mainly traditional rural areas of the province, the IFP still maintained its dominance, obtaining 71.3 percent of the vote.

However, the ANC significantly improved its performance in the rural areas, with 20.6 percent of the vote, compared with only five percent in 1994.

Election officials confirmed that a total of 3.4 million voters registered for the polls, which recorded a voter turnout of 46 percent.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1996


Africa-at-Large Boutros-Ghali Seeks Africa Backing for Re-election Bid


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency July 2, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi , PANA Correspondent


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, needs unequivocal African support to back his campaign for re-election for a second five-year term, according to diplomats here.

The diplomats say an endorsement by the Organization of African Unity at its upcoming summit in Yaounde, Cameroon, would send a strong signal that Boutros-Ghali, the first African to hold the position, could not be easily pushed aside.

"If the OAU fails to endorse him (Boutros-Ghali), he is finished," a U.N. observer claimed.

The 73-year-old Egyptian diplomat, whose current term expires at the end of 1996, announced on June 19 that he would run for a second term because of "strong encouragement from member states." 

But the United States, a permanent member of the Security Council -- without whose support a U.N. secretary-general may not be elected -- says it will not support him.

Washington has accused him of being an obstacle to reform at the U.N. and promised to use its veto, if necessary, to deny him the post.

Since then, the secretary-general has received "unlimited support" from the Egyptian government, has been virtually endorsed by other Arab states, and is said to enjoy the backing of China and France, also permanent members of the Council.

Asian and Latin American countries have also reportedly indicated their support for Boutros-Ghali.

He also got a boost from the Group of Seven industrial countries who met in Lyons, France, last week.

The countries adopted a statement hailing "concrete results" of his reform of the U.N.

However, there has been little or no public expression of support from Africa, his primary constituency.

The day after the secretary-general's announcement, the African group at the U.N. held one of its regular meetings but did not discuss the issue.

An African ambassador, who asked not to be identified, said the silence among Africans did not mean lack of support for the secretary-general.

"We have been discussing it among ourselves, and the general reaction is that of surprise, disappointment and frustration at the way the U.S. went about the whole issue," he said.

The envoy said "we feel he should have a second term, just like other past secretary-generals, and that Africa should support him totally," adding: "Our hope is that the OAU meeting will be able to endorse him for a second term."

The U.S. has already started consulting with African and other ambassadors to expalin its position on the matter.

According to the African ambassador, "they (U.S. diplomats) told us that Boutros-Ghali has lost the confidence of the people and government of the U.S., that it would be senseless for us to support him, and that their action is irrevocable."

"We only hope the OAU will not waver," he added.

An official at the U.S. mission to the U.N. confirmed that efforts had begun to "convince the Africans on the futility" of supporting the secretary-general.

"We have made it clear to the ambassadors that it is not an anti-African thing, it is anti-Boutros-Ghali," the official said, adding: "We don't think he is the right man for the job."

But according to the U.S. official, who did not want to be named, the U.S. was sympathetic to Africa's wish to have a second term and was willing to support another African candidate for the position.

Asked what will be the U.S. reaction if the OAU endorsed the secretary-general for a second term, he said, "we don't think they will endorse him...they will most likely praise him, and that's it."

But Egypt's ambassador to the U.N., Nabil Elaraby, feels the OAU would have to go beyond that.

"He (Boutros-Ghali) is the representative of a region, which is Africa," he said in New York. "They will have to express their point of view."


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Tunisia's Hopes For Atlanta Olympics


BYLINE: Bouazza Ben Bouazza, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

TUNIS, Tunisia (PANA) - Tunisia's 51 athletes to the forthcoming Atlanta Olympics is the country's largest since Rome in 1960, but officials remain cautious about a large medal haul.

"We don't expect to win medals in Atlanta, because of the high level of the competition with the presence of international-class athletes and our athletes lack of maturity", Mohamed Zribi says.

He is the director of High Level Sports Competitions in the Ministry of Youth and Sports. 

However, he expressed satisfaction at Tunisia's performances at recent regional and international meets, particularly during the All-African Games in Harare and those of French-speaking communities held in Paris.

Tunisia's Atlanta bound athletes comprise 18 soccer players and 12 for volleyball. The country qualified in six individual disciplines. There are six track and field athletics, six judokas, four boxers, three wrestlers, table-tennis player and one fencer. Athletes qualified for individual disciplines include five women, or the quarter of the team for individual sports.

"Qualifying such a large number of athletes at such high levelled competition is reason to be satisfied," Zribi said.

"These first results are a testimony to the effectiveness of training of (the country's sports elites and encourages us to continue in the same way," he said.

The "Atlanta Operation" was launched in 1993 during a select cabinet meeting, chaired by President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.

A long-term national sports development plan was also worked out to ensure high level training on a scientific basis, to prepare athletes for regional and international competitions including the Atlanta Olympics and the Tunis Mediterranean Games in the year 2001.

In 1996, Zribi said, about 4.5 million dinar (about 4.5 million U.S. dollars) were spent to the training the cream of athletes. At the same time, the number of indoor sporting facilities increased from six before 1987 to 58. Tunisia now has 74 turfed sports grounds compared to 21 just recently.

Meanwhile, a new Olympic size village for the first big games of the 21st century is being built near Tunis at the cost of at least 120 million dollars.

Tunisia's soccer players are drawn against a particularly strong teams: Argentina, Portugal and the United States. However, athletes in non-team sports provide the best hope for medals in that most are African champions or have won the title several times.

Such could be the case of Ali Hakimi, 20, who will run the 1,500 metres in Atlanta. He already holds the 1,000 metres junior world record of 2.16:84.

"It will be his first participation to such an event. Our real objective is to reach the highest level of the competition. We also think about the period after Atlanta: There will be the 1997 Mediterranean Games in Bari, Italy, and the Sidney Olympics in the year 2000," Zribi says.

Fully recovered from his shoulder injury following the last Africa championships in Pretoria, South Africa, judoka Skander Hachicha may clinch a medal, Zribi said, "if he does not meet the toughest guys in the first rounds. "

"What is sure, we are not going to Atlanta to work as extras. We will do our best to honour Tunisian and African sports," Zribi says.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Youths Oppose Security Assistance


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Some 2,500 Burundian students, pupils and

jobless people demonstrated in Bujumbura Monday in opposition to proposals for a regional military force that is to try and restore order in the country.

Proposals for the force, to come from neighboring states, follow fears that the ethnic violence between the Hutu and the Tutsi could degenerate into the kind of genocide that rocked Rwanda in 1994. 

The protesters demanded the enrollment of youths into the national army to fight the external force. Some of their placards read: 'The Youth is Ready to Fight the Foreign Troops and the Facilitating Regime.'

Others read 'We Demand the Enrollment of the Youth Into the Regular Army.'

The rally's organiser, Nyandwi Oscar, said "we want to show the world that Burundi has a dynamic and reliable youth."

At a regional summit in Arusha, northern Tanzania on June 25, the Burundian President, Sylivestre Ntibantunganya, asked neighboring countries to provide security assistance.

The request was accepted by the leaders of Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Tanzania and Zaire, who formed a commission to work out the force's operations.

The force is expected to help in putting an end to clashes between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi. The killings have been going on since President Melchior Ndadaye, a Hutu, was assassinated in October 1993.

An estimated 70,000 Burundians have been killed in revenge killings since Ndadaye's death.

The youths said they will stage another protest Tuesday to show their opposition to the proposed force. Burundi's main opposition party, the Unity for National Progress (UPRONA) has vehemently opposed the sending in of the external force.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 16, 1996


Congo;
New Presidential Candidates in Congo


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - The head of the Congolese Movement for

Democracy and Full Development (MCDDI), Bernard Kolelas, has announced his candidacy for the presidential election to be held in August 1997.

Other candidates are the incumbent head of state, Pascal Lissouba, the chairman of the Movement for Congolese Reconciliation (MRC), General Jean Marie Michel Mokoko, and Mrs. Angele Bambu from civic society.

Kolelas is also head of the opposition.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Zambia;
Treason Detainees Charged With New Murder Case


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Eight opposition members facing treason charges were Monday committed to Zambia's high court for trial after the state amended the case to also include one count of murder.

The men, who had earlier been charged with four cases of treason, now face only two counts of treason, including one count of murder. The new charge is in connection with the death of a police officer killed in a bomb blast at Lusaka International Airport last May. 

State prosecutor Teddy Nondo told Lusaka principal resident magistrate Francis Nsokolo Monday, when the eight appeared before him for mention, that the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) had issued a certificate to commit the accused to the high court.

The eight are all members of the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda.

Those charged with the murder are retired army generals Joseph Chintomfwa and Nicholas Zulu, Capt. Selemani Mpangula and UNIP Central Committee member Patrick Goma.

It is alleged that the four had on May 23, whilst acting together with other unknown persons and with a common purpose, murdered Ordon Banda.

The eight also have been charged with conspiring to procure by force the alteration of the new constitution of Zambia.

Goma, Zulu and Mpangula have further been charged with trying to recruit one Wilfred Mwale to acquire explosives in order to bomb government installations, in a concerted campaign of terror designed to force the government to withdraw the latest constitution of Zambia.

The four are also charged with writing offensive graffiti carrying messages against members of parliament and government leaders, in an effort to force government to withdraw the constitution of Zambia.

The eight, who include Kaunda's deputy, senior chief Inyambo Yeta, UNIP central committee member Rabbison Chongo and Kaunda's press assistant, Muhabi Lungu and Kaunda's head of security, Moyce Kaulung'ombe have been in detention since June 4.

They were earlier charged with preparing to overthrow the Zambian government by forming a terrorist group, Black Mamba, which has claimed responsibility of planting bombs in the country.

The eight detainees had their habeas corpus and bail applications rejected by the high court three weeks ago.

Their defence lawyers had during a habeas corpus hearing argued that the charges laid against the accused were false.

The lawyers said it was not true that the accused were responsiable for the bomb blasts because even after their detention the bombs were still being planted.

But the new indictment now states that the eight were acting with other unknown people.

The lawyers had also submitted that the state had no evidence against the accused and had not made an effort during the hearing to show evidence against the accused.

However, high court judge Peter Chitengi had in his ruling noted that it was not imperative for the state to give evidence since it may be keeping that until trial begins.

The defence lawyers said they will write to the high court to see whether they can be given a special summary trial.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Mozambique;
France Counters U.S. Claim Over Aid To Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Unlikely as it might seem France and the United States, two NATO allies, have made claims and counter claims over which of them is the largest donor of foreign aid to Mozambique.

Both have claimed this honour within the past two weeks.

First, it was the Americans. Outgoing U.S. Ambassador Dennis Jett said at a reception marking his country's national day, July 4, that the U.S. was the largest donor. The speech irritated several of the Europeans present. 

Today, on the 207th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, it was the turn of the French. Ambassador Didier Destremau said: "I shall recall here that it is France which, directly and through its contribution in the European Union, is the main donor to Mozambique'.

Statistics aside, Destremau, unlike Jett, avoided lecturing Mozambicans on how to handle their future. Destremau recipes were couched in the most general of terms, to which it would be difficult to take exception.

"While it is difficult today to imagine a revolution that would lead the people to take the king to the Guillotine, it is also evident that all of us, French, Mozambicans and others, should always be carrying out a kind of revolution in a modern way," Destremau said.

He called for an end to "old habits" in Mozambique as elsewhere. The struggle to abandon "the old" would be long and difficult, he said, "but if we don't start it today, the process will take a long time."

Destremau called for decentralization "to give the people in the provinces the feeling that they have their destinies in their own hands."

Yet, France has a highly centralized government inherited since its revolution.

"To carry out this cultural revolution, the rulers and all the people should have the strength and courage to abandon old concepts of excessive centralization," he said. "As always, we French, directly or through the institutions of the European Union are ready to help Mozambique make these revolutions."

To the evident surprise of some of his audience, Destremau claimed that France was "the only European country that borders on Mozambique."

He was referring to the maritime boundary between Mozambique and Reunion, and a handful of other islands in the Indian Ocean administered by France.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


South Africa;
Princess Di To Visit South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Princess Diana of the United Kingdom has been invited to visit South Africa later this year to meet President Nelson Mandela.

The invitation was issued by South African officials, after Princess Diana failed to meet the South African leader during his state visit to the United Kingdom earlier in the week. 

She had requested a private meeting, but this had not been granted by the South Africans. It was felt that such a meeting might have proved offensive to Queen Elizabeth at such a sensitive stage in the divorce proceedings between Prince Charles and Princess Diana.

Diana was not invited to any of the functions during Mandela's state visit. However, British officials were quick to emphasize that she had not been snubbed in any way. She simply had no specific links with South Africa, they added.

Although no date has been set for Diana's visit to South Africa, a spokesman in the presidency has indicated that it is likely to take place in October or November this year.

In addition to meeting Mandela, she would tour various charitable organisations, as well as visit her brother - the Earl of Spencer - who lives in Cape Town.

All indications are that divorce proceedings between Prince Charles and Princess Diana will be finalised by the end of this month, which means that she will be officially single by the time she travels to South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


United States and Africa;
France Counters U.S. Claim Over Aid To Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Unlikely as it might seem France and the United States, two NATO allies, have made claims and counter claims over which of them is the largest donor of foreign aid to Mozambique.

Both have claimed this honour within the past two weeks.

First, it was the Americans. Outgoing U.S. Ambassador Dennis Jett said at a reception marking his country's national day, July 4, that the U.S. was the largest donor. The speech irritated several of the Europeans present.

LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Sports- Olympics;
Nourredine Morcelli Holds Sway in Middle- Distance Races


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - For five years now Algerian athlete Nourredine Morcelli has been the top middle-distance runner, smashing world records in the 1000, 1500, the mile, 2000 and 3000 meter events.

In recent years, Morcelli has emerged victorious in the several scores of competitions. His only stinging defeat occured in 1992 during the Barcelona Olympic Games, where he took 7th position in the 1500m final, contrary to all expectations. 

"I was not at my best because of an injury which delayed my preparation," says Morcelli, brushing aside allegations that he is a sympathizer of the outlawed Algerian Islamic Slavation Front and therefore avoided climbing on a podium which was used by his pro-government female athlete, Hassiba Boulmerka.

Boulmerka, the Algerian athlete with the highest number of medals, twice world champion and Olympic champion, had dedicated her victory to her country's women and to President Mohammed Boudiaf, assassinated some weeks earlier.

Nonetheless, Morcelli remains the Arab world's most famous athlete. In Atlanta, his ambition will likely be to erase the sad memories of the Barcelona Olympics, where he failed miserably in the 1500m.

Since that setback, Morcelli has never relinquished his hold on the race, with a world record of 3min 27sec 37. His closest rival holds a time record two seconds different.

Last year's Goteborg World Championships marked his third consecutive victory in the world championships. He also emerged victorious during the world championships at Tokyo in 1991 and Stuttgart in 1993.

Only four other world-class athletes have won the World championship three times -- the American Carl Lewis, the Ukrainian Serguei Bubka, the Kenyan Moses Kiptanui and himself.

In addition, Morcelli is credited for winning the Grand-prix final ranking in 1994.

As a result of these achievements, Morcelli is always the best paid athlete during tough duels, with about 70,000 dollars per competition.

Sponsored by a sportwear making company and the Algerian National Hydrocarbon Company (Sonatrach), Morcelli earns enough money to make life comfortable for his seven brothers and two sisters.

Morcelli is so attached to his family to the extent that his brothers always accompany him to competitions. He always travels with his elder brother, Abderahmane, a former Algerian 1500m champion, who coaches him, and Ali, his young brother who plays the role of a pace-maker to improve Morcelli's performance and to tire other competitors.

How far will Morcelli go? No one knows exactly. However, one can safely bet that at the age of 26, Morcelli will be around for some time because of his stunning performance in the middle-distance races. A gold is what he is looking forward to in Atlanta.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigeria Prunes its Olympic Contingent to 136


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria pruned Monday night the number of its athletes and officials to the Olympic Games from a speculated figure of 600 to 136.

It also dropped four events from the list of 10 it had originally entered for the centennial Olympiad which begins Friday in Atlanta, United States.

Announcing the changes on national television, youth and sports minister Jim Nwobodo said the Nigerian government had approved participation in sporting events that could earn the country medals. 

He said Nigerians would not want a repeat of what happened at the Moscow '80 and Seoul '88 Olympic Games from which the country's contingents returned with "a bagful of scandals rather than medals."

A total of 77 athletes and 59 officials will now represent the country at the games.

Nigeria will now take part in athletics, boxing, football, table tennis, weight lifting and wrestling. It has dropped out of the judo, lawn tennis, badminton and swimming competitions.

Athletics accounts for the largest number in the contingent with 40 competitors made up of 21 men and 19 women athletes.

In football, 22 players, made up of 18 regulars and four alternates, will represent the country as previously announced. The squad is currently in the United States, tuning up for the event.

The boxing team has been reduced from six to four boxers while the table tennis squad has been trimmed down from eight to four players.

The weightlifting team has been cut down from six to two and the wrestling team from seven to four.

Monday's announcement ended a week of suspense and speculation about the size of the Nigerian contingent and the number officials to represent the country at the games.

Sports analysts however believe the decision to drop some of the sporting events, athletes and officials is due mainly to financial constraints.

Nwobodo had been in the federal capital throughout last week, lobbying for funds. It seems his efforts were not crowned with total success.

Some 155 million naira (6.89 million dollars) was allocated in Nigeria's national budget for sports this year. This was just about half last year's allocation.

A fund-raising drive launched nationwide to mobilize funds for the country's contingent to the games does not appear to have yielded much.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 16, 1996


Southern Africa;
South Africa Business Takes Over The Region


BYLINE: Abel Basutu, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

BULAWAYO, South Africa (PANA) - Nineteenth century South Africans made a great trek southward to the Cape mired in Afrikaaner mythology and fleeing Zulu hostility and British rule.

Their present day counterparts have started another great trek, but this time to the north to establish business empires with previously hostile African states.

Leading the way is President Nelson Mandela who, at the Southern African Development Community (SADC) summit held in Johannesburg last year, declared: "We must plant the seeds of Africa's rebirth."

"We take courage from realising that conditions for economic growth are becoming favorable throughout Africa," he told a SADC annual consultative conference in the city. 

Now South African conglomerates have taken his word and are venturing north to do business, taking advantage of the republic's return to democracy in 1994.

The list is endless and includes the republic's biggest hotel groups - Sun International, the Protea group, the Conservation Corporation and Southern Sun.

"We have appointed someone to look exclusively at possibilities in sub- Saharan Africa and Indian ocean islands," said Southern Sun's chief operations executive, Helder Pereira.

Southern Sun and Intercontinental have been involved in a joint thrust into Africa and are negotiating new contracts. The partnership intends to secure management contracts for existing hotels as well as new projects.

Negotiations have been going on in Kenya, the Seychelles, Ghana, Madagascar, Nigeria and Guinea.

Southern Sun recently opened its first Holiday Inn Garden Court in Zambia - the first outside South Africa - and won plaudits from President Frederick Chiluba for bringing jobs to the impoverished nation.

It has also been negotiating to expand its Sun Game Lodges portfolio into Namibia, Mozambique and Kenya.

The Protea Group - the world's 33rd largest hotel chain - has in the last two years spent over 35 million U.S. dollars refurbishing and operating hotels in 11 African countries.

It already runs hotels in Botswana, Malawi, Mauritius, Kenya, Reunion, Tanzania and Uganda, among others.

Sun International has also made huge investments in hotels and casinos in African and Indian ocean island hotels. It already operates hotels in Botswana, Namibia, Morocco and Swaziland.

The conservation corporation, which owns some top game reserves in South Africa, is working with the Zimbabwe government to open two new luxury lodges at Matetsi, 40 km from Victoria Falls.

Some of the republic's companies have been negotiating to build new hotels in Victoria Falls - a prime tourist resort in southern Africa.

Others have signed joint venture agreements or acquired equity in neighboring Zimbabwe's companies, encouraged by free exchange controls.

In the retail sector, South African conglomerate, Pepko Ltd, last year sealed a deal to acquire shares in Zimbabwean clothing retail chain, Power Sales Zimbabwe Ltd.

Chairman of the Cape Town-based company, Arnold Louw, said should the deal be successful, Pepko would expand activities of power sales in Zimbabwe.

Another South African retail giant, Pick'n Pay Stores, has signed an agreement to buy a portion of equity in one of Zimbabwe's largest supermarket chains, TM Zimbabwe.

The agreement, which is subject to Zimbabwean regulatory approvals, is set to come into effect in October once Meikles, the holding company of TM, has completed a corporate restructuring.

South Africa's Sentrachem Ltd early this year went into a joint venture with two Zimbabwean companies, Cairns Chemicals (PVT) Ltd and Hippo Valley Estates Ltd, to establish a distillery for production of high quality alcohol.

In the power sector, South Africa's electricity authority, ESKOM, the world's fifth largest electricity utility, plans to link most of Africa's 700 million people on the grid using hydro-power.

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe in March commissioned a 35-million- dollar 400-kilovolt inter-connector, enabling Zimbabwe to import up to 300 megawatts of power - an eighth of national demand - from South Africa.

Zimbabwe started importing power from South Africa in January under the project jointly undertaken by ESKOM, the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA) and Botswana Power Corporation.

ESKOM was reportedly mapping out strategies to harness power from Zaire's Inga river and the Zambezi river, which forms the boundary between Zimbabwe and Zambia.

South Africa's gas giant, ENRON, is investing 600 million US dollars to develop Mozambique's Pande gas field.

The impetus is the signing, last year, of an agreement allowing free exchange of generating capacity among SADC states.

South Africa's conglomerates, Anglo-American Corporation and GENCOR are expanding, buying mineral rights in many African countries including Ghana, Mali, Zaire and Ethiopia. For example, mining giant GENCOR is reportedly evaluating a scheme for a one-billion-dollar smelter near Maputo.

Several other projects are under way between South Africans and Mozambicans, under an ambitious Maputo Corridor project - a transport link between Maputo and South Africa.

The Standard Bank of South Africa, one of Africa's largest financial institutions with assets of more than 26 billion dollars, has been spreading its tentacles into Africa.

Trading under the name, Stanbic, the institution now operates in Botswana, Kenya, Lesotho, Nigeria, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

In Ghana, it operates under the name of Merchant Bank (Ghana), in Madagascar as Union Commercial Bank S.A, in Namibia as Standard Bank Namibia and in Mozambique as Banco Standard Totta.

Many countries to the north are embracing their former apartheid enemy with out-stretched arms but they resent the way the republic flexes its trade muscles in a show of strength.

These include Zimbabwe and Zambia, which have for years been battling to endorse preferential trade pacts with Pretoria.

Zimbabwean industrialist, Jonee Blachfield, believes time has come for Zimbabwe to stand up against economic dominance by South Africa and warns: " If we don't, we are in trouble."

But analysts say South Africa, with a Gross Domestic Product of 130 billion dollars - 20 times that of its nearest rival Zimbabwe - is being trapped in a web of ill-feelings for its prosperity.

"They must not deny that South Africa is a super power. However, South Africa must exercise its power with sensitivity, responsibility and circumspection," said Themba Sono, a lecturer in the department of business economics at South Africa's University of Witwatersrand.

South Africa is still subject to scrutiny though interest is now focused on the country's burgeoning economy.

"In many ways, South Africa is more of an emerged than an emerging economy," said Simon Hollis, managing director of Barings in Johannesburg, in an overview of the country's economy.

Burundi;
OAU Chief In Tanzania For Talks On Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 146 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Organization of African Unity Secretary- General Salim Ahmed Salim left here Tuesday for Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, for consultations with the special envoys of the European Union and the United States on Burundi, the trouble-torn central African country.

Salim will hold consultations with the two special envoys Wednesday and Thursday at the invitation of former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, the facilitator of the Burundi peace process, according to OAU sources.

The two-day consultations are being held "as a followup of the various decisions made on Burundi" at the OAU summit held last week in Yaounde, Cameroon.

Angola;
More Unita Troops Move into Assembly Points


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Unita troops in Angola are now moving into

designated assembly points in larger numbers, the Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA) said in a statement Tuesday.

The ZNA said in the statement that peacekeeping efforts in Angola were bearing fruit while road communications were also being improved. 

Commander of the multi-national United Nations Angola Verification Mission (UNAVEM III), Zimbabwe's Major Philip Sibanda, said earlier that he was not pleased with the slow progress of moving Unita troops into assembly points.

Unita and the government's MPLA forces engaged in a bitter civil war that raged for nearly two decades until a cease-fire agreement was signed in 1994.

Zimbabwean troops in Angola, besides their military duties which include monitoring cease-fire violations, have been involved in community projects.

As more Unita troops were expected to turn up at the assembly points, Zimbabwean troops have been requested to construct another base in Malange province.

Africa News


July 16, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Chiefs To Perform Rituals At Mass Graves Of Freedom Fighters


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Traditional chiefs are expected to visit Zambia and Mozambique to appease ancestral spirits at mass graves of thousands of the Zimbabwe's freedom fighters killed during the struggle for independence.

The visit, to perform rituals, is being undertaken by the Zimbabwe chiefs ahead of the national Heroes Day celebrations next month. 

Four Ndebele and several Shona chiefs, together with their counterparts in the two neighboring countries, will perform the rituals in provinces where identified mass graves are located. Zimbabwe's liberation struggle was carried out by guerrilla fighters with bases in Mozambique and Zambia, targets of cross-border raids by the forces of the white minority regime in Rhodesia (renamed Zimbabwe after liberation).

The chiefs would bring back to Zimbabwe soils from the burial sites for re- burial at a proposed national cemetery to be called Military Cemetery.

The cemetery will be established in Harare, the capital, exclusively for war veterans.

Africa News


July 16, 1996


United States and Africa;
United States Cuts Aid to Zambia


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)--The United States Agency for International Development has cut more than ten percent of its 25-million-dollar aid to Zambia, following it's adoption of a controversial constitution that bars former President Kenneth Kaunda from contesting presidential elections scheduled this year.

Usaid director in Zambia, Joseph Stepanek said Tuesday at a press briefing in Lusaka that his government was concerned that the constitution, adopted on the eve of the country's second multiparty elections, limits the right of Zambians to freely choose their president.

The initial cuts within USAID'S "democracy and good governance program" to four projects amount to approximately 2.5 million US dollars. Last year the agency spent about 25 million dollars on Zambian projects. 

The projects affected are the assistance to cabinet office in streamlining its internal administration and a project to upgrade training equipment at the Zambia Institute of Mass Communication in the capital.

Others are support to the Washington-based National Democratic Institute for its work on the forthcoming elections and a project to assist the Zambian parliament in improving its internal processes.

"These projects represent a total of one million dollars in bilateral assistance. We will also reduce the 1996 bilateral aid program from its present level of 19,024,000 us dollars to 17,500,000, an additional cut of 1. 5 million dollars," Stepanek said.

He said the United States has already expressed its concern to multilateral donors like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund whom it will influence to study Zambia's case.

Stepanek said the aid cut was a result of the initial review of the US- Zambian bilateral and multilateral relations announced by the State Department last May.

He said donors have remained concerned about the manner the constitution was adopted when in fact the government had earlier assured the donors that the constitution would be adopted through a consensus.

He said that the amendments to the constitution were seen to reverse Zambia's commitment to an open multi-party democratic political system embraced by the Movement for Multiparty Democracy government of President Frederick Chiluba in 1992.

Stepanek also noted that there was no major effort by the Zambian government to register voters in this year's scheduled presidential and general elections, which has clearly been an issue presently in Zambia.

"Registration of voters is one of our concerns and this has clearly been an issue right now in the country and we are worried about fair monitoring of the elections, open democracy and codes of conduct agreed upon," he said.

Stepanek, who admitted that his government has a tight budget like any other government, denied that the US was cutting aid to Zambia because of the tight budget.

Other major donors who have threatened to cut aid to Zambia include Britain and Japan.

Zambia's cooperating partners and neighbors have said they feared that barring Kaunda from the presidential race might be a recipe for civil strife in the southern African country.

The new constitution bars citizens of immigrant parents from becoming republican president and also bans traditional chiefs from participation in active partisan politics unless they resigned their traditional thrones. Kaunda had Malawian parents.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 17, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Japan To Host African Development Conference


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Japan will in 1998 host an international

conference on African development, to review progress and bolster momentum for development in the world's least developed continent.

The president and director of the Institute of International Affairs of Japan, Nobuo Matsugana, said Wednesday the conference would also be aimed at promoting Asia-Africa co-operation. 

Interviewed by journalists in Harare before he met President Robert Mugabe Wednesday, Matsugana said focus would be on encouraging the democratization process and on-going economic reforms.

Economic and cultural ties between Zimbabwe and Japan are strong as evidenced by the assistance Harare has received from Tokyo in the fields of road construction, water and sanitation projects and policy consultation.

"We are very happy with the political stability in Zimbabwe and the economic reforms and we are looking at fostering, enhancing and expanding our relationship," said Matsugana.

Zimbabwe at the end of last year, completed its first phase of the economic structural adjustment program which scored some successes in so far as opening up of the market was concerned.

International financiers are however, still pressuring the government to exercise more financial discipline and reduce the budget deficit.

Like other African countries, Zimbabwe is faced with a huge foreign debt burden of four billion U.S. dollars.

202 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 17, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela Holds Talks with -UNESCO's Mayor


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

PARIS, France (PANA) - The Director-General of the United Nations

Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), Federico Mayor, held a meeting with President Nelson Mandela of South Africa on Tuesday on areas in which the organization can assist Pretoria's development programs.

The two sides agreed to focus on human resources development, UNESCO said in a release.

"In the present economic and social context, UNESCO's main asistance to South Africa should be in the area of human resource development, especially for those children and adults who have no access to mainstream education and vocational systems currently available," Mayor said during talks with Mandela who was on a visit in Paris. 

South Africa is still burdened with huge inequalities including 60 percent adult illiteracy among blacks and 40 percent unemployment. "The heritage of educational deprivation remains a major problem," Mayor said.

UNESCO plans to develop an intensive learning program using audio-visual materials in the multiple mother tongues of South Africans, "so that vocational training can be transmitted quickly to the many, thousands of South Africans," he added.

They also agreed to expand cooperation with the South African Development Community (SADC), and said UNESCO has established an office in Pretoria to work with the country and the region.

"For us, the SADC region remains a priority and the best context for co- operation in that part of Africa," Major said, noting the importance that his organisation places on the World Solar Summit which will be held in Harare, Zimbabwe this September.

Mandela and Mayor agreed that programs related to vocational training, education, human resource development and other activities will be futher refined during the director-general's planned visit to South Africa from September 11 to 14.

Mandela said he was grateful for the assistance UNESCO has provided and continues to provide, and the honours it has bestowed on him personally.

South Africa rejoined UNESCO in December 1994, after an absence of nearly 40 years. Sicne then, the organization's activities in that country have focused on education, adult literacy, culture, communication, science and technology.

UNESCO awarded its Simon Bolivar prize to Mandela in 1983 while he was still incarcerated in South Africa's Roben Island prison, in recognition of his courageous struggle for justice and human rights.

Released after 27 years in prison in February 1990, Mandela paid a visit to UNESCO in June that year, during his first trip to Europe.

Two years later, he was honoured with UNESCO's Houphouet Boigny peace prize, an award he shared with former South African president Frederik de Klerk in October 1993.

During the Tuesday meeting, Mayor bestowed the UNESCO Gandhi medal on Mandela, describing him as"a symbol of peace, wise leadership, tolerance and farsightedness".

UNESCO also mounted a photographic exhibition that chronicles the life of the South African leader. The exhibition of 27 mainly black-and-white photographs by South African photographer, Alf Khumalo, will run through July 30.

LANGUAGE: English

203 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 17, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia To Immunize 1.6 Million Children


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga , PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - In an effort to eradicate polio, the Zambian government intends to vaccinate 1.6 million children below the age of five, irrespective of their current immunization status.

The anti-polio vaccination will be held under the country's national immunization days on July 19 and 20 and on August 23 and 24, health officials said in Lusaka.

The Zambian national immunization days will be held as part of a global strategy to eradicate polio from Africa by the year 2,000. 

Children are expected to be given two extra doses of the oral polio vaccine with a five-week gap between each dose. The national immunization team has selected two strategies to reach children in all communities in Zambia.

These children will get their doses at fixed vaccination posts or from mobile teams moving from house-to-house. The government has also declared this coming Friday and August 23 as half-days to enable the public to take children to be vaccinated.

Poliomyelitis is a crippling disease caused by a virus, known as "wild polio virus."

Virologists say that For every person having clinical symptoms of paralytic polio, there are 99 others infected who look healthy but spreading the virus.

Under normal circumstances the virus survives only in human body. It can however live for a few days in the environment.

During the last decades in Zambia, cases of poliomyelitis have been identified throughout the country. Statistics from the country's virology laboratory indicate that there were four Acute Flaccid Paralysis cases in 1992, eight in 1994, 45 in 1995 and six confirmed polio cases in 1996.

Since the expanded program on immunization was introduced in 1975, at least 75 percent of Zambian children younger than one year were vaccinated against poliomyelitis, by the end of 1995. Some 26 African countries, including Zambia, are expected to hold full or partial immunization days in 1996 under a global commitment to make Africa a polio-free continent.

Zambia is grouped together with Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda in the eastern Africa polio epidemiological block.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 17, 1996


Science;
AIDS Causes Development Setbacks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - AIDS caused human development setbacks of

between 10 years and six years in five eastern and central African states during the 1980-1992 period, says a United Nations report released Wednesday.

The "Human Development Report" issued by the UN Development Program (UNDP) shows that worldwide, HIV/AIDS caused an average loss of 1.3 years of human development progress.

The document says setbacks were particularly severe in Zambia, where it reversed human resource progress by ten years, Tanzania (eight years), Rwanda (seven years) and the Central African Republic (more than six years). 

The report bases its facts on findings by researchers at Columbia University and the Havard Institute for International Development in the United States. Burundi, Kenya, Malawi, Uganda and Zimbabwe lost between three and five years in human development, says the document. The countries mentioned are in what is described as the AIDS epicentre, where prevalence of the human immunedeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, range from between seven and 13 percent. The researchers used a method which compared the actual 1980 and 1992 human development index with the estimated 1992 index that would have occured in the absence of AIDS. Although tuberculosis causes more deaths since 1980, says the report, "AIDS has had a greater impact on human development precisely because AIDS deaths are concentrated in the age group 20-45," says the report. "This finding is significant. It shows that it is now out of date to argue that HIV/AIDs is an exaggerated health crisis diverting attention and funding from more important, though less spectacular, health problems of developing countries." UNDP cautioned that governments that do not take the AIDS threat seriously now, or shy away from action because of cultural or religious sensivities, "will pay the price later." " More resources, political commitment and innovation need to be brought to bear against this pandemic, while still maintaining adequate attention to other health challenges," the UNDP report says.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 17, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Allows Relief Flights to South


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan has agreed to the use of C-130 aircraft for the delivery of urgent relief supplies to the south of the country, the official daily 'Al Engaz Alwwtani' reported Wednesday.

Khartoum had barred the delivery of relief supplies to the south by aircraft after claiming that some organizations involved in ferrying them were taking arms and ammunition to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). The SPLA has been fighting the central government in Khartoum since 1983.

"Sudan has allowed the use of C-130 planes for transportation of relief," the state minister at the ministry of social planning, Majzoub al Ahalifa, was quoted as saying Wednesday by the official Sudan News Agency (SUNA). " Other planes will soon start flights for the transportation of relief and other materials within the context of the UN-sponsored Operation Lifeline Sudan."

Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) was organized in 1988 by the UN, the Sudanese government, and the SPLA to facilitate the delivery of relief supplies to people trapped by the fighting in southern Sudan.

Western donors were last week reported to have made an appeal for relief supplies to be allowed through. This follows an acute shortage of food in the war affected areas due to the ban on relief flights imposed by the Sudanese government.

The Sudanese official also said the UN had agreed to use Malakal, in Sudan's Upper Nile state, for distribution of the relief supplies instead of the Kenyan town of Lukishcokio.
