Africa News


July 19, 1996


Togo;
27 Deaths As Petrol Tanker Overturns in Togo


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LOME, Togo (PANA) - At least 27 people got burnt to death Wednesday night at Agame-He village, 67 km north of Lome, the capital of Togo, as they tried to steal petrol from a tanker involved in an accident.

Sixteen other villagers also suffered serious burns from the fire caused by an explosion from the oil tanker. 

The accident occurred along the Lome-Cinkasse road leading to neighboring Burkina Faso.

The fire was sparked by a kerosene lamp held by woman who got too close to the vehicle, causing the tanker to explode into flames. The fire engulfed the looters and the nearby shrubs.

The driver of the vehicle, Moussa Djibo of Niger and his assistant, were not at the scene of the accident when the explosion occured.

The two had returned to Tsevie, the district headquarters, 32 kilometers away, to report the accident to the police.

The Tsevie magistrate's court has opened up an inquiry into the cause of the accident.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Southern Africa;
Regional Interpol Office Opens In Harare


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A southern African regional office of theinternational policing organisation, Interpol, was opened in Harare on Friday, just months before the Southern African Development Community (SADC) free movement protocol agreement is effected.

A rise in crime is anticipated when the 12 SADC member states relax travel regulations and open their borders to nationals of member states. 

Home Affairs Minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, said the establishment of an Interpol sub-regional office would help member states cope with cross-border crime.

"Free movement of people in the region will be a big challenge for the sub- regional office as we await the ratification of the protocol by the end of the year," said Dabengwa.

The SADC region has become a haven for criminal activities such as car theft, drug trafficking and use of fraudulent travel documents.

"As our countries continue to strengthen their economies, we must at the same time underscore the point that without security, stability and prosperity within the region, there can be no socio-economic development," said Dabengwa.

The free movement protocol is scheduled to be effected by the end of the year, after heads of state ratify it.

Interpol has 176 member countries in different continents and the Harare office becomes the second such in Africa after Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire.

The organisation, the second largest after the United Nations, uses its information network to trace and apprehend international criminals.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwean Minister Says Britain Resumes Land Aid


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's Lands and Water Resources Minister Kumbirai Kangai said on Friday the British government has agreed to fund the country's land resettlement program.

Kangai told a news conference that he, together with the minister for local government, rural and urban development, John Nkomo, had met British Overseas Development Minister Baroness Lynda Chalker early this month and she had reaffirmed her government's commitment to the program.

"Our mission to London was successful because we wanted the British government to recommit their earlier commitment in 1979 at the Lancaster House Conference on facilitating the (land) resettlement program," said Kangai. 

But as he was addressing the news conference, British High Commissioner Martin Williams was telling a Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency (ZIANA) reporter that his government will not provide new aid for the land redistribution program unless the Zimbabwean government acquires land on the principle of willing seller-willing buyer.

"We want to continue to believe that any money on land must be on willing seller basis. It's something that we have made clear to government throughout. ..

"We have confirmed our own willingness to provide assistance to the land issue provided under the context of a satisfactory policy framework. We have proposed the idea of a roundtable conference to enable interested parties to join and some donors to contribute to the cost of the program," said Williams.

The Zimbabwe government needs about Zimdollars 1 billion (USD 100 million) to resettle over 80 000 families, 20 percent of whom have to be liberation war veterans.

A large portion of the land is to be taken, with compensation, from white commercial farmers.

Zimbabwe passed the land acquisition act of 1992 which enables the government to designate and acquire farms it wants to resettle millions of its landless people.

The land acquisition policy has been heavily criticized, especially by Zimbabwe's white commercial farmers who occupy about 70 percent of Zimbabwe's arable land.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Business and Finance;
Foreign Investment In South Africa Exceeds Projections


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Direct foreign investment in South Africa during the past two years has exceeded initial projections.

The boost in foreign investment is revealed in the latest report of Business Map South Africa, a local publication which focuses on business intelligence. 

The report says that actual and intended direct foreign investment in South Africa, since the 1994 general elections which ushered majority rule in the country, amounted to more than 4 billion U.S. dollars.

The figure exceeded provisional estimates of between 2.3 billion and 3.75 billion dollars.

The United States has been the leading investor in the country, far ahead of more traditional trading partners like Germany and Britain.

American investments since 1994 exceed 1.8 billion dollars -- more than double that of Germany, which ranks second with 730 million dollars.

The United Kingdom comes a distant third with 525 million dollars, followed by such other countries as Malaysia, Korea, Switzerland, France, Austria, Japan, Singapore and Taiwan.

The report also reveals that the dominant sector for foreign investment was that of food and beverages, which alone attracted 1.2 billion dollars. Other major fields of foreign investment were motors and components, electronics and information, and hotels and leisure.

A total of 45 investment portfolio from 10 new companies were focusing on the manufacturing sector. Thirty British companies were concentrating in the fields of engineering, telecommunications, oil, energy, chemicals and publishing.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


South Africa;
Talks On Trade Relations Between Germany and SADC


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - A highly significant round of discussions between South Africa and Germany will take place here, later this month, on the important issue of future trade relations between Europe and Southern Africa.

The German embassy in Pretoria has announced that German Deputy-Chancellor Klaus Kinkel will meet with President Nelson Mandela to discuss future links between the European Community and the 12-nation Southern African Development Community (SADC). 

Kinkel will be in South Africa from July 23 to 25, as part of a four-nation tour of southern Africa. He will also visit Botswana, Mozambique and Zimbabwe, the German embassy said in a statement, released here on Friday.

According to the statement, Kinkel will hold top-level meeting in all four countries. These discussions will concentrate on regional co-operation within the framework of SADC, as well as co-operation between SADC and the European Union.

On his return from state visits to England and France earlier this week, Mandela was confident that progress would be made in settling a trade agreement between the union and South Africa.

But he emphasised the importance of ensuring that any such agreement would include the other eleven members of SADC.

A recent report by one of the region's largest banks, Standard Chartered Bank, expressed the view that South Africa and Zimbabwe would provide the engine for future economic growth in southern Africa. It said southern Africa was entering a decade of strong economic growth and a better outlook than it had experienced in the last three decades


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Penny's looking for gold in the pool


BYLINE: Julian Drew, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Johannesburg -On Sunday South African swimmer Penny Heyns will finally know whether all the sacrifices and hard work of the past four years have been worthwhile.

The last time she appeared at the Olympic Games, her presence as an up-and- coming 17-year-old was heavily criticised by the South African media because she failed to win the national trials. That pressure saw her perform disappointingly to finish 32nd in her favoured 100m breaststroke event and 33rd over 200m.

Now there is only adulation and a different kind of pressure as she goes into the most important race of her career as the clear favourite.

After Barcelona Heyns took stock of her situation and decided that if she was going to improve and make an impact in Atlanta, she would have to relocate to America. That led to her 1993 move to Nebraska University where several South Africans already in residence and the quiet small town life of Lincoln, made it easy to adjust. 

She teamed up with former Czech swimmer Jan Bidrman who represented Sweden in the individual medley at Barcelona and a close bond quickly formed between them. "It is their relationship, even more so than Penny's talent and Jan's knowledge, which is probably the biggest factor in Penny's success story. They have a very close working relationship and complete confidence in one another's ability," says Nebraska's head swimming coach Cal Bentz.

"I was very lucky when I started coaching Penny because she was already a very accomplished swimmer," says Bidrman. "My plan was to give her a little more training every year so that she progressed steadily. In South Africa she only swam once a day and did less than 3 000m. Now she swims about nine times a week and does around 6 000m a session," reveals Bidrman.

Gym work too has played its role. As a top American football college -- Nebraska has won the national title for the past two years -- there are good weight room facilities and a team of experts to provide assistance.

"Every year I would do something different with my weight training and I didn't really know what worked best for me. After nationals in Durban this year, I went onto a programme which was specially designed for me and it appears to have made a difference," says Heyns, who has been swimming the fastest training times of her career since she started cutting back on her programme four weeks ago to be ready for the Games.

For technique, Bidrman subscribes to the methods of the Hungarian school of swimming, and in particular those of renowned former champion Josef Nagy who coached the men's 200m breaststroke world record- holder Mike Barrowman.

"When I looked at her stroke there were certain things I tried to emphasise, " says Bidrman. He prefers a very narrow, quick kicking action and had her hold a buoy between her knees to practise the required style. He also made her look down in the water while swimming instead of forwards, and encouraged her to swim on top of the water rather than to be submerged. More strength from weight training has also meant a better push-off from the wall at the turns which, combined with improved streamlining after her push-off, has also contributed to her lower times.

Heyns' form is such that she doesn't need to worry too much about what her rivals are doing. "You can't influence what others are doing. You must just focus on what you are doing yourself. I will just go out to swim my best and hopefully, if I do that, then things should go well," says Heyns.

Although winning the gold medal is her primary aim, the world record could also topple once more. "As far as times are concerned a lot of it is mental. If you decide that you can no longer improve on your best then it's time to give up, but right now I know I can break the record again," says Heyns.

As reigning world record holder it might seem like a race between Heyns and the clock for the Olympic title, but she is not likely to have it so easy. Samantha Riley is still a formidable foe despite her setbacks of the last year and Heyns is unlikely to disregard her.

At last year's major meeting, the Pan Pacifics in Atlanta, Riley was robbed of the chance of going head to head with Heyns in her favourite distance after being disqualified in her heat for what officials described as "a consistent use of a downward dolphin kick over the last 25m". It was a strange pronouncement and Riley has refused to alter her style.

But although she bounced back to take the 200m in a time of 2:24.81 -- five hundredths away from the world record -- and record the fastest relay split ever with a 1:07.19 for the breaststroke leg of the medley relay, the worst was still to come. At the world short course championships in Rio de Janeiro last December, in a 25m pool -- as opposed to a 50m pool -- temporarily constructed on Copacabana, she won the 100m and 200m breaststroke events in world record times.

A few weeks later, however, it was announced that she had tested positive for an illegal substance at the meeting and she faced the very real prospect of being banned during the Olympic Games. The world governing body was lenient though and she escaped punishment. It believed she did not intend to cheat by taking a headache pill containing a stimulant, but her coach was banned for two years for giving the tablet to her.

The 23-year-old Riley, who is two years older than Heyns, seemed to be affected by these traumas at the Australian trials in April. She failed to win either event but made the team by finishing second in both with times that would not make Heyns lose any sleep.

The other main medal prospect is America's Amanda Beard who finished third behind Heyns at last year's Pan Pacifics as a 13-year-old, and was always going to be a handful as she got older. The Chinese, too, have a newcomer to their ranks after their doping scandal of 1994, but 15-year-old Han Xue -- who broke the short course world record for 50m breaststroke twice earlier this year -- is yet to prove herself in the 100m.

Heyns will be aiming for a split at the halfway stage of around 31.8 seconds compared with her time at the same stage in her world record swim of 32.19, but if she should go on to win, political naivety could spoil her big day. A springbok tattoo on her shoulder is sure to solicit a barrage of probing questions from the world's media eager for an interesting angle on her story.

Although she may claim that she can't see what all the fuss is about and repeat that age-old adage that sport and politics don't mix, it was interesting to see the reactions from both sides of the fence. Nocsa played it diplomatically and refused to be drawn into the debate, while the white media reiterated Heyns' feelings and seemed to support them.

The only black journalist covering the Games said Heyns had gone out of control, while a far from political black team member said, "You don't do something like that if you want the respect of the whole nation. I believe that some people back home will be glad if she loses now."


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

231 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
A-to-Z of the Games in Atlanta Games


BYLINE: Mick Cleary and Kevin Mitchell, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Johannesburg - With the Centennial Games opening on Friday, Mick Cleary and Kevin Mitchell come up with the low-down on the Olympics, alphabetically speaking, from Athens to Zero

ATHENS. Birthplace - of the Olympics (but passed over for these Centennial Games) -- and birthplace, in Georgia, of Billy Payne, the real estate lawyer who brought the Games to Atlanta. "I feel sorry for Athens," Payne said when he returned from Greece with the Olympic Flame. But with a smile.

BASKETBALL. Did you know that China has the biggest player in the women's tournament? She is known as the Honey Monster, all 2,5m of her. The best, though, is widely regarded as the 2,3m American model Lisa Leslie. "These bones," she says, "they kind of fool people. I'm small, but I'm going to be out there mixing it up." 

COMPLAINTS. Despite every effort, there will be plenty over the next few weeks. The heat, transport, accommodation, water, tickets ... Frank Deford of Newsweek, who has just returned from covering Wimbledon, thinks the European press are spoiling for a fight. "They're already sharpening their knives," he told the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. "They're going to rip you."

DEFECTIONS. The two Cuban boxers, followed last Thursday by the country's best baseball pitcher and with four more rumoured to be hovering near the wire, are the sad face of the Games. Uncle Sam seems to be revelling, as well.

ENERGY. A key factor in performances in Atlanta will be the athletes' capacity for work. Ironically, some experts here think the track at the Olympic Stadium is a record-breaking fast one -- if the athletes can stand up to the energy-sapping conditions.

FLAME. The story of the Olympic Flame really started in dubious celebration of supposed Aryan superiority at the 1936 Games in Berlin. It has come full circle for one veteran Olympian. Paul DeBruyn competed in the marathon for Germany in 1932 and 1936, even though he was then living in the United States. Hitler asked him to stay in Germany. He declined. Last week when the Flame reached Daytona Beach, DeBruyn, 88 and now an American citizen, was there to celebrate.

GAYS. Atlanta will be the first Olympic city to host a hospitality suite for homosexuals -- although it took heavy lobbying to overcome earlier prejudices, as well as a few commercial truths. As the mayor's special adviser, Phil McDonald, says: "A lot of gay tourists will be coming to the Olympics because of their disposable income."

HEAT. The word you will be hearing more often than not over the next few weeks, apart from humidity.

INFORMATION. Another commodity of which there is no shortage. Info 96, called up on small screens all over the Olympic village, is the technological link between the eternally curious and the trivial.

JOKES. Who is going to carry the Flame into Atlanta? Anyone, as long as he's not called Sherman. How would Michael Buffer announce the Olympics? " Let's get ready to grumble!"

KNOWHOW. What Americans used to be known for. It will take all they have to overcome the logistical problems that Atlanta presents. Indications are they're getting there.

LOCALS. Here is what some Atlantans are saying about the Olympics in the local paper -- "The Olympics are here, and still no toilets. Visitors will remember the Atlanta smell." "The Olympics is like a hurricane: it's coming, we're not ready for it and we can't stop it."

MONEY. After heat, the word that most concerns the organisers. Estimates that the Games would bring spin-off billions to the city were said last week to be about $1-billion short. But advertising is booming. An adland expert said the Games "could usher in the most colossal, concentrated three-week advertising blitz in Madison Avenue history".

NIGHTMARE. They call it the Dream Team, but, for Charles Barkley, these Olympics have turned sour before they even start. The star basketball player is alleged to have assaulted 23-year-old Jeb Tyler in a Cleveland bar last weekend. Barkley says he was provoked and Tyler, who is considering later civil proceedings, says he will not press criminal charges. "I don't want to see Charles Barkley get arrested and detained for this," he said. "He would have to come back to Cleveland and get arraigned in two weeks. He'd miss the Olympics." What a neat guy.

OVERKILL. If you do not know which American soft drink has its HQ in Atlanta you will soon never be allowed to forget it.

PALESTINIANS. Their last appearance was a tragic one, in 1972, when terrorists killed 11 Israeli athletes. Abu Marahil, one member of their three- man team (they have two runners and a boxer), says: "We were at war then. Now is a new day and the Palestinian people and the Israeli people must learn to live together."

QUESTIONS. What journalists were unable to ask the IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch when he arrived at the Olympic village last Thursday. Rarely can so many hacks have tried so hard to get so close to someone they distrust so much.

ROYALS. Di won't be here (although she thought about it), but Anne will. The Princess Royal, feeding American hunger Britain's tattered old monarchy, was the crowd-puller at a charity dinner for Georgia's upwardly grovelling on Tuesday. Just $1 000 a ticket. It was a "frocks-and-rocks" do, as Anne's lady- in-waiting calls it. Last week it was Prince Albert of Monaco, tres downmarket though, with tickets going for as little as $100.

SOCCER. A key organiser of the tournament will be ex-Aston Villa player Phil Woosnam (a distant cousin of golfer Ian), who is the deputy competition manager. Woosnam, who has been here since his time with the doomed North American Soccer League 13 years ago and coached the Atlanta Chiefs, will retire after seeing Atlanta through. He has picked up plenty of American. " The warmth of the people of the South," he says, "and the beauty of all the trees -- that was the first thing that impacted me when I came." Enjoy, Phil.

TECHNOLOGY. These will be the highest of hi-tech Games. IBM has sponsored a worldwide web site -- which is http://www.atlanta. olympic.org. Traffic is heavy, up from 50 000 hits a day to more than seven million. The internal TV- computer network is called Scarlet -- after O'Hara. Atlanta is the home of BellSouth and Atlantans will be left a legacy of hundreds of thousands of miles of fibre-optic wiring: one of the reasons Atlanta got the Games.

UNITED STATES. If anything unites this country it is the chance to prove they can put on a show. For all the doomsaying, the Games are likely to go smoothly because of the co-ordination of services and security. "See that panhandler?" a cop pointed out the other day. "He's security."

VICTORY. The biggest victory of these Olympics will be an incident-free tournament. Don't bet on it.

WOMEN. There will be 39% more women competing here than in Barcelona, the best representation at the Olympics. All first-time sports must now include both sexes. This time it is mountainbiking and beach volleyball. But Gwen Torrance, twice a gold medal winner, points out: "Oh no, when you think of sport, you think of men. We've come a long way, but we've got a long way to go." There were no women at the 1896 Games, 1 058 by 1952 and here there will be 3 779.

X-CHROMOSOME. Not everything is as gender-specific as it might seem. Dora Ratjen, fourth in the high jump in 1936, later admitted her name was Herman. She claimed she was ordered to pose as a woman by the Nazis.

YOUTH or Yuk. The organisers hit the yuk button in a big way when they invented a wacky character called Izzy as the Games mascot, complete with imbecilic fantasy story. It has been rightly lampooned and ignored by the little folk.

ZERO. The chance most people give those playing the Dream Team. "We'll cover them like we did in Barcelona -- for the first 15 or 20 minutes," says NBC's sports president Dick Ebersol. "If it becomes non-competitive, we'll return for the end of the game."


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1996


Arts;
Who says South African film is dead?


BYLINE: Andrew Worsdale, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Johannesburg - After a seven-week shoot, a wrap party for "Fools," a co- production between France, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, the SABC, M-Net and our Department of Arts, Culture, Science and Technology, was held in Johannesburg last week. And, insobrieties aside, everyone was happy with the results.

Based on a short story from the award-winning collection by Njabulo Ndebele, the film tells the tale of a schoolteacher, Zamani (played by Patrick Shai), who falls foul of the community in Charterstown township when he's found molesting young girls. 

One of the girls' brothers, Zani, played by Hlomla Dandala (a newcomer from Wits University's drama school), sets out to challenge the teacher. Through the course of the narrative, their roles slowly reverse. And, while the young man begins to stray from the path, the older man slowly regains some of his dignity.

The story was adapted for film by Bhekisiswe Petersen, and within industry circles it has been suggested that the script is a bit flimsy. But Mozambican- based producer Pedro Pimenta flatly counters such talk. "We knew what we were going to do with it," he says.

Despite the fact that it's an apartheid story, the film-makers are adamant that they have a new take on the race saga. This, they say, is not your standard South African movie where all the blacks are good and all the whities bad.

Script supervisor Maureen Conway concurs: "The movie has an interesting local feel. It's not political per se, but rather a story about someone touched by politics." This is reflected in director Ramedan Suleman's treatment, which, according to Conway, "concentrates as much on atmosphere as on drama".

In other words, Fools is being shot as an art movie, and a major bonus in this regard is the presence of cinematographer Jacques Boquin, who has shot over 100 documentaries and several art pictures, including those of Raul Ruiz, the Chilean-born director based in France who makes films teeming with surrealist imagery.

Local actor Robin Smith claims that, in the past, he was considered too ugly to play fascists; now, in the new South Africa, he's only being cast as cops or AWB members. True to this paradox, he appears in Fools as a sjambok- wielding bad guy, absolved because the community wants his victim, the schoolteacher, to be punished. An ironic take on apartheid, executed in an artistic fashion ...

When I visited the set a fortnight ago to witness a high-school scene straight out of Sarafina!, I was struck by the multi-lingual babble on set. Here's a South African movie where they shout "Coupe!" instead of "Cut!"; where most of the communication between director and crew is in French.

It's a sign of the times: almost all of our local movies are currently being financed or produced by outsiders (Britain's Channel Four paid for Les Blair's Babel; Jean Delbeke is rumoured to have a movie in the pipeline, partially financed by the Flemish).

When are people like Edgar Bold, perhaps the most powerful independent producer in the country, going to wake up and smell the potential of films that don't just focus on the antics of Mr Safe/Mr Schlock, Leon Schuster?


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Zambia;
No More Fresh Aid From Japan


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Lusaka - Japan will not release any fresh aid to Zambia until the government renews its commitment to good governance, counsellor Takayaki Miyashita disclosed on Friday.

Counsellor Miyashita, in an exclusive interview in Lusaka on Friday, said the recent release of K16 billion should not be taken for granted by the Zambian government.

"I hope the country will not misunderstand our voice just as expressed by other donor nations," Miyashita said. "At this stage there is no slash of Japan aid which has already been signed but if the current situation goes on and does not come to an end then we may have to think twice." 

Counsellor Miyashita added: "Our embassy has met President Chiluba and his finance minister Ronald Penza on several occasions and we have emphasised that they should resume dialogue with the opposition but unfortunately there has been no positive response up to now."

But President Chiluba's press aide, Richard Sakala, reiterated that donor nations have to respect recipient nations' sovereignty and rebuffed claims that there was no dialogue between government and the opposition.

"No government should prescribe conditions on another government," Sakala said in an interview on Friday at Lusaka's Chipata Compound Health Clinic where President Chiluba was launching the Polio National Immunisation Days (NID's).

"This government is democratically elected and works on the basis of popular mandate of the people of Zambia," Sakala said. "The government is ready for dialogue. In fact there is a lot of dialogue because all parties are talking on all issues."

But counsellor Miyashita maintained the MMD government has violated a cardinal condition of "good governance" which is the basic benchmark for any aid from Japan.

"The purpose of our aid and projects is to better the life of the ordinary people and we have not changed our policy but unfortunately at the moment there is no positive and better direction towards democracy and good governance," Miyashita said. "Governance is our greatest concern. We understand and appreciate the stand most donor countries have taken. We don't want to apply double standards to our recipient countries but if the situation goes to worse we just have to apply stronger measures to this country."

National Party Lusaka Province chairman, Johnson Nzima, welcomed counsellor Miyashita's statement.

"The MMD government can only be moved by donor pressure," Nzima said.

Finance minister Ronald Penza in an interview on Friday refused to comment on the development until the Japanese government gives him an official stand on their donor aid flow to Zambia.

And Japan last week Friday signed a Grant Assistance for Grass Roots Project with the Association to Aid the Refugees (AAR) at Maheba Refugee Camp in North Western Province.

The grant which was signed on behalf of the Japanese government by counsellor Miyashita is worth $153,032 and will be utilised on three projects - a Water Project ($44,862), the Improvement of Agricultural and Livestock Farming Project ($22,751) and the Health Improvement Project ($85, 419) with which to procure a generator, a refrigerator, medicines and a 4 WD motor vehicle.

"The Japanese Grant Assistance for Grass Roots Project, under whose umbrella this grant falls, was first introduced in Zambia in 1990. This type of assistance is designed to promote development activities of NGOs, schools, hospitals and local communities at grass roots level," counsellor Miyashita said.

Counsellor Miyashita also said he was happy to assist Maheba Refugee Camp through AAR, which provides quite a number of unfortunate people with a roof over their heads and nourishment.

"AAR is active in allowing the refugees in the camp the opportunity of employment, education, vocational training for self-reliance, as well as looking after their health needs, thus giving them the opportunity to enjoy a normal daily life whilst away from their home environment," counsellor Miyashita said.

And receiving the grant on behalf of AAR, Kenji Hayasaka said the refugees had suffered of a chronic shortage of drugs and hoped the grant would help reduce their suffering.

Hayasaka however, said with the signing of the Lusaka Protocol the situation had improved because most Angolan refugees who made up 90 per cent of the 33,000 at Maheba had been repatriated.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Zambia;
Women Farmers Get Smiles Over Harvest


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Mkushi - Thirty-three women groups with a membership of five hundred and ten in Mkushi have this year produced about 9.2 tonnes of maize from the two hundred and thirty hectares they had cultivated.

Mkushi women development co-ordinating committee chairperson Ms Patricia Nalishuwa said in Mkushi that apart from maize production the women groups had also cultivated ten hectares of commercial sunflower, two hectares of groundnut seed, five hectares of pumpkin seed, one hectare of beans seed. 

She said Mkushi district co-operative union spent fifty million kwacha on women for the cultivation of two hundred and thirty hectares of maize, while Zambia Co-operative Federation and AFRICARE loaned the women thirty million kwacha for the production of pumpkins, beans, groundnut seed and commercial sunflower.

She said maize for the women groups would be bought by Mkushi district co- operative union at fifteen thousand kwacha per ninety kilogram bag while sunflower will be bought by AFRICARE while the other crop seed would be bought by ZAMSEED.

She said the women groups in Mkushi do not desert and they would repay the loans to the lending insdtitutions because she has already taught them on the importance of paying back loans.

She, therefore, called upon on other lending institutionsd to assist the women groups this year.

ZAMTODAY-NAIS


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Zambia and Zaire;
Zambia and Zaire 'Seal' Common Border


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia and Zaire have committed themselves are to take urgent measures aimed at combating crime that is prevalent at their common border.

In a joint-communique signed in Lusaka today at the end of a two-day meetings between the deputy minister of foreign affairs, Dr Peter Machungwa and his Zairean counterpart Lokondo Yoka, the two countries will from now onwards deal seriously with cross-border motor vehicle thefts and armed banditry by providing necessary information about known criminals to police of each other who may be harbouring in either country.

The two governments will also ensure that timely information especially on transit times of cargo to various destinations and security is provided to curb thefts of minerals like cobalt and copper. 

Copper thieves and those of cobalt will be treated like common motor vehicle bandits and these will be prosecuted within the applicable laws of the both countries.

Stolen goods will, when recovered, be handed back to the rightful owners once recovered.

Zambia and Zaire have for a long time been experiencing thefts of minerals and motor vehicles from either sides especially in border towns.

Prior to the signing of the joint communique Dr Machungwa described the two- day meetings with Mr Yoka as succesful.

He said the outcome of the meeting will help curb the crime in the both countries.

And Mr Yoka expressed happiness in that they managed to put in place legal and diplomatic instruments that will end smuggling in both countries.

He said the Zairean community will be informed that Zambian authorities will no longer accept goods impounded or stolen from Zaire.

Meanwhile Dr Machungwa has said Zambia and Zaire share common ties which must be strengthened in order that misunderstandings are avoided.

He said the two countries were both members of the Organisation of African Unity, United Nations and COMESA which must strengthen their resolve to work closely together.

Zambia and Zaire shared common poverty levels, long geographical ties and economic problems that threaten to derail meaningful cooperation.

Dr Machungwa was speaking at a dinner he hosted for his Zairean counterpart Mr Lokondo Yoka at Hotel Intercontinental in Lusaka.

He called on the two countries to work towards lessening cross border crimes which included thefts of copper from Zambia and cobalt from Zaire in order to improve the welfare of the two peoples.

He said enhanced economic cooperation would lead to success of both countries' development programmes.

On the political front Dr Machungwa noted that Zaire had contributed to peace in the region and cited the 1993 when President Mobutu sese Seko brokered the Angola peace talks.

He said Zaire had made sacrifices on the Rwanda and Burundi conflicts by accepting more than 2 million refugees who migrated from horrors brought about by warring factions there.

And Zairean deputy foreign affairs minister, Yoka said trade relations, economic ties and security must be strengthened as these were the connerstones of democracy.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Tobacco Farmers Meet Mugabe Over Levy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 959 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Senior officials of the Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) met President Robert Mugabe on Monday, amidst growing concern of their members about a 10 percent tobacco levy imposed on growers and merchants.

Parliament recently passed a bill enabling treasury to collect the levies, through which government expects to earn about 700 million zimdollars (70 million US dollars) annually. Controversy then followed the levy on the export crop which is expected to earn the country more than 7 billion zimdollars (700 million US dollars) this year, with the farmers saying their viability would be threatened while the government said it needed the revenue to boost its finances. 

ZTA President, Rob Webb, and his deputy, Richard Tate, had a lunch time meeting with Mugabe at his Zimbabwe House offices in Harare, where the issues came up for discussion.

The meeting was also attended by agriculture minister, Denis Norman.

"The five percent levy is going to have a severe effect on us," said Webb, who added that as a result of the levies, tobacco prizes had fallen by 18.4 percent.

He said small-scale farmers would be the worst affected by the levy.

"What we fear (for) most of all, is the small-scale tobacco farmer. They have had dry weather for many years and now they are going to suffer the most, " Webb said.

Many of Zimbabwe's 7,000 small-scale tobacco farmers rely entirely on the crop for their families' upkeep, with some grossing as little as 10,000 zimdollars (1,000 USD) a year.

Webb said although it was now too late to scrap the levy, the president had hinted he would speak to the minister of finance to see if the situation could be reviewed for the 1997 marketing season.

President Mugabe described the meeting as "cordial". "It has been a very good meeting, very frank and cordial," Mugabe said without elaborating.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Sudan;
Beshir Launches Sudan's First Oil Refinery


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - President Omar El-Bashir on Monday officially launched Sudan's first oil refinery, located 600 kms west of the capital Khartoum.

In a ceremony speech broadcast live on Radio Omdurman, Bashir said the refinery was established even as the country's funds were being withheld in foreign capitals. 

The plant started trial operations Sunday, processing 5,000 barrels per day. The quantity will rise to some 10,000 barrels per day of crude brought in from the Higlig oilfield in the south.

"God has assisted us when others turned their backs on us," Bashir told the crowd in a speech broadcast live by the state-run radio.

The Sudan News Agency, (SUNA), said the refinery will provide 10 percent of the country's Benzine needs, six percent of its gazoline consumption, and 70 percent of other fuel imports.

Sudan spends 360 million dollars on imports of petroleum products annually, usually at concessional prices from the Gulf states, especially Saudi Arabia.

But the oil-rich kingdom stopped the assistance after it accused Khartoum of supporting the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait which sparked the 1991 Gulf War.

Last month, the government announced a hike in the price of petroleum products by 50 to 60 percent.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Southern Africa;
Call For New Agricultural Technology in SADC


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Africa's poor food security situation will not be improved by increasing land under agriculture, but by developing technologies that enhance soil fertility, Zimbabwe's agriculture minister Denis Norman said here Monday.

He said because of the harsh production environment characterised by low fertility and fragile soils for thousands of Zimbabwe's small-scale farmers, use of fertiliser and other agro-chemicals should be increased. 

Addressing a week-long Southern African regional workshop on agri-inputs, marketing and extension, which opened inHarare today, Norman said food was likely to become more scarce and expensive.

The workshop, being attended by smallholder farmers drawn from the 12- nation Southern African Development Community (SADC), weeks to increase the participants' knowledge and skills of the role of plant nutrients in crop production.

"Area expansion has been the conventional way of increasing output but because of population pressure, this is becoming difficult...Thus the most viable option is the development and adoption of technological innovation," he said.

Southern African states have in recent years relied on food imports to supplement local stocks that have clearly been inadequate to cater for the rapidly growing population.

According to estimates of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), only 24 percent of future food needs can be met by putting new land into production, the remaining 76 percent has to come from intensification of production on currently farmed land.

In Zimbabwe for instance, maize yields in the smallholder farming sector averaged two tonnes per hectare compared to about seven tonnes in the large scale commercial sector.

Africa's inability to produce enough food for her people has been attributed to recurrent droughts, land degradation and falling investments in agricultural research and production.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


Burundi;
Tutsi Opposition Threatens Government


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (Pana) - The chairman of the Unity for National Progress (Uprona) led by Charles Mukasi said Monday in Bujumbura that the party has decided to withdraw its support for President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.

"I cannot publicly here tell you the methods considered by my party on the issue, but trust me, it is just a matter of days", he told thousands of angry students demonstrating at the party headquarters over the murder of 30 people (Tutsi) by Hutu militia at the week-end.

Hundreds of people sustained injuries, some serious, in the raid on Saturday by the Hutu militias, according to hospital sources. 

The students' representative, Oscar Nyandwi, in an interview, said Uprona " must withdraw its support to president Ntibantunganya and force him to leave".

"It is the present head of state who is responsible for the insecurity currently prevailing in the country. At least he has proven himself to be incapable of restoring peace and security", Nyandwi said.

Analysts say opposition to the authority of the president and the prime minister poses a serious threat to the 1994 pact signed by all parties, and which has so far made it possible to run public institutions in a country bristling with ethnic hatred.

On Sunday, Uprona urged "followers, friendly political parties and all Burundians" to observe three days of mourning starting Monday, for the people killed in the raid.

Uprona also accused the ruling Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU) led by President Sylvestre Bantunganya, a Hutu, of complicity in the massacres.

However, the government has since declared one week of national mourning in memory of the 304 victims.

In March, humanitarian organizations reported the killing of 300 civilians in operations launched by the regular army, at Mutoyi near Bugendana. Some suspect Saturday's killings were a revenge.

The escalation of violence comes at a time when the international community is supporting the initiative by Burundi's neighbors to send troops to the country for possible intervention should violence erupt.

Burundi has been torn by a war between the majority Hutu population and the minority Tutsi, who nonetheless, control the army, since the assassination in October 1993 of President Melchior Ndadaye (a Hutu) in an aborted military coup.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 22, 1996


United States and Africa;
South Africa Gets US Grant


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The United States has agreed to play a significant role in a new four-million-dollar project in South Africa.

Under an agreement, the United States Trade and Development Agency (TDA), will contribute 800,000 dollars to South Africa's Industrial Development Corporation. 

The funds will be used to help finance the cost of a feasibility study for the establishment of direct iron reduction plant here. This is the biggest grant ever made by the TDA on the African continent, and represents about 20 percent of the total cost of the feasibility study.

"This grant," says TDA Director, J. Joseph Grandmaison, "represents another effort by President Clinton to further strengthen the economy of South Africa" .

"Moving this project forward," he added, "represents a major step toward creating jobs and fostering economic development in the two countries, and it strengthens the trade relationship Between our two Nations."

The agreement was signed by the American Commercial Counsellor in South Africa, Millard Arnold, and IDC Managing Director, W.C. Van Der Merwe.

In terms of the agreement, the IDC will set up a joint American-South African team of engineering consultants to undertake a technical, environmental and financial study of the reduction plant proposal. Should the project go ahead, it will cost an estimated 800 million US dollars.

The United States Trade and Development Agency has been involved in a number of other projects in South Africa. It is also focusing on the development of transportation infrastructure projects in Africa to help sustain economic growth well into the next century.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 22, 1996


United States and Africa;
US Envoy to Liberia Calls on President Rawlings


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - United States special envoy to Liberia, Howard Jeter, has praised Ghana's President Jerry John Rawlings for the job he was doing on the war-torn Liberia as chairman of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS).

Jeter said here Sunday he had been to Liberia to interact with ECOMOG, the peace-keeping force launched by ECOWAS to see how the U.S. can help the force.

He praised President Rawlings's untiring efforts atensuring peace in Liberia. 

"The U.S administration is happy at the superb job you are doing as chairman of ECOWAS, and hopes that, with you around, we will make progress."

Rawlings told him that the change in the chairmanship of ECOWAS will not affect the organization's program for the peace process in Liberia.

Rawlings, whose term as ECOWAS chairman ends this month, said whoever assumes the position will definitely seek an end to the carnage in Liberia.

The president said even though the optimism expressed about peace in Liberia has been elusive, "there is a strong feeling now that we are on the threshold of peace than ever before." He said this is, however, based on the renewed commitment shown by the various factional leaders to bring matters to an end.

"It is up to all of us to make sure that we nail this problem in the coffin and bring a new lease of life to our brothers and sisters in Liberia."

The president reiterated the need for the United States and the international community to make good their promises, adding: "if all could cooperate in this effort at bringing peace to Liberia, it would bring about peace."

Welcoming the American envoy earlier, Mohammed Ibn Chambas, Ghana's deputy minister of Foreign Affairs, expressed Accra's appreciation for the interest being shown by the United States for the Liberian crisis and its efforts aimed at bringing peace to the war-torn country.

He said the fighting, which erupted last April in the Liberian capital of Monrovia, had set the peace process back. "But through the efforts of President Rawlings, ECOMOG has reasserted itself, bringing about peace and creating safe havens where civilians go about their normal lives," he added.

Chambas emphasized the need to put back on track the Abuja Peace Accord, saying the forthcoming ECOWAS summit in Abuja offers the best opportunity to impress upon the various factions that the only option left is to restore peace.

242 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


South Africa;
Inkatha to Appear Before Truth Panel


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Johannesburg - The Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) will feature prominently for the very first time when many of its members appear before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in two simultaneous sittings in KwaZulu-Natal region next week.

The commission will hold its human rights violation hearings in Port Shepstone from Monday August 12 to Wednesday August 14 where survivors and families of victims will relate stories of gross violation of their human rights.

The hearings will be at Marburg Haven, a well known civic facility very close to the Port Shepstone city centre. 

Among about 30 cases that will be heard by the panel of two commissioners and four committee members, will be that of 11 victims of a brutal massacre of IFP-aligned youths on September 4 1992, an incident that shattered and changed the lives of people of Nsangwini village near Port Shepstone in the KwaZulu-Natal South Coast.

The youths, all huddled in a hut at the home of local IFP leader, waiting for a bus that was to take them to a weekend conference in Ulundi, were unexpectedly cornered by unknown gunmen and massacred. Other cases due to be heard by the commission include those of murder, torture, massacres arson and kidnappings, allegedly perpetrated mainly by security forces and IFP members and officials.

Meanwhile, the very first amnesty hearings in Durban will coincide with the human rights hearings in Port Shepstone.

The amnesty hearings in Durban will be held at the Recreational Hall at the Westville Prison, from Monday August 12 to Thursday August 15. The prison Hall is easily accessible to members of the public and the hearings will be open to everyone and entry is free of any charge. The event will be fully covered by television, radio and other media. The hearings start at 9 each morning and last the entire day.

Three members of the AWB including the commandant of the Orde Boerevolk in Richards Bay, who killed seven passengers who were traveling in a bus near KwaMashu in October 1990 have applied for amnesty and will appearing before the commission in the Durban hearings.

The three men were sentenced to death, which was late commuted to 25 years imprisonment. The forth applicant for amnesty is former Empangeni murder and robbery unit detective, an alleged member of the IFP, who killed two badly injured suspects he claimed were ANC members.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Science;
Vaccination Discrepancies Under Probe in Zambia


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The Ministry of Health yesterday held a joint meeting with officials from the Central Statistics Office (CSO) to find out what could have led to the running out of polio vaccines at some posts during the first round of the National Immunization Days (NID).

NID co-ordinator, Mary Kaoma, confirmed in an interview yesterday that the two parties held a meeting at the NID secretariat "to address discrepancies in the population figures of the polio immunization exercise".

"The two teams agreed to firm up the target population of the under fives and margins there-in," Kaoma said, adding: "Further efforts to improve co- ordination between the Ministry of Health and the seconded staff from the CSO were also agreed upon." 

She explained that CSO has offered to further support the on-going NID exercise by beefing up its technical staff seconded to the NID's secretariat.

Kaoma attributed the running out of vaccines to "the overwhelming response".

"We ran out of vaccines because some mothers brought some over fives as well and the volunteers felt they couldn't turn them away," Kaoma claimed.

But a source at the NID's secretariat disclosed in a separate interview yesterday that the vaccines ran out because "the logistics were not put to the correct population of the under fives".

The 1.6 million target was far beow the actual number of under five children that needed immunization," the source said.

"The logistics were not put to the correct population of the under fives."

But Grace Kagodo, a consultant with the United Nations International Children's Fund (UNICEF), dismissed this.

"It was mainly because of the over whelming response and some over fives turning up," Kagodo said.

Meanwhile, early reports coming into the NID's secretariat from the districts indicate that the exercise was successful.

According to Kaoma, in Northern Province, Kasama district reported approximately 74 per cent of children under five immunized.

"In Southern Province, Livingstone and Kalomo South reported over 90 per cent coverage while Gwembe reported approximately 67 per cent," Kaoma said.

"In the difficult North-Western Province, they are determined to catch all eligible children and immunization will continue until Tuesday in some districts," Kaoma disclosed. "The full report will be released within the next two days."

The next round of NID's will occur on August 23 and 24.

LANGUAGE: English

244 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Zambia;
Voting Process Takes A Step Forward


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Livingstone - Kalomo politicians from both the ruling Movement for Multi- Party Democracy and the three main opposition political parties have commended government for coming up with a simplified voters provisional register and portable voters cards.

Speaking when they met for a briefing in the council secretary's office over the weekend, the opposing politicians said they were happy with the system government was usingfor the coming Presidential and Parliamentary election and had no complaints.

Kalomo Council Secretary Bernard Siwakwi said the meeting was peaceful and would like the peaceful atmosphere exhibited during their meeting to be extended to the campaign field.

Mr Siwakwi said Kalomo and Southern Province in general was a peaceful area which knows no political hooliganism and politicians in the multi-party system should endevour to maintain calmness. 

He urged for a clean power campaign during the forth coming elections and civil servants and public services workers would be at hand to give a helping hand for the opposing parties to ensure that Zambia enjoyed tranquility and harmony.

Meanwhile the National Party has called on the elections commission to strictly follow lied down electoral procedures if true democracy in the country is to be realised.

National Party secretary for elections Kalima Lwendo said today that the calling for by-elections for the vacant Mongu Central Constituency with only 90 days remaining before the general elections was unprocedural and a worst of country's scarce resources.

Mr. Lwendo said that the holding of such a by-election was totally unnecessary as it would not benefit anyone.

"It also raises two technical issues...under what register are they going to conduct this by-elections. Is it the 1991 or 1996 register or both?" he said.

There are so many anomalies regarding the 1996 voters register with the position political parties saying that the whole exercise should be declared nil and void.

Mr. Lwendo further wondered how the Elections Commission was very quick in declaring the Mongu Constituency vacant when they had failed to declare Mansa Central vacant following the imprisonment of area Member of Parliament Edward Chisha.

He accused the Elections Commission of tribalism and nepotism, and said if the elections office could boast of autonomous, it should have made attempts to declare the constituency vacant instead of waiting for directives from the government.

He also urged the commission to declare the Pambashe and Mandevu constituences vacant in order to adhere to the principles of democratic governance.

And a lot of people in Lusaka found no one to attend to them at many registration centres where they had gone to chech for their names and voters cards.

This happened in response to the Elections Office advert urging people in six provinces excluding Lusaka, Copperbelt and Central province, to check their names with elections officers at stations where they had registered.

Some registered voters in Lusaka today turned up at the centres were they registered in a bid to collect their registration cards and check for their names in the provisional register despite the announcement by the electoral commission that the exercise has been deferred.

Some of the registered voters told ZANA that they were not aware that the exercise has been defrred due to non-arrival of registration cards from United States of America.

The voters blamed the elections office for the short notice of the postponement of the collection of voters cards after all the publicity that the cards were now ready.

The Electoral Commission announced at the week that the it had decided to postpone the publication of of the provisional voters register in Lusaka, Central and Copperbelt provinces due to non-arrival of the cards from USA.

Public Liaison Officer Joel Sikazwe appealed to registered voters to be calm and wait for the arrival of their cards before they can check for their name in the provision registers.

He said it would be unfair for the commission to allow the voters to check for their names only and go back later to collect their voters cards.

In Zambezi the collection of voters cards and the checking of names from the voters registers from various polling stations on Zambezi west bank is going on at a very slow pace for lack of publicity in the area.

A visit by ZIS at Mapachi primary school on Zambezi west, four kilometres from the boma, found only 10 people have collected their voters cards by this morning.

Most of the villagers talked to said that they were not aware of the exercise of collecting the voters cards in which it have started today.

One of the villagers Maybin Salipako said that he had no idea about the collection of voters cards since the information is only on the radio which does not own.

Salipako appealed to the government to publicise the information for many people to go to their various polling stations otherwise many of them will stay without.

He said that the most affected villagers who are ignorant about the exercise are those leaving far in the bush at their fields cultivating their land.

He said that if many people will not collect their voters cards then it will affect the fourth-coming elections and the attendance will be poor.

And Zambezi district council secretary, Robinson Mwape, said it is still early but as time goes by, the news will spread and most of them will collect their cards.

Mr Mwape said that, all the voters registers and the cards have been succesfully distributed to all the polling stations in the district.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


July 23, 1996


Business & Finance;
African Currencies: New Zaire Takes a Plunge


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The New Zaire, which has taken a nose dive in the last two weeks, opened on Tuesday at the average rate of 44,178 to one U.S. dollar, from 41,366 previously.

Currency dealers attributed the latest plunge to the usual higher demand for hard currency in Kinsahsa during the vacation period. 

The Zambian kwacha has also continued to slide, though demand for foreign currency in the country is said to have only risen marginally. The kwacha averaged 1,282 for one dollar on Tuesday, from 1,274 previously.

But the CFA, riding on the back of a strong French franc, gained a few points this week, opening on Tuesday at the nominal rate of 501, from 511.9 to the greenback on the same day last week.

It traded at 490 (buying) and 520 (selling) for one dollar in Dakar on Tuesday. Last week the rate was 497 (Buying) and 527 (selling) to the greenback.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Southern Africa;
SADC Leaders To Meet In Maseru


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Leaders of the 12-member Southern African Development Community (SADC) meet in Lesotho next month, for the regional grouping's annual summit where trade, investment, energy and food security will top the agenda.

A SADC spokesman said in an interview Monday that the summit would, among other activities, review implementation of the SADC program of action, as well as discuss major economic and political developments in the region.

"Protocols likely to be considered by the summit include energy, anti-drug trafficking, transport and communications," the spokesman said. 

The summit, which starts Aug. 17, comes amid hopes that member states will agree on the finer details of a landmark treaty establishing a SADC trade facilitation protocol, and endorse measures to attract investment to the region, now one of the most attractive due to its relative political stability.

The trade protocol, first proposed soon after SADC's establishment in 1992, was aimed at boosting intra-regional trade as part of a wider strategy to create a regional market with over 150 million people and a combined gross domestic product of over 15.7 billion US dollars.

SADC ministers of trade and industry have already agreed that the protocol would eliminate tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, and establish mechanisms to ensure fair competition among investors in the region and encourage free movement of capital, goods and people.

Some member countries were said to be keen to sign the protocol and reign- in South Africa's perceived ambitions of swamping the region with its products. However, it was still unclear whether conditions imposed before the protocol could be signed had been fulfilled.

Among them was the recommendation at the SADC annual consultative meeting in South Africa in February this year that those countries affected by trade imbalances should first conclude bilateral trade agreements with members of the Southern African Customs Union (SACU), by March this year.

Some of the members who have yet to sign trade agreements with SACU countries included Zimbabwe and Zambia. SACU, the only customs union in the region, comprises Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland.

Also on the agenda for discussion by the council of ministers on August 21 and 22, would be the region's proposed Drought Relief Fund, estimated to have an initial capital of 30 million US dollars.

The SADC food security unit, based in Zimbabwe, was working out the legal modalities of the fund and expected these to be ready for discussion at the Maseru summit.

The revolving fund would assist drought prone member countries in times of food shortages, and seed capital would come from donors, SADC governments and non-governmental organizations.

A proposed protocol on the free movement of people is expected to generate heated debate, with South Africa likely to lead stiff opposition to plans to allow SADC nationals entry without restrictions.

South Africa, SADC's largest economy, was arguing that the protocol would worsen the exodus of economic refugees trekking down south in search of jobs.

Also to be tabled for discussion were plans to censure SADC members in arrears, following a decision by the SADC council of ministers in February this year to impose stiff sanctions on culprits.

Under the proposals, member countries in arrears to the regional body for more than three years could face expulsion.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Science;
AIDS Pandemic Retards Economic Development


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - HIV/AIDS infection cost an average 1.3 years of human development progress in some 56 countries around the world, surveyed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) between 1980 and 1992, according to the Human Development Report for 1996, released by the body.

It said that the impact was particularly severe on developing countries, which are said to account for 90 percent of the estimated 6,000 HIV infections which occur every day.

Research conducted for the UNDP at Columbia University and the Harvard Institute for International Development in the U.S., which has been included in the development report for the first time, shows that HIV/AIDS adversely affected the human development index (HDI). The index measures basic human capabilities, by ranking countries according to their average levels of life expectancy, educational attainment and basic purchasing power. 

The study compared the 1980 and 1992 HDI for the 56 countries with the estimated 1992 HDI that would have occurred if there were no Human Immuno Deficiency Virus (HIV) infection which causes the fatal Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS). It concluded that an average 1.3 years of human development had been lost due to the disease in the countries involved.

According to the report, some African countries, including Zambia, had suffered more than 10 years loss of development. Tanzania was estimated to have suffered some eight years of developmental loss. Others were Rwanda (7 years) and the Central African Republic, thought to have incurred similar loss. Burundi, Kenya, Malawi, Uganda and Zimbabwe were estimated to have lost between three and five years in human development progress, according to the findings quoted in the report.

The UNDP said it had become increasingly clear that countries in the world could not sustain high levels of economic growth without a strong foundation of human development. Some 89 countries had been hit by economic stagnation over the past 10 years, thereby reducing the incomes of more than a quarter of the world's population.

The report said that of the 46 countries that showed some economic progress during the period, 19 or more than 40 percent had suffered contracting employment opportunities or jobless growth.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 23, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigeria Protests Television Blackout at Olympics


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi and Mike Mbonye, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ORLANDO, United States (PANA) - Nigeria's National Olympic Committee (NOC) has formally protested to the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games (ACOG) over the television black-out of the Nigerian contingent at the centennial games' opening on Friday.

NOC secretary-general, Elias Gora, said Wednesday that the committee asked for an "unreserved apology for this discrepancy" in a letter sent to ACOG. 

Gora said, in a telephone interview from Atlanta, that the letter was addressed to ACOG president and chief executive officer, William Payne, and copied to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the Association of African NOCs.

According to the letter, the Nigerian Committee reminded ACOG that the black-out, by NBC television, which took a commerical break when the Nigerian contingent marched in, was a recurrence of the situation at the Los Angeles games in 1984.

"We feel such repeated action on Nigeria is rather deliberate," the letter said.

"We are very concerned about the future of the games if such ugly events are embarked on," it said, adding: "Our contingent is in Atlanta for the Olympics and not politics."

Meanwhile, Nigeria's acting consul-general in New York, Charles Awani, has condemned NBC's action, saying it was "deliberate rather than coincidental".

"We believe it is not in the spirit of the Olympics for them to select a few African countries for this type of treatment," Awani said. "It is not right especially against the backdrop of our relationship with the government of the U.S."

The Nigerian and United States governments have been at loggerheads as Washington has accused Abuja of human rights abuses.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Homosexuals Banned From Zimbabwe Book Fairs


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Gays and Lesbians Association of Zimbabwe (GALZ) has been banned from exhibiting in this year's Zimbabwe International Book Fair and from all future book fairs.

Issuing the order, the government of Zimbabwe said homosexuality is immoral and against the country's cultural ethics.

The Director of Information, Bornwell Chakaodza, said Tuesday that by barring GALZ from exhibiting at the Zimbabwe International Book Fair (ZIBF), the government was not contravening any of its laws but protecting the nation's cultural values. 

"In light of the foregoing, the position of the government of Zimbabwe has not changed. The Gays and Lesbians Association of Zimbabwe remain barred from renting a stand at this year's book fair.

"And they remain banned from displaying their books and other reading materials at future international book fairs of Zimbabwe," he said.

This is the second time that the government has banned GALZ from exhibiting at book fair.

Last year's ban provoked harsh criticism at home and abroad, including demonstrations against President Robert Mugabe when he visited South Africa, New Zealand and the Netherlands.

Despite last year's ban and Mugabe's condemnation of homosexuality, the organisers of the book had decided to allow GALZ to exhibit at this year's week-long fair starting July 30.

At the opening ceremony of last year's book fair, Mugabe described homosexuals as perverts and sodomists. He branded homosexuals as worse than dogs and pigs, adding they were not entitled to rights of any kind.

The Executive Director of the fair, Trish Mbanga, said "we want to exercise democracy. We cannot stop them from participating but people can just ignore them if they want to."

The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and the Zimbabwe Catholic Bishops Conference said there was nothing wrong with GALZ exhibiting literature, mostly on AIDS, which would benefit its members.

But a newly-formed Christian Communicators Association of Zimbabwe had threatened to mobilise Christians to boycott the book fair, and Sangano Munhumutapa, a pressure group, had threatened violence and "total sabotage", if gays were allowed to exhibit .

Chakaodza said "The barring of GALZ from renting a stand at the fair is not a question of contravening the laws of Zimbabwe or the country's own declaration of rights. Neither is it a question of violating freedom of art and expression.

"It is a question of protecting and guaranteeing the cultural health of zimbabwe."

He said GALZ had no right to publicly display literature and material at a public and cultural event where hundreds of children visited.

He denied recent press reports that information, posts and telecommunications minister, Joyce Mujuru, had said the government would not interfere with organisers of the book fair in their decision to allow GALZ to exhibit.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


Nigeria;
Government-Opposition Meeting Canceled in Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's opposition National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) has protested the abortion of its planned meeting Monday with government officials.

No reason was given for the last-minute cancellation of the meeting between NADECO and the National Reconciliation Committee (NARECOM). The meeting was to have taken place in Owo (western Nigeria), home of the of NADECO chief Michael Ajasin.

"It is regrettable that the military leadership has missed yet another opportunity to explore ways and means of resolving our lingering crisis through dialogue," Ajasin said in a reaction to the flopped meeting.

He added: "Nigeria, which belongs to all of us, is not at war. The lesson of history teaches us that a national political crisis is only resolvable through dialogue."

Nigeria was thrown into political turmoil after the annulment of its June 1993 presidential election by the last military regime.

Politician Moshood Abiola, acclaimed winner of the canceled poll, is awaiting trial for treason after he declared himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

The current military regime, led by Gen. Sani Abacha, set up the national reconciliation committee, headed by former information minister Alex Akinyele, to try and reconcile the political differences among Nigerians that arose after the annulment of the 1993 presidential election.

The government is implementing a transition to democracy program expected to end in October 1998.

Akinyele announced last week that the now aborted meeting with NADECO was to have served as part of government's reconciliation efforts.

He had also said the committee members would hold similar talks with exiled officials of the coalition.
