Africa News


July 23, 1996


South Africa;
No Legal Assistance For Former Hit Man


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Johannesburg - Dirk Coetzee, the police hitman who first exposed the existence of death squads in the police, will not receive legal assistance from the government when he is arrested on Friday this week for the 1981 murder of human rights lawyer Griffiths Mxenge.

The decision not to pay Coetzee's legal costs, even though he has cooperated fully with the African National Congress and the government to expose third force operations in the apartheid era, is in stark contrast to the treatment of other other dirty tricks operatives currently on murder charges.

Police are paying the full costs for Colonel Eugene de Kock, former commander of one of the most active death squads in the country, now facing more than 100 murder and fraud charges. The expenses of 19 murder suspects in the Magnus Malan trial are being paid by the South African National Defence Force. The combined costs of these two cases so far amounts to about R10- million. 

Coetzee told the Mail & Guardian he and another former hitman, Spyker Tshikalanga, would hand themselves to police on Friday. Both men expect to be freed on R1 000 bail.

The decision not to pay the legal fees and expenses incurred by Coetzee and other policemen involved in the forthcoming Mxenge murder trial was made in terms of a state regulation that officials who admit to criminal activities do not qualify for legal aid.

"We have been informed by the state attorney that we will have to pay all of our own costs including travel to and from Durban and lodging," said Coetzee. "This shows that it is better for all those people who carried out human rights atrocities to deny this instead of coming clean. Despite all this talk of truth and reconciliation, the system rewards those who lie."

The truth commission is known to be worried about the impact of Coetzee's recent comments on perpetrators who are considering whether or not to apply for amnesty, in return for full confessions about their involvement in human rights abuse during the apartheid era.

The police captain has stated publicly that he feels like a "used condom" and that it is not worth it for "all those Dirk Coetzee's out there" to reveal their past.

Coetzee also says he has been "abandoned" by the African National Congress. The renegade policeman says the organisation promised support in exchange for his early and valuable information about hit- squad operations in the police during the 1980s.

The policeman first revealed details about the notorious Vlakplaas unit to reporters from the Vrye Weekblad in 1989. "An intermediary, Andre Zaaiman, went to Lusaka to the ANC looking for a deal for Dirk. He came back to Vrye Weekblad and told us the ANC would look after Dirk in return for a full confession," says former Weekblad reporter Jacques Paauw.

'They never gave him an undertaking that he wouldn't be charged, because they couldn't. But they did agree to look after him. The ANC did do this until he got back from exile in London. And they also got him a job in the National Intelligence Agency."

However, Coetzee is also bitter because the ANC allegedly failed to include him on the list of people who were indemnified against criminal prosecution before they came back into the country from exile.

Jacob Zuma, deputy head of ANC intelligence and Coetzee's handler in exile, was not available at the time of going to press to answer queries about whether his organisation would assist its members now being charged for crimes they helped expose.

Coetzee has applied for amnesty from the truth commission, but this had not been processed by the time an order for his arrest had been issued by the KwaZulu-Natal Attorney General Tim McNally.

His trial could be postponed to allow his amnesty application to be heard only if the judge, AG and amnesty committee of the truth commission agree to do this.

Issue cover date: July 19


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 23, 1996


South Africa;
Who's Who In Mbeki's Private Think-Tank


BYLINE: Marion Edmunds, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Johannesburg - Deputy President Thabo Mbeki has set up a secretive, 24- strong think-tank called the Consultative Council to give him political advice.

All members of the group -- which appears to have no constitutional or administrative status despite its title -- are black. There are two women.

Two Cabinet ministers are on the council -- Minister of Safety and Security Sydney Mufamadi and Defence Minister Joe Modise -- as well as Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Aziz Pahad. 

Other members of the group include Cosatu general secretary Sam Shilowa, City Press editor Khulu Sibiya, Kagiso Trust chief executive officer Eric Molobi and National Olympic Committee of South Africa president Sam Ramsamy.

The council meets monthly at Mbeki's official residence in Pretoria. The deputy president's parliamentary counsellor, Dr Essop Pahad, appears to act as convener.

The two female members are Ann Letsebe, a lecturer at the Department of Social Work at the University of the Witwatersrand, and Durban-based human rights lawyer Linda Zama.

Five businessmen on the council are involved in African Renaissance Holdings, a broad-based investment syndicate. The chief executive of African Renaissance Holdings Bobby Makwetla is part of the group as well as a number of its directors -- Advocate "MacCaps" Motimele, Gabriel Mokgoko, Vincent Msibi, a Mmabatho-based doctor, and Seth Phalatse, who is manager of corporate planning at BMW.

Essop Pahad reluctantly confirmed the existence of the Consultative Council this week. "It's a forum that he calls from time to time. It's meant to meet monthly, but it does not always happen. The people in the group were selected because it was thought that they might be able to offer the deputy president useful advice," Pahad said.

"It is a set number of people and I don't think that they should speak to you about it," he added. Most council members said they could not talk to the media about their membership, or the nature of the council's discussions, referring the M&G to Essop Pahad.

Mufamadi denied the council was a kitchen cabinet, or that it was an exclusive sounding board, or club: "I would imagine that a person who was involved in policy-making processes would avoid insulating himself from people who are involved in activities affecting those processes," he said.

"The deputy president felt the need to be in dynamic contact with as many people as possible who are either involved in the ANC, but at the ground level, or who are involved with the community in various formations."

Another member of the council, Windsor Shuenyane, managing director of South African Breweries Centenary Centre in Newtown, Johannesburg, said the council was a way for the deputy president to hear the voice of South Africa's many constituencies.

"The deputy president wanted to be involved at ground level and hear the concerns of every constituency. All major constituencies are represented in this group," Shuenyane said.

"There is a general consensus that it is a confidential task group. We are just meeting and, for example, when the press goes hard at the deputy president we may talk about it and discuss what might be the cause. There is a member of the press there -- City Press editor Khulu Sibiya -- and he will contribute for the press, say how the press is thinking ... yes, there is quite a lot of discussion about the press," he said.

The City Press editor would not comment on his position in the group.

The chairman of the Development Bank of Southern Africa, Professor Wiseman Nkuhlu, said the council was in line with emerging black business and community interests. He said he concentrated on discussions on development and black economic empowerment which were his particular interests.

A striking aspect of the council is the absence from its ranks of some of the most influential members of the new black business community -- people like Nthatho Motlana, chairman of New African Investments Ltd, the Kunene brothers of Kunene Investments, Vusi Khanyile of Thebe Investments, veteran businessman Richard Maponya and Mohali Mahanyele, head of National Sorghum Breweries.

Other members of Mbeki's Consultative Council are: Professor Ephraim Mokgokong, rector of the Medical University of Southern Africa, Medunsa; Dr Vincent Maphai, director of the Department of Social Dynamics at the Human Sciences Research Council; M Maisela, marketing manager of Multi-Choice South Africa; Umtata-based T Boltina; ANC MP Dr Wally Serote; Professor P Zulu and general secretary of the South African Communist Party, Charles Ngakula.

ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa said the organisation's other senior leaders had not been involved in the selection of the group. "We have confidence in the deputy president and we believe that he has established a consultative forum in the best interests of the country so he can explore its richness beyond the government and the alliance."

An ANC MP, who did not wish to be named, said there would be some surprise in the party at the composition of the council. "It's not my dream team. There will be members of the ANC who won't be enamoured of this list," he said.

Issue cover date: July 19

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Zambia;
Women Aim For Political Office


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - AS Zambia approaches it's first national elections since the advent of multi-party democracy,more women are anxious for places as political candidates.

This came to light during a discussion on women as candidates between Zambia and America which was held at the American Centre in Lusaka. 

Zambia Democratic Congress representative, Susan Jere said Zambian women having been placed in an awkward position through traditions and cultural practices are fighting to convince society that they are credible political candidates.

She said the current situation of only seven women out of the 150 members of parliament shows that it would take a long time before women can have a fair representation in parliament.

And political director of the women's campaign fund in the US, Ms. Amy Walter, urged the National Women's lobby group in Zambia to identify a small number of women whom they would help financially if they are to succeed.

She said if they decide to help all the women candidates, the vision of the campaign fund would not succeed because there would be too many women who would want to benefit from the funds.

Ms Walter further urged the Zambian women to support the women who are current MPs and learn from them.

She cautioned the would be women candidates that it is extremely expensive to carry out a viable campagin if one is doing it for the first time.

Ms Walter also urged women who are aspiring for political positions to make themselves known in the communities in which they wish to stand.

She said this would help them to compete successfully against male candidates who are already known by the electorate.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Science;
Zambia Slates Environment Conservation As Priority


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Environment and Natural Resources Minister William Harrington has said his government maintains the policy of conservation a priority.

He said when the MMD government took office in 1991 it realised the need to strengthen the Environmental Council of Zambia to monitor environmental concerns and to provide solutions. 

He said government recognised the importance of awareness and that was why environmental education was incorporated in the country's national education policy.

Mr Harrington was speaking when he opened a weeklong Wildlife Conservation Society of Zambia training workshop at the Cooperative College in Lusaka.

He said years of neglect and lack of concern for conservation issues resulted in rundown infrastructure and deplorable living conditions for Zambians.

He told workshop participants drawn from primary, secondary and college lecturer-leaders of conservation clubs all over the country that the onus was on them to provide environmentally friendly attitudes in their students.

He directed the teachers to impart environmental conservation education through recognising values and clarifying concepts to children who would later teach their parents.

The ministry of environment enjoyed sound partnership with the wildlife conservation of zambia in the area of combating environmental degradation.

Many schools were benefiting in terms of supplementary education materials provided through the chongololo and conservation education programmes and the teachers were getting conected to the international world in the field of environmental conservation education.

"The people of Zambia are indebted to the efforts of the wildlife conservation society of Zambia which is disseminating informationon environmental and species protection," said Mr Harrington.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

272 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Zambia;
Belgians Call It Quits


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Belgian Embassy in Zambia will be closing at the end of August for financial reasons and both the Ambassador, Mr Luc Willemark and Foreign Affairs Deputy Minister, Dr Peter Machungwa confirmed the development in Lusaka today.

Mr Willemark said in an interview that the embassy was closing due to budgetary constraints back home and not political developments in Zambia. 

He said his government is also closing Consulates in some European countries and some embassies in Asia.

Mr Willemark said, however, that the co-operation section and the Belgium programmes in Zambia will continue to operate as before.

He emphasised that the closure was purely on budgetary reasons and not political ones.

Head of the Development Co-operation Section at the Belgian Embassy, Dirk Teerlinck, assured that development programmes though few will be continued adding that though he himself was pulling out of Zambia on Saturday this did not mean the end of everything.

And Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Machungwa said his ministry was aware of the closure.

He said the officials from the embassy informed the Zambian government that they were going to wind up business in Zambia at the end of next month.

He also said that reasons are that Belgium is finding it difficult to maintain some of its missions abroad due to the structural adjustment programme that she has embarked on.

"The reasons are just like the ones we are experiencing here in Zambia. We are also closing some embassies and High Commissions which we can't maintain," Dr Machungwa said.

He explained that the closure had nothing to do with the adoption of ammendments to the Republican Constitution which will restrict the presidency to second generation citizens.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Zambia;
Farmers Challenge Parliament's Gratuities


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) president Ben Kapita yesterday challenged the government to justify the legality of the K30 million each tax free gratuities to Members of Parliament.

In a press statement released yesterday, Kapita said "poverty in rural areas is continuing to increase. 

"The government always blames lack of funds for the lack of development in rural areas but can easily find K4.5 billion - more than double a national rural assistance programme - to pay itself a gratuity," Kapita's statement read in part. "Many rural MPs have rarely toured their constituencies to discuss problems and development programmes, how can they justify the K30 million tax free gratuity when they have not even started to do the job they were elected for?"

Kapita said that the hefty gratuity was more than double the K2 billion given out for the over 600,000 small scale farmers this year under the Rural Investment Fund.

"No MP can justify a gratuity that is ten thousand times greater than the money that government is prepared to make available to a farmer," Kapita said. "The decision taken by the government was daylight robbery."

Chief government spokesman, Amusaa Mwanam-wambwa, yesterday refused to comment on Kapita's charges.

But Penza last Friday told the Lusaka Press Club that all MPs including those "who had just been sleeping in Parliament during their term of office" were justified to get their gratuity as they were still doing their work " part of which also includes sleeping in the house".

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
South Africa Wins Two Medals


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Washington - The National Museum of African Art will participate in The Smithsonian's birthday celebration on the National mall with a series of free outdoor concerts and storytelling sessions, held in one of the pavilions on the mile long site. There will also be guided tours inside the museum, which is located at 950 Independence Avenue, S.W.

The museums activities are part of a free, two day celebration marking the Smithsonian 150th anniversary. Held on the mall and within the museums Aug. 10-11, this salute to the nations heritage will include an array of performances, family activities, exhibits and educational programs. Musical presentations and storytelling hosted by The Museum of African Art will take place in an outdoor pavilion, called "African Voices and Music", near the Smithsonian Metro station. 

On Saturday, Aug. 10, at noon 2 and 4 p.m. the featured performers will be Ghana Ensemble, a group of musicians who have been involved in traditional African music since their childhood. In addition to sharing the repertoires that reflect the many cultures Ghana, the performers will demonstrate dance steps and encourage visitors to join in. Sunday, Aug. 11, brings another day of festive music and dancing in the outdoor pavilion. The Umoja African Art company, an African drum and dance ensemble, will perform traditional music and dance of Zaire at noon, 2 and 4 p.m. This group of dancers and musicians are committed to sharing the cultural richness and beauty of Zaire and other African nations. On Saturday and Sunday at 1, 3 and 5 the outdoor pavilion will be the site of storytelling sessions led by museum education specialists and docents. Portions of the program will be interactive as storytellers engage visitors in tales highlighting the many cultures of Africa.

Throughout the weekend, visitors to the birthday party can stop by the museum which will be open from 10 am to 5:30 PM, to see this summer's popular exhibition "Crowning Achievements: African Arts Of Dressing The Head" which will be closing Aug. 18. On both Saturday and Sunday, museum docents will lead tours of the museum's collection at 11 a.m., 1 and 3 p.m.

The National Museum of African Art is easily accessible via Metro's blue and orange lines. Exit at the Smithsonian station. The museum is open daily from 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. In addition it is open Thursday evenings until 8 p. m., through Aug. 29.

July 24, 1996


Zambia;
Inspection Of Voters Registers Postponed


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - The elections office yesterday announced that the inspection of voters registers has been postponed until further notice in Lusaka, Central and Copperbelt provinces.

The postponement follows the non arrival of voters cards for the three provinces from the United States where they were being printed. 

"Electoral Commission will prescribe new dates for the three provinces as soon as the cards arrive from America," Elections Office spokesman, Joel Sikazwe announced yesterday.

But Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) secretary general, Derrick Chitala, charged that the move showed an intention to subvert the electoral process. " Unless the whole process is free and fair, there will be no elections," warned Chitala in an interview yesterday. "It's in the interest of the whole nation that we sit urgently to dialogue otherwise President Chiluba will be held responsible for subverting the democratic process. The whole electoral process is a sham."

And UNIP chairman, retired General Malimba Masheke, charged that the move was ill-intended.

"Copperbelt, Lusaka and Central Provinces constitute the heaviest number of registered voters compared to the whole country. Whether the cards are coming from the USA or Israel or from Nikuv locally they want to make sure there is an in-built majority," Masheke charged in a separate interview yesterday. " Unless there is a remedy to Nikuv, UNIP will not accept the results."

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Zambia;
Grain Bag Shortage Worries Farmers


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The government was yesterday urged by the Peasant Farmers Union of Zambia chairman, Patrick Kayeka, to intervene in the importation of grain bags to save his members from losing their grain.

Kayeka who has just returned from a field tour of Luapula Province revealed that there was a severe shortage of grain bags countrywide.

"Farmers fear losing their maize as there is a severe shortage of empty grain bags," Kayeka said in an interview yesterday. "And in cases where the bags are found they are too expensive for the farmers to buy due to the shortage." 

And sources at the Agricultural Market Information at the Ministry of Agriculture estimated the current stock of empty grain bags at just over 5 million against the needed 15.6 million for this year's harvest.

In its bid to liberalise the agro sector the government had left the marketing of the grain bags to the private sector but farmers cannot afford them.

"The bags are going for prices in the range of K1,500 and K2,000. And if you look at last year's price of K500 you will realise that the bags are now too expensive considering the low returns maize offers the farmer,"JKayeka carped.

But when contacted for comment, acting permanent secretary in the Ministry of Agriculture, Mulele Mulele, said government would give a statement later.

And last season's heavy rains have badly affected beans production in the Eastern Province.

This year's harvest has been termed as "extremely" low, leading to fears of a shortage in the Province and the hiking of prices in the long term.

"This year's 'good rains' have affected beans production," disclosed Alick Mbewe, manager of the Danish funded Muchilakubili Agricultural Project, in an interview in Lusaka yesterday. "The crop yield is affected by humidity and following the heavy rains the entire Province has suffered a poor harvest this season. The figures are really bad. "

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Sports - Olympic;
Reporter's Notebook From Atlanta


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Atlanta - Security concerns at the games' village in Atlanta are making life difficult for journalists covering the games, whether accredited or not.

It has been very difficult for journalists to get in touch with athletes and officials at the village, because of tough instructions from the Atlanta Committee for the Games (ACOG) to the effect that journalists must be escorted into the village by their countries' chef of mission, a tough condition.

A NAN correspondent seeking to interview some athletes and officials at the village had to spend hours at the gate without luck. Several journalists have now pitched their tents right in front of the gate to enable them "ambush" athletes and officials going in and out of the village. ----- 

Though journalists are said to be known for their whining, they are not the only ones complaining about problems at the centennial games.

Atlantans themselves seem to be overwhelmed by the thousands of visitors who have descended on their town, the resulting strain on public utilities and other inconveniences.

And smart entrepreneurs are cashing in on the people's feelings, forming an "organisation " called " Atlantans disgusted with the games (ADOG)" -- a bastardisation of the name of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games (ACOG) -- and offering T-shirts and other memorabilia for sale.

The organization's mascot is a blue dog called "pizzy", as against the games' mascot, "Izzi". -----

Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa is in Atlanta, apparently to help lobby for cape town's bid for the 2004 games.

However, the archbishop denies that his presence at the games has anything to do with lobbying.

"I didn't come to lobby but to meet people and to sell the idea that Cape Town is capable of hosting the Olympic games," he told correspondents outside the games village.

A picture of the retired archbishop's flashing a victory sign is on the cover of the official magazine of the bid committee, which is being widely distributed in Atlanta.

"We have proved it to ourselves and to the world that South Africa is a country where we can dream dreams, and where those dreams actually come true," he wrote in the 23-page magazine titled "2004".

Africa News


July 24, 1996


Sports- Olympics;
Nigerians Celebrate Victory Over Japan


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian work supervisors had to show leniency Wednesday morning towards the employees who reported late, after staying awake into the early morning hours, to watch the nation's under-23 soccer team beat Japan 2-0 in the 1996 Olympic Games.

The much-fancied Japanese, after their 1-0 victory over Brazil, had been dubbed "giant killers" in group 'D' which also includes Hungary.

Because of time difference, the much-talked about match in Orlando, Florida, kicked off at 1.30 AM Lagos time (12.30 GMT). 

From the shanty-community of Ajegunle to high-brow Ikoyi and Victoria Island, Lagosians were awake, giving what a commentator called "spiritual and moral support" to the national team in far-way Orlando.

Many residents had their afternoon nap Tuesday to prepare themselves for the "night vigil.

They were glued to their television sets for the encounter, with hundreds, mostly youths pouring into the streets, drumming and dancing at the end of the tension-soaked match.

In several residential quarters, those who watched the encounter at drinking houses continued the celebration until late in the morning.

But before then, anxiety had almost gave way to frustration, when the Nigerian team failed to penetrate the Japanese defence and score goals during the entire first half.

Thus, the first goal by Tijani Babangida, seven minutes to the end of the match, was greeted with deafening applause that reverbrated across the city of six million people.

The Nigerians, who had in their opening match defeated Hungary 1-0 on Sunday, sealed the Japanese hope in the 90th minute through an Austin 'Jay- Jay' Okacha penalty kick after a defender grabbed the ball in Japan's vital area.

The goal was greeted by another rapture from the Nigerians watching the match on television at home.

"The boys are fantastic," said a trader, James Akele, in a comment that summarised the mood of the nation.

However, sports journalist Jide Adebayo said the fact that Nigeria would defeat Japan was never in doubt.

"History is on Nigeria's side," he said, citing two previous ecounters between the two countries during the King Fahd Inter-continental Championship in Saudi Arabia.

But Adebayo warns that Nigeria should watch out against Brazil, in their last group match, as the South Americans have always had an upper hand against Nigeria in soccer.

The Brazilians Tuesday crushed Hungary 3-1 in their second match to win their first three points.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


279 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Japanese Played Well, Says Nigerian Coach


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ORLANDO, United States (PANA) - Nigeria's under-23 national soccer team secured a place into the next round of the Atlanta games following its 2-0 victory over Japan here early Wednesday.

However, Nigerian team handlers conceded after the match that the Japanese were a hard nut to crack.

At a post-match press conference, Nigeria's technical adviser, Bonfrere Jo, said that the Japanese played well, making the match very "difficult"

He said that the pattern of play the Japanese demonstrated in their match with Nigeria showed that their victory against Brazil Sunday was not a fluke. 

Meanwhile, the Nigerian sports minister, Jim Nwobodo, said that he was very happy with the outcome of the "wonderful" match. He asserted that his presence brought good fortunes to the team.

"I came all the way from Atlanta to watch this match because I believe it is a crucial match in the preliminaries," he delightedly told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN).

The chairman of the Nigeria football association, retired Air Commodore Emeka Omeruah, said that the result was a manifestation of hard work and prayers.

"I believe that the boys are beginning to show their mettle, that they are very good and we hope that this would be the beginning of good things to happen," he said.

"And if we are able to go to Miami and play well again, then we are sure that we are going to get there," he added.

The victory gave Nigeria six points and shot it to the top of group D, where a mere tie would ensure its qualification for the quarter-finals.

In the group's other match, Brazil took its anger out on Hungary, beating the Europeans 3-1, to tie with Japan at three points.

The Nigerians will next see action against Brazil in Miami on Thursday, in a match that promises a lot of excitement.

Meanwhile, Ghana, the Barcelona Games bronze medalist, kept its hopes alive with a 3-2 victory over Italy in a group C match in Washington D.C. Wednesday morning.

South Korea and Mexico tied 0-0 in the group's other match.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

280 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Science;
Combining Modern And Traditional Medicine Catches On


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The concept of combining traditional and modern medicine, which was pioneered in Zimbabwe at independence in 1980, is fast spreading to other African countries.

Barbara Sibanda, founder member of the traditional and medical clinic which this week celebrates 15 years of the unique experiment, told Zimbabwe Inter- Africa News Agency that Ghana, Malawi, Nigeria and Zambia were among the African countries that were studying the Zimbabwean experience.

The concept gives patients a choice between modern and traditional medicine under one roof and practitioners from either side liaise over the most likely successful form of remedy for an ailment. 

"Our success rate has been as good as any health delivery system. The choice for the patient is now wider, some kind of revolution in medical practice," said Sibanda. Her Bulawayo-based clinic employs a full-time medical practitioner, a traditional healer and midwives for its 25-bed maternity wing.

Sibanda established her clinic in 1981, amid stiff opposition from the medical profession. She has since opened the first rural outpost in Sigola communal lands on the outskirts of Bulawayo.

The outpost, which Sibanda described as fully subscribed, also runs a free immunisation programme for the under-fives.

In 1995 the clinic also introduced spiritual healing to cater for patients who believed in god.

Sibanda said those with faith-healing powers conducted their healing sessions in an adjacent wing. There were also plans to set up a theatre.

She said major ailments often referred to traditional healers by the medical practitioner included infertility, asthma, epileptic fits and mental problems.

The clinic which charges slightly lower rates for consultation and herbs, handles up to 100 patients per day.

Sibanda added that the concept was gaining recognition in most sub-Saharan African countries where, despite the advent of modern medicine over a century ago, up to 80 percent of African people had faith in traditional herbal treatment.

"The anniversary this week is to consolidate the contribution of traditional medicine to the health delivery system and demonstrate how the two can harmoniously be combined to produce good, even better results," said Sibanda.

Guests invited to the celebrations include Zimbabwe's health and child welfare minister, Dr. Timothy Stamps, a medical practitioner who has publicly disapproved of claims by traditional healers that they had found a cure for the deadly AIDS pandemic.

The president of the 40,000-member Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association, Gordon Chavhunduka, and that of the International Organization of Traditional and Medical Practitioners and Researchers, are also expected to attend.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Nigeria;
Eleven Coup Plotters Released After Six Years


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Eleven soldiers who have spent six years in prison for their alleged complicity in a failed coup against former Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, have been freed, military sources said in Lagos Wednesday.

Their release followed action initiated on their behalf by the human rights group, Civil Liberties Organisations, the sources said. 

Babangida beat off two coup attempts before he quit office in August 1993.

The first, led by his former friend, Gen. Mamman Vatsa, was foiled in December 1985. Vatsa and other officers implicated in the coup were executed, while others were imprisoned.

On April 20, 1990, another group of military men led by Maj. Gideon Orkar staged another coup attempt against the Babangida regime, in which several soldiers and civilians were killed.

About 70 soldiers, tried by a special court after the second coup, were executed, while a number of other military men received prison sentences, some for life.

Babangida handed over power Aug. 26 ,1993, to an interim national government led by a businessman, Ernest Shonekan.

On Nov. 17, the Shonekan government was overthrown in a palace coup mounted by Gen. Sani Abacha, Nigeria's current head of state.

Abacha was a key figure in the Babangida regime and was defence minister in the interim government.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


282 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Reports Loss Of Two Soldiers In Border Fighting


BYLINE: Yahya el Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese army announced here Wednesday that two of its soldiers got killed in Sunday's battle near the border with Eritrea.

Army spokesman Gen. Mohamed Sanousi Ahmed said in a communique, published by the state-owned newspaper, al- Sudan al-Hadeith, and Akhbar al Youm, an independent daily, that an infantry unit, assisted by armoured vehicles, Sunday attacked the Sudanese border post of Jebel Abu Gamul. 

However, the statement did not specify whether the attacking forces were Eritrean or anti-Khartoum government dissidents based in that neighboring country.

It only said the Sudanese forces confronted the invading forces with strength and bravery forcing them to retreat into Eritrea, leaving behind several of their number dead. The number of enemy killed was not given.

Reports of Sunday's border fighting were first broken Tuesday by the Sudan News Agency (SUNA) which did not speak of any government army losses.

The statement said the army was in full control of the situation and that the government troops and the citizens in the area were ready to repulse any aggression.

Eritrea cut off diplomatic relations with Sudan at the end of 1994, amid claims that Khartoum was inciting moslem Eritreans against the government.

Khartoum denied the accusation, alleging Asmara severed the relations under pressure from some Western quarters, in return for financial assistance.

Sudan got embittered early in 1995 when an alliance of banned Sudanese political parties held a conference in the Eritrean capital, Asmara. The opponents declared their intention to topple the government of Gen. Omar Bashir by military means.

The exiles charged Abdul Aziz Khalid, an army officer who defected from the Sudanese army, with the task of raising an army in eastern Sudan and to launch an armed struggle against the Bashir government.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


283 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Government Gets Tough With Strikes


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Thousands of teachers and civil servants in Swaziland will get a pay shock this week, when government applies a "No Work - - No Pay" policy following their illegal strike in June and early July.

The teachers, members of the Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT), will lose 18 days pay in their July salary cheques and 15 days in August. 

The pay cuts were confirmed by the Secretary to the Cabinet, Frank Bucham, Wednesday, to the teachers' and civil servants' leaders when negotiations over their 18 per cent salary increase demands resumed.

The leaders were further warned that their associations also faced the risk, under the kingdom's law, of being banned for the illegal strike.

President of the teachers association, Meshack Masuku, and his civil servants counterpart, Absolom Dlamini, expressed shock and anger at the tough line taken by the government and threatened to seek the king's intervention.

The teachers said the pay cuts were unnecessary because they had agreed to teach overtime on Saturdays and during the August holidays to make up for work days lost during their strike.

The civil servants claimed they were being punished unfairly because they had been forced to join the strike by gangs who had threatened violence against them if they continued working.

Bucham said the two associations could face further penalties for contempt of an industrial court order that they return to work.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 24, 1996


Swaziland;
SADC Leaders Begin Meeting On Swaziland


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Four Southern African leaders began meeting in Maputo Wednesday to find possible solutions to problems in Swaziland where trade unions and human rights groups are demanding democratic changes.

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, who chairs the troika of Southern African leaders that helped solve problems in Lesotho in 1994, arrived here Wednesday morning to join South Africa's President Nelson Mandela, Botswana's Ketumile Masire and host President Joquaim Chissano.

King Mswati 111 of Swaziland sent acting Prime Minister Sishayi Nxumalo for the talks, being held at the Ponta Vermelha state house on the Indian ocean front. 

Nxumalo is expected to brief the leaders on the latest developments in his country.

The tiny mountain kingdom of Swaziland, the only Southern African country in which political parties are banned, has for more than year been hit by a series of pro-democracy strikes and has been under mounting international pressure to return to democratic rule.

King Sobhuza 11, Mswati's father, outlawed all political parties in Swaziland when he introduced emergency rule in 1973, suspending at the same time the Westminster-style constitution inherited at independence in 1968.

The Southern African leaders, without Chissano, met in Pretoria, South Africa, in March where the situation in Swaziland was also discussed and King Mswati III promised to take action towards constitutional reform.

"We will consult the nation on which way to go forward from here," he said, adding that he would "move swiftly with the people of Swaziland" to institute constitutional reforms.

Most active in pushing for constitutional reforms has been the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions, which has been joined by opposition political parties and now formed as the Swaziland Democratic Alliance.

King Mswati in May announced he had set up a People's Parliament at Ludzidzini, 50 miles south of the capital Mbabane, which would start hearing constitutional submissions by ordinary Swazis that same month.

The monarch also said a constitutional committee and the Swaziland National Council would also be set up in May as part of the moves towards democratic reforms.

However, trade unions and political parties are convinced the king, who has absolute authority over the country's 900,000 people, is buying time and has no intention of lifting the 1973 decree banning political activity.

The United States and Britain are some of the powerful countries supporting constitutional reforms in Swaziland. British Overseas Development Minister Lynda Chalker has told the monarch delays could result in "radical elements" hijacking the process.

Meanwhile, the South African Press Association reports that King Mswati has invited the Swazi people to a national meeting at Ludzidzini royal kraal Friday where he is expected to announce the members of a new constitutional committee responsible for implementing the constitutional review.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

South Africa;
Commission Meets Dutch Reformed Church Leaders


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Johannesburg - A meeting between members of the Moderamen of the Western Cape Synod of the Dutch Reformed Church (NGK) and members of the TRC took place on Wednesday, July 24, in Cape Town.

A number of issues were discussed with a particular focus on the role of the churches may play in the TRC's long-term goal of reconciliation. The meeting explored various ways of encouraging members of the white community to participate in this process.

The necessity of evenness in the approach of the TRC was also emphasized.

The meeting was chaired by the moderator of the NGK (Western Cape), Dr. Frits Gaum, and it was also attended by Dr. Coenie Burger, Prof. Pieter Coertzen and Rev. Christo Alheit of the NGK. The TRC delegation consisted of Mary Burton, Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, Piet Meiring and Wilhelm Verwoerd.

Addis Ababa - Before leaving for Atlanta, Georgia, to take part in the 1996 Olympic Games, Ethiopian athletes met with Ato Dawit Yohannes, Speaker of the House of Peoples Representatives.

He said on the occasion that it would be a great surprise if the athletes win medals, because they did not get the assistance they should have been given from the government, which was new and preoccupied with activities that required more attention.

The eight-man and eight-woman athletics team members will register good results because they all exercised for eight consecutive months, according to athletics chief coach, Dr. Wolde-Meskel Kostre.

Africa News


July 25, 1996


Ethiopia;
Effort to build multi-national defence force successful


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ministry of Defence in a statement issued yesterday announced that efforts geared toward building a multi-national defence force with a uniform leadership and organization has been highly successful.

The national composition of the defence army was made proportional following the demobilization of TPLF combatants the largest in the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) as it was observed in the three day review meeting the ministry held to assess its performance in 1988 E.C. in the presence of Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence Tamirat Layne, Chief of Staff Major-General Tsadkan Gebretansay and other higher officials. 

Thousands of youngsters from Oromiya, Amhara and southern Peoples Regional States were recruited and trained in basic military science and politics to join the National Defence Force, according to the statement.

Militiamen from various political organization who were active in the struggle against the totalitarian Derg regime, including a multitude of Afar, Gambela and Somali nationals have joined the ranks of the new National Defence Force after passing through the proper military training, it added.

Ex-servicemen who were found to be loyal to the constitution with promising professional competence have also joined the defence force.

Building a defence force capable of defending the country against internal as well as external anti-peace elements is indispensable, it said, adding the army has received professional training so as to grasp the cause for which it stood and commit itself to its success.

The ministry has used the proceeds from the sale of old vehicles and other properties for the purchase of materials necessary for the defence force.

Peasant militia force has been organized in the Amhara, Oromiya and Southern Peoples regional states in a bid to curb security problems that might surface in some localities.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Ethiopia;
Tigray intellectuals urged to brace up for development


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Addis Ababa - The head of the Tigray Regional State Ato Gebru Asrat urged native intellectuals to urgently respond to the need of the regional people who he said languished for years as a result of natural and man-made calamities.

Opening a symposium attended by over 700 native intellectuals here in the capital, he said the problems of the Tigray people could be alleviated when only the natives who pledged to struggle along with the people through employing their know-how-and labour work towards this end.

Although pledging to work for the people is one of the manifestations of commitment to the popular cause, he said, adding this could be realised when one urgently responds to effecting his determination. The responsibility entrusted upon each intellectual in changing the livelihood of the people who once lived in misery could not be underestimated, he added. 

Ato Gebru said although encouraging results have been registered in the rehabilitation and reconstruction activities in the region much more is expected af all the natives in expediting the ongoing social and economic undertakings.

The head of the regional state demanded the participnats to thoroughly discuss the five-year development programme and explore ways and means of implementing the strategies.

Ato Haile-Selassie Wolde-Germima, Chairman of the coordinating committee of the workshop, remind the participants to actively participate in the discussion and forward proposals.

The development activities carried out in the past four years and future plans include the reconstruction of infrastructures, soil and water conservation, forestry development, mining as well as preservation of historical heritages, tourism and population affairs.

Issues for discussion including development policy and strategy of Tigray as well as implementation programmes were presented by Ato Abay Tsehaye, executive committee member of the regional council and Dr. Metiku Haile.

Meanwhile, native intellectuals residing in Addis Expressed determination to discharge their professional responsibilities and work for peace and democracy for which the people have paid sacrifices.

In a five-year resolution they passed at the end of the two-day symposium Sunday the over 700 intellectuals said the people of Tigray have played a great role in overthrowing the dictatorial Derg regime subsequently enabling the Ethiopian people live in peace.

The resolution said the sacrifices paid by the Tigray people enabled the intellectuals become beneficiaries of their profession.

The intellectuals expressed their commitment to participate in revitalizing the war-devastated economy of the regime by tackling the problems which will be encountered in the course of the reconstruction activities based on the democratic culture nurtured by the people and TPLF.

In the course of the symposium, problems that hindered the direct participation of intellectuals in the regional development activities were discussed, while solutions to the problems were forwarded.

Participants of the symposium, have also indicated that there was low spirit among the intellectuals in initiating themselves to be involved in regional development activities by tackling some social problems they have faced.

Woizero Aregash Adane, secretary of the Tigray Regional State Council, said the council would give support for the implementation of the plans and initiatives of the intellectuals that centres on public interest.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


289 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Ethiopia;
World Bank pledges to finance health projects


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Nazreth, Ethiopia - The World Bank said yesterday it would support the all- round efforts of the government to promote material and child health care programme in the country.

World Bank deputy country representatives, Dr. Sudarshan Gooptu said the World Bank would finance projects aimed at improving the health situation of mothers and children particularly to the most deprived rural areas of the country.

Addressing a project assessment workshop here, Dr. Gooptu said the noble guideline of the World Bank is promoting economic and social progress in developing countries, like Ethiopia and improving the living standards of their people. 

He said, following a reform programme, the country has been showing encouraging progress in the health sector. The recent UNDP human development report could be a clear testimony for the country's overall development since the new government came to power, he said.

In Ethiopia the living standards remain low and access to social services is less than adequate, Dr. Gooptu said adding efforts should be made towards alleviating the socio-economic problems of the people.

Dr. Lamisso Hayesso, Vice Minister of Health, said on his part that the family health project, being financed by the World Bank and the Government of Ethiopia, would cost 32.3 million birr.

He said 19.7 million birr of the total package is secured in loan from the World Bank while the balance is to be covered by the government.

According to the agreement, hundred health stations and 19 health centers are to be constructed throughout the country.

Dr. Lamiso said the construction of such health institutions would raise the health service coverage of the country by 10.8 per cent.

The project is expected to come to an end by the year 1997.

Heads of regional health bureaux and planning and programming offices, experts from the various ministries and World Bank representatives are attending the two-day workshop.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Gays Could Be Heading For A Showdown


BYLINE: Tambayi Nyika, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's largely heterosexual society, repulsed by homosexuality, could be heading for a showdown with an increasingly assertive and foreign-backed gay and lesbian lobby, which is refusing to stay cooped up in closets.

The Gay and Lesbian Association of Zimbabwe (GALZ) has successfully applied to participate and exhibit their material at the forthcoming Zimbabwe International Book Fair (ZIBF) scheduled for July 30 to August 03.

The association and their sympathizers see this as a victory following the 1995 controversy during which they were banned from exhibiting at the fair.

An international furor was created when Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe viciously attacked gays and lesbians as sexual perverts and sodomists, and threatened to have them locked up if they publicised their activities. 

"If we accept homosexuality as a right, as is being argued, what moral fibre shall our society ever have to deny organized drug addicts, or even those given to bestiality the rights they might claim under the rubric of individual freedom and human rights including the freedom of the press to write, publish and publicise?" asked Mugabe.

The government has again banned GALZ from exhibiting at the 1996 book fair to "protect and guarantee the cultural health of Zimbabwe from possible erosion" and has berated organizers of the exposition for having allowed them to participate.

But the association and its members say they will not be bullied into withdrawing from the book fair and will proceed with their participation on the same terms as any other approved exhibitor.

The majority of Zimbabweans strongly oppose the sexual preferences of gays and lesbians on religious, cultural and moral grounds.

Mugabe's attack on gays and lesbians in 1995, which had the full support of local writers, appeared to have silenced GALZ.

But not to be cowed, GALZ launched a counter worldwide campaign against " persecution" which resulted in demonstrations against Mugabe in South Africa, Nigeria and some European countries.

GALZ's planned re-entry into the book fair could therefore illustrate Zimbabwe's vulnerability to pressure of international politics and donor funding.

A spokesperson for the Netherlands embassy here in Harare has justified the Dutch government's support for GALZ.

"We as a nation fully understand the plight of GALZ and are in full support of their fight to be treated equally. We feel they should not be discriminated against for any reason. It is a fundamental human right," said the spokesperson.

At the height of the 1995 controversy, at least three ZIBF trustees sympathetic to GALZ resigned and there were veiled threats of the traditional book fair donors influencing the relocation of the annual exposition to South Africa where gays and lesbians are recognized and protected by law.

Thus, the return of GALZ is being viewed by the majority of Zimbabweans as arm-twisting by foreign donors and a slap in the face of culture, religion and morality.

"In our culture you do not exhibit sex. It is taboo. I do not want my five- year old daughter to see information not suitable for her. We know they have a right to their sexual preferences but not in public. In our culture we select things according to age, sex, even customs," says writer Cont Mhlanga.

"The power of donor funding is clear here. He who pays the piper calls the tune. Because they are giving us money they are dictating the standards of our morality," laments Pathisa Nyathi, a cultural activist who sits on the ZIBF board of trustees.

It appears the decision to allow GALZ'S participation was imposed by an invisible force outside the ZIBF.

Trustees, George Kahari and Nyathi claim that the issue was never discussed during preparatory meetings for the 1996 fair, only for them to read about it in newspapers.

"The board is against their practise and the majority of them are not aware of their participation. We will never accept that as part of our culture," says Kahari.

ZIBF executive director, Trish Mbanga defends the organization's decision as democratic.

"We are not forcing people to go and look at the material they have no interest in, no one is going to say look at this, look at that," she told a local television panel discussion.

Although government has said it will continue to oppose GALZ's participation, it has somewhat scaled down the 1995 aggressive stance.

"We expect the organizers to respect our culture. We are going to tell them that we do not accept that," says Nathan Shamuyarira, the country's industry and commerce minister.

But writer Mhlanga believes Zimbabwe lost the battle against GALZ in 1995 when Mugabe's attacks gave the world the impression of persecution of minority rights, particularly during an international event on human rights.

"And because of GALZ's powerful links the whole issue has been politicized as a human rights issue and oppression of the minority. We should have adequately prepared to deal with the issue because it is not going to disappear," says Mhlanga.

It remains to be seen whether the GALZ exhibition at the book fair will go ahead without any disturbances from their opponents, among them Mugabe who has vowed at various international fora that he would never allow gays and lesbians to do as they please in his country.

Already, a Harare-based pressure group, Sangano Munhumutapa, has promised that should GALZ exhibit at the book fair, they would burn down its stand.

"They can do what they want with their bodies in the privacy of their homes, but certainly not to exhibit at the book fair," says Lawrence Chakaredza, president of the pressure group linked with the university of Zimbabwe students.

If Sangano Munhumutapa's threat is to be taken seriously, and if GALZ and its members are determined to defy the government ban and make a showing at the book fair, then a showdown is almost certain.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigerian Eagles Face A Herculean Task


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's under-23 soccer squad, the Eagles, face a tough task Friday morning in Miami when they play Brazil, world soccer giants, in the last 'Group D' match of the centennial Olympiad.

After snatching the maximum points in their matches against Hungary and Japan, Nigeria's "dream team," is poised for an all-out war on the Brazilians to prove a number of points.

Barring the unexpected, Nigeria, one-time under-17 world soccer champion, would like to prove that it is equally capable of bringing home its first Olympic gold. 

The Eagles will also be anxious to prove that Brazil is not invincible and leave behind them previous embarrassments and defeats suffered at their hands.

This will be the third time both countries are meeting at the Olympics.

At the Mexico Olympics in 1968 the Nigerians, leading 3-0, allowed the Brazilians to come from behind and level matters before regulation time.

In Seoul in 1988, when they last played Brazilians, they were walloped 4-0.

Should Nigeria make it to the quarter-finals, it will be the first time that the country will go beyond the preliminaries of the Olympic soccer event.

But the Brazilians, despite their 0-1 defeat by Japan, are still book- makers favourites.

The South Americans will be desperate in their third encounter with the West Africans. They know a loss means doom. A mere draw will not help matters either.

Nigeria is currently leading the group while Brazil is at par with Japan, except for a superior goal advantage.

On the same day Ghana, Africa's other representative still in the race, will battle against 'Group C' leaders, Mexico, in a bid to grab a quarter- final ticket.

The unexpected 1-0 defeat of the Barcelona '92 bronze medallists had put them in a tight corner.

They had to fight from 1-2 down to beat Italy 3-2 on Tuesday in Washington.

A draw against Mexico may guarantee them a place in the quarter finals, provided Korea does not beat Italy with a large goal margin.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Sports -Olympics;
African Athletes Urged To Put Out Their Best


BYLINE: Mike Mbonye, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ATLANTA, United States (PANA) - The president of the Association of Olympic Committees in Africa (ANOCA), Jean Claude Ganga, has urged African athletes competing in the on-going Olympic games to put out their best in their various fields.

"I want all our athletes to bear in mind that the entire African continent is solidly behind them as they compete against the rest of the world and we want them to put in their best".

Ganga charged the athletes to prove to the rest of the world that they can conquer the world in sports and use sports to make up for Africa's inability to send somebody to the moon. 

"The time has come when African athletes should be given the desired respect in sports" he added.

Ganga, who is also the president of the national Olympic committee of Congo, praised South African swimmer, Penny Heyns, who has so far won two gold medals.

"I sincerely believe that the medals will flow in for Africa when the track and field events begin on July 26," he said.

He stressed that Nigerian, South African, Kenyan, Somalian, Ethiopian and Mozambican athletes are capable of winning medals in the track and field events, adding: "I know they will do their best to carry our various flags to high places".

On the protest of the Nigeria Olympic committee over the blackout of its contingent by the NBC TV during the opening ceremony, Ganga said he was backing the committee and was very concerned about the situation.

"I am backing the Nigerian Olympic committee because Nigeria is one of the biggest countries in Africa and does not deserve the treatment she received from the American television network NBC," he said.

He said he had already taken the matter to the international Olympic committee, and the local organizing committee to ensure that the incident does not happen again.

Africa News


July 25, 1996


Southern Africa;
Chiluba Apologises For Ministers' Rude Remarks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has

reportedly apologised for statements by members of his cabinet who had accused Southern African leaders of meddling in the internal affairs of his country.

"President Chiluba apologised for some of the rude remarks made by some of his colleagues," President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe told a news conference in Maputo Wednesday at the end of a Southern African Development Community meeting to discuss Swaziland, where the monarch is under pressure to introduce democratic reforms. 

The ministers had particularly accused SADC leaders of making statements in support of former President Kenneth Kaunda.

"We are not interfering in the internal affairs of Zambia. But if we see any developments that we view and interpret as signs of conflict, we cannot keep quiet. If there are such signs in Zimbabwe my colleagues can seek an explanation," said Mugabe who was flanked by his colleagues in the newly- formed SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security, South African President Nelson Mandela, Ketumile Masire of Botswana and host President Joaquim Chissano.

He was responding to a question.

Zambia, hit by a wave of bomb attacks and violent demonstrations after amending the constitution to bar Kaunda from running for president again, is being monitored by the SADC organ which is anxious that the situation may worsen.

Mugabe said the SADC organ was not happy with the events in Zambia. "We want to see Zambia move in a direction of peace and stability."
