LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


294 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Kenyan Minister Appeals For Education Outside School


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

NANYUKI, Kenya (PANA) - The third general assembly of the Forum for African Women Educationalists (FAWE) opened here Thursday with a call for a shift of emphasis towards girls outside schools to esure their integration into the maistream of African education systems.

Opening the meeting, Kenya's Education Minister Joseph Kamotho said it was important to ensure that all girls enrol and are retained in schools until they complete their education.

He said that while girls in schools needed moral and financial support, those who drop out of school because of pregnancy should also be assisted and readmitted into the school system to continue their studies. 

The assembly is taking place at the equatorial town of Nanyuki some 250 km north of Nairobi, the Kenyan capital.

"We have not given adequate attention to the girl who is outside the school, 'The Missing Girl', and this forum of distinguished women educationalists should deliberate adequately on the plight of the girls out of school," he said.

Kamotho noted that while African countries had increased primary school enrolments between 1990 and 1995, the growth rate in enrolment by girls advanced very slightly to 45.8 percent in 1995 from 45.4 percent in 1990.

"Nineteen countries in sub-Saharan Africa, in fact registered a significant percentage decrease in the participation of girls while there was an improvement in net enrolment ratio. The ratio for boys reached 65.7 percent compared with 56.1 percent for girls.

He urged the delegates to make firm recommendations to their governments on how to improve access, equity and quality of the education of girls at primary, secondary, university and tertiary levels.

Turning to the Kenyan situation, Kamotho said girls' schools were performing better than their male counterparts. Over half of the top 20 positions were taken by girls' schools in national examinations.

Kamotho added that the government had launched a program of finding 'The Missing Girl'- by introducing formal education for the street girls and others who drop out of school, so that they can continue with their education.

Introducing the minister, FAWE chairperson Gennet Zewide, who is also the Ethiopian education minister, said that the forum had created 19 national chapters.

The two-day meeting has brought together some 46 leading African educationalists, who include university vice-chancellors and professors and education ministers from 27 Africa countries.

The forum is being held on African soil for the first time. The first and second in 1992 and 1994 congresses were held in Bellagio, Italy.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Airways To Resume Flights To New York


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria Airways is to resume flights from Lagos to New York under a partnership agreement it has signed with the United States airline, World Airways, it was announced here Wednesday.

Nigeria Airways managing director, Group Captain Peter Gana, told reporters late Wednesday in Lagos the flights would resume August 1. 

The flights were stopped in October 1994 due to a number of reasons, including alleged drug trafficking.

In a retaliatory move, Nigeria also withdrew landing rights from American Airways, which was then flying on the New York-Lagos-New York route.

Under new the agreement, passengers from Nigeria will be flown to Dakar, capital of Senegal, from where they would board World Airlines for their journey to New York.

Gana said the partnership agreement's negotiations were concluded in June in New York.

He said the new agreement solves the problem Nigerians were facing in obtaining transit visas when travelling through European capitals.

To get to New York, travellers from Lagos had to use a foreign airline ( Swiss Air, KLM, Sabena, Lufthansa, Air France). They also had to transit through the countries of origin of these flights, hence the need for transit visas.

"Nigerians do not need a transit visa to go to Senegal. This will save our passengers a few more dollars. It will also save travel time," Gana said.

According to Gana, passengers would be taken to Dakar aboard a Nigerian Airways aircraft.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Burundi;
UNESCO Protests Against Violence In Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Dakar, Senegal (PANA) - UNESCO Director-General Federico Mayor has

protested against the escalation of violence in Burundi and all acts which interfer with the peace process in that country.

"As events of the last few days show, a climate of generalised terror has been created which prevents all attempts at dialogue, slows the return to security and stability and compromises peace initiatives undertaken at the national, regional and international levels, notably those begun in Arusha, Tanzania," he said in a statement issued in Paris Wednesday. 

Saying that he was greatly concerned by the tragic situation in Burundi, which is characterized by the repeated murder of innocent civilians and the weakening of its institutions, Mayor appealed to the political and military authorities as well as to the Burundian people that the force of reason may prevail over the reason of force.

"I ask them urgently to recall the values on which the Burundian nation is founded - respect for life, tolerance and peace - to safeguard the nation's unity in this difficult moment," he said in the message. UNESCO, he noted, is engaged side by side with the Burundian people in the peace process. "I renew this commitment once again and I express my complete solidarity with all those who ceaselessly work for national reconciliation".

He called on the international community to give Burundi all the help it needs to extricate itself from a dramatic impasse which threatens the stability of the entire Great Lakes region, adding that for its part, UNESCO is ready to support all such initiatives.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


297 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Burundi;
OAU Warns Against Military Take-over in Burundi


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity has warned against any attempt to overthrow the legitimate government in Burundi, saying it would impose sanctions on any regime that takes power by force in the troubled central African country.

The warning was issued Thursday, after an urgent meeting of ambassadors of the member-states of the OAU Central Organ on Conflict Management, summoned earlier by the OAU secretary-general.

The meeting considered the latest "extremely dangerous and highly explosive" situation in Burundi, where the president was on Wednesday reported to have taken refuge at the residence of the United States ambassador in Bujumbura.

"Any attempt to overthrow the legitimate government of President Sylvestre Ntibantuganya and to take over power through illegal means will not be accepted by Africa and will be strongly condemned and opposed by the OAU," a statement issued by the Central Organ said. 

It urged African countries and the international community "to prepare themselves to isolate completely any regime taking over in Burundi by force or any other pretext."

In such an event, it added, African states and the international community should be prepared to impose sanctions against the regime.

The statement was read to the press by OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim.

Salim said a meeting of the leaders of the the central African region would meet soon to decide on how to tackle the latest development in Burundi.

He said former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere was undertaking "urgent consultations" with the leaders of the countries in the area on the date and " widest possible attendance" of the summit.

The summit will consider, among others things, the "the speedy implementation" of the decisions of the recent Arusha summit particularly on the provisions of "security assistance to Burundi."

In this regard, the organ said "the provision of such security to Burundi is needed now more than ever before."

It added that since the assistance had earlier been requested by the Burundi government, the alternative option would be a multinational force for humanitarian intervention, as recommended by the United Nations.

Salim said the regional summit will send "a clear and loud message of the intentions, firmness and cohesion of the countries in the area to all parties in Burundi about the situation in the their country and peace prospects.

"Everything humanly possible has been done to avert tragedy in Burundi, but the political actors in the country refused to see reason," he said.

Now, he added, the regional summit has to devise a means of containing the dangerous situation in order to save lives and create the necessary conditions for sanity to prevail.

Salim said the issue was not how many troops regional countries can provide for deployment in Burundi, but rather the necessary finance and logistics "on security assistance to Burundi.

He said troops can be provided by Tanzania, Ethiopia and others, but would not elaborate.

Asked to comment on the accusation of treason against Ntibantuganya by the opposition UPRONA party, when the president sought refuge in the residence of the U.S. ambassador in Bujumbura Wednesday, Salim said this was "highly irresponsible."

He said the president's party too can accuse UPRONA of high treason and of fomenting and creating tension that could degenerate into chaos in Burundi.

Ntibantuganya, a Hutu, took refuge in the residence of the U.S. envoy after his helicopter was pelted with stones when he tried to attend the funeral of 340 persons (Tutsis) massacred at a camp for displaced persons over the weekend.

"Even at this last hour the forces of sanity and reason could prevail in Burundi to avert further bloodshed and tragedy," Salim said.

In another development, the OAU chief immediately left for Abuja, to attend a peace conference of West African leaders on Liberia, opening in the Nigerian capital Friday.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Southern Africa;
SADC Signs Agreement On Refugees


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Southern African Development Community Executive Secretary, Kaire Mbuende, today signed an agreement with the Assistant High Commissioner for Refugess, Sergio Vieira de Melio, that will formalise the working relations betweeen the two organisations.

The agreement seeks to address the problems of refugees and forced population movements within and outside the SADC region.

The agreement is also aimed at addressing the social, economic and political issues in the region which result in forced population displacement. 

Refugee protection and provision of humanitarian assistance at national and regional levels in order to create sustainable capacity to provide protection to refugees are some of the highlights of the agreement.

The agreement also seeks to promote accession to international instruments relating to refugees and encourage SADC countries to amend their national legislation affectiong refugees.

According to UNHCR statistics the total number of refugees in Southern Africa has reduced from two million to about 300,000 following recent completion of repatriation of Mozambican refugees from neighbouring countries to their homes.

Dr Mbuende and Mr De Mello agreed to mount training for government, NGOs and other organisations on refugee migratory issues and to monitor and respond to the challenges of refugees and migratory movements in the region.

Meanwhile Dr Mbuende says the implementation of the Berlin initiative would broaden cooperation between SADC countries and the European Union.

Dr Mbuende said in his brief to German foreign minister Dr Klaus Kinkel that information was vital to ensure protocals were implemented.

He said SADC and the European Union were conducting seminars on regional integration and ways of combating illicit drug trafficking.

The Berlin initiative would also look at small and medium scale enterprises and SADC programmes on water and energy resources development and the clearance of landmines in Angola and Mozambique.

Dr Mbuende said the newly created sadc organ for politics, defence and security was intended to uphold democracy, peace and stability in the region.

He said the organ would work closely with the OAU and other international organisations to promote preventive diplomacy and a culture of human rights observance.

Germany and other EU countries could come in and assist in investment, human resource and development of information infrastructure and technology.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


299 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Algeria;
Press Freedom Groups Call for Algerian's Release


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

New York - The following is a joint communique from the Committee to Protect Journalists (New York) and Reporters Without Borders (Paris) issued July 26, 1996:

Two international organizations that defend press freedom, the New York- based Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) and Paris-based Reporters Without Borders (RSF), today demanded the release of Chawki Amari, a cartoonist with the independent Algerian daily La Tribune, and called on the government to end legal proceedings against two of his colleagues from the paper.

The trial of Amari, Kheireddine Ameyar, La Tribune's publisher, and Baya Gacemi, the editor in chief, will begin on Monday, July 29. Amari was arrested at his home in Algiers on the morning of July 4. He is charged with desecrating a national emblem for drawing a cartoon, published on July 2, which depicted the Algerian flag in a satiric manner. If convicted of this offense, Amari could be sentenced to up to ten years in prison. On July 10, an examining magistrate denied Amari's request for bail. He is being held at Serkadji prison. 

On July 3, La Tribune's offices were sealed and Ameyar and Gacemi were placed under judicial supervision and ordered to appear before the court twice a week.

Publishers of independent newspapers in Algeria yesterday denounced the detention of Amari and the suspension of La Tribune and called for an end to press censorship. Algerian journalists, who for three years have been the targets of an assassination campaign by extremists, held a one-day strike on July 15 to demand Amari's release and the reopening of La Tribune.

CPJ and RSF consider the imprisonment of Amari and the suspension of La Tribune to be grave violations of press freedom. And we believe that government censorship, which forces the press to print government propaganda as news, jeopardizes journalists who face a constant threat of assassination by terrorists.

CPJ and RSF join our Algerian colleagues in calling on the government of Algeria to demonstrate its commitment to freedom of the press by: -- immediately releasing Chawki Amari -- ending legal proceedings against Kheireddine Ameyar and Baya Gacemi -- lifting the suspension of La Tribune -- and ending government press censorship

For information, contact: Avner Gidron (212) 465-1004, x105


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Boxer Gets To 2nd Round!


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Atlanta - Zambia's flyweight boxer Boniface Mukuka on Tuesday pumped up Zambia's hopes for a boxing medal when he beat Mohamad Zbir of Morocco.

Mukuka, who joins bantamweight Dennis Zimba in the second round of the boxing preliminaries, outpointed Zbir 11-4 during the bout.

Evidently inspired by Zimba, Mukuka looked sharp and crisp throughout the three rounds, using his jab with perfection. His style set the crowd and the reporters abuzz with excitement. 

Due to the apparent lack of coordination, Mukuka's next opponent in the 51 kg division was not immediately known.

The other Zambian yet to fight, Davy Mwale, a silver medalist at the All African Games held in Zimbabwe last September, was expected to step into the ring yesterday while Zimba fights in the second round on Friday.

As Olympic competition entered its fourth day on Tuesday, flyweight Eric Morel became the first US boxer to lose - to Cuban Maiko Romero - and also the first to embrace the great Olympic tradition of cashing in as quickly as possible.

He was courted by several boxing agents who wanted him to turn professional. He agreed to sign some million-dollar contracts.

In the medals watch, Penny Heyns of South Africa and Danyon Loader of New Zealand both became double gold medalists. Loader added the 400 freestyle to his win in the 200 freestyle on Saturday night. And Heyns won the 200 breaststroke after taking the 100 breaststroke Sunday night.

The host nation, United States, also recorded history on Tuesday night.

The U.S.'s all-teen women gymnasts won the team gold medal for the first time in Olympic history.

The victory increased the number of medals won by the United States to 24 with Russia in the second place with 16 medals. South Africa, the only African country on the medals list has three medals, all coming in swimming.

As the tension builds up to the start of track and field events on Friday, Africa's biggest hope for double medals, Frankie Fredericks of Namibia announced that he will run both the 100 meters and 200 meters races.

After planning to skip the Olympic 100 meters to focus on the 200, the Namibian has run so fast this year - the two best 100 times in the world - that he reluctantly decided to enter both sprints.

Fredericks, second in both events at the '92 Olympics, began the year figuring his best chance for a medal was in the 200. Then he ran the second- and third-fastest (9.86 and 9.87) times ever in the 100.

"I've run better 100s this year than I've run 200s," said Fredericks, who begins the 100m on Friday. "So I think it would be stupid for me to run just the 200."

Zambia and Commonwealth 400 meter-hurdles champion Samuel Matete, meanwhile, has been picked by 14 US newspapers and magazines as the favourite in the 400 hurdles.

The newspapers and magazines, including Sports Illustrated, picked Matete over American champion Bryan Bronson and Derrick Adkins for the event whose preliminaries begin on Monday. Matete is expected in Atlanta over the weekend.

And in an interesting debut, Americans and former number one tennis players in the world, Monica Seles and Andre Agassi won their Olympic debuts.

Seles, who was born in Yugoslavia but became a US citizen in 1994, beat Li Chen of China 6-0, 6-4. Agassi had a more difficult time, losing his serve twice in the first set before rallying to edge Swede Jonas Bjorkman 7-6 (8-6), 7-6 (7-5).


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 25, 1996


Zambia;
Women's Lobby Teleconference With US Experts


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala and Sam Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Organisations wishing to sponsor women in politics should identify and focus attention on a small number if their objectives are to succeed, American experts advised.

Charlene Drew Jarvis and Emmily Walter of the Women Campaign Fund in Washington yesterday advised the Women's Lobby and other groups not to take on many women if they want to assist them to political office.

Answering questions on the "Women as candidates" during a Worldnet Dialogue between Lusaka and Washington at the American Centre, Jarvis and Walter said women should exploit the areas where they are credible. 

"It is important that women involve themselves in things where they are credible and can do better," Jarvis advised. "These areas could be used to champion the cause of the women."

Zambia Civic Education Association's lawyer Christine Kunda and Zambia Democratic Congress vice-president, Susan Jere, the panelists in Lusaka, lamented the problems faced by women in climbing to political office.

Jere said women could only be at par with men in politics if affirmative action is introduced, a suggestion she said government had thrown out.

Walters said women had good chances to be elected to political office because they were generally regarded as honest people who do not get involved in scandals and other vices.

And local government deputy minister Wendy Membe yesterday revealed that government was preparing an advancement of women strategic plan to the year 2000.

Officiating at the subregional meeting of the African Regional Co- ordinating Committee for the Integration of Women in Development at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre, Membe said government would give equal opportunities to every one.

"The government attaches great importance to the meeting in view of that fact that we are going to the general elections," Membe said. "We are going to give equal opportunities to very one regardless of gender."

Africa News


July 25, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Tight Cup Schedules Worry Soccer Body


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) is worried that Zambia's tight programme involving both the Africa Cup and World Cup qualifiers will have a terrible effect in getting foreign-based professional players.

Association general secretary, Julio Chiluba, in an interview after a press brief on Tuesday, observed that it will prove difficult to get most players from their clubs. 

"We will surely have some problems in getting some foreign-based players because our games are too tight. We have some Africa Cup matches closer to World Cup games, in such situations, you cannot rule out difficulties," said Chiluba.

On October 6, Zambia plays Mozambique in an Africa Cup qualifying match at Lusaka's Independence Stadium before taking on Congo in a World Cup Group C tie on November 10, in an away match.

The team returns to action on January 12 with aWorld Cup match against South Africa, before playing neighbouring Malawi two weeks later in Lilongwe in an Africa Cup of Nations qualifier.

"The FAZ executive committee will meet with the coaching staff to see how we can solve the problem, it's an urgent issue that needs a lot of attention," Chiluba assured.

Elijah Litana, the Saudi Arabian-based star defender has in the past proved difficult to get as his club rarely allows him freedom to move an inch outside the oil-rich Kingdom. Zambia's other outside-based players include celebrated skipper, Kalusha Bwalya playing his club football in Mexico, his brother Joel playing in Belgium, and Jonstone Bwalya who features in Switzerland.

Africa News


July 25, 1996


Zambia;
Parties Compromise On Talks and Leaders


BYLINE: Sipo Kapumba, The Post of Zambia (lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Ruling MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata, has given conditional approval of the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) president Dean Mung'omba's willingness to compromise over chairmanship of the inter-party talks.

Sata, in an interview yesterday, said Mung'omba's statement was "very welcome" but he should formalise it in writing that his party had accepted President Chiluba as chairman. 

"Dean should write that he will accept President Chiluba as chairman," Sata said. "Each party should write to indicate that they are willing to accept the President to chair the talks."

Sata said other parties should emulate Mung'omba who had shown maturity in the matter.

"This is a good development, I think we are getting somewhere," Sata said. " Mung'omba's stand can only come from a mature politician."

Sata insisted that only the President Chiluba could give the opposition the answers they needed.

"At the moment we are in the saddle and we have the answers and not a neutral chairman," Sata said.

Mung'omba in an interview on Tuesday said parties should be flexible in their approach to the talks to ensure progress.

"It is in the best interests of the country for us to run away from rigid positions," Mung'omba said. "If the chairmanship is a rigid position it should be considered from both our side and that of the ruling party."

And victory ministries leader, Pastor Nevers Mumba, said in an interview yesterday that he was making his own efforts to get the government and opposition to a round table but it was too soon to elaborate.

"The church is trying to get both the opposition and government to relax the conditions they are placing on each other before they seat," Mumba said in an interview yesterday.

July 25, 1996


Egypt and Zambia;
Egypt Appeals For Peace In Zambia


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Egyptian ambassador to Zambia Khaled Osman has appealed for peace in Zambia during the run-up to the presidential and general elections.

Ambassador Osman made the appeal in an interview at his residence in Lusaka yesterday, during a reception to commemorate the 44th anniversary of the Egyptian Revolution. 

"We hope Zambia will pass through the elections in peace because we as Egypt stand for development of the whole Africa," Ambassador Osman said.

And ambassador Osman in his speech said Egypt had adopted a programme to assist in decolonisation of Africa soon after the revolution in 1952.

Ambassador Osman said Egypt was enjoying warm relations with Zambia which he said were evidenced through existing programmes of technical cooperation.

"The cooperation between Zambia and Egypt is the bridge of solidarity between the two countries," Ambassador Osman said. "Last year mutual trade increased though not to a satisfactory level."

Speaking at the same function, mines minister Keli Walubita, said Egypt and Zambia enjoyed cordial relations in many fields of technical cooperation.

"The government cherishes Egyptian assistance to Zambia especially in the field of agriculture and education," Walubita said.

Ambassador Osman refused to comment on his government's view on the prevailing political climate in the country.

The reception was also attended by many other ambassadors and high commissioners accredited to Zambia.

Leaders of the main opposition parties did not attend the occasion though ambassador Osman said they had been invited to attend.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 25, 1996


Zambia;
China Can't Fill Zambian Aid Gap


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - The Chinese Embassy in Lusaka yesterday said China cannot fill the aid gap left by the Western donors and it would be wrong for anyone to imply otherwise.

According to counsellor of the embassy, Chen Zhanfu, China has been giving aid to Zambia for many years but it is nowhere near the levels donated by the Western governments mainly Britain and the United States.

"China as a developing country also needs investment badly from other nations and that is why we are developing an open policy towards other countries," counsellor Chen Zhanfu said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday. " The little aid we give to Zambia has become even smaller because China has adjusted its foreign aid policy to include private enterprise." 

Counsellor Chen Zhanfu revealed that the Chinese government would now like to encourage private businesses to link up with other companies in the developing countries as a way of fostering development.

"The $18 million which was given to Mulungushi Textiles last month as a soft loan springs from an agreement between Zambia and China to rescue the mills which were built through Chinese aid in 1984," counsellor Chen Zhanfu said. "The $3.5 million dollars grant aid is for a project to be decided on between the two governments."

Counsellor Chen Zhanfu pointed out that altogether, the $21.5 per cent Chinese aid given this year falls far short of the almost $700 million in Western aid which Zambia formerly received.

"Therefore it is impossible that we can cover this gap,"counsellor Chen Zhanfu said.

The Mulungushi Textiles aid programme will be carried out with the help of Chindo Textiles in China's Shandong Province.

But Zambia Democratic Congress deputy secretary general, Azwell Banda, criticised statements made by the Chinese government that there were no political strings attached to the aid saying this was a fallacy.

However, counsellor Chen Zhanfu insisted that the aid was based purely on project lines.

"We are not interested in balance of payments support since we only have capacity for project aid," counsellor Chen Zhanfu said.

Banda said he regretted the impression created by the state media that China was ready to fill the USA and UK aid gap.

"The way the granting of this aid was reported was very bad as it was blown out of all proportion making it appear as though it was manna to fill the gaps left by the Western countries," Banda said.

And chief government spokesman, information minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, concurred with counsellor Chen Zhanfu.

"Zambia recognises the Chinese government's aid conditions and is grateful for the support," Mwanamwambwa said in an interview yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Nigeria;
Television Program To Air On Nigerian Human Rights


BYLINE: Globalvision


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

New York - Globalvision's "Rights & Wrongs" this month is airing a special report on the human rights crisis in Nigeria, an issue that has received scant coverage in the American media.

The first week's program, hosted by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, examines the sanctions debate, reporting on a lobbying war between human rights groups and Nigeria's military rulers. The program identifies Al Lehn, former Senator Bob Dole's National Security Advisor, as a key lobbyist for the Nigerian military junta. It also features the first American broadcast of the last television interview with Nigerian environmental activist and writer Ken Saro-Wiwa who was hung by the military authorities after a trial that human rights groups denounced as a farce.

The program offers the background on the current crisis featuring reports on, and interviews with, key players including: Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, Hafsat Abiola, the daughter of Nigeria's imprisoned Presidential election victor Moshood Abiola, Innocent Chukwume, an official with Nigeria's Civil Liberties Organization,South Africa's Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and US human rights activists Randall Robinson of TransAfrica, Gay McDougall of the Int'l Human Rights Law Group, Kakuna Kerina of the Committee to Protect Journalists, Gerald LeMelle of Amnesty International and Mike Fleshman of the Africa Fund.

Rights & Wrongs shows videos provided by Witness and others produced for the Nigerian Embassy in the United States and the Shell Oil Company. Shell Oil met with Rights & Wrongs but refused to allow its executives to go on camera. Nigeria's strong man General Abacha did not respond to interview requests.

For more information, visit Globalvision's internet site at www. globalvision.org/globalvision/ . Contact Danny Schechter e-mail rights@globalvision.org.

307 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Ethiopia;
EPRDF pledges to go ahead with food self-sufficiency plan


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front(EPRDF) yesterday called on the nation to coordinate efforts to realise self- sufficiency in food through the implementation of the five-year development programme.

In a statement the general council of the front issued at the end of its second general meeting held on July 21, the council said the implementation of agricultural extension programme nation-wide over the past year has resulted in commendable increase in production.

The EPRDF vowed to do all it can to realise its plan to increase production ten-fold this production year, the statement said. 

Capacity building efforts both at the central and regional levels are under way for the successful implementation of the extension package in particular and the programme as a whole, it said adding that important achievements have been made in this regard.

Tangible measures have been taken through concerted effort of the central and regional governments to build capacities of leaders who could play a key role in expediting rural development at zonal and woreda levels, the statement added.

It added that capacity building training will continue with much vigour to maintain what has been gained so far.

The statement said regional governments have also realised the importance of an made efforts to involve the people and regional development associations in the implementation of the extension package. "In this regard, roads, dams and soil and water conservation works carried out in the different regions are clear testimonies." it added.

Regional development and aid organizations have made a promising start in raising funds from both local and foreign sources for the alleviation of social and economic problems in the regions, the statement said.

Due attention would be given to translating into practice the mechanisms employed to enhance public involvement in development activities besides promoting the role of associations in all the regions beginning next year, it said.

The central government in line with the top priority it gave to the expansion of infrastructures has secured over 1.1 billion dollars in loans and aid to asphalt the highways, the statement said.

Development and expansion of infrastructure would help facilitate the improvement of the living conditions of the people besides creating favourable conditions for investors interested to involve in the industrial and agricultural sectors.

The council expressed readiness to promote encouraging, favourable conditions in regions next year to enhance participation of investors in regional states.

The council meeting devoted to assessing its performance throughout the year in the political and economic spheres noted in its statement that it has extended various supports to political parties and administrations where the front has no organized existence by forging relations on the basis of mutual respect and cooperation.

The EPRDF general council commended activities carried out in implementing the programme as satisfactory but underlined the need for serious measures to curb the corruption and embezzlement witnessed at various levels of government structures.

It called on the Ethiopian peoples to staunchly fight against all forms of corruption so as to pave the way for prosperity and sustainable development.

The front vowed to exploit all resources at its disposal to implementing the five-year development plan and urged the public at large to carry on with vigour its involvement in development activities to achieve its goals.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Ethiopia;
President appoints constitutional inquiry council


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - President Negasso Gidada yesterday appointed six members of the constitutional Inquiry council at the National Palace.

Dr. Fasil Nahom, Ato Amare Amogne, Ato Getahun Kassa, Ato Ahmedin Ibrahin, Woizero Sinidu Alemu and Ato Beyene Bulti were the officials appointed as members of the constitutional Inquiry Council. 

The council members nominated by the House of Peoples' Representatives were presented to President Negasso by House Speaker Dawit Yohannes.

Speaking on the occasion, Dr. Negasso said he appointed the constitutional inquirers in accordance with the constitutional right vested in him and that the appointment is the first of its kind in the history of Ethiopia.

President Negasso urged the appointees to live upto their expectations entrusted to them.

The Council of constitutional Inquiry in line with the provisions in Article 84 of the constitution examines claims submitted to it by a court or a party to a dispute relating to the contravention of the constitution by federal or state laws and submit its findings to the Federal Council for a final decision.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Weekly African Press Review


BYLINE: Dan Sibongo, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Burundi's continued slide into anarchy was again a focus of the African media this week.

They warned that the tiny, yet highly volatile, central African state, where a coup took place Thursday, was at the tether and could soon plunge into massive ethnic violence -- the kind that hit neighboring Rwanda in 1994.

Burundi's former Tutsi President Pierre Buyoya was proclaimed the new head of state Thursday by the Tutsi-dominated army, replacing Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu.

Ntibantunganya, 40, had been President since September 1994. He was jeered and pelted with stones by some Tutsi earlier Tuesday while at the burial of over 300 Tutsi civilians killed in the Gitega massacre. He later fled to the U.S. ambassador's residence in Bujumbura where he and his wife sought refuge. 

A return to order was, however, still possible -- if Africa took decisive action on Burundi, said the African media.

"Day after day, Africa's image emblazons the television screens across the globe. Sadly, it is an image of the dead and the dying.

"Lately, the continent's visage is epitomised by the genocide in Burundi, where the Hutu and Tutsi mutilate each other in an orgy of deep-rooted hatred comparable only to that in neighboring Rwanda," the government-owned Times of Zambia said.

"Even before the shame of meaningless mayhem in Rwanda that left a barren country populated more by the sight of death than life is over, another case of mass extermination brews in neighboring Burundi," it said.

Yet Africa's response to the crisis in Burundi has been fickle, the paper added. And unless this changed, hopes for any peace would be lost.

It said the Organization of African Unity's plans for an on-the-spot assessment of the crisis this weekend was a step in the right direction.

The decision to dispatch the mission was reached by the Central Organ of the OAU Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution at a meeting in Arusha, Tanzania, June 25.

Burundi's neighboring states at the summit decided to send in a regional force to restore order and help set the ground for peace.

The Times said it hoped the force, vehemently opposed by radical quarters in the Tutsi minority, would be deployed soon.

"History has shown how little effect words alone have on factions resigned to eliminating each other," the Times said.

"Floundering over Burundi will reflect the desperate inadequacies Africa is said to host, that cause it to fail to come to terms with its own existence."

The Ugandan press was near unanimous in urging global support for former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere's efforts to bring peace to the central African state.

"At times it seems Nyerere is fighting a hopeless battle," the state-owned New Vision said in an editorial. It was however essential that the entire international community, especially Burundi's neighbors, threw their lot behind Nyerere's peace initiative.

"The alternative is too horrible to contemplate," the paper said in an editorial.

It said the massacre of some 300 Tutsi in the Gitega region last week showed Burundi's ethnic extremism had reached unprecedented heights.

The New Vision said it was clear the killings had been carried out by Hutus of the National Council for the Defence of Democracy.

It said the killings were in the cycle of violence that has hit the central African states.

"Last year they (Tutsi-dominated army) backed the ethnic (Hutu) cleansing of the Bujumbura suburbs. For the last month Tutsi militias have been undergoing military training in Bujumbura. Backed by ex-president Bagaza, they are demanding incorporation into the army," it said.

"In a chilling echo of the genocide in Rwanda, they are arming themselves with clubs stubbed with nails. Gradually the scale of killings and massacres on both sides have escalated... Burundi is poised on the brink of the precipice."

The New Vision added: "The extremists on both sides have taken over Burundi and are preparing to fight to the death."

The paper said there was, however, still hope for peace. "It is not too late to build bridges because there are still moderate Tutsi and Hutus who would prefer accommodation and compromise to all-out war."

It urged Burundi's neighbors to honor plans for a force to restore order to the troubled country.

But in Dakar, Senegal, the state-owned Le Soleiel said Burundi had stumbled beyond the edge, and a return to order was now unlikely.

"The scenario for a terrible tragedy has been completed and an explosion can hit at any time," the daily said.

It said order had broken down with the flight of president Ntibantunganya into the American ambassador's residence.

Another troubled spot which attracted the media is Liberia.

As leaders of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) begin a summit Friday in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, they are expected to discuss how Liberia can return to the path of peace after more than six years of factional fighting.

In response to the desperate humanitarian situation in that nation, West African leaders took the initiative of dispatching a peace-keeping force in 1990.

"But more than six years and 35 different agreements later, the situation is yet to normalise," the semi-official Daily Times, published in Lagos, said.

Initially, the problem had to do with the fact that members of ECOWAS were working at cross-purposes with some actively sabotaging the peace process through their collaboration with one or more of the faction leaders.

"While the situation now appears to have changed," the paper noted, "peace still eludes Liberia precisely because the various warlords find that, curiously, war can be a profitable venture".

Following the recent upsurge of fighting in Monrovia, the paper welcomed the suggestion that ECOMOG, the sub-regional force, be empowered to assume a more robust posture (more soldiers, plus amoured personnel carriers and helicopter gunships) so that it will be in a position to overwhelm any or all the warlords put together.

"This is what is happening in the former Yugoslavia where, 60,000 heavily armed troops are poised to take on any party in the Balkan conflict which chooses to take on the peacemakers".

Sadly, however, the Daily Times pointed out that the economies of the countries reeling under the weight of sundry problems, cannot support such an expensive venture.

It expressed the hope that at their summit, the leaders will once again renew their appeal to the international community, particularly the United States and the European Union, to provide ECOMOG with all the logistics it sorely needs to be able to carry out the task.

The summit, the paper stressed, must make it clear to the warlords that patience is running out and they must shape up. "It must be declared to them in no uncertain terms that should they continue to prove to be obstacles to peace, they will have only themselves to blame."

Africa News


July 26, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Nigeria In Olympic Quarter-Final Despite Defeat


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MIAMI, United States (PANA) - Nigeria Friday advanced to the quarter-finals of the centennial Olympiad soccer event despite losing 0-1 to world champions Brazil in the last game of the "Group D" preliminaries in Miami, United States.

Though Brazil, Nigeria and Japan (which beat Hungary 3-2 the same day) all ended up with six points each, Nigeria sailed through on goal difference.

Nigeria will meet Mexico in Birmingham in a quarter-final match on Sunday while Brazil takes on Africa's other surviving team, Ghana, in Miami. Mexico and Ghana advanced from group "C". 

Other quarter-finalists are Argentina, France, Portugal, and Spain.

Until the outcome of the Japan-Hungary was known, Nigeria was not sure if it was heading home or to Birmingham.

Ronaldinho had put Nigeria's qualification in doubt with a 30th-minute goal, scored even as he complained of an infraction.

The goal was the crowning of a relentless onslaught by the Brazilians, which forced Nigeria's goalkeeper Joseph Dosu to make a series of incredible saves to ensure a respectable scoreline for his side.

Five minutes before Ronaldinho's goal, Dosu pulled up three of his best saves as the Nigerian defence line wilted under pressure.

The Nigerian "dream team" came into the match in the second half after coach Jo Bonfrere made substitutions to give more bite to its attack.

The team squandered its best chance to tie the game in the 73rd, when Daniel Amokachi got a quick pass from Tijani Babangida at close range. Instead of ramming the ball home, he ran into Brazilian Goalie Dida.

Speaking after the match, Bonfrere said he was satisfied with his team's play and the outcome of the match. He said the loss might very well be a wake- up call for his players.

Brazilian coach Mario Zagallo told reporters he was impressed with the level of play of the Nigerian "dream team" and Africa's other representative, Ghana.

Zagallo said it would be tough for his players if they had to meet Nigeria again in the semi-final.

The overwhelming majority of the 56,000 people who watched the match cheered Brazil.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Southern Africa;
Lack Of Information Undermining Comesa Trade


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)--The intra-regional trade among members of the Common Market for East and Southern Africa (Comesa) is being hampered by lack of adequate information on trade prospects, an official of the International Trade Centre said in Lusaka Friday.

Speaking at a one-day Comesa business promotion seminar, Jason Spencer- Cooke said that because of insufficient information Comesa states imported some 16 billion US dollars-worth of goods annually from outside the region, while only one billion dollars worth of business was generated from trade within the region.

Spencer-Cooke, who is an advisor at the Geneva-based ITC, said this was as " a result of lack of information on the availability of goods in the region and importation requirements by individual countries within Comesa." 

The seminar, attended by Zambian entrepreneurs, is the first in a series planned by Comesa for members of national chambers of commerce in all the member-states of Comesa.

Spencer-Cooke said that the Comesa sub-region and Africa as a whole needed to seize the present economic "enabling environment" to break onto the world market or risk lagging behind and continue to be marginalized in international trade.

Quoting expert estimates, he said Africa could record a three-billion dollars trade deficit by early the next century despite the preferential access to world markets being accorded to the continent and other developing regions under the Lome conventions.

"The (trade) opportunities are there and these projections could be proved wrong provided businessmen on the continent took up the challenge and effectively compete for the world market by providing the needed goods," he said.

Comesa Secretary-General Bingu wa Mutharika, who officially opened the seminar, also challenged entrepreneurs in Comesa to be innovative and ensure quality products, so as to make an impact on both the local and international markets.

The Lusaka-based Comesa secretariat operates a computerized trade information network (Tinet) to assist member-states identify markets and products within the region as a way of helping to boost intra-regional trade.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Campaign for Resumption of Ivory Trade Gathers Support


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe, which next year hosts the convention on international trade in endangered species, is attracting support for its campaign to be allowed to resume trade in ivory.

The chairman of the Zimbabwe National Conservation Trust, Boyman Mancama, said Friday that if the elephant population continued to grow it would not only endanger the elephants themselves, but would also be a danger to the environment in which they lived. 

He urged non-governmental organizations to support the Zimbabwe government in its fight for the resumption of trade in ivory.

The trade was stopped in 1989 following the listing of elephants in Appendix I of CITES, which banned all trade in ivory and elephant skins.

Zimbabwe and a few other Southern African countries want elephants removed from Appendix I to Appendix II, which allows regulated trade in ivory.

Zimbabwe has a growing population of elephants of about 65,000, some 35,000 more than the recommended carrying capacity of its wildlife areas.

Mancama said Zimbabwe's wildlife management policy has been acclaimed to be among the best.

It was this excellent management effort that had given rise to the vast elephant population growth, he said.

"Normally good managers get rewarded for their achievements, not punished as is now the case," he said.

It is expected that Zimbabwe will use the meeting of the 1997 CITES in Harare to campaign for the resumption of ivory exports.

Western environmentalists fear that a proposal to downgrade elephants could lead to massive slaughter by poachers.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


313 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Liberia;
Mozambique Condemns Coup In Burundi ;
Call For Sanctions Against Liberian Warlords


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - A ministerial meeting of the Economic Community of West African states (ECOWAS) opened here amidst suggestions that heavy sanctions be imposed on Liberia's warlords.

The meeting, of a nine-nation ECOWAS committee on Liberia, is being held ahead of the summit of heads of state and government of the community, which begins Friday in the Nigerian federal capital. In his opening speech, Executive Secretary of ECOWAS Edouard Benjamin urged the ministers to consider "obtaining the support of the United Nations Security Council for the adoption of a resolution imposing heavy sanctions on the (Liberian) faction leaders." 

A similar proposal was made by African leaders at the summit of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), held in Yaounde, Cameroon early this month.

"The sanctions should cover the creation of an international tribunal before which they (faction leaders) can be summoned to answer for their crimes, should they persist in spreading terror and desolation in their country," Benjamin said.

Benjamin said ECOWAS members and the international community were becoming frustrated by the seemingly endless Liberian peace negotiations.

He said although peace had returned to Monrovia, the Liberian capital, it was anybody's guess how long "this lull" would last because all the factions are reluctant to observe a total ceasefire.

"They are all being circumspect and their distrust of one another is such that hostilities could break out at any moment," he warned.

Benjamin called for the beefing up of the ECOWAS peace keeping force, ECOMOG, "by increasing its numbers, strengthening its logistics and providing it with adequate funds."

The peace force sent to Liberia in August 1990, is estimated to be 10,500 troops-strong, with Nigeria's contingent accounting for about 75 percent.

The chairman of the ministerial committee, Ghana's Foreign Minister Obed Asamoah also spoke in support of sanctions against the Liberian faction leaders.

He said this could include freezing of the assests of the warlords in member states, expulsion of members of their families and their collaborators from members states and requesting the United Nations Security Council to impose visa restrictions on them.

Ghana, the current chairman of the 16-nation economic community, has hosted several meetings on the Liberian peace process.

Asamoah said despite the frustration being felt by the international community, ECOWAS should not abandon Liberia.

He called for the review of the Abuja accord, saying it was "running behind schedule."

The review, Asamoah said, should take into account plans for election to be agreed by ECOWAS, the Liberian Council of State, the OAU, the U.N. and other international organizations.

"Elections (should) be targeted to take place by the end of 1996 or soon thereafter, after which an end point would be set to end ECOMOG's involvement in Liberia," he said.

Addressing the committee earlier, Nigeria's Foreign Minister, Tom Ikimi spoke of the need to review the time-table of the Abuja peace plan on Liberia.

He rejected calls for election before disarmament.

The nine-nation committee is made up of Ghana, Benin, Togo, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia, Senegal and Nigeria.

-O-

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 26, 1996


Burundi;
South Africa Denies Recognition To New Burundi Regime


BYLINE: Adamu Lawal Toro, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa announced Friday it would not recognise the new government of Burundi led by former military ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, who was installed by the army as interim president in Bujumbura Thursday.

"The South African government strongly condemns the increasing senseless violence in Burundi and wishes to make it clear that it will under no circumstances recognise any change of government in that country brought about through force," foreign minister Alfred Nzo said of the new development in the tiny central African country. 

Burundi's former president, Sylvester Ntibatunganya, a Hutu, was forced to flee into the United States embassy compound in Bujumbura on Wednesday after he was stoned by angry Tutsis, as he arrived for the mass funeral of over 300 people massacred by suspected Hutu rebels.

Nzo said the South African government supports the efforts of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to deploy a peackeeping force in the country.

Thursday's coup was also condemned by the OAU Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim.

He said the continental body would not recognise the new leader who was defeated in the 1993 elections that brought an end to the previous military administration in the country.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


315 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Burundi;
Warnings of Double Genocide In Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Burundi woke up under a military administration Friday, headed by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, who initiated that country's pluralistic experiment with the mid- 1993 multiparty parliamentary and presidential elections.

He took over from President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, who has taken refuge in the residence of the American ambassador in Bujumbura.

In a statement Thursday, Burundian Defense Minister Firmin Sinzoyiheba, justified the army's action to "the socio-political disorder in which the country has been plunged, the inability of the country's institutions to deal with this catastrophic situation, the de facto resignation of the President of the Republic."

It also cited the fact that unspeakable acts of genocide and killings almost everywhere in the country "have become commonplace, the inability of political parties to deal with the crisis in a coherent manner, and the proven inefficiency of the government convention." 

Buyoya, a retired Tutsi army officer who lost in the July 1993 polls, has been returned to power by the army, which is dominated by his minority ethnic group.

That army has repulsed attempts by the international community to effectively mediate in the conflict which erupted in Burundi after the Oct. 21, 1993 assassination of the Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye, who defeated Buyoya in July the same year.

Following the advise of OAU after the takeover, South Africa, a major African power, stated Friday that it would not recognise the new Tutsi- dominated military administration in Bujumbura.

The United Nations, the European Community and United States government have also condemned the military takeover in Burundi.

Observers of the Burundi situation believe the military takeover in Bujumbura was a move to pre-empt the intended sending of a regional force to prevent a possible genocide.

However, according to Oxfam, the international community needs to act fast otherwise a double genocide is likely with both the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels committing widespread abuses.

Oxfam called upon western governments to back vigorously the peace plan brokered by the former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere and accepted by the Burundian and regional governments.

It welcomed the Norwegian government's aid of 500,000 U.S dollars to Nyerere's peace initiative and appealed to the British government and other governments to match Norway's forthright action.

However, without strong international involvement, the world might again be compelled to stand by and watch the shadow of Rwanda pass over Burundi.

"Rwanda and Bosnia have tragically shown that only swift decisive action can save lives. How many bodies have to be counted before the world takes action?, said David Bryer, Director of Oxfam.

The charity organization called for urgent actions to stop "the frantic amassing of weapons of all kinds by each group" and stop armed incursions from neighboring states.

It said, however, that Burundi's crisis will not be solved by short term action and will require a comprehensive economic rehabilitation package to alleviate the effects of poverty which have done so much to inflame the crisis.

In spite of these warnings and condemnation, however, swift action from the international community is unlikely due to the lack of interest towards the age-long Burundi ethnic crisis in general.

Even if the Clinton administration had said Wednesday that Howard Wolpe, his special envoy would return to the region over the weekend and offered logistical backing for the proposed regional force, the fait accompli in Bujumbura might be difficult to reverse.

The U.S government, probably due to its past experience in Somalia, has categorically stated its troops would not take part in the proposed security assistance to Burundi.

Reports monitored here quoted an American government spokesman as saying Washington "is not prepared to contribute troops to any kind of UN operation in Burundi."

A State Department spokesman only said "someone in the international system or one group of countries or one country will have to stand up and lead this operation."

He said "there are countries in Africa well placed to do this," adding: "It may also be that there are some European countries who could lead this kind of operation, countries that have an historic influence and role to play in the region."

In 1994, the international community, including the big powers showed similar hesitations to intervene in Rwanda. The result was the massacre of between 500,000 and one million people.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


316 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Busines;
South Africa Takes Its Time Over Free Trade Mandate


BYLINE: Lynda Loxton, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - As the South African government continues to finalise its mandate for negotiations with the European Union on a free trade agreement (FTA), the ramifications of such a deal are becoming more complicated.

African National Congress MP and trade expert Rob Davies told the Mail & Guardian this week that more evidence was emerging of how much South African Customs Union (Sacu) states could be affected if the FTA, as presently envisaged, went ahead.

He said the Namibian Economic Policy Research Unit, for example, was " gravely concerned about the impact of the FTA on revenue in Namibia" after doing an impact study.

"They found that a reduction of a substantial part of tariffs to zero, as distinct from a reduction in tariffs, would be bound to affect the overall revenue pool of customs duties and that Namibia could lose anything up to 15 to 20% of total government revenue if this is not addressed," he said. 

The EU had indicated it was not prepared to provide Namibia or other Sacu states with any compensation for this, but had suggested South Africa should find another way to fill the gap.

"They say that we need to understand that a customs union based on revenue derived from protectionism may not be sustainable in a globalising world," Davies said.

"Perhaps what should happen is that the customs union should base itself on some revenue source other than customs duties."

Just what that alternative could be has been left vague, but value-added tax has been mentioned, which is bound to create an outcry.

"What's true for Namibia is obviously true for the other countries," Davies said.

"Swaziland is now being urged to cut its budget deficit, and for Lesotho the size of the customs revenue is larger than for any other country. This is a highly significant and important issue."

He welcomed the fact that some neighbouring countries had started to identify their own interests, especially since they were all members of the Lome Convention and there was speculation that the FTA was increasingly being seen as a possible model for relations with developing countries when the current Lome agreement expired.

Apart from the loss of customs duty revenue, an FTA-type of arrangement would limit the access of Sacu states to the EU, while at the same time exposing them to competition from highly subsidised EU exports.

Despite growing impatience by the EU, South Africa is insisting on drawing up its negotiating mandate and having it approved by all interested parties, including parliament, before it starts negotiations with the EU. Davies said Trade and Industry Minister Alec Erwin had indicated that negotiations could possibly start in September or October.

'The EU has been complaining that we are taking our time, but I think that for us to go into negotiations without an anchored mandate could be a huge mistake," Davies said.

"They have got an anchored mandate, which has gone through processes and been approved, and points to a clear position for member countries."

Already, some observers have hinted that the EU mandate was the product of a very tight set of compromises in Europe, and South Africa should not imagine it could shift the agreement very far.

"The whole history of EU negotiations is that 90% of the negotiations take place in Europe and only a fraction takes place with the other parties," Davies said.

As a sweetener, EU officials were saying that by anchoring itself to Europe, South Africa would be making its liberalisation programme credible and attractive to investors, no matter what the consequences.

"The extent of the liberalisation that we want to make credible should surely be our choice rather than somebody else's. The point that also needs to be raised is, investment to serve what market?"

The investments could serve the domestic, regional or European markets. An FTA of the kind envisaged by the EU would impose huge adjustments on companies presently serving the domestic and regional markets and this, in turn, would inhibit investors from entering South Africa. Any comparative advantage that South African firms had would be wiped out.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


317 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
SA Developers Under Fire For Slow Housing Delivery


BYLINE: Tebello Radebe, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - Private developers look set to be next in line for criticism over slow housing delivery. So far, the government and the banks have borne the brunt of most of the attacks.

A report by the Centre for Policy Studies (CPS), the focus of a housing workshop in Johannesburg next week, recommends that the government policy shift away from "developer-driven" housing delivery towards a more "people- centred housing delivery process".

The study, conducted by senior research consultant Mary Tomlinson, contradicts many beliefs held by state policy-makers and others by stating:

l Contrary to popular opinion, people are dissatisfied, not because they do not get the conventional "four-roomed" house; rather they feel they are not able to obtain maximum value for their R15 000 state subsidies. 

l Given a choice, people would have preferred to have purchased their own building materials with, say, a housing voucher, to build.

l Developers have failed to "negotiate proper" social compacts with communities, contradicting the general view that negotiations have been held up by talks with "unrepresentative leaders".

Among the most startling findings of the study is that most beneficiaries have never heard of "social compacts" -- a key requirement of the government housing subsidy scheme designed to ensure community participation in housing projects.

"Therefore problems do not lie with a needless insistence on involving beneficiaries in decisions, but with a failure to follow this approach vigorously enough," says the study.

Mpumalanga Provincial Housing Board chairman Saths Moodley told the Mail & Guardian that if four of the top developers awarded the bulk of the housing projects in the province had been on target, "we could be showing a higher delivery rate". Mpumalanga leads all the other provinces with the fastest delivery.

One of the developers, the New Housing Company (Newco) had to deliver more than 8 000 houses and has managed only 2 204 to date. Significantly, 1 906 of these houses fall within the R15 000 subsidy limit and therefore go to people who cannot afford housing credit.

Deon Sutherland, Newco director responsible for Mpumalanga, admitted that the rate of delivery has been slow, but "was confident that his company will be able to deliver more houses now".

Sutherland warned that delivery delays pushed up costs owing to materials and interest hikes on holding costs. He estimated interest on holding costs for Newco Mpumalanga at about R1,8-million a year. Material costs were rising at the rate of one percentage point a month and electricals at 16% annually.

These hikes are ultimately paid by the beneficiary; otherwise, the overall value of what can be built for the R15 000 subsidy is reduced, he said.

Sutherland pointed out that the social compact concept served a useful purpose during the apartheid era -- to ensure housing delivery was not a top- down process and that it was legitimate.

Many social compact processes now delay delivery because some people use them as platforms to pursue other agendas, he charged.

Social compacts need change from being dominated by "community representatives" to being forums for the beneficiaries. He said the recently elected local authorities served the roles of community representatives adequately.

Mawela said: "Social compacts do not work well in all areas. There are also administrative problems such as delays in conveyancing and deeds registration, as well as the different prices developers have to pay to obtain land, which influence the ultimate product that can be delivered and also at which time."

Mawela was emphatic that private developers were essential to the housing process. "Just imagine what would happen if people just took money from the government to do their own thing. How would you ensure that the money really gets used for housing?"


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


318 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Business;
'Clothing Industry In Tatters' in South Africa


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Johannesburg - In the next five years, the effect of strikes in the clothing industry will be minimal as the clothing sector will have collapsed. South Africa will be forced to embrace imports, argues Econometrix economist Tony Twine.

Twine says the economy, while in a transitional phase, will not benefit from a strike in the already declining sector. However, neither will management or workers benefit from such a strike, he says. Twine cites the example of the motor industry strike two years ago. Workers' demand for a wage increase was met by employers after nearly six weeks of striking, but workers were then forced to waive any claims for further increases for the next two years, until production caught up again. 

Twine adds that while there is sympathy for industries that are declining owing to holes in the customs net, the move towards lowering import tariffs will benefit the economy in future.

But Peter Cragg, executive director of the Cape Clothing Manufacturers' Association, an employers' body, says the industry can "definitely be saved" by, among other things, developing competitive goods for niche markets and containing input costs.

Twine's view, he says, is clinical and certainly not a model of encouragement for manufacturers.

The strike, argues Cragg, is about containing input costs. "This is not just the union asking for a marginal increase, it's about a total cost perspective, which means consumers will feel the pinch and they are the ones who will ultimately decide the industry's future."

Jabu Ncgobo, general secretary of the South African Clothing and Textile Workers Union (Sactwu), says he is aware of problems in the industry, but meeting workers' demands for a 10% increase will not bring it to its knees. " It is going downhill owing to a number of factors, including the lowering of tariffs and the skipping of customs and import duties. Our demands will not cause the industry to collapse any further."

The strike by Sactwu has allowed employers to exercise their right to lock- out and has generated support among employers for "selective and partial" lock-out action, intended to bring pressure on strikers, while not prejudicing workers who refuse to support the strike.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


319 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Business;
SA Communists Pressure Government Over Investment


BYLINE: Lynda Loxton, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Johannesburg - A leading member of the South African Communist Party has called on the government to take tough action to stop the "investment strike" by the private sector.

African National Congress MP and SACP central executive committee member Philip Dexter told the Mail & Guardian that business seemed intent on pitting members of the ANC-SACP-Cosatu alliance against each other in a bid to break it so that it could play a dominant role in shaping economic policy.

Dexter said this was "extremely irresponsible and unpatriotic". It was sending a message to foreign investors that "we are not a nation of winners, but people who can't agree on anything". 

He believes a crunch point is coming. Domestic and foreign capital are not investing "and if they do they are investing in a manner that is short-term, speculative, get-your-money-out-quickly".

For this reason, the SACP remains opposed to the lifting of remaining exchange controls because it could lead to capital flight.

SACP criticism of the government's commitment to the gradual easing of exchange controls has led to speculation that the alliance is in danger of splitting, but Dexter denied this, adding that criticism and debate were healthy and normal in the alliance.

"I think the policy framework is a response to the kind of squeeze that the government is feeling at the moment. It was the best response in that it was the least worst choice. It is an attempt to keep sovereignty within our country and not undermine the agenda of the ANC-led alliance.

"But, if we are honest, there are contradictions and those need to be resolved. There's going to be a bust-up and there is going to have to be some kind of showdown between business, labour and government.

"It requires the government being tough, saying to the unions, right, we agree that your wages are low and we are prepared to make a commitment, but you have got to make a commitment to productivity. Saying to business, if you don't invest in the areas that we identify, then we are going to penalise you, we are going to tax you."

This could harm the economy, but the present lack of investment was equally damaging and "one sometimes has to experience a little bit of pain to get better ... we have got to keep on reminding ourselves that this is not a normal economy, this is not a normal country and business in this country is not normal. It basically looks after the interests of a tiny white minority and until we break out of that and until we transform...we are going to have to go the hard route."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


320 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Business;
SA Unions and Government At Odds Over Economy


BYLINE: Madeleine Wackernagel, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - The government was this week keen to distance itself from the growing row over the Congress of South African Trade Unions' criticism of its growth and development strategy.

"We are not going to get embroiled in a debate through the media," said a representative for the Ministry of Finance.

But Finance Minister Trevor Manuel earlier reiterated that the parameters of the macro-economic framework "were not negotiable", giving rise to speculation that the government was headed for a showdown with the unions and a consequent break-up of the ANC-SACP-Cosatu alliance. 

Such claims were quickly denied by insiders. "It was naive of Manuel to think

he could get away with it without some sort of response from labour," said one. "Now the unions have had time to consider the strategy, they are airing their concerns, rightly. But there is room for debate -- indeed, it is healthy and necessary. People are over-reacting."

Jeremy Cronin of the South African Communist Party concurred: "Within the alliance there is very strong support for ongoing debate on macro-economic policy. Manuel has not said he is ditching the reconstruction and development programme in favour of self-inflicted structural adjustment, so the alliance is not at risk. There is no major policy rift, just debate.

"Our concerns lie with the excessive fiscal constraints in the government's strategy; a policy of low inflation and high interest rates will squash growth. In addition, it is overly dependent on private-sector investment; we would like a greater public sector role with backing from the market.

'But the strategy has to be flexible, situations change constantly. Already, the Budget deficit is at 5,9% of gross domestic product, against a target of 4% for 1996-97. So one can't take a rigid approach. The reality is more fluid.

"This is not a silly argument about nationalisation versus privatisation or fiscal restraint versus lassitude, but we are concerned that alternative models were not considered. There is no easy populist alternative; we understand the constraints. But equally, we need to steer a middle path."

Cosatu's Sam Shilowa echoed these concerns, but saved his most vehement criticism for the market. "We are in danger ... of relinquishing our national sovereignty in the sphere of economic decision-making and sacrificing it on the altar of profits."

The problem for the markets was not that Cosatu criticised the growth strategy -- "they would, wouldn't they" was the general assessment -- but that the government should not cave in.

"As long as the government stays firm and sticks to this course, investors will not be put off," says Dennis Dykes, chief economist of Nedcor. "We've had very strong statements from the government in the past few months on policy, signalling its commitment, so people know where they stand. It's uncertainty that puts investors off."

The logical forum for ongoing debate on economic issues is the National Economic Development and Labour Council. The government is due to present its plan next month, with a report-back from the three constituencies scheduled for February 1997.

But while Manuel is certain to stick to his guns on the parameters of the plan, the details are up for negotiation, leaving plenty of room for confrontation and controversy, says an insider.

Cosatu may dig in its heels, although national strikes are not expected. " At the end of the day, we'll deal with this in a typical South African way, and thrash it out until we eventually reach an understanding."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
