Africa News


July 26, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
No Gold Medal For South African Broadcasting Corporation


BYLINE: Justin Pearce, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Johannesburg - The South African Broadcasting Corporation will not reveal how much it spent on sending 87 staffers to cover the Olympic Games in Atlanta -- amid accusations the quality of the coverage barely justifies sending an SABC team at all.

The SABC's efforts have been roundly lambasted by sports journalists in South Africa. Chief among the criticisms is that SABC journalists attempt to comment on sports for which they are not qualified, while on the other hand the SABC switches over to foreign network commentary at moments when a homegrown South African perspective would be most valuable. 

For example, the SABC relied on New Zealand's Channel Seven network to interview double gold medallist Penny Heyns. After the interview, Heyns was asked if there was anyone she would like to thank, and she thanked her family and friends back home. The interviewer added "how about a thank you for Channel Seven", which Heyns conceded, whereupon viewers were taken back to the Topsport studio where anchor Nick Collis remarked bitterly: "How about a big thank you to the Topsport team too?"

South Africa's hockey match against Malaysia and South African boxer Victor Kunene's fight against Czech Pavol Polakovic were covered by Australian commentators.

At other times, TV viewers have had to contend with South African commentators referring to boxers simply as "the red one" and "the blue one", dropping such gems as "the crowd comes from all over the world", or attempting to comment on lesser-known sports such as judo and showing themselves to be embarrassingly ill-informed about the finer points of the sport.

This was in addition to the minor glitches such as screening times in the small hours being changed at short notice, and footage of swimming appearing over the commentary on the South Africa-Australia hockey match.

Mail & Guardian sports editor Christian Stephen said the SABC broadcast team was guilty of "ill-prepared and inaccurate comments on sports they don't understand".

Sunday Times sports editor Cherylin Ireton agreed: "Some of the commentators didn't have the vaguest clue."

South African Sports Illustrated editor Matthew Pearce described the quality of the coverage as "shocking".

The 87-strong team sent to the games breaks down into 48 from Topsport, 15 Airtime staff, 11 from Television News and 12 from SABC Radio. The radio crew comprises two co-ordinators, two news staffers, one technician and nine commentators who among them handle all 11 official languages. In addition to the team of 87 were the commentators for Radio Metro and 5fm who received commercial sponsorship.

SABC liaison officer Marj Murray said she did not think the team was excessive given the task they had to perform. She said presenters had been chosen for their ability to do on-camera presentations, their competence at voice-overs on edited inserts, their aptitude for research, and their ability to do their own make-up for on-camera presentations.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
SA Post Office Banks On Future In Rural Areas


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Johannesburg - The Post Office, the institution which once symbolised bureaucratic incompetence, could be converted into a rural bank which will stimulate a thriving small-farm economy in the countryside.

The lack of banking services in the platteland -- along with soaring levels of rural crime -- is fast becoming a major block to the government's land reform programme, according to a commission set up to look into financial services in the countryside.

The department of Land Affairs last year started a pilot land redistribution programme as the first phase of an ambitious policy aiming to redistribute 30% of all arable land before the turn of the century -- and to ensure that the new owners use it productively.

But banks have been withdrawing from small rural towns at a rapid rate over the last few years and organisations involved in pilot schemes around the country say the lack of rural credit and basic banking services for a new class of black farmers is fast becoming a major obstacle to effective land reform. 

But now the commission established to investigate the ways in which efficient financial services can be supplied to rural areas has come up with the novel idea: the Post Office can be used to remedy the problem by providing basic banking services to small rural businesses.

"Commercial banks have a low level of outreach and service provision especially in poor rural areas, where people have to travel long distances to major towns for banking facilities," says a report of the commission released last month.

"The transformation of the Post Office is potentially far-reaching. An expanded branch network will provide a vehicle for improved financial services to rural areas, in addition to its responsibility of providing a communication network and postal services ... Consideration should also be given to using post office savings accounts as a basis for providing emergency credit to poor people."

The report notes that very little of rural peoples' already meagre savings are retained in the rural areas of South Africa and are therefore not available to be invested in low-cost technologies, tools, livestock and other items needed for farms to grow. South Africa has the lowest savings rate among developing nations.

Another problem is the high level of rural crime. The report notes that small mobile banks or cash pay-out companies which use armoured cars to travel from one town to another have been targeted by organised gangs. The result is that the cash vans, often shadowed by a helicopter, race into town and leave immediately after dispensing their payments. No extra banking services can be offered as a result of this way of operating.

"Many small businesses in rural areas periodically need relatively small amounts of money for operating capital and other purposes. At present the fact that a family member is a pensioner may qualify them for some short-term loans, for example, access to a pension permits a credit line for tractor hire in some rural areas," the report says.

"If the Post Office were to allow savings to qualify for leverage of short- term loans, this could be innovative in extending the modest lines of credit which people need ... The parastatal Post Office system offers the developmental state a very real possibility of using the available national infrastructural base to great advantage, helping to normalise rural life, after the disruption of forced removals."

The commissioner's team -- chaired by Helena Dolny, wife of former Housing Minister Joe Slovo -- suggests a task group be set up to investigate a range of proposals about how the Post Office can be transformed effectively into a rural development agency.

The report also recommends the Land Bank be restructured so that its current bias in favour of existing commercial farms be shifted into a support role for land-reform programmes and the financial needs of emerging black farmers.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa's First Legal Marijuana Farm


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa's first legal dagga plot -- an experimental project near Rustenburg in the North West province -- has just completed pioneering research which could provide farmers with a lucrative new cash crop.

The Tobacco and Cotton Research Institute (TCRI) recently produced a report on a two-year research project aimed at developing a biological model for industrial hemp. This plant cannot be used as a drug but will have massive value as an industrial crop.

Paul Cohen, coordinator of the programme, says his firm, the Southern African Hemp Company (SAHC), received permission from the Department of Health two years ago to import five strains of hemp from the Netherlands in order to test their adaptability to South African conditions. The research project was jointly conducted by SAHC and the TCRI. 

The first phase of the work has now been completed and the organisation is consulting with the Land and Agricultural Policy Centre in Johannesburg as well as the government's land and health ministries about the prospect of moving into a more extensive development phase.

"This is a very serious project that could allow South Africa to develop an industry based on a genetic resource that is well adapted to South African conditions."

Adds LAPC director David Cooper: "This is valuable research which shows the many constructive uses that cannabis may have. If more research around its potential is developed this could have possible advantages for new emerging farmers who could easily grow it as a viable cash crop."

The plant could also be used by established commercial farmers to supplement existing activities. Countries all over the world are now using hemp to provide raw materials for thriving paper, clothing and building- material industries. The seeds of these plants are also capable of producing highly nutritional oils.

SAHC has completed a report on the potential for using strains of the type tested near Rustenburg for a range of industries in South Africa. The most useful applications for the local strains are in the pulp, paper, textile, food and construction industries.

Hemp fibres are used to make good-quality paper and building materials used in roofing insulation and construction boards.

The strains under examination at ARC have a content of about 0,4% of tetra hydra cannabaloid (THC) while the powerful dagga plants used as a drug have a THC content of 6% to 10%.

The great advantage of the plant is that it is well- suited to South Africa's climatic conditions and does not require heavy use of pesticides and fertilisers -- chemicals that have caused serious ecological damage in commercial farming regions of South Africa.

"If we can develop the non-intoxicating plant for industrial use here it would be a valuable example of how renewable plant resources can be used to promote development in a sustainable way," says Cohen.

The LAPC now plans to send results of the Rustenburg study to Land and Agriculture Minister Derek Hanekom so that various state agencies can begin discussing policy about the prospect of allowing a legitimate hemp industry in South Africa.

Some agricultural economists argue that dagga is already one of the country's biggest cash crops -- rivalling the sugar industry in terms of the amount of money it turns over annually and an activity that funnels money into poor households -- and that it would be easy for small farmers to switch to non- toxic and legal variants.

Cooper says one of the major problems to be addressed before any moves to legalise some strains of hemp is the possibility that non-toxic strains will be used as a cover for growing the real thing on rural farms.

However, with an effective regulatory system, hemp could become one of South Africa's most innovative ways of using the land.

Hemp strains are the basis of legal industries in China, India, England, France, Italy, Spain, Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, the Czech Republic, and numerous other states.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


342 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
Workers And Boers Create Fruitful Synergy


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Johannesburg - The Lomati Valley, a fertile piece of subtropical bushveld that lies in the shadow of the Lebombo Mountains in Mpumalanga, has produced some of the hardiest of South Africa's pioneer farmers: men who moved into the malaria-ridden area on the Mozambican border in the 1930s and, with DDT pesticides to protect them, turned the land into some of the continent's most productive real estate.

That is why Piet de Wet, a tough entrepreneur who made his fortune as a beef baron in the Free State, came to the valley early this year. The self- made millionaire decided at retirement age that, instead of hanging up his khaki shorts and velskoene, he would break just one more piece of new ground.

Only Inala Farms's pioneering men and women are very different, if not exactly opposite, to the kind of white men who came into the valley 60 years ago, took the land and used exploitative methods -- harsh even by South African standards at the time - -- to fill the valley with lush groves of mangoes, pawpaws, pineapples, bananas, tomatoes and endless rows of sugar cane. 

This is because Inala is a place where the farmworkers -- about 580 men and women who were issued eviction orders just eight months ago -- now own a majority share in a commercial estate worth more than R24-million and fast becoming the most productive real estate in a corner of the country where farmers are already renowned for producing subtropical fruits of the highest export quality.

It is a place where De Wet and his managers, a clan of khaki-clad boers and a former minister from the old KaNgwane government, have decided to stick by the new owners and make the farm dispel the legend that land reform in South Africa will inevitably result in rural decay.

And in the process these men have acquired a new zest for cultivating the land they love. "Land reform will only work if there is a successful marriage between the aspirations of the landless and the motives of private enterprise with a conscience. Development has to be intertwined with real hard- core business for it to work," explains De Wet.

"A farm, you see, is not like a mine. You have a never-ending cycle of replacement, a responsibility to channel profit and resources back into nourishing its main resources which are the land, the water and its people. When you do this the land talks to you. It says: 'You are gonna have to look after me otherwise I'm just going to leave you.' "

Just two months after De Wet was appointed as Inala's chief executive officer, he has used this philosophy to turn the farms into a sub-tropical paradise where you can walk among the trees and pluck pawpaws and mangoes for lunch or visit the plantation where local police arrived two months ago to verify that a bunch of Dwarf Cavendish bananas weighed 77kg and could be entered in the Guinness Book of Records as one of the heaviest ever harvested in the world.

New fields have been planted and export contracts are rolling in. Already performance is outstripping a business plan aimed at making a profit of R5- million by the end of next year. The company is already so buoyant that Inala plans to open an offshore company with Reserve Bank approval on Jersey Island that will be 40% owned by the farmworkers, to handle its international marketing and foreign-exchange earnings.

It is estimated that within 10 years Inala will be making a pre-tax profit of R30-million per annum. Already minimum wages have risen by some 250%. And there is, literally, a gold mine on the farm that may be worked in the near future by an association of small miners.

Eight months ago the future of the Inala Farms looked very different. The old owners, a legendary pioneer family in the Lomati Valley called the Schoemans, ran up so many debts that the banks forced the farms into liquidation. A group of sugar- cane farmers from KwaZulu-Natal called the Crookes put in an offer for R16-million, but said they would only buy if the farm was cleaned of its workforce.

The liquidators promptly issued eviction notices and, in November last year, the workers began singing struggle songs and doing the toyi toyi at the entrance to the farm. When the Crooke brothers arrived to inspect the estate, one of them was assaulted.

"You know the amazing thing is three of the old white managers stood with us at the protests," says Albert Sibiya, chairman of the workers' committee that represents the new shareholders.

"They didn't really toyi toyi but one of them, Danie Basson (who belonged to the army's special forces), had just been bitten on the foot by a snake. He had a drip with medicine and was just waving this about to show his protest. I think it was a sign that they really love this place."

The workers threatened to burn the farm from one corner to the other if the sale went ahead and the Mpumalanga government was forced to intervene. Premier Mathew Phosa contacted Land Minister Derek Hanekom who asked the Land and Agricultural Policy Centre (LAPC) to visit the area and come up with a solution.

The LAPC, in turn, sent an enterprising consultant called Simon Forster to do a feasibility study on the idea that the workers could use household grants to buy the farm. Forster structured a package that involved each of the 600-odd farmhands putting each of their R15 000 grants into a R9-million kitty, and a consortium of private investors forking out another R7-million to buy the farms -- which were promptly given the name Inala by the workers, an isiSwati word that means "Place of Great Harvest."

"Conditions were appalling at the time," says Forster. "Some workers were earning R5 a day. There was no running water two of the three compounds and some of the children had kwashiorkor. There was no day-care centre for the babies so mothers had to wrap them up and take them into the fields during working hours. Some workers tell me that some of them died after being bitten by snakes in the cane fields."

Forster ran the farm -- along with its remaining managers -- for a few weeks after it changed hands. He promptly took one of the old farm manager's houses and turned it into a day-care and community centre where milk is served for the babies. He put potable water into the compound and he built showers and toilets near the packing shed for men and women who had been forced for as long as they could remember to relieve themselves in the fields.

"The estate was like a multi-engined aeroplane firing on all cylinders, but all out of sequence," says De Wet. "It just needed someone to come in and tune and fly off with its people on board. I said to the workers when I got here, 'Look I can't do it without you. You could probably do it without me. But just maybe we can all do it better together.' And I can tell you it's a real trip now."

What is it that drives people like De Wet to pioneer these new ways of using the land and South Africa? "My motivations are two," he says.

"The one is that I don't have any problems with making money. The other is that it just gives me a thrill. You could say I have always supported the aim of our new government to improve the lives of these people. But I am not doing this for politics because there are only two organisations I really belong to -- the Dutch Reformed Church and the (nearby) Malelane Country Club. "

De Wet, who is fond of saying that the softest thing about him is his teeth, runs the farm with a rod of iron.

"I kick arse when I have to and I tell the workers that if anything moves, you salute it. If it doesn't move, you paint it or keep it spotlessly clean."

Is this the kind of thing the workers had in mind when they decided to buy into the farm? It is as though the question never even crossed Albert Sibiya's mind. "We need him to be like that. If he wasn't the farm would go bankrupt and we would all lose."

Down at the new community centre, the workers are now practising songs that are different to the ones they sang whenever the liquidators came to the farm last year. A local schoolteacher has been asked to compose a hymn that tells the story of this unique farm and a choir is practising nkosi Sikelele for the day when President Nelson Mandela comes to witness the way things are being done at Inala.

And in the evening, the white managers sometimes gather at their club on the banks of the Lomati River to have a braai and sing uncouth songs about rugby and women.

At an event like this the farm manager, Johan Minnaar, explained why he was so dedicated to the experiment. "It is because we want to turn history on its head," he said.

Forster, the mastermind of these strange happenings down in the Lomati Valley, adds: "The experiment has already dismissed the popular notion that land reform simply involves giving marginal land to poor rural people so that they can simply have a secure place to stay.

"Inala is an example of how innovative ways of doing things can even produce more benefits than were originally intended by land reform policy makers to benefit people who have always worked the land."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
Amnesty Hurdle Cleared by SA Court


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian Reporters, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Johannesburg - The Constitutional Court this week cleared a hurdle which barred potential amnesty applicants from confessing their crimes.

The court on Thursday shot down a bid by families of leading apartheid victims to have sections of the National Unity and Reconciliation Act -- which robs victims of their right to civil and criminal redress against human rights violators -- declared unconstitutional. 

The court held that the provisions in the Act honoured the Constitution, which stresses the need for the truth to emerge and for as wide as possible an amnesty to be granted.

Lawyers representing several of those seeking amnesty said earlier their clients were waiting for the judgment before making applications to the truth commission.

The judgment also clears the way for the commission's amnesty committee to make known its first round of findings.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


South Africa;
Silence Undermines Truth Body


BYLINE: Stefaans BrUmmer, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Johannesburg - The Truth and Reconciliation Commission has been left in the lurch by those it needs most to solve the mysteries of the past -- human rights abusers -- and attorneys general are being blamed for their failure to show up.

The commission this week said while about 1 800 people have applied for amnesty, 1 650 of them are prisoners -- known cases where convicts argue their crimes had a political dimension. Of the about 150 who are not prisoners, it appears no more than a few dozen involve "fresh" cases where no prosecutions have been instituted. Less than five months remain before the amnesty applications deadline of December 15. 

Figures across the spectrum, from human rights lawyers and individual truth commission officials to representatives of the "old guard", this week said the main reason perpetrators have failed to come forward is uneasiness that the possibility of self-exposure at the commission may damage their chances in courts of law.

Since the commission's "proportionality test" may well mean those guilty of more serious crimes will not get amnesty in spite of confessions, many are staying put, taking a gamble on not being caught.

Some argue KwaZulu-Natal Attorney General Tim McNally's indictment last week of Dirk Coetzee and security police colleagues -- in spite of Coetzee and two of his co-accused having lodged amnesty applications -- has increased perpetrators' uneasiness about the truth process.

Human rights lawyer Brian Currin, who counts a number of perpetrators among his clients, said this week: "This has become a major problem. I have even advised some people not to apply."

Currin said while the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act ruled out the courts using confessions before the truth commission's amnesty committee as evidence, confessions may well alert attorneys general to the culprits in unsolved cases, who may then prosecute on the strength of their own investigations.

Dumisa Ntsebeza, acting commission chair while Archbishop Desmond Tutu was abroad this week, said the commission was not overly concerned about the low turn-out, as it was hoped there would be a change nearer to the December deadline. "I don't think it is (a crisis) for the commission, but it is a crisis for the perpetrators. You know what human beings are like. There is the problem of a bottle neck, as we anticipate a mad rush closer to the cut- off date."

Ntsebeza, who also heads the commission's investigative unit, said the commission and the attorneys general shared the desire for the pursuit of the truth, but that the different end result of both processes -- criminal justice seeking prosecution, and the commission encouraging amnesty applications to harness reconciliation -- caused "tension".

He said the attorneys general have co-operated with the commission on many levels, but that there was no full agreement on which classes of investigations they should hand over to the commission. Though the commission had taken no decision yet, it would not "waive any rights" allowed it by the Act to subpoena witnesses, including attorneys general, to supply information.

Ntsebeza pointed to two instances of potential conflict with Jan D'Oliveira, Transvaal attorney general. D'Oliveira has made no secret that he regards the tentative approach to the commission by 22 former and serving security force operatives last month as an apparent attempt by some of them to pre- empt intended prosecutions -- and that he still wants to prosecute in the more serious cases.

But Ntsebeza said: "We have asked for all the relevant information. (That means D'Oliveira) will not be able to prosecute in the medium term, but for us it is the wider picture ... A complete picture can only emerge if we have as much information as possible."

He also said the commission wanted to subpoena Joe Mamasela, the former Vlakplaas operative both McNally and D'Oliveira want to use as a state witness in exchange for indemnity. Said Ntsebeza: "We have said we are not going to waive any of our rights, and we have in fact briefed legal counsel for an in camera hearing (with Mamasela)."

Some attorneys general are known to be reluctant to hand over cases and witnesses as they believe their prosecutions -- especially serious cases where amnesty may not be given by the commission -- will be prejudiced irrevocably if they are first exposed to the quasi-judicial procedures of the amnesty committee.

McNally confirmed he had met other attorneys general in Pretoria this week. He would not say what the talks were about -- apart from discussion over media criticism of his handling of the Coetzee case. It is likely the talks included aspects surrounding the need for a co-ordinated approach where criminal prosecutions may have an impact on the workings of the commission.

It has been argued that the threat of prosecution is the "big stick" which will supplement the "carrot" of the commission's amnesty offer in getting human rights perpetrators to confess.

Ironically, Currin -- and Coetzee's lawyer, Julian Knight -- found themselves in bed this week with former police commissioner General Johan van der Merwe and the Foundation for Equality before the Law in attacking the approach of the attorneys general. The foundation, which has among its members top names from the apartheid security establishment, was established after McNally started his prosecution of former defence minister Magnus Malan.

While no one argued prosecutions should not be instituted against those who failed to apply for amnesty or failed to make full confessions, they agreed the "selective" prosecutions at the moment created uncertainty.

Said Currin: "The attorneys general -- certainly McNally -- have been acting in an unpredictable way ... What we need is legislation that all (political) prosecutions are suspended pending the (finalisation of the) commission."

Van der Merwe said: "You take a big risk if you ask for amnesty now, and then you are charged. After that you can hardly excercise your normal rights in terms of the Criminal Procedure Act ... to exercise (your) right of silence, or to plead not guilty, or to wait and see the evidence."

Knight said: "What the attorneys general are doing in deciding to selectively prosecute people is having the effect of putting people off from coming forward -- which is protecting the master puppeteers of the old regime from detection."

He pointed out that security force operatives applying for amnesty forfeited their chance of qualifying for state legal support should the matter go to court -- as with Coetzee -- since only those who maintained their innocence qualified under treasury regulations.

McNally this week said he looked at matters "from the other side" to that of the commission. "Is there anything to stop prosecutions where people have applied for amnesty or intend to ask?"

He said the Malan trial was not relevant to the amnesty debate, as the accused have maintained their innocence. In the Coetzee case, he has also not had any notification that the accused want a trial postponement pending their amnesty hearings.

McNally said the attorneys general had met the commission -- and he was due to meet it again soon -- to discuss areas where their interests overlap.

D'Oliveira was not available for comment.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Nigeria;
TV Program Airs Special On Nigerian Rights Crisis


BYLINE: Globalvision


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

New York - Globalvision's "Rights & Wrongs" this month is airing a special report on the human rights crisis in Nigeria, an issue that has received scant coverage in the American media.

The first week's program, hosted by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, examines the sanctions debate, reporting on a lobbying war between human rights groups and Nigeria's military rulers. The program identifies Al Lehn, former Senator Bob Dole's National Security Advisor, as a key lobbyist for the Nigerian military junta. It also features the first American broadcast of the last television interview with Nigerian environmental activist and writer Ken Saro-Wiwa who was hung by the military authorities after a trial that human rights groups denounced as a farce.

The program offers the background on the current crisis featuring reports on, and interviews with, key players including: Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, Hafsat Abiola, the daughter of Nigeria's imprisoned Presidential election victor Moshood Abiola, Innocent Chukwume, an official with Nigeria's Civil Liberties Organization, South Africa's Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and US human rights activists Randall Robinson of TransAfrica, Gay McDougall of the International Human Rights Law Group, Kakuna Kerina of the Committee to Protect Journalists, Gerald LeMelle of Amnesty International and Mike Fleshman of the Africa Fund.

Rights & Wrongs shows videos provided by Witness and others produced for the Nigerian Embassy in the United States and the Shell Oil Company. Shell Oil met with Rights & Wrongs but refused to allow its executives to go on camera. Nigeria's strong man General Abacha did not respond to interview requests.

For more information, visit Globalvision's internet site at www. globalvision.org/globalvision/ . Contact Danny Schechter e-mail rights@globalvision.org.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

346 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia May Renew National Coach's Contract


BYLINE: Celani Shongwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Government has indicated that it will renew national team coach, Roald Poulsen's contract when it expires in October this year.

Permanent secretary in the Ministry of Sports, Arthur Yoyo, yesterday said Poulsen's endeavor to improve the standard of football in the country has been appreciated by any self respecting citizen of the country. 

In an interview at his office, Yoyo said when the coach's contract expires they would renegotiate with their Danish counterparts with a view of maintaining the coach.

He said Poulsen would forge ahead to prepare the country for the forthcoming international competitions including the World Cup and the Africa Nation's Cup.

"When the time comes to review his permit, the government of Zambia will decide appropriately in consultation with the Danish Government how best Poulsen's programme of preparing the National Soccer team for the World and Africa Cup qualifying games would be accomplished," Yoyo said.

He said Poulsen's contractual agreement in the country is between the Zambian Government and the Danish Government.

"Therefore all contractual agreement of that nature are handled at that level and not at ministerial level," Yoyo said.

Contacted for comments , Poulsen said the Government has not yet pronnounced anything to him and as such could not commit himself.

"I would be in a position to comment as soon as I get a correspondence from my employers," Poulsen said.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


347 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Winning Streak Continues


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Atlanta - Zambia continued its quest for medals in boxing following an impressive win by Davis Mwale who decisioned Steven Kevi of Papua New Guinea on Wednesday.

Fighting in the Light Welterweight division, Mwale beat Kevi 16-3 on points as the Summer Olympics entered its fifth day of competition.

With the victory, Mwale joins Bornface Mukuka and Dennis Zimba who have qualified to the second round.

While it is too early to start counting the medals, Mwale's outright victory over Kevi has caught the eyes of American journalists and agents who were not impressive with African boxers, especially when most of them lost on Saturday when the boxing competition started. 

Several agents called this journalist to find out whether any of the Zambian boxers were interested in turning professional. Queries were referred to the Zambian officials accompanying the boxers.

But for Mwale, Mukuka and Zimba, their minds must be focused on their second round bouts, especially Zimba who is scheduled to fight today.

And today marks the beginning of the much awaited track and field events. For Zambia, the hopes for track and field medals are in the running shoes of Ngozi Mwanamwambwa, Samuel Matete, Clinton Bufuku, Charles Mulinga, Godfrey Siamusiye and Frank Nkandu.

Mwanamwambwa, the first Zambian track and field athlete to test the track, faces an onerous task in the 200 and 400 metre races. Although a proud holder of several collegiate titles in the United States, Ngozi is up against the best of the women sprinters in the world.

In the 200 meters, she faces Merlene Ottey of Jamaica, Irina Privalova of Russia, Carlette Guidry of United States and Juliet Cuthbert of Jamaica. All these women have run the 200 meters race in less than 22 seconds. Mwanamwambwa's best time ever is slightly above 22 seconds.

Even in the 400 meters, Mwanamwambwa is up against those that have run faster than her time, including France's Marie-Jose Perec whose 48.83 is as good as any of the men.

In men's steepchase, where Siamusiye will be competing, the race has been deemed the Kenyan Olympics. Siamusiye, who is the current US college champion in 10,000 meters, admits he has to summon extra speed and endurance to even qualify to the semifinals of the competition.

In this "pick your favourite Kenyan," race 3-time world champ Moses Kiptanui is still the man. The World Record holder figures to lead his compatriot, Matthew Birir and Joseph Keter to at least their third consecutive 1-2 finish and maybe a repeat sweep.

Charles Mulinga, who has won several international races in the 5,000 metres is also in the race favoured to be won by either Ethiopians or Kenyans. Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia is the top pick while Kenyans

Paul Bitok, Tom Nyariki and Shem Kororia are also top contenders. The race also features two Moroccans who have ran faster that Mulinga's time.

Bufuku who competes in the 200 meters has nothing but miracles to perform in this race that is dominated by Americans and Namibian Frankie Fredericks.

And so the best hope for a medal among Zambians is with former world and current commonwealth champion in 400 metre hurdles, Samuel Matete.

Matete, whose 47.10 time set at Zurich in 1991 is the best among those competing at this year's Olympics, is the favourite. He is so popular that he has to avoid the media before his race to concentrate.

Mindful of the fact that the Olympic medal is the only championship he has not won, Matete should also keep in mind the incident at the 92 Games when he was disqualified for allegedly stepping on the line.

" I will do my talking on the track," Matete said before he left for Atlanta.

Matete's strongest rivals are Americans Derrick Adkins and Bryan Bronson who have forged a great rivalry the last few years. Matete ranked No. 1 in '94, Adkins took over last year. So far, Matete has been almost unbeatable, while Adkins has chinks in his armor. U.S. champ Bronson is shy on experience at this level.

Since Zambia's only medal at the Olympics was achieved by the late Keith Mwila here in the United States at the 1984 Games, maybe luck will hold that Zambia's first Gold Medal will be won in the United States.

And talking about medals, United States continued its relentless mining of Olympic silverware by increasing their tally to 28 medals against Russia's 23 medals. Russia, however, has an edge winning eleven Gold medals to U.S. 10 Gold medals. Interestingly, at the end of day five of competition, Great Britain has only one medal - a bronze.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Business;
Plans Announced For Zambian Agricultural Show


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - Over K80 million will be spent by the Show Society of Zambia (SSZ) in organising this year's national agricultural and commercial show, disclosed convenor, Ezra Sakala, in an interview.

According to Sakala, this represents almost double what the society spent last year.

"We have spent slightly over K80 million in preparations and we hope to raise more than what we are pumping in," said Sakala, who is also the vice president of the SSZ. 

But Sakala was declined to reveal who the guest of honour will be this year.

"I cannot at this point say who the guest of honour will be," Sakala said. " It's up to State House to tell us who the guest of honour will be. I don't know whether it will be the President or a foreign dignitary."

But a source, who declined to be named, said all the dignitaries who have been invited so far have spurned the invitation.

"All presidents from neighbouring countries have refused to come because of the political situation in the country," the source said. The show has always been opened by presidents of neighbouring countries.

Meanwhile, Sakala has disclosed that there has been a shift on the type of exhibitors at this year's show.

"The dwindling parastatal sector has led to a shift from the large scale to the small and medium scale exhibitor," Sakala said, adding: "I don't know if this is an indication of what is happening to our economy."

He, however, noted that there has been an overwhelming turn-out of exhibitors for this year's show.

"The turn-out is higher than last year," Sakala said. "We are still having companies coming to ask for space. We are expecting exhibitors from Sweden, Russia, the USA, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Kenya."

Sakala further disclosed that despite the brahuha that the mad cow disease has caused in the United Kingdom, the society will be exhibiting British beef.

"We are calling this year 'the year of the British beef' and we will be exhibiting British beef as well as other exotic varieties," Sakala said.

And, according to Sakala, for the first time the livestock section will have on display Ostriches.

"It will be interesting to see what products the Ostrich can offer," Sakala said.

For entertainment, the society has lined up a variety of entertainers, among them the Zambia Army.

"The Zambia Army has been absent from the show for sometime now. This year they will put up silent drills, artillery assembling drills and calisthenics," he said.

A South African motor cycle stuntman, Gathro, has also been invited while a new group of majorettes called the Country Girls will entertain the little ones.

Commercial committee chairman, Dev Babber, said at a press briefing yesterday that all was set and most of the exhibitors have met the deadline for preparing their stands.

"We are satisfied with the preparations so far," Babber said. "We are confident that the quality of stands will be of great satisfaction."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


Zambia;
Party Secretaries Prepare for Talks


BYLINE: Goodson Machone and Sipo Kupumba, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Lusaka - Secretaries of opposition political parties yesterday met at the offices of the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) in Lusaka where they resolved that they all meet on Monday to lay the ground work for the inter-party talks.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy general secretary, Azwell Banda, said in an interview last night that all secretaries present unanimously agreed to meet on Monday as time was running out.

"We are inviting the MMD secretary, Michael Sata, to this meeting so that we can prepare the ground work for the inter-party talks," Banda said. "The sooner we resolve the issue of the Constitution and electoral process, the better because time is running out." 

But Sata, in a telephone interview last night, said opposition secretaries have not communicated with him.

But Banda stressed that "time was running out" and insisted that the talks should be held before the end of the verification of the voters register.

"Time is running out and this was recognised by all secretaries at today's meeting," Banda said. "One hopes Sata will respond positively."

And ZDC president Dean Mung'omba yesterday charged that the MMD was not ready for dialogue with the opposition.

Mung'omba said the MMD's insistence on preconditions before inter-party talks proved it was not ready for dialogue.

Reacting to MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata's insistence that ZDC should write a letter indicating its willingness to accept President Chiluba to chair the talks, Mung'omba said that was taking his "good intentions a bit too far".

"Sata's response is unfair and shows lack of seriousness," Mung'omba said. " I get the impression that it is them and not the opposition who are not interested in meeting." Mung'omba suggested that instead of putting conditions, a preliminary meeting of secretaries could be held where details of how the meeting should proceed could be worked out.

"Preliminary meetings shall have to be held under which we can discuss the management of the meeting which include the agenda," Mung'omba said. "We are not going to narrow our position in the newspapers, such a meeting is where we shall discuss the details."

Mung'omba in an interview on Tuesday said his party was ready to compromise over the chairmanship of the inter-party talks and have President Chiluba chair so as to meet the MMD's demand in the interest of progress.

But Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) chairman Roger Chongwe disagreed with Mung'omba that President Chiluba should chair the meeting.

"No person can be a judge and jury in his own case, we need a neutral chairman," Chongwe said in an interview yesterday.

Chongwe said President Chiluba's decision to assent to the constitution and his refusal to listen to calls for the cancellation of the Nikuv contract showed he was not interested in dialogue.

"Even if we talk to him today what will he do?" Chongwe asked. "He does not want to talk, he is not serious."

The National Democratic Party (NDP) said the initiative of resuming the talks lies with the government and it was up to them to announce the date for talks.

"It would therefore clear a lot of doubts and remove the prevalent atmosphere of uncertainty if the MMD government took the bold step of showing total and unquestionable commitment to the talks by proposing dates for these talks," said NDP national trustee Derrick Sinjela in a statement yesterday.

Sinjela, however, welcomed statements from Sata and Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda expressing readiness to hold inter-party talks.

Meanwhile, ZDC has adopted a retired teacher Munyinda Siyanga, as its candidate for the Mongu Central by-elections.

A statement from ZDC yesterday said Munyinda, a former Regional Examinations officer for Western Province, was selected in March and was now being given the chance to stand.

July 26, 1996


Arts;
Southern African Musicians Set Tour


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's ragamaffin star Daddy Zemus will be touring Southern Africa with Boom Shaka.

Anthony Kafunya popularly known as "Daddy Zemus" told The Post in an interview that he is expected to travel to South Africa to make final arrangements for the tour slated for November. 

"I am expected to link up with them in South Africa before flagging off the tour. We will be touring South Africa, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia," Zemus said.

He revealed that the tour would take about six weeks.

And to get himself tuned to the mood of the tour he will be holding a show at Encore Entertainment Centre in Zambia this week.

"The show is the beginning of my stage campaign before my tour with Boom Shaka. My stage campaign will also be in form of a country-wide tour," Zemus said.

He said that he would use the show to exhibit his new album Juju Lover.

Some of the songs on Juju Lover are: Dance With Me, a remix of Tigwilizane, Anyamata and Don't Give Up.

Zemus will be playing with Jazz in Tune, True For Real, Steve Lox and Street Gong.

Zemus also revealed that he had signed a contract with Bongo Studios to release his new album.

"I have signed a much better contract now unlike the one I had signed earlier on that almost liquidated. I ended up selling all my rights," Zemus bemoaned.

351 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


United States and Africa;
Liberia Contact Group Endorses Abuja Framework for Peace


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Washington DC - The State Department July 25 issued the following statement and communique on the meeting of the 13-member International Contact Group on Liberia, which took place in Washington on July 18:

On July 18, 1996, the International Contact Group on Liberia met in Washington, D.C. The countries comprising the ICGL include Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States.

Representatives from each of these member nations, as well as representatives from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the European Commission, were present at the meeting.

The Group voiced continuing support for the Abuja framework and commended ECOWAS for its active role in the restoration of peace in Monrovia. ICGL members also pledged their continued support for the peace process and discussed several ways in which they could further assist ECOWAS in attaining a sustainable peace in Liberia. 

Attached is the Communique issued at the conclusion of the meeting.

The International Contact Group on Liberia held its third meeting in Washington D.C., July 18, 1996. Representatives from Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States as well as ECOWAS (the Economic Community of West African states), the United Nations, the Organization of African Unity and the European Commission attended.

The meeting heard reports on the situation in Liberia and on preparations for the Economic Community of West African states (ECOWAS) Summit that will convene July 26. The Contact Group expressed appreciation for the roles ECOWAS as well as the U.N. and OAU have taken in the Liberian peace process, commended Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings for his leadership over the past two years and encouraged ECOWAS to remain actively engaged in the process.

The Group voiced support for the Abuja framework and hoped the ECOWAS Summit would determine ways to strengthen its implementation. Members commended the West African peacekeeping force (ECOMOG) for its efforts to restore Monrovia as a civilian safehaven and encouraged ECOMOG to maintain calm in Monrovia and its environs. Members called on Liberian faction leaders to honor the cease-fire and move forward on disarmament and demobilization in order to create a secure environment where electoral activity can take place within a reasonable timeframe and the population is able to express its will freely.

Affirming that the peace process needs the support of the international community, Contact Group members agreed to continue to explore ways they could assist the peace process, including the ECOMOG peacekeepers. Training and equipment assistance as well as possible logistical support for additional troop contributions by ECOWAS member states were discussed. The Group further underscored the importance of donor countries redeeming the pledges made at the United Nations sponsored Conference on Liberia in October 1995.

Members of the Contact Group urged Liberian factional leaders to honor the Abuja framework, respect the decisions of the ECOWAS summit, and cooperate fully with the peacekeeping efforts of ECOMOG as well as the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) and with the humanitarian efforts of the international community and nongovernmental organizations. Continued noncooperation with the ECOWAS peace process and disregard for humanitarian law and human rights could influence the international community to seek measures against the violators.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Ends Aid to Niger Over Election


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Washington DC - State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on July 25 announced a series of measures aimed at expressing U.S. displeasure over the conduct of the recent election in Niger:

The July 21 acceptance by the Nigerien Supreme Court of the results of the recent presidential election in Niger does not change the view of the United States that the electoral process was fraudulent. The regime of General Ibrahim Mainassara Bare seriously compromised the validity of the process by abolishing the independent electoral commission on the second day of voting and replacing it with a national commission controlled by the government, by barring party representatives and independent observers from the vote counting centers on the second day, and by placing the political candidates opposing General Bare under house arrest. The government-appointed electoral commission subsequently announced provisional results showing voter participation and votes for Bare significantly greater on the second day than on the first. As a consequence, we do not believe the announced outcome of the elections is a true reflection of the wishes of the Nigerien people. 

This derailing of the electoral process was particularly regrettable given the compliance with election laws and the strong emphasis on transparency that characterized the 1993 legislative and presidential elections and the 1995 parliamentary elections, which enjoyed the confidence of the Nigerien electorate.

The United States is also deeply concerned by the violations of human rights and repression of civilian freedom conducted by the Bare regime immediately following the dissolution of the independent electoral commission and continuing through the past weekend.

In response to Niger's clear abandonment of democracy, evident in both the military coup earlier this year and the fraudulent election, the United States is:

-- Terminating current bilateral USAID assistance programs to the Government of Niger.

-- Withdrawing and not replacing the Security Assistance Officer in our Embassy in Niamey.

-- Continuing to suspend all military assistance programs.

Just as the U.S. is terminating its current assistance programs to the Government of Niger, we expect other donors are examining their assistance to Niger. If earlier assistance pledges erode significantly, this could regrettably have negative implications for the sustainability of Niger's structural adjustment program with the IMF.

We call upon all interested governments to express their disapproval of the fraudulent elections in Niger and to join with us in taking measures to support the people of Niger by pressing for the return to democracy.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 26, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Issues Welcomes Chad Election But Voices Concern


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Washington DC - The United States government has welcomed the election in Chad but expressed concern over reported irregularities. The following is the text of a statement by Nicholas Burns, State Department spokesman, on July 25. 

The United States congratulates the Chadian people on the maturity and conviction which they demonstrated while voting in Chad's first-ever multiparty presidential election.

We applaud those Chadians who have worked hard to promote a free, fair and transparent election, but we regret the many reports of irregular practices which undermine the credibility of the electoral process. These reports include the banning of meetings, government interference in the electoral process, intimidation of voters and opposition party representatives and manipulation of vote counts. All are contrary to internationally accepted standards for free, fair and transparent elections.

The United States will pay close attention to the upcoming legislative elections, and calls on the Chadian government, political parties and the traditional friends of Chad to work together to ensure a free, fair and transparent election of Chad's first multiparty legislature.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


354 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 27, 1996


Zambia;
Dutch Government To Help Women Politicians in Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Royal Netherlands Embassy in Zambia is to continue giving financial assistance to women candidates through the National Women's Lobby Group.

Secretary of the Women and Development from the embassy, Ms Monique Calon, said it would provide finances for women standing in this year's elections to enable them carry out viable campaigns regardless of their political affiliations. 

She was speaking at the African Women Conference which ended in Lusaka yesterday.

Ms Calon lamented that it was unfortunate that most political parties in Zambia are not willing to put up women as candidates in the forth-coming elections.

She said women should be allowed to stand in order to advance the country's democratic development.

Ms Calon whose organisation funded the women's Beijing trip said she was not disappointed that Zambia is among the 33 African countries that have not implemented the Beijing platform resolutions.

She said if more women are given a chance to be members of parliament most of the resolutions would be implemented for the benefit of the country as a whole.

At the conference which ended yesterday a working executive was put in place to spearhead the implementation of the Beijing resolutions.

The new executive includes Ethiopia's Mitikie George as President while Zambia's Sr. Auxillia Ponga was elected as a committee member.

The Beijing resolutions includes health for all, eradication of poverty, girl child education and equal opportunities for both men and women.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 27, 1996


Business;
China To Start Processing Copper In Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Kabwe - China will this year start processing copper and production of copper rods in Kabwe, visiting Chinese deputy governor for Jiangxi province, Zhou Zhiping, confirmed in Kabwe today.

Speaking when he paid a courtesy call on Kabwe mayor, James Chansa, at the civic centre, Mr Zhou said he was happy to learn that the Zambian government through Kabwe municipal council had solved the land issue where the plant would be erected before the end of this year.

"I am pleased to learn that the land issue has been solved. This is a good start. The project will not only affect Jiangxi provice, but the central government of China as well. With cooperation from local leadership, the project will start before the end of this year," Mr Zhou informed the mayor, councillors and chief officers who welcomed his delegation. 

The Chinese delegation also include Mr Ren Hong Sui, vice-general manager and senior engineer for China Jiangzi Corporation, Mr Hu Renbao, vice president, China Jiangxi Corporation for water conservation and hydropower construction and Mr Ma De Diang, senior economist in the same corporation.

They are here to inspect the site where the copper processing plant would be built.

In his brief welcome remarks the mayor said his council has expidited the allocation of land and the title deed issued by the Zambian government.

"We had earlier expidited procurement of investment licence. The only thing we are waiting for is to have full technical details of your project so that environmental council of Zambia can assess the impact of the project in the environment," Mr Chansa told the four-man delegation.

He said Kabwe has a reservior of highly trained and experienced industrial personnel, abundant land while rail and road network have been developed.

"We are looking forward to more Chinese investments from your province in the field of agriculture, industrial, mining, housing and wood processing," Mr Chansa said.

The Chinese delegation earlier paid a courtesy call on central province deputy minister, Mr David Mpamba who appealed for more foreign investors to bring industries and create jobs for local Zambian people.

Mr Mpamba who was flanked by his provincial acting permanent secretary geoffrey akafekwa thanked the people of China for continued cooperation in many fields.

He noted that China had constructed Mulungushi Textiles in Kabwe, Mukuku Bridge on the Luapula River, TAZARA and Kafushi rice scheme.

"We appreciate technology from China in rail and road networks," he said.

In reply, Mr Zhou informed the minister that both Zambia and China belonged to the third world and needed to support each other in development.

He said friendship between the two nations began during hard days of Zambia's struggle for independence adding that the warm friendships should be cemented through setting up of such industries like the copper processing plant in Kabwe.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 27, 1996


Zambia and Burundi;
Zambia Takes Stand On Burundi


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian government will not recognise the Pierre Buyoya led military regime that snatched power from legitimate Burundi President Sylvester Ntibantunganya on Thursday.

Foreign Affairs Minister Lieutenant-General Christon Tembo said in Lusaka today that Zambia supports the stand taken by the Organisation of African nity (OAU) to condemn the coup in Burundi.

Gen Tembo said Zambia will as a member of the OAU work closely with the African body to see how best the situation in Burundi can be normalised. 

The Zimbabwe and South African governments have also said that they will not recognise the Buyoya military government which has already taken measures aimed at restoring peace in the trouble-torn central African state.

The Buyoya regime has imposed a dusk to dawn curfew throughout the country, disbanded the Burundi parliament and closed the international airport and borders.

Gen Tembo said although the cabinet has not yet sat to discuss the Burundi issue, government is already agreeable to the stand taken by the OAU announced soon after the coup by secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim.

In another development, Gen Tembo could not confirm when President Chiluba apologised to the Southern African heads of state for statements made by some cabinet ministers on the internal affairs of Zambia.

Gen Tembo said he was unable to give a local confirmation to the reported apology announced by Zimbabwe president Robert Mugabe during a news conference at a SADC meeting in Mozambique yesterday.

The minister has just returned from a business trip in Ethiopia, East Africa and some neighbouring countries but did not disclose the purpose of the trip.

The Zimbabwean leader is quoted to have said that President Chiluba has apologised to his counter-parts in the region for the remarks made some cabinet ministers accusing them of meddling in the internal affairs of Zambia.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 27, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Commission Hears East London Amnesty Applicants


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Johannesburg - The Amnesty Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation is scheduled next week to hear separate amnesty applications from Kwane Sebe, son of former Ciskei leader Lennox Sebe, and from 12 Mdantsane residents who necklaced four alleged gang members.

The applications will be heard by the five-member Committee at hearings in East London. 

Sebe, 38, the former commander of the Elite Unit of the Ciskeian Police, is serving 21 years in prison for the bombing of a bottlestore and a house belonging to his former second-in-command, Mr Zandisile Ngwanya.

Court evidence was that a six-man unit of the Ciskeian Defence Force blew up the Keiskammahoek bottle store with military explosives in May 1989. Sebe was convicted of malicious damage to property and jailed for nine years on this charge. In a later trial, he was jailed for 12 years after being convicted, again of malicious damange to property, for the bombing of a house in Peddie in December 1989.

The Mdantsane applicants are serving terms of imprisonment rang- ing from 10 to 23 years after being convicted of murdering four alleged members of the Killer Boys' gang in Mdantsane in February 1987.

The applicants are: Bonakele Horatius Jwambi, 48; Luyanda Kana, 34; Mzwabantu Patrick Katsi-Katsi, 33; Mseki Mbusi, 38; Bangikhaya Petros, 27; Xolile Edgar Nkukwana, 30; Mandlenkosi Jabavu, 35; Mbuyiselo Klaas, 29; Raymond Monwabisi Kana, 39; Mabongo Jamela, 33; Thando Kana, 31; and Soyiso Zuzani, 30.

They murdered Mr Folie Bushula, Mr Mpumelelo Mbinqo, Mr Mkhuseli Yellem and Mr Archie Booi Swartland. They were sentenced in the Bisho Supreme Court on June 6, 1989. They have declared themselves in their amnesty applications to be members or supporters of the African National Congress.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996

358 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 28, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Olympics Bomb Does Not Deter Athletes


BYLINE: Mpho Dibeela of the Botswana Press Agency, Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Atlanta - Morale of Botswana athletes at the Olympics has not been deterred by the explosion of a pipe bomb that killed two people and injured 110 others early Saturday morning at the Centennial Olympic Park.

"We have confidence in the security, hence our training has not been affected" Coach Raj Rathedi said Sunday morning.

Justice Dipeba takes the track on July 31st in the 200m dash while the 4 by 400 metres relay team competes on August 2nd and Marathon runner Benjamin Keleketu fares on August 4. 

Thousands of spectators and tourists have put on a brave face and attendance has not dwindled in the different sporting events.

Meanwhile the Park has been closed while the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI) are investigating and will be opened with increased security.

Reacting to the accident, American President Bill Clinton said it was " an act of cowardice that stands in sharp contrast to the courage of the Olympic athletes." But, he said, the Olympic spirit will prevail.

Addressing the press on July 28 the President of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch expressed sympathy to the families and friends of those affected by the explosion.

"I am very grateful to the authorities for the excellent response and the security measures that have been taken" Samaranch said.

IOC head further said the important part of the Olympics, the competitions, were going extremely well. He said records were being broken both on the track and by the largest number of spectators the Olympic have ever enjoyed.

And many interviewed said they will not be discouraged to make the Olympics their best of times. Although extra-cautious the streets are still streaming with tourists and the mood for the games has not gone down.

A Turkish journalist covering the games died of heart attack while rushing to the blast scene where an unidentified woman died on the spot after the 1. 25 am explosion that shocked thousands who were enjoying a music concert.

The 21 acre Park was a colorful combination of merchandise and souvenirs exhibitions, kioks and many were lured to this area like a metal to a magnet.

But now the scene is depressed in emptiness as the police survey the area in hunt for evidence that could lead them to the man who up0setted the whole mood of the Olympics and left many scarred for their lives.

But still the Olympic spirit persists, although now with the observation of a moment of silence in every event and flags at half mast, and athletes are setting new records both in the track and field.

Canadian Donovan Bailey became the fastest man in the world when he won the 100 metres dash at 9.84 seconds upsetting 9.85 previous world record and beating the favourite, Namibian Frankie Fredericks to the second spot at 9.89 seconds. Third was Trinidad's Ota Boldon.

Defending champion Linford Christe was disgraced out after qualifying for the finals for a double false-start.

Gail Devers of the United States won the ladies race at the same time with Jamaican Merelian Oti. The drama on the track continues to unfold as is in other fields of this centennial Olympics.

NOTE: Dibeela, who reports for the Botswana Press Agency, is covering the Olympics under a special program between The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
