359 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


United States and Africa;
Washington Group Says Liberian Peace Needs Support


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2867 words


 

Washington DC - The following is an "Update and Alert" on Liberia from the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa- related legislation:

After a resurgence of violence last spring, relative calm has returned to parts of the Liberian capital, Monrovia, over the past two months. The West African peacekeeping force has regained control over the city and armed factions loyal to different warlords have been separated.

However, the peace process which collapsed violently in April is not back on track. The humanitarian situation remains desperate. International involvement, whether from West African states or the broader international community, still falls far short of the measures necessary to curb the power of the warlords and open up space for Liberian civilians to reestablish a functioning society.

The United States and others are discussing the prospects of holding elections in Liberia before the end of the year. Liberian civic groups as well as outside observers, however, warn that meaningful elections are impossible unless the power of the warlords is effectively checked. They emphasize the need for disarmament and demobilization of the factional fighters, monitored by a more effective international military presence. 

Since the April explosion of violence in Monrovia, the United States has kept open its embassy there and has taken a higher-profile role in the peace process. Washington has pledged an additional $30 million to the West African peacekeeping force, known as ECOMOG, to enable it to maintain minimum levels of stability so that longer-term peace efforts and humanitarian relief can go forward. The U.S. government has also stated strongly that the international community will isolate anyone taking governmental power in Liberia by force.

Despite these steps, the current level of international involvement remains insufficient. Without a higher level of engagement by the United States in particular, renewed peace efforts will be vulnerable to violent and repeated collapse.

To increase the chances of sustainable peace, diplomatic and humanitarian assistance must be accompanied by support for:

* An adequate international peacekeeping presence, to ensure disarmament of the factions. This may require an expanded United Nations force if ECOMOG proves incapable of the task;

* Sanctions to deter and restrict the international trading channels by which Liberian warlords exchange diamonds and other Liberian resources for arms;

* A greater voice for Liberian civilians at home and outside the country, such as by convening a broad national conference with international sponsorship and support.

Six Years of War

Liberia was founded in the early 19th century by African Americans who returned to Africa as settlers. Their descendants, known as Americo-Liberians, dominated the country's government for more than 150 years. Ties with the United States were close, with continuing high levels of aid and investment. In the 1960s and 1970s, Liberia received the highest per capita level of U.S. aid of any country on the African continent.

In 1980 the settler-dominated government was overthrown. Many Liberians hoped for reform and a shift of power to the indigenous 95% of the population. But military leader Samuel Doe bypassed grassroots opposition groups and ran a military dictatorship, favoring his own small ethnic group.

The United States provided massive support for the Doe regime in the 1980s, with a total of $402 million in aid between 1981 and 1985--more than during the entire previous century. At the time Liberia was a key staging post for a large-scale covert U.S. operation against Libya's Muammar Qaddafi. Washington continued its support for Doe despite documented human rights violations and a 1985 election widely seen to be marked by fraud and repression.

In late 1989 insurgents led by Charles Taylor crossed into Liberia from the Ivory Coast, beginning a war against the Doe regime. The conflict led to high levels of atrocities against civilians by Taylor's forces, the remnants of Doe's army, and as many as five other armed factions. Doe himself was killed by another rebel leader in September 1990.

Washington provided humanitarian aid--more than $425 million from 1990 through mid-1995. But former U.S. officials testify that they were instructed not to take an active role in peacemaking. The initiative for peacekeeping and peace negotiations was left to the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), with Nigeria playing a leading role.

The West African peace-keeping force arrived in late 1990, after the conflict was well under way. Its intervention has been flawed, but is generally credited with saving lives. West African governments meanwhile have supported continuing mediation efforts. The most recent is the Abuja accord of August 1995, which provided for an interim government involving all the warlords, and for the disarming and demobilization of their forces before elections this year.

The Abuja accord came after almost six years of war which killed as many as 150,000 out of a population of 2.6 million. Some 800,000 people fled the country as refugees, and more than a million were displaced from their homes within the country.

Accord Breaks Down

Implementation of the Abuja agreement depended on either the goodwill of the warlords or decisive international support for their disarmament. Neither materialized. Liberian civilians were kept out of the process, and the predictable breakdown came in April when warlord Charles Taylor decided to launch an attack in Monrovia against a rival force. Both sides had by then infiltrated armed forces into the capital, previously a relatively safe haven from the conflict in the countryside.

The fighting forced the evacuation of humanitarian relief agencies. Their supplies were looted by the warlords, who used the relief goods for military ends. In mid-June, 13 international agencies said they would not reestablish full operations in Liberia until minimal security can be assured.

Fighting has recently recurred in several other parts of the country. Despite the relative normalcy in the capital, Liberians say that off the main streets there is no security. Basic services, such as electricity and running water, are not available, and food is scarce. During June over 1,500 bodies were recovered by health workers from shallow graves.

The primary responsibility for the war over the last six years--and for the latest violence in Monrovia--lies with the leaders of the Liberian armed factions, who have put their personal quests for power above the desire of Liberians for peace. The record of the West African peacekeeping force, which brought some stability to parts of Liberia, has been mixed, and its failure to react when violence broke out in April contributed to the high level of destruction.

But the international community must also shoulder a large share of the blame. In the case of Liberia, with 150 years of close U.S. ties, " international community" means above all the United States. The U.S. failure to respond to the initial outbreak of war in 1989-1990 cost the lives of thousands of Liberians and close to $500 million in emergency aid.

When the latest peace agreement was signed, many observers warned that it was doomed to collapse without adequate international support for disarmament and demobilization of the militias and for the peacekeeping efforts of ECOMOG. That support did not come. This failure invited a costly humanitarian disaster and set the scene for the evacuation of U.S. citizens and many other foreign residents in April.

Giving Peace a Chance

The majority of Liberians want peace. But the chances of achieving it are slim unless the capacity of the warlords to make war is curbed.

Liberian civil leaders and traditional rulers, meeting with ECOWAS leaders in mid-July, urged strong international sanctions against faction leaders to enforce compliance with peace agreements. They stressed that ECOMOG should be empowered and provided with logistical support to enforce peace by disarming combatants, as a precondition to free elections.

The Liberian leaders also demanded that the international community impose sanctions on the export of Liberian natural resources by the warlords. "On no account should there be elections without first complete disarmament, encampment and integration of these combatants into the society," stated the chair of the Liberian Bar Association, Frederick Cherue.

In sum, three basic steps are needed if Liberian civilians are to have a chance to rebuild their society. The United States must play an active role in providing high-level and consistent diplomatic pressure and financial resources in support of the entire process.

(1) The international peacekeeping force already on the ground must be maintained and upgraded. West African states must continue to play a central role in peacemaking and peacekeeping, regardless of the shortcomings of their past involvement and doubts about the future. (Leadership of West African peacemaking efforts is shifting, as Ghana's President Jerry Rawlings ended his term as chair of ECOWAS in late July. His successor is General Sani Abacha, head of the Nigerian military regime.)

But the West African states do not have the diplomatic clout, the credibility, or the logistical resources to do the job entirely on their own. The ECOMOG force needs adequate logistical support. Its efforts also need to be supplemented by consistent backup and monitoring from the wider international community, including an expanded United Nations peacekeeping presence which can balance the West African role.

(2) The peace process must be linked to plans for disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration of combatants. Continued participation by faction leaders in the political process should be contingent on their cooperation with disarmament, as specified in the Abuja peace agreement. The warlords likely will only comply with such demands if action is taken to block the flow of arms. This includes strong and effective pressure on neighboring countries, particularly Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso, and Guinea, to restrict the supplies of arms to the factions.

At the same time, disarmament will not be possible without simultaneous planning for demobilization. Successful reintegration of former combatants into civilian life in turn depends on the creation of economic opportunities within the civilian economy. Delay in planning these elements was one of the main reasons for the failure to disarm in the period since last fall. Such a comprehensive plan will be costly. But it is more practical--and, in the long term less expensive--than responding to repeated humanitarian emergencies.

(3) Steps must be taken to guarantee a more active role for civilian institutions in the transition. Last year's Abuja accord was praised by some and criticized by others for making the faction leaders the key players in the transitional government leading to elections. This could only work if prompt disarmament and international protection for civilians were implemented simultaneously.

The peace process should provide political space for the vast majority of unarmed Liberians and Liberian civic institutions. It must not be held hostage by any of the armed faction leaders. Unless new measures are taken to protect and encourage vibrant civilian political activity, the peace process will be again be doomed to fail.

What You Can Do

(Note to non-U.S. readers: This posting is provided both for your background information and for possible forwarding to those of your U.S. contacts you think would be interested.)

1. CONTACT THE ADMINISTRATION

Write to National Security Advisor Anthony Lake and to Secretary of State Warren Christopher. Urge that the United States increase its active engagement in the search for peace in Liberia. Talking points:

* The United States bears special responsibility for helping to resolve the situation in Liberia because of its historical ties to Liberia and U.S. aid to the Doe regime.

* Peace agreements cannot succeed without much more active international support for disarmament and demobilization of factional fighters, and for West African and international peacekeeping efforts. This requires sanctions to block the flow of arms to the warlords.

* Liberian civilian institutions must play a more active role in the transition to a legitimate government. Elections will only be meaningful if there is security and a real opportunity for Liberian civilians, inside and outside of Liberia, to have a greater voice.

Mr. Anthony Lake National Security Council Washington, DC 20500 Fax: (202) 456-2883

Secretary Warren Christopher U.S. Department of State Washington, DC 20520 Fax: (202) 647-6434

2. CONTACT CONGRESS

Send copies of your messages to the Africa subcommittees in Congress and to the Congressional Black Caucus. Consider enclosing a short note thanking these members of Congress for their efforts to focus attention on the crisis in Liberia, and asking them to continue to press the Administration for stronger action.

Addresses:

Sen. Nancy Kassebaum Chair, Africa Subcommittee 302 Russell Senate Office Building Washington, DC 20510 Fax: (202) 224-3514

Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen Chair, Africa Subcommittee 127 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Fax: (202) 225-5620

Rep. Donald Payne Chair, Congressional Black Caucus 417 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Fax: (202) 225-4160

3. KEEP INFORMED

For updates on the situation in Liberia, contact Ezekiel Pajibo, Africa Faith and Justice Network, 401 Michigan Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20017. Tel. (202) 832-3412. Fax (202) 832-9051. E-mail: afjn@igc.apc.org.

For more information, contact the Washington Office on Africa at 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202- 546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


July 29, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Commends Sao Tome/Principe On Recent Election


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Washington DC - Following is the text of the statement by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on the presidential elections in Sao Tome and Principe:

The United States commends the people of Sao Tome and Principe upon the successful conclusion of their presidential elections and congratulates President Miguel Trovoada on his re-election. Throughout the two-round electoral process, the National Electoral Commission worked closely with international observers, including some sponsored by the United States. We are pleased to report that observer teams found the elections to have been free and fair. We also note reports that former President Pinto da Costa has conceded and pledged to work for the good of his country.

Less than a year ago, we commended Sao Tome and Principe for demonstrating that reason can prevail over force when President Trovoada was restored to office after a week-long attempted coup. At that time, we expressed the hope that the restoration of the democratically elected government would lead all parties in Sao Tome and Principe to rededicate themselves to democratic ideals and practices. We now urge all of the citizens of Sao Tome and Principe to work with their elected leaders through the established government bodies. We also urge their leaders to redouble their efforts on behalf of the people of Sao Tome and Principe

LANGUAGE: English

361 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Business;
Gender A Priority For Norwegian Aid To Zambia


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - The Royal Norwegian government has said gender support is among its first five priorities for donor aid to Zambia.

The second secretary for development cooperation at the Norway embassy Kikkan Haugen said at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel last Friday, during the official launching of Women Entrepreneurs Development Association of Zambia (WEDAZ) that for sustainable development to take place, women must be supported.

"Women play a very significant role in productive activities, and development can only be sustainable if women participate fully," Haugen said. 

"And our list of areas that should be given priority, in supporting measures that improve the situation of women producers is among the top five, and this strategy is not one that only exists on paper, but is one that has had very practical consequences," he said.

Haugen whose NORAD gave WEDAZ about K18 million to set up a secretariat also disclosed that the 1992 bilateral development cooperation with Zambia has a very substantial share aimed at women development.

"Nearly all the activities that are supported by Norway have taken gender issues into consideration, because we believe that the endeavours you are involved in are of utmost importance for the development of Zambia," he said.

But Community development deputy minister Lt Colonel Scholastic Ngoma urged WEDAZ to be transparent in the use of the grant they got from NORAD to inspire other donors to provide more support.

"The temptation to use a larger portion of the grant to corver administrative costs should be desisted, we will be encouraged if the grant would be used o support well designed programmes which can contribute to sustainable development," Ngoma said.

She said her ministry supports initiatives aimed at building capacities in communities, especially among disadvantaged groups, like women.

"Disadvantaged groups must be assisted to become economically strong and productive, by implementing appropriate strategies in consultation and with the support of cooperating partners," Ngoma said.

WEDAZ chairperson Vivian Mthetwa said her organisation will conduct training for women entrepreneurs so they can run their businesses effectively and will set up a revolving fund to provide loans to women.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Matete Speeds Towards 400 Meters Final With An Eye on Gold


BYLINE: Charles Katongo of the Zambia Daily Mail, Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Atlanta - Zambia's medal hopeful Samuel Matete on Monday morning eased to the semi-finals of the 400m hurdles in the on going Centennial Olympic games when he posted the fastest time of 48.21 seconds to finish first ahead of seven others in heat three of the competition.

Matete, the 1991 world champion, is entering the event as a favourite to mint the gold but he has to beat current world champion Derrick Adkins of the United States of America who also qualified to the semi finals with a time of 48.46 seconds in heat seven.The current world and Olympic times of 46.78 and 46.78 respectively were set by Kevin Young of the United States of America at the Barcelona games in 1992. 

Matete, whose personal time of 47.10 is the best here and with which he won the world championship title in 1991 in Japan, took off from his block in lane five like a rabbit and flew over the hurdles like a gazelle, rounding the last corner ahead of the pack with powerful graceful strides which have seen him win all his events in Europe in the last few months prior to the Atlanta Games.

But the semifinals would miss the expected tough competition among the world's greatest hurdlers following the pulling out of Jamaica's Winthrop Graham because of a knee injury he sustained 80m after starting the race. Graham was running in heat five from which Jon Ridgeon of Great Britain and Marc Dollendorf of Belgium qualified.

Matete and Adkins have met three times this year and all occasions, the Zambian has won.He is making his third attempt at winning an Olympic medal after the last two attempts flopped.

In Monday's event, all the runners were forced to run at top speed to get to the next round and Matete's time, the best so far, probably indicates that he is capable of lowering it to emerge the first and win the gold.

The other Zambian likely to win the other medal, Godfrey Siamusiye, was also being expected to run his 3000m steeplechase competition last night. Siamusiye and 5000m runner Fackson Nkandu, who takes to the tracks on Thursday are the only two Zambians apart from Matete competing in the Olympics following the exit of the four boxers who lost all their fights in the second qualifying round.

NOTE: Charles Katongo, a reporter for the Zambia Daily Mail, is participating in the International Journalists Coverage Program, sponsored by The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996

Africa News


July 29, 1996


Sports;
Four-nation Cricket Draw Out


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya has been drawn against Sri-Lanka in the opening match of the four-nation cricket tournament to be staged in Nairobi from Sept. 28 to Oct. 7.

A fixture issued here Sunday by the Kenya Cricket Association shows that the second match would be between Pakistan and South Africa Sept. 29. 

South Africa meets Sri-Lanka Oct. 1. The date for the match between Kenya and Pakistan would be determined by the other fixtures.

Kenya will play its third match against South Africa Oct. 3, while Pakistan takes on Sri-Lanka Oct. 4.

The finals of the tournament will be Oct. 6. However, the organising committee has set aside October 7 as a reserve day just in case the finals are interrupted by rains.

Africa News


July 29, 1996


Southern Africa;
SADC Police officials meet in Windhoek


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 134 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - Police officers from the Southern African

Development Community (SADC) started a meeting Monday in Windhoek, Namibia, to discuss crime and policing in the sub-region. 

The three-day meeting, preparatory to a ministerial meeting to be held in the Namibian city, will also discuss security at the SADC meeting.

The officers will also look at ways to improve the coordination of police activity between SADC member-states.

SADC includes Angola, South Africa, Botswana, Mauritius Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Liberia;
ECOMOG Needs 10,000 More Troops In Liberia


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - The out-going field commmander of the West African Peace Keeping Force in Liberia (ECOMOG), Maj.Gen. John Mark Inienger, has said the strength of the force should be raised to at least 18,000 men to enable it accomplish its mission in the war-torn country.

The peace mission, sent to Monrovia by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) in August 1990, is currently estimated at 8,500 soldiers, with Nigeria having the largest contingent.

The force has so far failed to end the six-year-old civil war in Africa's oldest republic, due mainly to the uncooperative attitude of the warring factions.

"To compel them to give us cooperation, ECOMOG needs to have an overwhelming presence in Liberia," Inienger told PANA in Abuja, where he attended the just-ended ECOWAS summit. 

However, he drew a parallel between "peace-enforcement" and the "deterrent force", which is being advocated, saying that apart from enhanced numerical strength, ECOMOG should also be properly equipped if it is to be credible.

"When we talk about strength, we are not talking only of numbers. We are talking about armed personnel carriers, helicopter gunships and what have you, " he said, adding, "once you get all these things, you should be able to assert yourself."

Inienger, ECOMOG commander for the past three years, also accused the Liberian warlords of lacking good faith.

"For the peace agreements to be implemented, all parties have to demonstrate good faith. That, in the case of Liberia, is lacking," he said.

"They (the warlords)," the general said, "come to the conference table, agree and sign a document in a most ceremonious manner, only to go back on the ground to renege on the agreement."

The Liberian war has killed at least 150,000 people, despite some 13 peace accords and more than 50 meetings held to stop it.

Inienger said the weakness of ECOMOG was also most visible in its inability to enforce an arms embargo along Liberia's borders.

He said the force was only able to restore Monrovia to the current state of relative peace, after fighting and looting resumed April 6, when troops deployed to the hinterland to monitor disarmament, were called in.

For arms restrictions to succeed, the general said, countries sharing borders with Liberia, should prevent the warring factions from smuggling ammunition through their territories.

Inienger said he supported sanctions against the factions to make them see reason, but warned that ECOWAS members should harmonise the measures to eliminate possible loopholes that could be exploited by them.

He also chided those in the international community that had made pledges to the peace effort that they had failed to honour.

"People made pledges and some of the pledges have not been fulfilled... even as we continue to cry for resources to beef up our strength," he said.

The outgoing ECOMOG field commander rejected the suggestion that making the warlords members of the Liberian Council of State under the 1995 Abuja peace agreement was a mistake.

He said it was much more difficult to negotiate with them in their various enclaves. "We must do everything to retain them so that we can continue to talk to them," he added.

On whether to hold an election before disarmament in Liberia, Inienger said all agreements on Liberia had been predicated on disarmament, "but the bottleneck has been the unwillingness of the parties to disarm."

To get round the problem, he said, disarmament could be "by-passed."

"This is a possibility, it has been done elsewhere, it can be done in Liberia," he added.

According to him, elections could be held in safe havens in Liberia and among Liberian refugee populations across West Africa.

The population of Monrovia, put at 400,000 before the war started in 1989, is now estimated at 1.2 million.

Inienger said this number and Liberians abroad, could add up to 70 percent of the country's estimated 2.5 million population.

"That can confidently take you to an election provided you involve the international community," he added.

Inienger, a former Nigerian state governor, has been redeployed to head the country's army Command and Staff College, in the northern city of Jaji.

Maj.Gen. Victor Malu, one-time ECOMOG chief of staff, is the new commander of the peace force in Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


366 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Burundi;
Kadhafi Calls For Understanding


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libyan leader Col. Moammar Kadhafi has appealed to the international community not to condemn Burundi's new president without understanding the circumstances that led to his reinstallation.

"It is useless for the time being to condemn the new Burundian President Pierre Buyoya without understanding the circumstances which led to his comeback," Kadhafi said in a statement issued to PANA in Tripoli. 

If Maj. Buyoya has taken power with the aim of stopping the ongoing ethnic massacre and enhance security in Burundi, "he should rather be supported and we should not be hostile to him".

Maj. Buyoya, a retired Tutsi officer who led Burundi from 1987 to 1993, was returned to power by the Tutsi-dominated army Thursday in a bloodless military coup.

He took over from President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, who went into hiding at the United States embassy in Bujumbura Tuesday last week.

Ntibantunganya went to the embassy after being pelted with stones as he arrived for the burial of over 300 Tutsis who were massacred at a camp for displaced people.

The massacre was attributed to Hutu rebels, who have denied the allegation.

Several members of Ntibantunganya's cabinet and other Hutu dignitaries are also hiding in diplomatic missions in the Burundian capital.

Buyoya, who relinquished power after organising Burundi's first multiparty elections in June 1993, has pledged to restore "frank and honest" dialogue between the various components of the Burundian society.

However, the ouster of Ntibantunganya has been described as "illegal" by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Burundi;
Bujumbura Gradually Returning To Normal


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundi's new President, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, has appealed for understanding from the international community.

Addressing diplomats here Monday, Buyoya said he would announce a new cabinet within the next two days. 

He would, he added, involve dignitaries from the majority Hutu ethnic group in the new government.

He urged Hutu personalities who have taken refuge in foreign embassies to return home, promising them state protection.

"The international community which you represent has to understand the goal of the ongoing action is to avert a genocide", Buyoya told the diplomats.

The new president made a similar remark Sunday during a news conference, explaining that he did not return to power through a "classical coup d'etat."

According to him, the decision of the Burundian army to return him to power was "an action to save a people in danger and to restore peace through dialogue with all those who agree to lay down their weapons".

Buyoya was beaten in the multiparty elections of 1993, six years after he had seized power in a military coup d'etat.

The situation was gradually returning to normal Monday in Bujumbura where classes have resumed at the sole university.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


368 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
South African Outrage At Atlanta Bombing


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa has come out strongly against the bomb attack which took two lives at the olympic games in the American city of Atlanta.

The official spokesman for President Nelson Mandela, Joel Netshienzhe, has revealed in Pretoria that the South African leader has expressed his outrage at the bomb blast. 

He described the week-end blast as "an outrageous act, not only against the people of Atlanta and the United States, but against all humanity as a whole".

The president emphasised, however, that the South African olympic games team was not being recalled from Atlanta because of the bombing.

The possibility had been considered, but the South African government believed that there was adequate Olympic games security to ensure the safety of all international athletes.

Netshitenzhe added that Mandela wished to send to all athletes -- particularly the South African contingent -- a clear message that the hearts of all South Africans were with them at this difficult time.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Libya;
Kadhafi Calls For Understanding of Burundi Coup


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libyan leader Col. Moammar Kadhafi has appealed to the international community not to condemn Burundi's new president without understanding the circumstances that led to his reinstallation.

"It is useless for the time being to condemn the new Burundian President Pierre Buyoya without understanding the circumstances which led to his comeback," Kadhafi said in a statement issued to PANA in Tripoli. 

If Maj. Buyoya has taken power with the aim of stopping the ongoing ethnic massacre and enhance security in Burundi, "he should rather be supported and we should not be hostile to him".

Maj. Buyoya, a retired Tutsi officer who led Burundi from 1987 to 1993, was returned to power by the Tutsi-dominated army Thursday in a bloodless military coup.

He took over from President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, who went into hiding at the United States embassy in Bujumbura Tuesday last week.

Ntibantunganya went to the embassy after being pelted with stones as he arrived for the burial of over 300 Tutsis who were massacred at a camp for displaced people.

The massacre was attributed to Hutu rebels, who have denied the allegation.

Several members of Ntibantunganya's cabinet and other Hutu dignitaries are also hiding in diplomatic missions in the Burundian capital.

Buyoya, who relinquished power after organising Burundi's first multiparty elections in June 1993, has pledged to restore "frank and honest" dialogue between the various components of the Burundian society.

However, the ouster of Ntibantunganya has been described as "illegal" by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Uganda;
Uganda's Woman Peace Envoy Makes Exit


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Nairobi - Mrs. Betty Bigombe, Uganda's Minister of State for the Pacification of the North pulled out of the hotly contested Gulu Municipality election race last month and flew out to the United States for post-graduate studies.

In the wake of her departure, Mr. Norbert Mao, her challenger for the parliamentary seat was declared winner, ending weeks of acrimonious dispute over the validity of the election results that initially gave Mr. Nobert Mao, a youthful lawyer, 8,830 to Mrs. Bigombe's 7,089 votes.

The results of the June 27 parliamentary elections were nullified by Uganda's Electoral Commission following Mrs. Bigombe's angry denounciation of alleged malpractices.

Before leaving, the accomplished peacemaker and diplomat held a meeting with her campaign workers at which it was decided she quit the race. The campaign managers were particularly riled by her opponent's alleged tactics including depicting Bigombe as an obstacle to peace in Acholiland, northern Uganda. 

"Her opponent has depicted the insurgency in the north as a war between Mrs. Bigombe and the people, when actually it is an act of rebellion against the government. They seem to think that the removal of the candidate from affairs of the North would end the problem," lamented her chief campaigner Mr. Sam Oduny.

Mrs. Bigombe clearly feels betrayed by her own people. Her departure was also seen as a security measure as she could have been harmed by rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) who have proved quite irrational in their recent actions.

One of her most recent disappointments was the killing in cold blood of two Acholi elders by the LRA on June 13. The two elders, Samson Okot-Ogoni and Chief Olanya Lagoni were killed while on mission to make contact with the rebels as a prelude for substantive discussions between them and the government.

Observers, say it became clear to Mrs Bigombe that her 10 years of pursuing peace and getting the rebels to stop the rapes, looting, arson and abductions of boys and girls for enforced conscription to their ranks, had taken a major setback. She may also have felt betrayed that President Yoweri Museveni abandoned her when she encountered severe problems with her electoral opponent in the parliamentary elections. Museveni could have continued to list Mrs. Bigombe in his cabinet appointments announced on July 6 purely for moral support but this was not his style. Instead the President announced the appointment of Owiny Dollo to replace Mrs. Bigombe as peacemaker in the north. Like his predecessor, Mr. Dollo is an Acholi.

Another significant appointment is that of Dr. Martin Alliker as Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. Alliker, a professional dentist in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, and Kampala for many years, is also a traditional chief of the Acholis of Kitgum District. A wealthy man, he has substantial international business contacts. He is a relative of the late General Tito Okello, former Head of State who died last June.

For her incessant campaigning for peace, Bigombe was named woman of the year by one of Uganda's leading newspapers, the Monitor.

"When I first came to this post, the rebel groups were numerous and enjoyed the support of about 90 per cent of the populations," she observed in 1990.

Bigombe, in her mid-40s was based at the Gulu Military Barracks. She often flew in a government helicopter from one bush stop to another, seeking peace and encouraging the rebels to understand that the government of the day was here to stay.

Many of the rebels were former soldiers in the disbanded Uganda National Liberation Army (UNLA). They feared that the post-1986 government of President Yoweri Museveni would penalize them for the atrocities they committed against the people in other parts of Uganda, notably in the Luwero Triangle in the north, where tens of thousands were massacred in the early 80s.

She was one of a handful of northerners to support the cause of the National Resistance Army (NRA) of Yoweri Museveni, indeed as early as 1983. She argued that "the north needs a new face in politics" and was rewarded with a job to pacify the north by encouraging ex- UNLA to come to terms with the new situation in Uganda. Her ministry often had meagre funds and sometimes lived off the Army to make any headway in the dangerous task of making contacts with the unpredictable rebels.

She was motivated by her instinctive understanding of the Ugandan situation and once said that Joseph Kony, the former Catholic catechist turned rebel leader, "had absolutely no motive for taking over the government." Her quest for peace for her own Acholi homeland was made doubly difficult by the fact that nobody knew the rebels' agenda.

Her biggest success so far, is convincing the military to treat surrendering rebels humanely. Such people are given counselling at a World Vision facility in Gulu and are allowed to return to their communities.

President Yoweri Museveni once observed that it was the tenacity of people like Bigombe that had convinced him to accept parallel peace talks with the rebels. "Otherwise I prefer to kill them," said Museveni.

While pursuing the difficult task of pacifying the north, she had virtually no family life. Her husband lives abroad with their two children.

She was a lecturer in African literature at Sophia University in Tokyo, Japan, an occupation that nurtured her liberal outlook. She chaired the Afro- Arab women's club in Tokyo and later worked with the African Development Bank (ADB) in West Africa.

Her departure comes at a critical time when Ugandan rebels are acquiring apparent greater support from the regime in Khartoum which accuses Ugandan authorities of supporting the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of John Garang.

The rebels recently massacred more than 100 Sudanese refugees in a camp in northern Uganda. Authorities said it was clear the rebels were executing a mission on behalf of the Sudanese government."

Meanwhile Anglican bishops from Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Sudan, Burundi and Zaire, condemned the July 13 and 14 massacre of Sudanese refugees in northern Uganda, terming the act "satanic". The bishops were in Kampala to attend a Pre-Lambeth Conference in preparation for the World Anglican Lambeth Conference in Canterbury, England in 1998.

The Bishop of Namirembe Diocese the Rt. Rev. Samuel Sekkade said it was now more necessary than ever for both sides in the northern Uganda conflict to seek a negotiated settlement to the crisis.

The Anglican bishops' sentiments are shared by the Uganda Catholic Bishops Conference which has sent the head of the Ugandan Episcopal Conference Bishop Paul Kalanda of Fort Portal to the northern town of Gulu, to try and make initial contact with representatives of the rebels.

Bishop Kalanda is accompanied by two other bishops, the veteran Bishop Adrian Ddungu of Masaka Diocese and Bishop Erasmus Wandera of Soroti. Their stay in Gulu coincided with the July 13 massacre of more than 100 Sudanese refugees in the Acholi-Pii and Agago refugee camps in the neighbouring Kitgum District.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


371 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Kenya;
The Misunderstood 'Spear Planting' Practice Among The Maasai


BYLINE: Ndiso Kinyumu, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Nairobi - Tell a fellow Kenyan man that you either worked in the Kajiado and Narok regions in the Rift Valley Province, areas mainly inhabited by the pastoral Maasai people, and the next most probable question will hinge on whether you liberally enjoyed the privileges accorded to a male visitor after the simple act of planting a spear outside the host's hut.

It is widely held that Maasai men lend wives to their "visitor" age- mates, thanks to shoddy anthropology and contradicting explanations from the Maasai themselves.

The arrival of a male visitor in his agemate's homestead is announced by the planting of a spear outside the main hut.

It is said that the spear planted by the visitor, serves as a warning to the husband that another man is temporarily in control -- something akin to the "not vacant" sign seen on the door latch of public washrooms.

Apart from these contestable allegations, the spear is seen as a symbol of Maasai military prowess. It is the standard weapon in the Maasai armoury and any warrior (moran) without one would be likened to a state without an army. 

Kenyan history manuals teach that British imperialists failed to coerce the Maasai into ceding territory, because of the latter's military prowess. Consequently, the colonizer was forced to negotiate for Maasai land that he got through fraudulent treaties entered into with illiterate Laibons (Chiefs- cum-spiritual leaders) who simply thumb-printed the communities' prime- grazing areas to the white settlers.

Apart from the Nandi who are somehow linguistic cousins to the Maasai, other Kenyan communities were simply pacified into surrendering huge chunks of land to the white settlers.

Because of the cultural and military significance of the spear, it is not surprising that a near-religious reverence is accorded to it. For instance, it would be unthinkable for a Maasai lady to arm herself with a spear. It is simply a warrior's weapon. Old men do not carry one with them, probably because of its weight--about seven kilogrammes.

Back to the issue of wife-lending: Joseph Miaron, a development worker with Group Ranchers Education Programme, a non-governmental organization (NGO) working among the Maasai people in Loitokitok, in the slopes of neighbouring Tanzania's Mt. Kilimanjaro, will not hear of this. He says; "Like other men the world over, the Maasai guard their matrimonial beds jealously."

"It will have to be a mad society where you lend your wife to a stranger," he protests. Nevertheless, he agrees that Maasai did and still do accommodate strangers in their houses. He is however quick to clarify that, whereas such strangers are allowed to sleep in the same hut with the host's wife, decorum demands the appreciation of this hospitality. In this respect, the visitor is strictly expected to confine himself to the bed allocated to him while the host's wife must never sneak out of the matrimonial bed.

But given human beings' propensity for mischief, "why would anyone trust his wife with another man? It has to do with society responding to the dictates of the environmental realities of the harsh savanna which feature expanses of wildlife-infested, waterless and foodless tracts of land," explains Miaron. As such it would be morally irresponsible for any Maasai man to deny another accommodation, consigning him to suffer the vagaries of the savanna.

Those who maintain that the accommodation business is an exercise in moral laxity should know better. Age-old conventions are adhered to. Stranded strangers introduce themselves to manyatta (village) elders, specifying their clan which is an integral part of the Maasai social organisation, their age groups and other details to help the elders vet their sincerity, before allocating the visitor a place to spend the night in a hut that must belong to his age-mate in accordance to custom.

Once in the age-mates' hut, the visitor is properly fed before being offered a bed. Due to the preponderance of polygamy among the Maasai, the owner of the hut may opt to go and sleep in any of his other wives' huts as a show of respect for the visitor.

"This has given rise to the misconception that we share wives. It does not mean he has handed over the wife to the visitor," says bank clerk Robert Melly, 25, from Laikipia.

What happens when a man senses that the limits of his hospitality have been overstepped?

Chief Moses Ole Mosiany resignedly maintains that there were and still are cases of mischief. "To pre-empt the designs of the spouse and the visitor, a man can insist on sleeping on the same bed with the suspect," proposes Tikolo Ole Siriwo, aged over 60. "Whatever precautions are taken, there is no way of knowing what goes on between your wife and the other man," admits Ole Murumbi, 57.

Talking to senior Maasai citizens, one gets the impression that they are desperate about the wife sharing business. "We normally have two beds -- one for visitors who must be your age-mates... We don't care if they (visitors) conspire with your wife...there is no point in guarding your women. It's impossible," believes Ole Nkobei who lives around Isinya, some 50 kilometers south of the Kenyan capital, Nairobi. "This attitude perhaps is explained by the fact that the old men, unlike their sons grew up when the wife lending culture was rife among the Maasai," says a priest who, fearing that his views would alienate some of the new faithful in his church, requested anonymity.

Samperu Ole Tauo, is in his early 30s and a "modern" Maasai who has worked for several NGOs. "I have stayed in a manyatta (traditional Maasai village made of huts set in a circular pattern) and I have witnessed the day to day life of the Maasai. If such immorality (wife sharing) takes place, it must be on a very small scale," he maintains.

On the other hand, it would appear the story has two sides. School teacher Viola Mayian, 22, agrees that some women are morally loose and misuse tradition for their own selfish needs. She however points out that the educated Maasai will not hear of such primitivity as wife sharing. "You don't expect me to be lent out by my husband - I'll just quit the marriage," she retorts.

But one should not misconstrue the act of a visitor planting a spear outside his age-mate's hut to imply that the Maasai condone promiscuity.

Although little is said about the offending male, tradition demands that any wife who misuses her hospitality to entertain ...risks the not- too-soft walloping that is administered on wayward spouses. Apart from beatings, the offending woman is subjected to heavy fines (in the traditional sense) which may feature a calving cow produced by her maternal family. The blotch that goes with adultery notwithstanding, the idea of parting with a calving cow becomes very painful, given the high esteem in which the pastoral Maasai hold livestock. Indeed it is joked that Maasai greetings feature cattle, pasture and family in that order.

Maasai traditional law, it would seem, prescribes no specific punishment on spouses having affairs outside marriage. "Punishment ranges from forfeiting livestock to being killed by the aggrieved party," says the priest, who earlier on requested anonymity.

But does a spear planted outside a hut really indicate that the man of that house has ceded it to another? "Spears are usually planted outside huts during the day because it is cumbersome to enter inside the low-roofed Maasai huts carrying one. They never serve as 'No Entry' signs," says Miaron.

He also punctures more holes in the spear-as-sexual-licence talk by maintaining that "since spears are normally carried by morans, the issue of old men using them for immoral purposes does not arise."

Morans usually move in groups and what one would find is a cluster but not a single spear, says Miaron. However, this sounds too perfect. Obviously there must be a time when a moran travels solo.

To Miaron, the spear myth has been peddled by "devilers and prostitutes of Maasai culture for monetary gains from the tourism circuit."

"They see us as a commodity that has to be marketed, packaged in what is normally referred to as state of nature...yes they want tourists to come and see the exotic aboriginal man," he fumes.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Anglican Bishops Prepare Agendas for 1998 Gathering


BYLINE: Jane Gitau, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Nairobi - The alleviation of poverty and development of good leadership are issues likely to rank high on the African bishops agenda for the ten-yearly Lambeth Conference for Anglican Bishops scheduled for 1998. And the Lambeth Conference will be asked to lobby with governments of the North to "forgive us our debts".

At a pre-Lambeth meeting held recently in Kenya's coastal town of Mombasa, some 500 kilometres south-east of the capital, Nairobi, all 19 bishops of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) agreed that the most important social issue for the African Church is poverty and a general feeling of marginalization.

The Rev. Joyce Karuri, a facilitator at the Mombasa meeting, observed that people behave desperately when they are in desperate conditions thus poverty has led to violence and family break-ups, and lack of concern for others. " The poverty of developing nations affects humanity because there is no security, there is a lot of degradation of the environment, plots and school land end up being sold with no regard for the future," said Rev. Karuri who is also the Director of Communications in the CPK Diocese of Kirinyaga in the country's Eastern Province. 

Violence, said Rt. Rev. Samson Mwaluda of the Diocese of Taita Taveta, Coast Province, is further perpetuated through the media and is likely to be worse here than in the North because of poverty.

The solution to these was seen as two fold. It includes on the one level a realistic solution to the external debt crisis and fair trading, and on the other mobilization of better and honest leadership as well as conditions of service.

Poverty, the meeting heard, has pushed corruption to every plane of society, not excluding secular and church leaders. They use their positions to both grab and amass as security for the future. But with a better economic and welfare scheme to prepare leaders for retirement, the threat of an insecure future would be minimized.

The church leaders observed that true democracy is needed in the church to ensure more transparency, but this should be exercised in collegiality and consultation with others, especially the pastoral care committee. Bishops should adopt a simple life-style, without destroying the credibility and integrity of a minister of the Gospel of Jesus Christ.

But it was perhaps the reality of the fragile unity in the church that stirred the most emotions. Still fresh with the memories of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, emphasis was put on the reconciliatory role of the church.

"There are divisions in the church based on class, race, tribe, land tenure etc. These need to be overcome through teaching about the sanctity of human life, emphasizing the doctrine of creation, human dignity and equality of all people made in the image of God," the first conference document says.

The CPK bishops also acknowledged the tremendous influence of mass media, violence through movies and screening of wars, all of which visit people right in their living rooms through television sets. Family members cannot even face one another in their homes without the stranger - the TV, to which very few positive values can be traced.

So, Lambeth will be asked to help lobby for production and screening of good movies that promote unity and positive values. But above all, the church needs to awaken from her stupor and set an agenda rather than react to what others have done.

Noting that the church tends to be comfortable with most things and watches helplessly as young people are drawn to the devil, the Dean of the Province Rt. Rev. David Gitari said: "We should point out the close connection between Christian and African initiation rites especially the sacraments of baptism and confirmation. We would like the body of Christ to be more committed to the Christian upbringing of children and initiation into Anglican thoughts and practice, so that they are not lured away into modern cults."

The acceptance and recognition of homosexuals within the Anglican Communion is likely to be of major concern in the next Lambeth meeting. Fronted by the American Church which has already ordained a non-celibate homosexual to the diaconate, the move, unless strongly opposed, may be a first step in making the practice legally acceptable within the Communion.

Apart from the ordination of women, an issue that particularly sparked controversy in its early stages in 1982, homosexuality is the one issue which is likely to tear the Anglican Communion right down the middle.

For the Kenyan church leaders, homosexuality is yet to become a major issue for the local church. But the bishops nevertheless agreed to offer a scholarly response with understanding and sensitivity as to why it is not a problem in Kenya today.

It is important, they said, not to let the key issues of poverty and culture be hijacked by the homosexuality debate. But "if the bishops of Kenya remain silent on the issue, they may fall behind on it because others are presenting aggressive views on it," said Dr. Robert Song, a facilitator from the University of Durham, United Kingdom.

The Province of Kenya, with an Anglican following of some 3 million faithful does not have a woman bishop. However, the province has 40 ordained women priests among 19 bishops and 1,200 priests, serving in 22 dioceses countrywide.

And in Southern Africa, the Synod of Bishops met in February to consider the Lambeth Conference themes. They were joined by representatives of the Provinces of Central Africa and the Indian Ocean. They reflected on the recent period of great change within the province, especially in South Africa, Mozambique and Angola.

Said Archbishop Desmond Tutu, emeritus bishop of Cape Town and former head of the Anglican Church in South Africa; "The challenge of the church is to labour with God, to help God's children to become ever more fully human which is a glorious destiny."

In particular the Church needs to engage in the secular debate on how best moral and ethical foundations of society could be promoted. Added Tutu; "It is the right of all baptized Christians to have access to a spirituality that will enable them to engage critically as Christians, both as individuals and as members of the community of faith, in these vital public issues." The issues include human rights, human sexuality, racism and the family.

The bishops highlighted the primary task of evangelism in their region. Emphasis was put on the search for dynamic ministry. In this context there was clearly a greater role for the laity to play in order to "free the ordained ministry to refocus its vocation." It was hoped that the region could offer some reflection on how to avoid the marginalisation of those without power and those with little hope. It seemed clear that this part of the African Church will be calling for the Lambeth Conference to give time for each region to give presentations of their life, culture and concerns.

Each province at the meeting will now prepare its own submission and covering report, focusing on the major areas of common concern which the regions would like to see on the Lambeth Conference agenda.

Meanwhile, the Province of South-East Asia was inaugurated on February 2, 1996 at St. Andrews Cathedral in Singapore. It becomes the 37th province of the Anglican Communion worldwide. The new province comprises the four dioceses of Kuching, Sabah, Singapore and West Malaysia.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Dr. George Carey, installed the Most Rev. Moses Tay as the first Archbishop of the new province, at a service at the St. Andrew's Cathedral, Singapore.

Dr. Carey spoke of the long process which had led to the formation of the province: "Many of us believe that this historic event is the fruit of much prayer, planning and agonizing discussion which has taken years to accomplish. "

In his sermon at the inauguration, Dr. Carey spoke of "the difficulties encountered in setting up the province," and urged the four dioceses not to allow ethnic factors to divide them. The province's rich and diverse heritage was manifested in the service as portions of the Scriptures were read in Bahasa Malaysia, Tamil, and Mandarin, while the service itself was conducted in English.

During the inauguration service, the Archbishop of Canterbury relinquished his metropolitical authority and presented the Deed of Relinquishment to the new Archbishop. Dr. Carey also handed the Primatial Cross to the Primate saying: "Bishop Tay, I give you this Primatial Cross as a sign of the ministry we share with our Lord Jesus Christ. May His love be your inspiration, His suffering your example, and His humility your authority as Chief Shepherd of His Church in this place."

The new diocese brings together four very different dioceses and many more countries. The Diocese of Kuching is composed of two countries, Sarawak and Brunei Darussalam. The Diocese of Singapore unites Anglican churches in Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Singapore. The Dioceses of West Malaysia and Sabah also bring together different peoples, languages and cultures.

Canon John L. Peterson, Secretary General of the Anglican Communion, was present at the inauguration and afterwards said: "The Anglican Communion looks forward to the strong support this new province can give fellow Anglicans world-wide, especially in crisis situations. The South East Asia resources are bountiful and could be of enormous help to less fortunate areas of the Communion where a strong Christian witness is needed. I welcome their new united presence in the family with open arms."

The Lambeth Conference has since 1898 brought together all the bishops of the Anglican Communion to map out strategies for the churches' involvement every ten years. The Communion presently consists of 37 provinces each under an Archbishop. The head of the 70 million strong worldwide Anglican Communion, the Archbishop of Canterbury, is recognized as the primus inter pares - first among equals and is always the convener of the Lambeth Assembly.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Army Overthrow Comes After Warnings


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Bujumbura - The coup in Burundi on July 25 came despite warnings a day earlier by the United Nations Security Council, the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the European Community and other leading Western nations, that any attempt by the military to seize power from Ntibantunganya's government through illegal means or under any pretext would be resisted.

In Geneva, the World Council of Churches (WCC) linking 330 churches in 100 countries, appealed on July 25 for urgent action by the international community to prevent genocide in Burundi, as the United Nations decided at the same time to pull out non-essential staff.

But thhe Tutsi-led Burundian army moved in and installed former president Pierre Buyoya as Head of State, ousting Hutu president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, the Defence Ministry announced on the national radio. 

At the same time, the tiny central African nation's army closed the country's borders and airports until further notice, the radio quoted Defence Minister Colonel Pirmin Sinzoyiheba saying.

The national assembly, political parties and all political associations were also suspended until further notice, the radio said.

The 46-year-old Buyoya, a former Tutsi officer, previously grabbed power in a military coup in 1987 and served until June 1993 when he handed back peacefully after being defeated in the country first democratic elections by the late President Melchior Ndadaye, later killed in an abortive coup by the Tutsi-led army in October 1993.

The overthrow of Ntibantunganya, 40, had been brewing for several days with the collapse of a fragile power-sharing agreement between the rival ethnic groups aimed at preventing a Rwanda-style genocide in Burundi.

The main opposition party, the Unity for National Progress (UPRONA) had accused the Hutu president of high treason and announced that it was withdrawing its support for him.

Ntibantuganya, who came to power in 1994, fled in fear for his life to the protection of the United States ambassador's residence on the night of July 23, after the mainly Tutsi-led opposition withdrew support for him.

Rumours of a coup were high after UPRONA denounced a September 1994 government convention that is the basis of the country's institutions, providing a power-sharing agreement between the Hutus and minority Tutsis. The accord, set up in an effort to avoid the genocide that left between 500, 000 and one million people dead in neighbouring Rwanda two years ago, had come under increasing pressure with the escalation of ethnic fighting in Burundi.

More than 20 people have been reported killed in the latest wave of violence since the previous weekend slaughter of 330 Tutsis, mainly women and children, an attack blamed on Hutu rebels.

In October 1993, soldiers launched an abortive coup attempt and murdered Ndadaye, the country's first democratically-elected Hutu president, unleashing inter-ethnic blood-letting which claimed more than 50,000 lives.

Although the army had denied on July 25 that it was staging a coup, it made a veiled warning of military intervention in the country's political crisis, saying it "recommended" that politicians avoid creating a constitutional vacuum.

Several senior government ministers and Hutu party officials had also fled to Western embassies or neighbouring countries as political tensions escalated.

Around 2,000 people marched through the streets of the capital of the tiny central African country on the morning of July 25 demanding Ntibantunganya's resignation, but he said in a radio interview there was "no question" of him stepping down.

Tutsi Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo, at loggerheads with Ntibantunganya, had also said that he was prepared to quit because of the "collapse of the consensus built around the current president."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Uganda;
Expert Says Uganda Can Feed Itself And Neighbours


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Kampala - A two-day National Forum on Food Strategy which focused on food security in Uganda, has concluded that Uganda has the ability to feed itself and at the same time export a substantial amount of food to Eastern and Southern Africa.

The July 23 to 24 Forum on Food Strategy was organized by the Ministry of Planning and Economic Development. It was sponsored by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Participants included government officials, the private sector and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) among others. 

The Vietnamese born Dr. Nguyen Tuan, Senior Policy Adviser to the Export Policy Analysis Unit (EPAU) presented a paper in which he asserted that with proper planning, market identification and decimation by all concerned parties, including Uganda's impoverished small scale farmers in this East African country with a population of 17 million people can feed itself and its neighbours.

"This is very possible," says Dr. Nguyen Tuan. The EPAU report emphasised that enhanced production of maize and beans, the regional staples, could reverse poverty on Uganda's small holding and in turn underpin general economic development in the country.

Dr. Nguyen Tuan's presentation observed that with appropriate policies at all levels, Uganda could export one million metric tonnes of maize and beans by the year 2000.

The export of one million tonnes of maize and beans could earn the country US $200 million and possibly overtake coffee as the main export crop. Unlike coffee, the prices of maize and beans would not be subjected to wide fluctuations which often hurt Uganda's small scale producers, because most times these prices are depressed.

Already this year alone, Uganda is selling to Kenya more than $20 million worth of maize with more sales expected due to erratic rainfall in grain producing areas in Kenya's Rift Valley region.

The paper by Dr. Nguyen Tuan advocated trade negotiation between Uganda and its neighbours to encourage them to purchase Uganda surpluses. Kenya alone imports hundreds of thousands of metric tonnes of maize from a variety of international producers annually.

The emphasis on proper market planning was accentuated as a pivotal factor to ensure that Uganda's hard working farmers do not undergo the experience they faced in 1988/89 when they produced too much maize for state-owned Produce Marketing Board. The result was that farmers were abandoned as huge amounts of food went to waste.

Uganda's new Minister in Charge of Agriculture, also the country's Vice- President, Dr. Specioza Wandira Kazibwe has promised to carry out "radical surgery" in the next five years to ensure food security and poverty alleviation in the small holdings. Dr. Wandira was a surgeon by profession before she was appointed to the Cabinet in 1989.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Christian Radio To Launch Series For African Children


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Nairobi- Trans-World Radio (TWR) which broadcasts purely Christian and Christian related programmes from Manzini, Swaziland, will on August 1 launch a special programme on children in difficult situations in Africa.

The programme, to be launched in Kenya, will be aired weekly on the state- owned Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) radio. It is a joint venture between TWR and a German child care organisation, Kindernothilfe. 

According to Mrs Pauline Ngunjiri, the TWR co-ordinator and Mr. Felix Kaloki, Kindernothilfe's project officer, the radio programme, expected to run for one year, will mainly focus on African children in difficult situations such as civil strife, diseases like HIV/AIDS and refugees.

TWR is directly responsible for the actual direction and production of the programme while Kindernothilfe will provide financial support.

Ngunjiri said the programme is special in that it draws attention to specific areas in the life of the African child. "Otherwise we have general issues on children in our normal line-up", she explained.

The official ceremony to mark the beginning of the TWR children's programme will take place at Gatima Primary School, Kawangware, some 20 kilometres from the city centre.

The immediate past head of the (Anglican) Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Archbishop Manasses Kuria will deliver the key address at the function. Since his retirement last year, the Archbishop has devoted his time and efforts to the work of street children through a children's home he established to meet the needs of such needy persons.

A press release announcing the launching of the new programme, says TWR hopes to mobilise children to tune in to the KBC Kiswahili service, network with non-governmental organisations in a bid to solicit relevant information from the ground and explain TWR's impact in Kenya and Africa as a whole.

TWR goes on air in 20 languages through programmes that are developed and produced by African Christians who live and work among their audiences.

The radio station, on air since 1974, has been beaming from short- wave (SM) and medium-wave (MW) transmitters situated in the southern African kingdom of Swaziland.

The Christian station broadcasts its programmes through seven national radio networks based in Kenya, Namibia, Botswana, Senegal, Benin, Zambia and Burundi.

The Nairobi network acts as the regional headquarters and studio, producing programmes for Swaziland and other centres.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Mozambique;
UNHCR Completes Historic Programme In Mozambique


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Maputo - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) ended its largest repatriation and reintegration programme in African history on July 24, when it turned over to the Mozambican government more than 1,500 projects that will be incorporated in the country's long-term development plans.

Sergio Vieira de Mello, UNHCR's Assistant High Commissioner, handed over 1, 571 projects worth $80 million in formal ceremonies attended by Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Leonardo Simao

and representatives of UN agencies and non-governmental organizations, says a UNHCR press release here.

In his remarks, Vieira de Mello praised the governments and people in Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Swaziland, South Africa and Tanzania for their generosity and hospitality towards the more than 1.7 million Mozambican refugees who sought asylum in the 1980s. 

He also congratulated this southern African country for the peace and stability it has achieved so far, and urged Mozambicans to continue to strive for development. He emphasized that the task of reintegration, rehabilitation and development is not yet complete and said UNHCR is committed to support Mozambique.

"In the coming days, I will be visiting the Great Lakes region from where we receive on daily basis, images of horror and terror, very similar to those we used to receive from Mozambique before the general peace agreement. I will bring with me the incentive of peace in Mozambique as the best antidote for the despair brought about by the sombre situation in that region," Vieira de Mello said.

UNHCR's integration projects included rehabilitation and construction of clinics, hospitals, schools and water facilities. The government and its bilateral UN and NGO partners are expected to continue support of the returnee areas as part of Mozambique's sustainable long-term development programme.

Food distribution to returnees, at its peak reaching more than 1 million beneficiaries, had been phased out by April 1996. UNHCR was also involved in the distribution of seeds and agricultural tools.

The repatriation exercise started in 1993 following the signing of a peace accord on October 4, 1992 in Rome that ended 20 years of civil war in Mozambique. More than 1 million people lost their lives and up to 4 million were displaced internally during the conflict.

By October 1995, UNHCR had helped bring home by train, bus, ship and plane some 378,000 Mozambican refugees. Another 1.3 million refugees, mainly from Malawi returned spontaneously to their districts of origin.

UNHCR has closed down most of its 20 field offices in Mozambique--a process that is expected to be completed by September. The UN agency will then maintain a small presence in the capital, Maputo, to handle refugees and asylum seekers in this country.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Algeria;
New Islamic Group Declares Holy War


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Algiers - A new Islamic fundamentalist group has declared holy war on the Algerian government, amid growing evidence of internal dissidence within the four-year Islamic insurgency against the country's military-backed regime.

Calling itself the Islamic Movement for Spreading the Faith and Holy War (MIPJ), the new faction said in a statement issued here on July 22 that it had split from the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) and was declaring a new jihad, or holy war, against the regime.

The hardline GIA, torn by internal divisions, has split into several factions apparently determined to outdo each other in acts of murderous violence against the Algerian government. 

The statement, whose authenticity could not be immediately confirmed, bore the signature of Mustapha Kertali, a former GIA "emir" in the Larba region, a fundamentalist stronghold south of Algiers.

The splits have been accompanied by a new escalation in the violence while Algeria's President Liamine Zeroual resumed consultations on July 15 with the opposition to try to find a way to end the civil war that has ravaged this north-west African country since 1992.

In his statement, Ketali said his group included GIA dissidents and former members of the Armed Islamic Movement (MEI) and the Islamic Front for Armed Holy War (FIDA).

The MIPJ appealed to all "combatant sections" to place themselves under its banner to consolidate forces and pursue the jihad.

It also announced its defiance of the GIA "under whose banner the jihad has become illicit."

Armed Islamic extremists, including the GIA, have been fighting the military-backed Algiers authorities since the cancellation in January 1992 of legislative elections which the now-outlawed FIS was poised to win. Some 50, 000 people are estimated to have died in the conflict.

Twelve people died and 14 were injured on July 20 when a bus carrying employees of a state-owned vehicle company was attacked at Keddara, 50 kilometres south-east of the capital.

Earlier on the same day, five people were killed and 30 injured when a bomb exploded in a cafe in Kilea, west of the capital.

The authenticity of the MIP statement which was sent to several news organizations, has not yet been verified.

A week ago, a statement purportedly issued by the GIA, said it had ousted Djamel Zitouni as its head in a leadership purge.

The statement said Zitouni, alias Abou Abderahmane Amine, who claimed responsibility for the murder of seven French Trappist monks in May, belonged to a faction that had been "manipulated" by the Algerian security.

Official censorship on all matters relating to security makes it difficult to evaluate the true scale of recent violence, and newspapers, threatened with suspension, have generally not published reports on the killing of civilians.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
