Africa News


July 29, 1996


Liberia;
Regional Body Proposes Trial For Liberian Warlords


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Abuja - The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) has endorsed a proposal that envisions possible war crimes trials for Liberia's faction leaders, the head of the organization said here on July 23.

That resolution presented this month by the Organization of African Unity (OAU) called for "imposition of severe sanctions" on the warlords, ECOWAS executive secretary Edouard Benjamin said.

The sanctions should include "the possibility of setting up a war crimes tribunal to try all those who have been involved in the violation of human rights of Liberians," he said in a report presented to a meeting of ECOWAS ministers. 

"The perpetrators of the heinous crimes in Monrovia should not be allowed to continue any longer or go unpunished," said Benjamin, a Guinean national.

The Liberian conflict was a key agenda item of a two-day ECOWAS summit which began here on July 26.

An estimated 150,000 people have died in Liberia since civil war broke out in December 1989. The faction leaders have signed around a dozen peace accords, the latest of them last August in Abuja, Nigeria, only to resume fighting.

"Faction leaders, especially those on the Liberian interim government, have made attempts to rewrite portions of the Abuja Peace Accord," Benjamin said.

Despite the signature of that accord, the military aspects of it, especially disarmament and demobilisation, have remained "largely unimplemented," he added.

Several pledges from international organizations last October during a United Nations conference on

Liberia have gone unfulfilled while ECOWAS member states which pledged additional troops to an African peacekeeping force in Liberia have also failed to keep their word, Benjamin said.

But ECOWAS will continue to urge the international community to provide increased material and financial assistance to the peacekeeping force as well as humanitarian assistance to Liberian refugees in neighbouring countries and displaced persons in Liberia, he added.

Current total arrears of payment by ECOWAS members amount to $52.9 million, noted Benjamin adding that lack of adequate funding is hampering implementation of the community's programmes for Liberia.

The ECOWAS decision comes amid reports that the United Nations and non- governmental aid groups lost $8.2 million worth of motor vehicles during looting that accompanied factional fighting in the Liberian capital.

In a report released on July 22 in the Liberian capital, the UN humanitarian assistance office in Monrovia said 322 vehicles valued at US dollars 4,991,571 were stolen from the UN and its agencies during the looting spree in April and May.

Another 167 vehicles valued at $3,203,226 were stolen from international non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

"It is no secret that the majority of these vehicles are now in the hands of factional leaders and fighters, who despite concrete evidence and repeated appeals by the international community, refused to return them so that we can assist Liberians in need," the UN statement said.

"These vehicles are being used to further fuel factional aspirations and the war effort," it said, adding that only nine of the vehicles have been returned or recovered.

Also looted at a significant cost, the UN said, were many basic humanitarian assistance items such as food and medicines, blankets, well- drilling equipment, chlorine to provide safe drinking water, plastic sheeting for shelter and seeds and tools for agricultural development.

The UN release also complained of "intangible loses of medical, logistical and administrative expertise and know-how which have diminished with the evacuation of the majority of international staff from Liberia during the crisis."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Egypt Hosts Inter-Faith Conference To Boost Islam


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Cairo - A landmark conference gathering Muslim and Christian leaders from 90 countries opened here on July 24, with the aim of countering the Western image of Islam as a religion that preaches violence and intolerance.

The three-day conference was organised by the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs and drew 150 delegates under the banner, Islam and the future of the dialogue between civilisations.

From the Christian side, Pope Shenuda III, head of Egypt's Coptic community, attended along with representatives of churches in Egypt and the rest of the world. 

Also said to be attending was a representative of the Vatican, the seat of the Roman Catholic Church, although his name was not given by organisers, as the Apostolic Nunciature of Cairo was not available for comment to confirm if the Holy See would participate.

Islamic leaders were represented by the secretary general of the Organization of the Islamic Conference Hamed al-Ghabed, the sheikh of Al- Azhar, Egypt's highest Sunni Muslim authority, Mohamed Sayed Tantawi as well as the muftis, or religious leaders, of Bosnia and Jerusalem.

The conference was taking place in a large Cairo hotel and mostly brought together religious affairs legislators.

Iraq, Sudan and Iran were not officially represented and no Jewish organization had been invited to participate.

"Political conditions don't allow it. When a total peace reigns between the Arab states and Israel, then conditions will be right to invite Jewish men of religion," said Egyptian Religious Affairs Minister Hamdi Zaqzuq.

Former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was also among the guest speakers. Addressing the press here a day before the conference opened, the Egyptian Religious Affairs Minister declared that "this conference is a message to the world to show that Islam is a religion of tolerance calling for a peaceful co- existence between people and rejecting extremism and terrorism in all forms."

Egypt has for the past four years faced a violent campaign by Muslim militants demanding the institution of Islamic rule in the country, leaving more than 1,000 dead since 1992.

The conference was set to end on July 27, the day before celebrations for the birthday of Mohammad, Islam's main prophet.

"We want this conference to be a forum for dialogue and not for a fight between different ideologies," Zaqzuq emphasized.

It "will be an opportunity to present to Westerners the real principles of Islam. The judgement of Islam is always linked to extremism, violence and terrorism. It is automatically accused of any act of terrorism in the world before even those responsible are identified," observed the Religious Affairs Minister.

He pointed out that Muslims were neither involved in the "Oklahoma bombing, the incidents in the Tokyo metro not the assassination of (Israeli Prime Minister) Yitzhak Rabin."

"Terrorism is not exclusive to Islam, it is an international phenomenon, even if some who foment it claim to work in its name. On the contrary, Islam is often the victim of aggression," Zaqzuq argued.

"The world has witnessed over the past four years the genocide of Bosnian Muslims by the Serbs. Even though the perpetrators were Christians, no one spoke of Christian extremism. As Muslims, we refuse to follow this style and stick the label of extremism on to Christianity," he added.

The conference, during which some 60 papers were presented, advocates that " dialogue is the only possible future in this age where means of communication have broken down all barriers," Zaqzuq said.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Gays' Association Exhibits At Zimbabwe Book Fair


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Harare - The battle for survival and recognition of the Gay and Lesbian Association of Zimbabwe (GLAZ) is on, and this time they are set to prove a point with the approval of their application to exhibit literature at this year's Zimbabwe International Book Fair (ZIBF) which runs from July 26 to August 3.

GLAZ spokesman Mr. Keith Goddard, told APS that contrary to popular belief and official stance on homosexuality, more homosexuals from both races (black and whites) are coming forward to join the organization.

Opening last year's ZIBF, President Robert Mugabe took a swipe at the gays and lesbians who had booked a stand at the fair to educate the public on their sexual experience. He attacked GLAZ members who believed they had a constitutional right to exist, likening them to immoral people. 

"I find it extremely outrageous and repugnant to my human conscience that such immoral and repulsive organisations, like those of homosexuals who offend both the law of nature and the morals of religious beliefs espoused by our society, should have any advocates in our midst and even elsewhere in the world.

"If we accept homosexuality as a right as is being argued by the association of sodomists and sexual perverts, what moral fibre shall our society even have to deny organized drug addicts, or even those given to bestiality, the rights they might claim and allege they possess under the rubrics of individual freedom and human rights, including the freedom of the press to write, publish and publicize their literature on them?" complained the Zimbabwean Head of State.

Following President Mugabe's, other organizations' and individuals' anger over homosexuality, flowers, instead of people were displayed at the empty stand in 1995.

But this year, the story is a different one as the ZIBF trust has approved the GLAZ's application to exhibit books written to counsel sexually disturbed people.

Mrs. Trish Mbanga, the executive director of ZIBF, who nevertheless refused to comment on President Mugabe's position, confirmed that the homosexuals' association was scheduled to participate at the 1996 fair.

"Their application has been approved. The trust has decided to accept their application. The book fair is governed by the censorship board and we abide by the laws of Zimbabwe. We are confident that there will be nothing offensive that will be displayed," said Mrs. Mbanga.

"As far as we are concerned, we feel we have got to be there (at the fair) and our intentions are that people ought to know what we do and not what the newspapers have been saying that we would display pornographic material. We have been talking to some churches and they have admitted that they don't have the understanding but now they have started talking to us. Some churches are more sympathetic than others and women are more sympathetic than men generally," said Goddard.

Although Goddard claimed more people including those in rural areas were joining the organization, he could not disclose the size of GLAZ. "This is the figure that nobody knows in the world. People are threatened especially in this country, this is why they don't reveal it in public," he added.

Zimbabwe is not the only country in the world where gays are causing problems. In Britain and America gay people have been at loggerheads with their respective authorities.

But in some parts of Europe, the situation is changing favourably towards homosexuals. Iceland recently became the latest European country to legalize homosexual marriages and the International Gay Pride Day has been formed in recognition of homosexuality.

Other countries are Denmark (1989), Norway (1993) and Sweden (1995). But in Zimbabwe, a row erupted soon after the Head of State expressed his sentiments on gays, with the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF) Member of Parliament, Tirivanhu Mudariki, mobilising the youth to " be vigilant" and sniff out immorality.

Even non-constituent MP, Chief Makoni advocated for harsh punishment for homosexuals: "All found practising this evil should have stiff punishment meted out if they are to stop the evil than to send the culprits to prison where they will do it more," said the MP.

Church organizations went out of their way last year to show their support for the president's stance, with the Assemblies of God Africa Church taking to the streets to demonstrate against homosexuality. However nobody knows how the issue will be resolved although there are claims that some churches have established dialogue with gays and lesbians.

Meanwhile, the Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC), has said it will not stop any attempt by delegates to the 8th General Assembly of the World Council of Churches (WCC), to discuss among other things, homosexuality. The conference is scheduled to be held in Harare from September 6 to 23, 1998.

The 1996 Zimbabwe International Book Fair which began last week, has attracted 250 exhibitors and is expected to bring 5,000 trade visitors to see the five tonnes of books on display.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 29, 1996


Science;
Mixed Picture on Population Trends in Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

London - A new survey on population trends in Africa has painted mixed pictures of life in Cote d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast), Morocco and Central African Republic.

The study conducted by the United States-based Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) says data from Cote d'Ivoire has revealed that although women in the country are now bearing less children than in the past, they still have to face the death of their offspring in the same proportion that they did 15 years ago.

According to the authors; "The rise in child mortality observed over the recent years can be explained in part by deterioration of the country's economic situation which affects the most vulnerable groups of the population first."

The DHS study says as soon as newborns stop being breastfed, they are exposed to the risks of under nutrition and infections directly related to the economic, sanitary and environmental conditions. 

"It is also possible that the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) epidemic has resulted in an increase in child mortality: either directly since some children died of the disease or indirectly because, at the household level, children faced a worsening of their living conditions," they added.

The key statistics provided by the country's Enquete Demographique et de Sante says, in 1987, for every 1000 infants aged one month, 41 died before reaching their first birthday. It also showed an increase in the post- neonatal mortality to a level of 47 per 1000. A similar situation was observed regarding child mortality; starting around 1982, for every 1000 children aged one, 57 would die before reaching their fifth birthday. Around 1987, the figure increased to 62 per 1000 and now stands at 67 per 1000.

The authors thus conclude that "the high level of post-neonatal mortality may possibly be due to the fact that a vast majority of infants are not exclusively breastfed as recommended until the first four to six months of life." After this time the child is expected to gradually feed on solid foods.

But mothers in Cote d'Ivoire introduce their infants to other types of liquids or even solid or mushy foods earlier than they should. "These practices put infants at risks of contracting infectious diseases, particularly diarrhoea, for which they receive little, if any, treatment," say the authors.

In Morocco the DHS survey found that there has been a decline in fertility over the past three years. This, the authors of the survey say is due to the fact that there is an increase in the age of first marriage. At 15-19 years of age, nine out of ten women are still single and 60 per cent at 20-24. Overall, 42 per cent of women 15-49 years are not married.

"Fertility decline in Morocco is also a result of the changes in the behaviour of couples towards family size. Among married women, 63 per cent declared wanting no more children. Furthermore, among the 43 per cent of women who declared wanting another child, 26 per cent would rather space their next birth by two or more years," the authors said.

In Central African Republic, the report describes the level of maternal mortality as "very disturbing." There were 948 death of women from maternity related causes for every 100,000 births. In comparison, rates were 652 and 510 respectively in Niger and Senegal.

According to the report, "the under-five mortality rate is high as there were 157 deaths of children under five for every 1,000 live births, or almost one in six children."

Elsewhere in sub-Saharan Africa, rates range from 77 per 1,000 in Zimbabwe, 126 per 1,000 in Cameroon, 187 per 1,000 in Burkina Faso to 318 per 1,000 in Niger, where a low vaccination coverage, under nutrition problems and a weak prenatal care coverage may partly explain this high level of under-five mortality.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Business;
OPIC Signs Protocol For New South Africa Fund


BYLINE: Overseas Private Development Corporation


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Washington, DC - As Vice President Al Gore and South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki looked on, Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) President and CEO Ruth R. Harkin signed an investment fund protocol for a $120 million fund that will make equity investments in South Africa and other nations in Africa's southern region.

"This fund brings the first sizable pool of private capital to southern Africa dedicated to projects that offer new workplace opportunities for the region's black population," Mrs. Harkin said at Commission meetings held at the State Department earlier today. "Experienced fund managers and a focused investment strategy will enable this fund to move quickly to capitalization, with sound investments following shortly." 

Mrs. Harkin signed the protocol with Mr. Maceo Sloan, Chairman of the Durham, North Carolina-based Sloan Financial Group, Inc. The Fund, called the New Africa Opportunity Fund, L.P., is managed by New Africa Advisers (NAA), a subsidiary of Sloan, and is backed with an OPIC investment guaranty. With managed assets of more than $3.5 billion, Sloan is the largest African- American owned investment firm in America.

The management team of NAA includes experienced investment professionals located in Johannesburg, South Africa supported by the Sloan organization in North Carolina. NAA was the first U.S. investment firm to locate an office in Johannesburg in 1992, providing American investors access to African securities markets.

The Fund, one of 23 OPIC-backed investment funds, will focus on the development of businesses which are owned by the region's majority population. It is expected to increase the level of U.S. goods and services flowing to southern Africa and to generate significant regional economic development. In addition, the Fund will support the return to South Africa those American companies that left during the boycott period.

"I am pleased to announce this fund during these important Gore-Mbeki Commission meetings," said Mrs. Harkin who is Vice Co-Chair of the Commission's Trade and Investment Committee. "Investor reaction to historic events in the region have been very positive, and this OPIC-backed fund will make it possible to capitalize on the exciting new opportunities."

In addition to South Africa, the Fund will pursue investments in other southern African counntries including: Angola; Botswana; Lesotho; Malawi; Mozambique; Namibia; Swaziland; Zambia; and Zimbabwe.

All investments made by OPIC-backed funds are reviewed to ensure a positive impact on the U.S. economy and that the projects take steps to protect the host country's environment and respect worker rights. Since 1971, OPIC has supported $84 billion worth of investments that will generate $43 billion in U.S. exports and help to create and support 200,000 jobs.

For further information, contact Allison May Rosen, 202 336-8636.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


383 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Boxers Out Of Olympics


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Atlanta - As Nigeria qualifies to the semi-finals Zambia's hopes for medals at the Atlanta Olympic Games dwindled to three after two more boxers were beaten on Sunday.

Only three athletes, 400 metres hurdler Sam Matete, Steeplechaser Godfrey Siamusiye and 5,000 metres specialist Frank Nkandu, remain in contention for medals.

As for the boxers, Flyweight Borniface Mukuka lost 13-4 on points to Albert Pakeev of Russia while Light Welterweight Davis Mwale was outpunched by Bolat Niyazymbet of Kazakstan, 11-3 in the second round of their respective divisions. 

The left-handed Pakeev had Mukuka in trouble right from the start with his southpaw style and won easily. Mwale was in similar trouble with Niyazymbet although he tried to put a spirited fight.

Matete, the top favourite was expected to take to the track at about midday on Monday while Siamusiye was expected to race in the 3,000 steepchase first round later in the evening.

With the Games starting to recover from the explosion that rocked the Olympic Park on Saturday, track and field events took centre stage on Sunday with sensational Carl Lewis barely making it to the finals of the long jump, the only event he is taking part in.

Lewis' last leap was the best of the day, and sent an ominous warning to his competitors: Each time he has led after the qualifying round, he's won Olympic gold.

A victory on Monday night would give Lewis his ninth gold medal and fourth straight in the long jump, tying him with discus thrower Al Oerter as the only Americans to win gold in four straight Olympics.

The other closely watched American, Michael Johnson , jogged the final 30 metres in the 400 semifinals, easily winning his heat in 44.59 seconds.

World-record holder Butch Reynolds failed to qualify for Monday's final when he fell with a hamstring injury.

In soccer, Brazil, which has never won an Olympic gold medal in men's soccer despite four World Cup titles, moved a step closer to ending that drought on Sunday. The Brazilians broke a 1-1 halftime stalemate to defeat Ghana, 4-2.

Brazil advances to the semifinals on Wednesday where it will have a rematch with Nigeria, a team it defeated in Group D play, 1-0.

In the other quarterfinal, Nigeria defeated Mexico 2-0 in a game in which Nigerian goalkeeper Joseph Osu made incredible diving stops. Augustine Okocha scored both goals for Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sudan;
US Congress To Aid Opposition Controlled Areas In Sudan


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

...London - Since coming to power in a coup d'etat in 1989, the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime in Khartoum has been barred from receiving United States economic development aid because, first, it overthrew a democratic government and, secondly, it became a sponsor of international terrorism. That bar has applied to the whole of Sudan, even those areas under the control of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). Now, however, the situation is about to change thanks to a re-evaluation of the situation in Sudan by the US Congress.

A recent amendment to the USAID Appropriation Bill for 1997 has exempted the SPLA controlled areas of the South, the Nuba Mountains and the Ingessina Hills, from the bar on US development aid. These areas will now receive direct USAID assistance for "capacity building", for instance. Such funds that are made available will be directed through non-governmental organisations (NGOs) operating in the SPLA controlled areas. 

The congressional appropriations committee has made it clear that no aid will be made available to the areas under the control of military factions who have allied themselves with the NIF regime. Passed as part the 1997 US Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Programmes Appropriations Bill on 29 May, the full text says:

"The Committee authorizes AID to use development and disaster assistance funds for capacity building purposes in areas of Southern Sudan outside the control of the government of Sudan. The committee strongly encourages AID to make funds from these accounts available to non-governmental organizations for this purpose. The committee expects that these funds will not be used in areas controlled by Southern factions that have and continue to cooperate with the government of Sudan."

Scope for Real Help

Passage of the bill does not necessarily mean that the needs of Southern Sudan will be fully met. While there are many US and foreign NGOs working in the SPLA controlled areas, some of these have not always seen their role as one of assisting the economic and social development of the South, but merely as delivering relief. Co-operation between the NGOs and the local communities has often been poor.

In the past there has been confusion between international and indigenous NGOs. Setting up an NGO in the South has often meant setting up an Arab faction alongside it. The USAID will now only go to areas outside of Khartoum's control and this should help avoid any future confusion. It should not be difficult for the USAID personnel to establish two basic criteria under which development aid will flow to the SPLA controlled areas. Firstly, territorial control will have to be fully established. That is crucial to the security of the NGO personnel in the field. Secondly, the people who will benefit from the aid need to be identified.

Showing Leadership

The provision of USAID is an important step towards the future development of the war affected parts of Sudan. It may even become a catalyst in the search for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

By passing this amendment to the aid bill, the United States Congress has once again shown itself as a leader of the world. This is not the first time the US Congress has led the way on matters concerning the situation in Sudan. In October 1993, on the invitation of the then chairman of the House of Representatives Sub-committee on Africa, Congressman Harry Johnston, the leaders of Southern Sudan, Dr John Garang and Riek Machar, signed the historic document which unleashed the current political agenda on Self- determination. Mr. Johnston and another friend of Sudan, Congressman Frank Wolf of Virginia, were no doubt instrumental in the exemption of the SPLA controlled areas from the ban on US aid to Sudan.

While this publication welcomes the move to provide the SPLA controlled areas of the country with aid through the NGOs, we are concerned that some of this aid will also be provided to the UN agencies. We fear that the UN agencies have always acted only on the bidding of the Khartoum regime. They have, for instance, failed to deliver aid to the Nuba Mountains when they know there is a serious need there. We would urge the USAID to confine its aid to Southern Sudan to the NGOs only and to exclude the UN.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sudan;
Deteriorating Economy In Sudan Could Spark Changes


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

London - In all the recent changes of government in Sudan from civilian to military and vice versa, the deterioration of the national economy and its direct effect on the lives of ordinary people has been the main spark for change. The decline in the national economy may yet prove to be the downfall of the current National Islamic Front (NIF) regime. Today the economy has not merely worsened, it has collapsed into a state of bankruptcy. Add the ongoing civil war in the South, another traditional cause of defeat for regimes in Khartoum, and the picture is truly bleak for the NIF regime.

The NIF regime has been in charge of the national economy for seven years and has passed at least six annual budgets. It cannot escape responsibility for the economic crisis now facing the country. The regime passed its sixth annual budget in January this year. Six months on , that budget has fallen by the wayside due to chronic overspending and mismanagement of the economy.

Following the sham elections in March, there is a new parliament and a new minister of finance. As a result, the condition of the national economy has been at the forefront of discussion. Even the regime's own statistics, which can hardly be relied upon, provide a frightening assessment of the economy. 

Some Basic Facts

Debate during May and June centred upon the State of the Nation address given by the newly elected president, Lieutenant General Omer Hassan El Beshir. In a reference to the economy, he stated that his regime would act to alleviate the economic hardship of the ordinary Sudanese citizen.

The actions of his new minister of finance since taking office have had the opposite effect. Taxation has more than doubled and subsidies have been removed from many staple commmodities, without any regard to the incomes of the most vulnerable members of society.

The minister's reforms were hurried through without recourse to discussion and debate in the parliament. There was plenty of consternation in NIF circles because of the discrepancy between El Beshir's address and the minister's actions. However, both El Beshir and the speaker of the parliament and NIF political mentor, Dr Hassan Abdulla El Turabi, have given their support to the new measures.

Lieutenant General El Beshir said that the measures were necessary to preserve the economy and should be supported. He said that the measures would only adversely effect the lower one third of the population which could be remedied by other measures. He did not specify what these might be. El Beshir added that more than seventy percent of the population was wealthy enough to cushion the impact of the new measures. He was implying that the two thirds who live in the North could withstand the measures whilst the one third who live in the South did not matter! Despite the regime's claims to have created enough wealth in the North over the past seven years to make every individual wealthy, the truth of the matter is that select group of NIF supporters have been allowed to convert national assets into private wealth for their own benefit. The ordinary citizen is considerably worse off today than he was in June 1989.

Turabi Pledges Support

For his part in the debate, Dr Hassan Abdalla El Turabi informed the members of parliament that they had neither the power nor the right to question the measures of the minister of finance. For the time being, he has had his way and has controlled the parliament as a speaker is meant to. However, the hidden powers behind Constitutional Order Number Thirteen, which created the parliament and which was reportedly drafted by El Turabi and force upon El Beshir, allows the parliament to impeach the president and to question and sanction his ministers. In such an eventuality, the speaker of the parliament would succeed the president. Perhaps Dr El Turabi is reining in the power of the parliament at present, in expectation of a more opportune moment to exercise these hidden powers.

Members of parliament did discuss the minister of finance's statement and contrasted it with an earlier address of President El Beshir. Apparently, the minister of finance told the parliament that if the members wished to receive their salaries regularly, then fresh funds would have to be raised by the measures he is implementing.

The Sudanese public has not proved to be as compliant as the parliament. Many individuals are resisting the new measures by refusing to pay the additional taxes and boycotting certain goods in the market.

Types of Measures

The new economic measures include: new taxation; the curtailment of any new public expenditure; a freeze in on salary increases; and price rises on certain basic commodities. Sugar is to increase from L250 Sudanese pounds per kilogram to L500, for instance. That is the state controlled price at which citizens can buy their monthly ration of one kilo per family. The free market price has risen from L600 Sudanese pounds per kilogram to L980. Bread has increased from L50 per loaf to L80. Petrol has risen from L1,700 per litre to L2,500. Diesel fuel has gone up from L300 per litre to L1,200.

Deficit Spending

The new measures are intended to check the deficit spending of the regime. The state has been printing money without earning any income because there are no exports. State borrowing from the central bank is supposed to be regulated and controlled by law. Ceilings for borrowing are set at the time of the budget and should not be altered without due process. The budget in January set the ceiling at nine billion Sudanese pounds. By the beginning of May that figure had been overspent and fallen by the wayside. By the end of the year, it is expected that the borrowing will have risen to L300 billion. In January, the total amount of money permitted to circulate in the economy was said to be L17 billion. By the end of May more than L600 billion had been printed by the state.

In addition to the measures outlined above, the regime has begun to attack its own system of political and constitutional decentralisation. The Islamic federal system has created over twenty-five regions and over sixty-five provinces. These political entities have no taxation powers of their own. All taxation powers will now be concentrated in the central ministry of finance. The finances of all public institutions will also be operated from that ministry.

In Southern Sudan, where the regime must finance the ongoing war, the situation of state finances is desperate. The military has not been paid for months. The so-called popular support for the military, in the form of food and supplies, including trucks, could not be transported to the South because of the lack of fuel. There is an undeclared mutiny among the regime's troops in the South. Most have been in Southern Sudan for at least five years when they were promised only six months' tour of duty. They no longer want to fight and are asking to be returned to the North. The regime has no troop replacements for them and even if there were troops, the logistics for transport and supplying them is a real nightmare for the regime. But above all, there are the financial problems and the NIF regime has all but declared itself totally bankrupt.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Business;
Gambia Eyes Saudi Investment in Key Sectors


BYLINE: M. Ghazafar Ali Khan, Daily Observer (Banjul)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Banjul - In a move to bolster bilateral commercial ties, The Gambia is seeking cooperation from Saudi Arabia especially in the agricultural and natural resources sectors with a comprehensive package of proposals discussed with the officials of the Riyadh Chamber of Commerce and Industry (RCCI) in Riyadh.

The RCCI Agriculture Committee headed by Shihab Al Suweilem discussed the proposals. The talks will pave the future course of cooperation between the Kingdom and The Gambia. The Gambian side was led by the Gambian Ambassador Baba A. Drammeh. 

Referring to the growing bilateral relations between the two countries, Ambassador Drammeh pointed out that the Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank (IDB) has recently extended financial assistance of $3.5 million to set up four schools in his country. The envoy said that several infrastructure projects worth millions of dollars had been submitted to the Saudi Fund for Development (SFD). These projects include building a university in Banjul, setting up an international conference facility and building road networks in the rural areas as well as in the coastal areas. Referring to short and medium-term prospects for Saudi investors in the Gambian agricultural and natural resources sectors, Ambassador Drammeh pointed out that his country provides added incentives to foreign investors including profit repatriation, allocation of land, availability of foreign exchange, etc.

Several areas of potential investment for Saudi and Gulf nationals include fisheries, livestock production, forestry, wildlife and tourism. The horticulture in The Gambia is favored with abundant underground water reserves, fertile land, relatively low labour costs and proximity to Western markets.

On the question of the conditions of Gambian Muslims, Drammeh lauded the role of Arab world saying that a massive mosque built at government cost was inaugurated by the Imam and Khateeb of the Haram Mosque in Makkah, Sheikh Saleh Humeid, recently.

Issue cover date: July 10, 1996

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Zambian Runner Blazes To Semis


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Atlanta - Commonwealth and Zambia 400 metres hurdles Champion Samuel Matete blazed through to the semifinals of the Olympic Games with a sensational run yesterday ( Monday) at Atlanta's Olympic Stadium.

Wearing an all black outfit with the Zambian colours across his chest, Matete won his race in 48.23 seconds, the best 400 metre hurdles time so far at this year's Olympics. 

The former world champion showed how well prepared he is right from the starting blocks, gliding easily over the first two hurdles. Matete was so smooth that he did not miss a single step as he began his quest for the only title he has not won.

Matete failed to win a medal at the Barcelona Olympic Games in 1992 after he was disqualified on a controversial call, alleging that he knocked his hurdles onto the path of another runner.

This time it was ballet on track as Matete was perfect, barely touching the ground, let alone the hurdles. He looked focused and well placed throughout the race.

Although known more as a powerful finisher than a powerful starter, Matete took charge of the race right from the begining, slowing down a little bit around the 200 metres leg but kicking up speed on the home stretch.

"This is just one race, I have two more to run before I can celebrate," Matete , who stands as Zambia's major Gold medal hopeful, said after the race as the more than 80,000 spectators cheered him on.

Matete's semifinal race is set for tomorrow at 7 p.m. (U.S.time ) when he faces his greatest rival, American Derrick Adkins who also qualified for the 400 metre hurdles semifinal.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Centennial Park Reopens


BYLINE: Charles Katongo of the Zambia Daily Mail, Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Atlanta - Centennial Olympic park, Atlanta's Olympic fans' land mark where two people died after a pipe bomb blast on Saturday morning opened to the public on Tuesday morning with tens of thousands of faithful fans attending the memorial service which was conducted by Co-Chairman of the Atlanta Committee for Olympic Games(ACOG) Andrew Young.

Amid increased tight security which included hand searching of bags and added electronic surveillance, the fans paid homage to the deceased in a moving sermon which was punctuated with hymns as the fans bowed their heads in memory of the two lives lost when disaster struck the park built specifically to celebrate the games. Nita Whitaker and Georgia mass choir also performed the "power of the dream". 

The fans, who had to wait for three agonising days for the park to reopen following its closure on Saturday morning were in full swing, once again rushing into the water fountain of rings to "annoint themselves with the renewal spirit" and possibly cool themselves down as they awaited the park's momentum to return to full speed.

Almost all the fans interviewed maintained that they had no misgivings about returning to the park, adding that the increased security measures did not affect their free movement in the park.

"This is one place in the town of Atlanta where one can unwind after a hectic day watching the games. It is such a wonderful place and it would have been a shame to miss it just like that. Iam glad it is open again"said one fan from Italy.

After trumpeter Wynton Marsalis performed "just a closer walk with thee", Billy Payne, ACOG president addressed the crowd. He later declared the park open as the fountain of Rings were turned on much to the amusement of the fans who broke out into a thunderous applause.

In attendance was the IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch and other celebrities including US Olympian Janet Evans. The families of the victims were all seated in the front rows and the fans held a moment of silence breaking out into the funfare which they had missed for three days.

The entertainment programme saw famous Ladysmith Black Mambazo taking the At&t stage first with Angelique Kidjo coming on at 13.00 hours local time.The mood in the park was that of contentment,as all revellers mingled and moved freely in a place which was envisioned as a central gathering area for the thousands of visitors expected to come to the city during the summer of 1996, and later for future generations to enjoy.

This is the same park whose place in the history of the Olympic games was assured, though in a very sad manner , when a misguided person placed a pipe bomb which went off when almost 50,000 people were enjoying themselves, killing two and injuring 110 others. FBI investigations into the blast are still continuing.

NOTE: Charles Katongo, a reporter for the Zambia Daily Mail, is participating in the International Journalists Coverage Program, sponsored by The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.

Business;
Currencies - CFA Maintains Stability


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 93 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The CFA, riding on the back of a strong French franc, maintained last week's gains, to open on Tuesday at the nominal rate of 501.7 to the U.S. dollar, from 501.8 on the same day last week.

In Dakar on Tuesday, the currency traded at 487 (buying) amd 517 (selling) to one greenback. Last week, the rates in the Senegalese capital were 490 (buying) and 520 (selling) for one dollar.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Business;
Kenya Stockmarket Records Huge Turnover


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - There was improved activity at the trading floor of the Nairobi stock exchange (NSE) during the week, with the turnover rising to shs 63 million Kenya shillings compared to the 50 million shillings in the previous week. (1 U.S dollar = 57 shs).

The number of shares traded improved to 1.9 million from 1.7 million.

The NSE index lost 14.11 points to close at 3134.99. The plantations sector moved 100,000 shares, representing 5 percent of the week's traded volume. 

REA vipingo traded 88,000 shares at between 11.20 and 11.80 shillings. Kapchorua dealt 5,500 shares at 65 shilings cum dividend down from 116 shillings the previous week.

Commercial and services sector traded 400,000 shares which accounted for 21 percent of the week's volume. Kenya Airways traded 331,000 shares at between 11.20 and 12 shillings. Nation Printers and Publishers stabled at 101 shillings after trading 31,000 shares.

The financial sector traded 1.2 million shares which represented 57 percent of the week's trading. The National Bank of Kenya moved 458,000 shares at prices fluctuating at between 15.20 and 16.50 shillings.

The housing finance company of Kenya moved 213,000 shares traded at between 24 and 26.50 shillings, while the Barclays Bank rose to 121 shillings from 112, but slipped to 110 shillings by the close of the business on Friday.

Meanwhile, the Kenya government has gazetted a new Central Bank bill that seeks to give the bank's governor security of tenure and at the same time limit government borrowing from the financial institution in order to curb inflation.

The Central Bank of Kenya amendment bill 1996, to be tabled in parliament, proposes substantial amendments to the bank to ensure that it effectively controls expansion in money supply thereby containing inflationary pressures.

The bill will also limit net credit to the government from the bank to 5 percent of the level of ordinary revenue in the latest audited accounts of the governments.

The proposed amendments seek to empower the bank to, among others, formulate and implement foreign exchange policy, hold and manage its foreign exchange reserves, licence and supervise authorised dealers, and promote the smooth operation of payments.

The bill also restricts the period all directors, including the governor and deputy governor, can serve in the board to only two terms, while retaining each term at four years.

These changes, which are in line with the economic reforms for the 1996- 1998 period, are meant to give the bank more independence in managing monetary policy and to pursue an appropriate monetary policy at all times in order to ensure general price levels remain stable.

To enhance accountability, the bill proposes that the Central Bank submits monetary policy statements every six months to the government, containing a review and assessment of the implementation of the monetary policies.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Business;
Oil Company Shares Rally On the Nigerian Stock Market


BYLINE: Paul Okolo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Oil company shares rallied back to the top on the Nigerian stock exchange last week after about a month of lethargy.

Investors' interest in them soared on the impressive full year trading result of one leading oil marketer, while others advanced on investors positive sentiment. 

African Petroleum posted an impressive result for the year ended Dec. 31, 1995, lifting its share to 28.03 naira, a 1.33 naira gain (1 U.S. dollar = 81 naira).

The sector had been dull for some weeks due to the lower than expected quarterly results announced which sent investors looking to other sectors.

One analyst said investors were returning after soaking in the effect of the oil company results and realising that the falling profitability was temporary.

It is only a matter of time before oil firms return to the top," a stockbroker told PANA.

Losses were recorded mainly by the brewing concerns as well as Nigerian Tobacco Company whose performances have fallen below par recently.

However, food shares remained strongly in demand, seeing Nigerian Bottling Company, Cadbury, the flour millers and Union Dicon salt appreciating.

The all-share index which opened at 5,843.99 rose in the week by 59.31 points to 5,878.44. This compares with 24.86 points in the preceding week.

Meanwhile, the number of equities quoted on the exchange increased to 182 with the listing of the shares of Longman Nigeria Plc, a publishing firm.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Flight Service To Link Harare And Malaysia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LANGKAWI, Malaysia (PANA) - Malaysian airlines will introduce a flight service between Harare and Kuala Lumpur before the end of this year, following an agreement reached between the two countries last week.

Zimbabwe's minister of transport and energy, Simon Khaya Moyo said in an interview in Malaysia on Monday that air services between Zimbabwe and Malaysia would be economically beneficial to both countries. 

Moyo said during his week-long visit to Kuala Lumpur, he agreed with his Malaysian counterpart, Ling Sik, to let the two countries airlines establish flight services between them.

"We have finalised the agreement between the two countries, and the Malaysian airline will be the first to introduce air services. At a later date Zimbabwe will reciprocate," Moyo said.

He expressed confidence that the air route to Kuala Lumpur would be viable for Zimbabwe, as it would be used by tourists from the Asian country.

Moyo, who came to Malaysia to participate in the Air Services Exhibition attended by 17 countries and 110 aviation companies, said the government would move fast on the construction of a new airport to enable the country to cope with the anticipated increase in tourist arrivals.

Because of the importance of the new airport to the Zimbabwean economy, Moyo said he visited Malaysia's second 3.05-billion-dollar airport under construction to learn from them.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Portugal Airlines Suspends Harare Service


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Portugal's national airline, TAP, Tuesday announced the temporary suspension in October of its flights to and from Zimbabwe.

In a statement, the airline said it was reducing its operations from the beginning of the European winter period as an economic measure and to enable it to fulfill its commitments to the European Union. 

An airline spokesperson emphasized that the suspension would be temporary, with service expected to resume as soon as the "present circumstances necessitating the suspension had changed".

The last northbound service from Harare, he said, would be on October 6, while the last inward flight would be Oct. 20. "Tickets already issued and those between now and Oct. 6 for travel out of Harare, up to and including travel Oct. 6, will be fully honoured," he said.

He noted that passengers from Harare on return flights will be routed on TAP flights to Johannesburg, with onwards connections to Harare.

LANGUAGE: English

394 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Sudan;
Khartoum Zoo Lion Dies Before Breakfast


BYLINE: Yahya el Hassan, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - A lion collapsed and died in a Khartoum zoo just as it was about to devour its daily breakfast of veal meat.

The director of the zoo's natural history museum, Dr al-ajiba al Haj Ali told the official newspaper, al-Sudan al Hadeith (Modern Sudan) Tuesday that a group of veterinarians who inspected the liver of the dead lion established that its death was caused by viral jaundice.

The death of the lion called "Lu'Lu'a" (pearl in Arabic) was "not only a loss for the visitors or the zoo, it is a loss for the workers who treated it as one of their family," the Sudanese official said. 

The lion was placed in the zoo after it was confiscated from a western relief official living in a luxurious residential area in Khartoum. The relief worker apparently brought it from game-rich southern Sudan.

The unidentified relief official used to keep a lion and a lionness but the female was electrocuted on a rainy day.

Since the death of its partner, Lu'Lu'a used to sleep beside its owner until neighbors complained of the presence of a lion. The animal was then confiscated and placed in the Khartoum zoo last year.

Khartoum zoo was created during British colonial rule (1900-1956). It served as a transit point for wild animals destined for Europe.

The sanctuary was located in the Mogran area in central Khartoum overlooking the Blue Nile and a few meters from the convergence point with the White Nile.

However, the current government of Gen. Omar el Bashir decided to dismantle the zoo and distribute the animals to the various states.

However, the big animals, particulary the rhinos, giraffes and elephants were moved to a new zoo erected a few blocks to the south-west of the old one.

The government wanted to use the commercially attractive area, that used to be occupied by the zoo, for the construction of an international hotel and supermarkets. The move was also meant to ease pressure on the area, which is frequented by hundreds of families each holiday and causing traffic jams and sometimes incidents.

But, a few months after the animals were transfered to a poorly vegetated zoo, elephants and monkeys died.

Lu'lu'a was the last in the list of animals that have been dying at Khartoum's new zoo.

Nonetheless, even in his death, Lu'lu'a remains useful. His body will be mumified, filled with hay and school children will come to learn something about natural history and animals.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Ethiopia;
Trial Of Mengistu's Men Adjourned for Two months


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The trial of 71 senior officials who served under former Ethiopian dictator, Mengistu Haile Mariam, was Tuesday adjourned for two months.

The court hearing the case of the officials, accused of murder and crimes against humanity, will resume Oct. 1, 1996.

Before the case was adjourned, a former inmate related a horror story about the callousness and cruelty of the Mengistu's military regime, also known as " Derg", during the "Red Terror" campaign, which it unleashed against its perceived enemies between 1976-77. 

He told the court how 16 fellow immates heard their names broadcast over the state radio early one morning in October 1976, as having been "executed" for anti-revolutionary activities. They were summoned about 15 minutes later to be taken away by armed soldiers for the "real" execution elsewhere.

Alemneh Gessesse, 47, formerly a labour organiser, said he was thrown into jail after he was accused of opposing the Derg and advocating for a democratically elected government.

He was testifying before the central high court of Addis Ababa in the case of 71 former members of the Derg on charges of genocide and crimes aganist humanity.

Twenty-five of them are being tried in abstentia, including Mengistu Haile Mariam, who now lives in exile in Zimbabwe in May 1991, a few days before the collapse of his regime.

The 46 defendats appearing before the court have all pleaded not guilty to the charges of genocide and crimes against humanity, which carry the death sentence under the 1957 Ethiopian penal code.

Gessesse further related three incidents between October 1976 and May 1977 at which he saw numerous prisoners taken, never to return.

The "Red Terror" campaign was believed to have been launched in Addis Ababa in October 1976 after the first attempt on the life of Mengistu. The Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Party was blamed for it.

Three other witnesses also testified Tuesday explaining to the court how their close relatives were arrested by armed men at night and had their homes searched, apparently for anti-Derg pamphlets.

To this day, the witnesses said, they never learned what had happened to their loved ones or why they were arrested.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


396 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


United States and Africa;
Peace Corps To Teach In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The United States peace corps is planning to send 30 volunteers in South Africa early next year to train rural primary schoolteachers.

The American aid agency has confirmed that, while slashing programs elsewhere in Southern Africa, it remains ready assist South Africa in overcoming the educational crisis it is facing. 

The new peace corps director in South Africa, Earl Yates, confirmed that the volunteers will offer training to teachers and administrators at primary schools in certain rural areas where the problem is most severe.

Should this program prove successful, another team of 30 volunteers would be sent to South Africa in October next year, said Yates. Operations would then be expanded to include training in health and environmental issues.

The United States has channelled 600 million dollars in aid into South Africa since the historic April 1994 elections, making it the top sub-Saharan recipient of American aid.

This is generally attributed to American enthusiasm for a successful South African transition from minority rule to rule democracy.

The American peace corps has a budget of 218 million U.S dollars this year. It has more than 600 volunteers operating in such African countries as Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Namibia, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

However, this figure is expected to drop to about 400 when the peace corps withdraws from Botswana later this year, and from Swaziland in 1998.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 30, 1996


Burundi;
Classes Resume In Burundian Schools


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Lectures have resumed at the university and secondary schools all over Burundi after being stopped for several weeks, as students staged demonstrations aimed at forcing the resignation of President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, who was replaced last Thursday by Maj. Pierre Buyoya.

At the Mutanga campus, north of Bujumbura, lecture halls were filled with students. 

Habonimana Jacques, a young medical student, said nothing could prevent him from completing the academic year "since our objective of booting out the inept government and restore peace in the country has been achieved."

The chairman of the "Rumuri" students association, Nyandwi Oscar, said that even if classes have resumed, "we are not going to tone down our vigilance or let the new president (Major Pierre Buyoya) to do whatever he likes".

He added: "For us, the principle is simple: we give confidence, but at the same time we check what is going on."

On the risk of the university getting too involved in politics, Myandwi said that "in the current state of government inaction and open warfare in Burundi, it is hardly acceptable that the academic community remain inactive or stay away from the fray since its components are within shooting range of the guns just like all other citizens".

Three quarters of high schools visited by the, PANA Correspondent

Tuesday morning in Bujumbura have resumed classes, one month before the end of the academic year.

The Gitega Institute of Agricultural Science in central Burundi remained closed Tuesday, because six people were killed there Sunday night during clashes between people from the majority Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 30, 1996


Burundi;
Five African Presidents to Meet Over Burundi


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Five African presidents are scheduled to meet Wednesday to discuss the situation in Burundi, where the legitimate head of state has been replaced by a military-installed leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya.

The presidents are from the neighboring countries of Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. They will meet in Arusha, northern Tanzania.

The secretary general of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), Salim Ahmed Salim, will also attend the summit.

Salim left Addis Ababa Tuesday for the summit, which has been summoned by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, who has been mediating in Burundi's ethnic-related political crisis.

The OAU condemned last Thursday's coup d'etat against President Sylivestre Ntibantunganya.

The condemnation was issued the same day by its body on conflict management, which held an urgent meeting at ambassadorial level in Addis Ababa.

It threatened sanctions against any regime taking power by force in the troubled central African state.

The OAU body also urged member states and the international community to isolate any such regime and to impose sanctions against it.

Further, it backed the proposal by the United Nations secretary general for a multinational force for "humanitarian intervention" in Burundi to avert further bloodletting between the majority Hutu and Tutsi communities in the country.

The two ethnic groups have been carrying out mutual revenge killings since the assassination of the democratically-elected Hutu President Melchior Ndadaye Oct.21, 1993.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Soccer Group Speaks Out On Trainer


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Former national team assistant trainer Jones Chilengi has warned the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) against falling to the idea of recalling veteran trainer Fred Mwila.

Chilengi, who now coaches Zimbabwe premier side, Hwange United, insisted that he was personally against the coming back of Mwila and veteran Profund Warriors coach Boniface Simutowe because of their bad relations with national team players.

"Having worked with both Mwila and Simutowe, I don't think this is the right time to call them to the national team because none of the players like them and if the coaches are not liked by players, how can we expect a team to win," observed the former Zamsure coach, who however described Mwila and Simutowe as being among the best in Africa. 

According to Chilengi, Zambia failed to win the Africa Cup because of the same problems where FAZ officials decided to recall Simutowe and City of Lusaka's Fred Nasilele who were not in good terms with other members of the team.

"We had our best chance of winning the Africa Cup but because some people wanted to show they were in big positions, they messed up things by taking Simutowe to the team when they knew most players were not free with him, we must now learn from the past and achieve a double qualification,"

Recently, FAZ officials announced they will round up all Zambian coaches based outside and those within to help in the preparations.

Asked if he would consider coming back to assist the national team, Chilengi said he could not make it as he was still under contract with the Zimbabwe's Hwange Untied.

"Zambia will always remain my country but as at now, I am still on contract and as such I can not come back to work here. But still I feel very strongly on the Zambian national team," said the coach in an interview at Woodlands Stadium last Sunday when he came for a short stay in the country.

July 31, 1996


Arts;
(DOUCMENT) Ghanaian Drummer and Dancer To Perform in US


BYLINE: Hayor Dance Company


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

East Lansing - Professional Drummer and Dancer, Francis Kofi, direct from Ghana, West Africa will appear in a special performance in East Lansing, MI.

The performance takes place on Saturday, August 10, 1996, 6 p.m. - 10 p.m. at the Wesley Foundation/MSU Kiononia Auditorium, 1118 S. Harrison Rd., East Lansing, MI (behind Trowbridge Shoprite, parking located in back of University United Methodist Chruch 1120 S. Harrison). 

An authentic Ghanaian dinner will be served promptly at 6:30p.m., a short lecture and the performance begins at 8:00p.m.

For tickets and information, contact Francis Kofi at 517 332-3490.

Francis Kofi is the Artistic Director for the Hayor Dance Company in Ghana, West Africa. This fund raiser is intended to accomplish two things: to increase the awareness of traditional Ghanaian drumming and dancing and to insure the continuance of such artistic forms for the generations of the next millennium.

Zambia;
Netherlands To Help With Development Projects In Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Royal Netherlands Embassy has expressed willingness to fund development projects in the copper mining town of Chingola.

Acting Town Clerk, Patrick Teleshi, revealed this at a District Development Cordinating Committee meeting that the embassy was ready to fund the projects under the DDCC. 

He explained that even if the Netherlands Embassy was ready to fund such projects which are also funded through the constituency development funds money from either could be used for other projects.

There was debate on Chawama Clinic which needed roofing and a mortuary. One committee member said the clinic needed roofing on the the new wing to deconjest the old wing.

The money needed for roofing is between K40 million and K50 million. The members felt the new wing was too costly as such it was better to build a mortuary to alleviate problems for the people in the area immediately and most members felt people had fifficulties in transporting corpses to and from Nchanga North Hospital mortuary nd onwards to the cemetery.

It was revealed that the Engineering Institution of Zambia, Chingola Branch, had promised to raise funds for the mortuary.

But the district director of health, Dr. Simwanza Chila said she had not been contacted by EIZ on the matter.

402 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Southern Africa;
Commander Tells Generals To Communicate On Personal Level


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Direct communication at an interpersonal level among defence commanders within the Southern African region is an inevitable pre-requisite to regional peace and stability, Zambia Army commander, Lt-General Nobby Simbeye has said.

He was speaking at the official opening of the second operations Sub-sub Committee five days conference of the Interstate Defence and Security Committee (ISDSC) held at Inter-continental Hotel in Lusaka.

General Simbeye noted that attendance of regional meetings at Sub-sub Committee level had tremendously improved. He also hailed defence forces in the region for their commitment and involvement. 

"This is a positive development which has demonstrated the commitment by defence forces in the region which is a pre-requisite to peace and stability." he said.

The purpose of the meeting attended by eleven member states, except Tanzania, was to co-ordinate, compile, approve and finally adopt the reports from the various Sub-sub committees for presentation to the defence chiefs at a date yet to be decided.

Chairman of the Conference, Major-General Gibson Kamanga from the Malawi Army was thrilled with the spirit of co-operation and excellent response exibited by ISDSC member states who attended the meeting.

The first meeting was held in Malawi, in May, to pursue and inform various Sub-sub committees to investigate ISDSC involvement into areas of concern in the region.

Amoung the recommendations and resolutions made prominent was the need for a mechanism for combating action against coup plotters. General Simbeye urged the participants to come up with practical solutions on the same.

Other such areas of concern include the establishment of a satellite telecommunications system, inauguration of the regional committee for disaster preparedness, management and resoultions of regional conflicts.

General Simbeye also urged the meeting to consider the establishment of a combined operations command centre where command and communication control, intellegence, information and planning will be carried out.

He also emphasised that bilateral and multilateral agreements are necessary for success in times of sudden disaster.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 31, 1996


Southern Africa;
Southern African Generals Meet


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - Generals from southern African states have been meeting in Lusaka this week to co-ordinate and investigate Interstate Defence and Security Committee (ISDSC) involvement into areas of concern in the region.

The ISDSC conference is being attended by South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Malawi, Namibia, Swaziland, Lesotho, Zimbabwe and Zambia. 

The only member state not attending is Tanzania.

Welcoming participants to the conference ISDSC operations sub-committee chairman, Major General G. R. Mautanga of Malawi, said among the specific issues the meeting is looking at is that ISDSC recommends a system for the establishment of a mechanism for action against coup plotters in member states.

And speaking at the same function Zambia Army commander, Lieutenant General Nobby Simbeye, said the meeting should work out what each member state can contribute individually and what resources may be pulled together through ISDSC.

"It was essential for the region to have disaster relief mechanisms in order to effectively and quickly respond to disaster strikes," Lt. Gen. Simbeye said. "It is therefore prudent to think about establishing a combined operations centre where command and control communications, intelligence, information, logistics and contingency planning can be coordinated and executed."

Maj. Gen. Mautanga said the conference was a preparatory meeting for the defence chiefs meeting to be held in September this year.

This is the second ISDSC operations sub-committee meeting and will last three days.

LANGUAGE: English

404 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Another Zambian Joins Matete In Athletics Semis


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Atlanta - On the night that Carl Lewis made what may be his farewell Olympic appearance and he took one gold medal with him, Zambia's own Godfrey Siamusiye began his chase for an Olympic medal.

Running in the first round of the men's 3,000 steeplechase, Siamusiye clocked 8:30.56 to win second position and a berth in the semifinals.

And on the same day that 400 metres hurdler Samuel Matete qualified to the semifinals, Siamusiye showed why he may be the next best thing to come out of Zambia in track and field by giving veteran Kenya runner Joseph Keter an interesting race. Keter won the race in 8:30.23. 

Other top qualifiers in the steeplechase include Abdelaziz Sahere of Morocco, Matthew Birir and Moses Kiptanui both of Kenya and Italian Angelo Carosi.

Both Matete and Siamusiye are expected to run in the semifinals tonight are likely to make it to the finals of their respective events if their performances on Monday were a correct gauge of their determination.

But the Olympic story on Monday night belonged to Carl Lewis who reached the pinnacle of his career, tying an Olympic record by grabbing the gold in the same event for four consecutive Summer Games. The victory brought his Olympic gold medal total to nine.

Lewis shared the spotlight at Olympic Stadium with two Johnsons Michael in the 400 metres and Allen in the 100 metre hurdles -- who both set Olympic records while winning gold medals.

Michael Johnson moved one step closer to a historic Olympic double when he ran away from the field to win the 400 in 43.49 seconds. That broke the old mark of 43.50 set by Quincy Watts in 1992.

Now he points toward the 200 metre competition today. He set a world record of 19.66 seconds in that race last month in winning the US trials, but then lost to Frankie Fredericks of Namibia in a race earlier this month. No one has ever won the 200 and 400 in the same Summer Games.

Allen Johnson added a gold medal to the world title he captured last year by winning the 100 meter hurdles in an Olympic record 12.95 seconds. He broke Roger Kingdom's mark of 12.98.

But Monday was also a good night for African runners as Ethopian Haile Gebrselassie led a pride of African runners to win the men's 10,000 metres Olympic gold. The 23-year-old Ethiopian surprised world cross country champion Paul Tergat of Kenya to win with Morocco's Salah Hissou coming in third.

It was the second gold of the Games for Ethiopia after Fatuma Roba's win in Sunday's women's marathon.

African was also awashed with two surprise bronze medals and bitter disappointment for Maria Mutola of Mozambique in the women's 800 metres final.

Mutola, recovering from a heavy cold, won a bronze in her race for Mozambique's historic first Olympic medal but it was an upset defeat for the 23-year-old who had dominated the event for the last three years.

Uganda's Davis Kamoga, who only took up running seriously two years ago, finished third behind American Michael Johnson in the men's 400 metres final for Uganda's second medal in Olympic history.

Nigerian Falilat Ogunkoya, 26, took bronze in the women's 400 metres final, overshadowed by an Olympic record set by Marie-Jose Perec of France. Ogunkoya set an African record of 49.10 seconds in gaining her bronze, the first medal of the Games for Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Parties Call On SADC To Emulate Donors


BYLINE: Sipo Kapumba, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Lusaka - Eight opposition party leaders have urged the Southern African Development Community (SADC) to emulate the donor community which has condemned the re-emergence of dictatorship in Zambia.

The leaders who met in Lusaka on Monday night, resolved to send a three man delegation to SADC states to reinforce their call for tougher action against the MMD government in view of the recent constitutional amendments.

In a joint communique released by Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) chairman Roger Chongwe yesterday, they described the current political situation as " explosive", adding that intervention from the SADC countries was needed to diffuse the tension. 

"The presidents expressed the belief that the member states of SADC should be seen to be in the forefront in promoting democracy and democratic practices in the region," Chongwe said. "They should not be seen to be taking a second place to that taken by the international donor community which has shown its strong support for and condemnation of the dictatorship that has been created in the country by the legislative measures enacted by the MMD government."

They reminded SADC countries of the role Zambia played and sacrifices it made in the liberation of the sub-region and said they expected a reciprocal gesture.

"The presidents therefore expected the SADC leadership to stand by the Zambians in their effort in rejecting anarchy and fascism which is taking root and branch," the statement said.

The opposition welcomed recent calls by government leaders, including vice- president Godfrey Miyanda, for the resumption of inter-party talks but said this should be put in writing indicating when the talks should occur. However, they reiterated that for the talks to succeed they should be chaired by a neutral chairman.

They criticised the government for continuing to hold by-elections so close to the elections saying this was a ploy to divide the opposition. To counter this, they pledged to work closely in future elections and possibly form and electoral pact.

They reiterated their earlier call on the government to allow voters to use their national registration cards in the coming elections in view of chaotic registrations exercise done by Nikuv Computers which has resulted in many errors.

UNIP was represented by party president Kenneth Kaunda, the National Party by vice-president Daniel Lisulo and the Zambia Democratic Congress by deputy general secretary Azwell Banda.

Other parties in attendance were the National Democratic Party, National Salvation Party, Grass Roots Welfare Party and the Revolutionary Socialist Party.

SADC countries have a security organ amongst whose objectives is the maintenance of regional security.

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe in Maputo on Wednesday said SADC countries have a right to advise each other using the organs if they see signs of danger in their neighbours.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 31, 1996


Business;
More Cobalt Discovered In Zambia


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - Caledonia Mining Corporation, currently carrying out mining explorations in the country has announced a second significant cobalt discovery in Chililabombwe's Nama area.

According to a Reuters report from Toronto last Sunday, the Canadian mining conglomerate announced the discovery in the geochemical anomoly C area located 11 km northwest of the original Nama discovery area. 

The report revealed that of the 23 drill holes the company had made, 20 had encountered cobalt mineralisation, with 12 holes intersecting significant cobalt values.

"Holes 80 and 81, located 250 metres apart, both ended in mineralisation with intersections of 94 and 59 metres respectively, and hole 76 intersected 0.041 per cent cobalt and 0.102 per cent copper over 21 meters," the report said.

Recent leach tests carried out on hole 80 gave cobalt recoveries of about 40 per cent, giving rise to plans of further drilling in the area.

Earlier in May, Caledonia Mining Corporation chairman, Dannis Mcleod, announced in Lusaka their first major discovery of a 2.5km long by 350 metres copper anomoly in Ndola rural's Kadola area.

The company further discovered 3 (three) kilometres long by 700 metres of nickel, cobalt and copper anomoly.

All the holes drilled for mineral prospects were at a depth of 10,000 metres.
