Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
American Runner Under Pressure As He Faces Matete


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - Pressure will be on American Derrick Adkins as he faces Zambia and former World 400 metres hurdles champion, Samuel Matete, in the Atlanta Olymics semi finals tonight.

But for the Golden boy Matete, it will be an event he will use to confirm to the rest of the world that he is in a class of his own-what with his 48.23 seconds finish in the first round race on Monday! 

"Everyone in America is taking of Matete as the champion in the 400m, he actually stands as the best so far and we are just waiting for tomorrow (today) to see if he can live to his reputation," said Maidstone Mulenga, a Post Correspondent in America.

While everyone looks at the Zambian as the champion, fears are emerging that he may be affected by too much talk of him as the Olympic champion.

Matete stunned the world in 1991 when he clocked a record 47:08.91 to finish first in the world 400m hurdles meet in Japan and since then he has not looked back.

But as for now, he will have to work really hard to inform the world that the world 400m hurdles record of 46:78 secs, the Olympics record of 47:19 secs and the All Africa Games record of 48:03 secs, a record he actually broke in 1991!

Which is why everyone in Africa is looking to the Golden boy, Matete to redeem Africa what with the failure of Mozambique's wondergirl, Maria Mutola who on Monday settled for a bronze medal in the 800m women race!


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Swaziland Fares Poorly in Atlanta


BYLINE: Sifiso Dhlamini of the Swazi Observer (Mbabane), Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Atlanta - It is again happening as it has been the case in the past many years that the name of this beautiful Kingdom of Swaziland is stained before the number of countries participating in the Olympic Games.

One is left wondering what the country did to deserve such a disgusting humiliation in the world of sports.

Swaziland has never held any dignity since the Olympic Games began to be in place in the past centuries and it looks like, the country's performance will continue to be so bad until- nobody knows when. In the current Olympic Games being held in Atlanta, Georgia, Swaziland is a shame to most. But to other competitors, it is a blessing to have Swaziland because some athletes would be finishing last instead of last but one because they would have no one to outpace when the Swazi athletes are not there. 

Swaziland has, this year, performed badly than ever, failing to impress in all the activities her athletes have participated in so far. Up to this moment of the Atlanta Olympic Games, the six-men Swazi team has had four of its members knocked out and there are only two remaining.

Awaiting to participate in the marathon this coming Sunday is Isaac Simelane and Tornado Sibandze while the rest of the Swazi athletes did not just fail to make the grade but were humiliated out of the games.

It is an indisputable fact that most of the 196 countries taking part in this year's Olympic Games have an ultimate goal of winning medals yet with Swaziland it is mostly not the case. Considering a number of factors, the main being the lack of facilities, Swaziland cannot, at this stage, expect to land in any of the medal-winning positions in such big games but that does not mean the country can not do better than at present.

It does not mean Swaziland is not capable of winning medals but chances for that are very slim. The best the country can achieve is to compete satisfactory and show signs of improvement each time it participates in such games.

So what boggles the mind most is that when going through Swaziland's Olympic history, there seems to be no improvement and a future glare also signals that never will there be any.

Just now we complain that the country is being let down by the poor performance being recorded in every Olympic Games. Since it is clear that we are still far from mining any medals, why is there no improvement of national records or at least, satisfactory performances. All the local athletes who are now out of the Atlanta Games performed below their capabilities and one wonders who to put the blame to for this.

The fact remains and will always be there that Swaziland does not hold good reputation in the Olympic Games. It is even more embarrassing to compare our country with the rest of the African states some which have more unstable economic status than ours. Most nations except for Swazis have realised the importance played by sports.

With Swaziland being the worst African country in the Olympics, others who are almost on the same line but are quite better include Tanzania, Guinea Bissau, Niger, Botswana and Lesotho. At least some of these countries have managed to advance to the next rounds of their respective competitions and those who have not, have improved their national records yet with Swaziland it is zero.

Without maybe mentioning African countries like South Africa, Nigeria, Kenya, Algeria, Egypt and some others who have good sports facilities, there are good examples such as Uganda, Burundi and Ethopia who are doing it the right way yet they have no infrastructure like Swaziland. Some of them such as Uganda and Burundi are even worse with facilities but have athletes progressing to finals of the Olympic Games and they set themselves a number of national records here in Atlanta.

It is very astonishing that in all the four appearances, Swaziland has not recorded any positive result except earning embarrassment. The Swazi athletes who have been beaten hands down in the Olympic Games include Victor Shabangu (long jump), Themba Makhanya (800me), Daniela Menegon (swimming) and Dan Mathunjwa (boxing). So again, one is left wondering whether it is quite worth it to continue participating in these that the significance of Olympism is not to win but to compete and make friendship with the other participants. But then, it is unacceptable when a country like Swaziland has to be humiliated for the benefit of the others as it is the case here in Atlanta. There has never been a time when Swaziland rejoiced for participating in the Olympics except of boasting of exposure which has bore no fruits. We have long passed the stage of making friendship with other countries but now is time to have signs of positive performances.

There is a solution to this problem but there are no people with love for sports who can assist is setting up the standards. It is known to all that the main barrier to sports development in Swaziland is lack proper facilities but neither the government or any of the companies show willingness to assist with setting up the necessary structures. In sports, we need facilities more than anything else and this has been a song for the number of years but no one seems to dance to it. Swaziland is not that poor such that it could not afford a synthetic track, tennis courts, 50-metre swimming pool and a sports hall that will accommodate the number of indoor activities such as boxing, badminton, weight-lifting, volleyball and some others.

What should the citizens of this country do for government to see that there is a need to have sports taken more serious? It is even more disturbing to note that we have a Minister in Prince Sobandla who appears to love sports but when it comes to actions, he is a complete write-off. He is only there by the word of mouth. Much is expected from the Minister because he always attends the prestigious sports competitions such the Olympic Games as he is presently in Atlanta and has been in both the Commonwealth and All Africa Games in the past.

To make matters worse, he is the head of the Zone Six Supreme Council for Sports in Africa-Zone Six which comprise countries which are much sensitive when it comes to sports. Holding such a position, our Minister should be exemplary to the other countries by setting good standards in sports development in Swaziland.

No miracle is expected from Prince Sobandla's Ministry but only the will to improve the sports sector in this country. We want facilities to be able to perform well both locally and internationally.

There is absolutely no way we blame the athletes but only to sympathise with them to be entered for such big games when they have not undergone any serious preparations.

NOTE: Sifiso Dhlamini, from the Swazi Observer, is covering the Olympics under a special program between The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Botswana's Dipeba Loses in 200 m Heat


BYLINE: Mpho Dibeela of the Botswana Press Agency (Gaborone), Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Atlanta - Botswana's Olympic debutante, Justice Dipeba wilted to pressure when he came fifth in the opening rounds of the 200 metres Olympic dash on July 31, failing to qualify for the next round.

He fared well below his 20.7 seconds national record, clocking 21.09 seconds tailing four other runners as Koji Ito of Japan clocked 20.56 seconds to win their heat 10 of the 200 metres.

Dipeba running from the outside lane took off at a slower pace, than others and only came harder at the closing stages. But it was too late, Botswana's fastest athlete has been eliminated and so were the hopes of the 1.3 million nation. 

He carried the country's flag into the opening ceremony of these Games, a role which symbolised how much Botswana depended on him - but still he wilted and left locals flattered in the process. Hopes for a medal were placed miles away.

His manager, Justice Makole said at the end "he was under too much pressure to perform. And besides, the weather was changing - it was hot" he added.

It was his first time in a stiff competition of this kind, and hopefully it was a learning experience, Makole said, "in future he will do better."

Now Dipeba stands to redeem his dwindling image as a reserve in the 4 by 400 metres relay on Friday, August 02. He had qualified for 400 metres race but did not fare in it, preferring to give himself more time in preparing for 200 metres.

The only boxer, Healer Modiradilo lost in the opening round while Benjamin Keleketu will be the last to participate on August 04 in the men's marathon.

NOTE: Dibeela, who reports for the Botswana Press Agency, is covering the Olympics under a special program between The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


410 of 410 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 31, 1996


Sports - Olympics;
Kamoga Gives Uganda Second Medal and Raises Hopes


BYLINE: Wangwe Mulakha of New Vision (Kampala), Freedom Forum


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Atlanta - Three years ago Davis Kamoga was playing football for a local club in Kampala. He did not think of taking to track neither did he believe he could attract the attention of the world.

Last week, his dream was to reach a final in the men's 400m at the Olympic Games. And just as the dream came he had recorded himself as the second Ugandan to win a medal on the track in the Olympic games after legendary John Akii Bua. Kamoga on Monday rose to the gun from lane two against seven big names in the event. He ran down the bend looking beaten. He stretched through to the 300m mark still on a losing trend but as he came to the home straight he was spurting. Over 82,000+ spectators were on their toes, necks craned as they cheered front runner Michael Johnson.

But the Ugandan was not done although he seemed last. Another push and he was making it past the rest save for Roger Black of Britain and Johnson. Had the race went another two meters, silver was Kamoga's goal but all the same he had fullfilled his long time dream. 

He is now the focus at the Olympic Village and Ugandans scattered in the United States of American have quick to discover the new- found hero. Kamoga himself is in high spirits. he talks less. Poses for photographs and has been signing autographs since Monday when he set his feat with a new national record of 44.53 seconds.

Ugandans resident in Georgia and surrounding states threw a victory part in the outskirts of Atlanta city Tuesday. To them, it was "Time to celebrate the dreaming , and the hoping, and the reaching, and the believing, and the performing of a special dream" They were congratulating Kamoga and wishing that the 'achievement mark a life time dream come true.'

At least they had US $400 on offer to the athlete. Education and Sports minister here at the opening ceremonies promised a reward of Ushs 2m/= for bronze medal winners, a feat achieved by Kamoga.

The Ugandans set a target for Uganda government. "If Coca Cola could spend US $ 400m why can not Uganda also spent at least dollars 2000 to 4000 to expose athletes like Kamoga who are set to recapture the glory for Uganda", said Patrick Ayota a finance director in a vote at the party.

He had been put on the track by National Council of Sports Chairman Geoffrey Kizito, who appealed to the Ugandans in the States to find training opportunities for athletes. "Facilities at home are poor. If you are in positions of influence please find connections for our athletes", the NCS boss pleaded.

He said the victory of Kamoga alongside greats like race winner Michael Johnson of the USA was a reminder that revival was underway. He said the medal was one of those expected had it not been that several other athletes suffered injury in reference to Julius Acon and Francis Ogola both students of George Mason University College in Washington DC.

But Ayota was not amused that Uganda should continue to be referred to the legacy of Idi Amin when there are other areas to improve the image. He advised there should be priorities on sports and that the phenomenon of calling athletes to train a week to competition should stop.

"We either invest now in sports or never", Ayota said as he promised on behalf of other Ugandans in USA to assist wherever possible. Kamoga current high profile runs starts three years back when a he attempted the Bugembe grasstrack during a national championship. According to national track coach Absolom Jakech Ojwang, the young soccer player proved better on the track and we advised him to keep it up.

Came the 1994 Commonwealth Games and Kamoga, 28, was not considered despite having qualified, something Ojwang regrets. That could have served as his springboard, the coach confesses.

The new one lap expert was however given his chance last year during the East and Central Africa meet in Nairobi. Kamoga won his heats and the final breaking a national record set by Amos Omolo at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City. Heads started rolling and an invitation for the Engen IAAF permit meet was extended where he again performed excellently in Nairobi before another championship in South Africa the same year. Came the World Championship in Gortenburg, Sweden and Kamoga was a semifinalist.

Ojwang describes his athlete's rise as tremendous. Said the coach: "It is rare for an athlete who started on grass could reach the epitome of the sport in so short a time. First time on the tartan track in Nairobi was victory.

" It was victory in two years to reach a World Championship( semi final. It is even greater for an athlete of Kamoga's background to win a medal at the Olympics after only three years on the track. Getting an Olympic medal is not a simple matter, " the fiery speaking coach said. He describes the athlete as soft-spoken but 'acts more'.

Kamoga trains in Italy under an Italian guide and hopes to continue given the support. "I have run many races in Italy and outside it," he said. He believes many meets at times cause fatigue and stress but he is not ready to forego the chance. Why? 'Because I must reach the limits'. Before he ran his qualifying heats, his focus had been set on at least running under 45.00. He eyed reaching the final at least and be counted among the last eight in the world. He set his feat and now wants to attack the Commonwealth Games due in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 1998.

His other wish is to find a home in USA to easy and improve his talent like many great athletes who have been successful with bases in USA. Meanwhile, distance runner Acon has blamed his poor performance on the injury he developed while in Europe on altitude training. He said treatment in Washington DC has been horrowful as his coach American tutor tried to make him fit for his first Olympics.

The 1994 world junior champion over the 1500m distance said he under went 15 injections in a very short time when doctors tried to improve his hamstring injury.

He therefore missed his training during that time and could therefore make a good start at the race. he finished sixth during the qualifying heats. Grace Birungi in the 400m women on her part lost her kit at warm up an hour to the competition. She told The new Vision a fellow runner mistakenly picked it and it took her 30 minutes to locate. by then she had lost concentration , added coach Ojwang.

In the other championships, table tennis players Mary Musoke, June Kyakobye and Paulo Mutambuze were eliminated by the strong Chinese, Japanese and Korean pals. they however scored fairly, setting good impressions to their coach Francis Mulinda.

Mulinda is happy Uganda made a second appearance at the Olympics in table tennis. He hopes they will do better next time. Musoke was the first at the Olympics in Barcelona in 1992.

Heavyweight weightlifter Ali Kavuma finished 10th in his 108kg weight category with a new national record lift of 260 kilograms. He scored 110 in the snatch and 150 for the jerk. Mario Kalinke of Germany won the gold with a total 390.0 and runners up V. Scerbatihs of Latvia and another German D. Prochorow also lifted the same weight to grab silver and bronze respectively.

NOTE: Wangwe Mulakha, a reporter for New Vision in Kampala, Uganda, is covering the Olympics under a special program between The Freedom Forum and the International Olympic Committee.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
